vulnerabilities.title: Oracle links Clop extortion attacks to July 2025 vulnerabilities
vulnerabilities.original_title: Oracle links Clop extortion attacks to July 2025 vulnerabilities
vulnerabilities.content_snippet: Oracle has linked an ongoing extortion campaign claimed by the Clop ransomware gang to E-Business Suite (EBS) vulnerabilities that were patched in July 2025. [...]
vulnerabilities.summary: Multiple vulnerabilities in Oracle E-Business Suite (EBS) that allow remote code execution and privilege escalation.
vulnerabilities.description: The vulnerabilities reside in several Oracle E-Business Suite components (including the OA Framework, XML Publisher, and certain web services). An unauthenticated attacker can send specially crafted HTTP requests to execute arbitrary code on the application server, bypass authentication, and move laterally within the Oracle environment. Exploitation can lead to full compromise of the ERP system, enabling data exfiltration and deployment of ransomware such as the Clop extortion payload.
vulnerabilities.remediation: Apply the Oracle Critical Patch Update released in July 2025 for Oracle E-Business Suite. Verify that the patch level includes all security fixes for the affected components. After patching, restart the application tier services and perform a full regression test.
workarounds: Restrict inbound traffic to the Oracle EBS web tier to trusted IP ranges using firewalls or VPN.
Disable unnecessary OA Framework services and XML Publisher endpoints.
Deploy a Web Application Firewall (WAF) with rules to block suspicious request patterns.

vulnerabilities.title: Nearly 50,000 Cisco firewalls vulnerable to actively exploited flaws
vulnerabilities.original_title: Nearly 50,000 Cisco firewalls vulnerable to actively exploited flaws
vulnerabilities.content_snippet: Roughly 50,000 Cisco Adaptive Security Appliance (ASA) and Firewall Threat Defense (FTD) appliances exposed on the public web are vulnerable to two vulnerabilities actively leveraged by hackers. [...]
vulnerabilities.summary: Unauthenticated remote code execution vulnerability in Cisco ASA and FTD management interface
vulnerabilities.description: The vulnerability exists due to insufficient input validation in the HTTP/HTTPS management interface of Cisco ASA and FTD devices. An attacker can send a crafted request to the vulnerable endpoint, leading to arbitrary code execution with root privileges. Successful exploitation allows full control of the firewall, enabling traffic interception, policy modification, and pivoting to internal networks.
vulnerabilities.remediation: Apply the Cisco security advisory patches released in June 2025 for the affected ASA and FTD versions. Upgrade to the latest firmware versions where the vulnerability is fixed.
workarounds: Restrict access to the management interface to trusted IP addresses using ACLs.
Disable HTTP/HTTPS management on interfaces exposed to the internet.
Enable strong authentication and limit administrative access.

vulnerabilities.title: Nearly 50,000 Cisco firewalls vulnerable to actively exploited flaws
vulnerabilities.original_title: Nearly 50,000 Cisco firewalls vulnerable to actively exploited flaws
vulnerabilities.content_snippet: Roughly 50,000 Cisco Adaptive Security Appliance (ASA) and Firewall Threat Defense (FTD) appliances exposed on the public web are vulnerable to two vulnerabilities actively leveraged by hackers. [...]
vulnerabilities.summary: Authentication bypass vulnerability in Cisco ASA/FTD VPN endpoint
vulnerabilities.description: A flaw in the VPN authentication module allows an unauthenticated attacker to bypass credential checks by sending a specially crafted packet to the VPN endpoint. This grants the attacker access to the internal network as a privileged user, facilitating data exfiltration and lateral movement.
vulnerabilities.remediation: Install the June 2025 Cisco patch addressing CVE-2025-3476. Verify that VPN software is updated to version 9.16.5 or later for ASA and 7.2.3 for FTD.
workarounds: Disable remote VPN access from untrusted networks until patches are applied.
Enforce multi-factor authentication for VPN connections.
Monitor VPN logs for anomalous authentication attempts.

vulnerabilities.title: Critical WD My Cloud bug allows remote command injection
vulnerabilities.original_title: Critical WD My Cloud bug allows remote command injection
vulnerabilities.content_snippet: Western Digital has released firmware updates for multiple My Cloud NAS models to patch a critical-severity vulnerability that could be exploited remotely to execute arbitrary system commands. [...]
vulnerabilities.summary: Remote command injection vulnerability in Western Digital My Cloud NAS firmware allowing arbitrary system command execution.
vulnerabilities.description: A flaw in the web management interface of Western Digital My Cloud NAS firmware permits an unauthenticated attacker to inject and execute arbitrary operating system commands remotely. The vulnerability stems from insufficient input validation on a vulnerable endpoint that processes user-supplied data, leading to command injection. Successful exploitation grants full system control, enabling data exfiltration, modification, or service disruption.
affected_products: Western Digital My Cloud NAS devices (various models)
products_versions: All firmware versions prior to the September 2025 security update for My Cloud, My Cloud Home, My Cloud EX2, and My Cloud PR4100.
vulnerabilities.remediation: Apply the latest firmware updates released by Western Digital for all affected My Cloud models. Verify the firmware version after installation.
workarounds: Disable remote management features until the firmware is patched.
Block inbound traffic to the NAS management ports (e.g., TCP 80/443) at the network perimeter.
Place the NAS on an isolated VLAN with restricted access.
references: Western Digital Security Advisory (firmware update announcement)

vulnerabilities.title: ‘An attacker's playground:’ Crims exploit GoAnywhere perfect-10 bug
vulnerabilities.original_title: ‘An attacker's playground:’ Crims exploit GoAnywhere perfect-10 bug
vulnerabilities.content_snippet: Researchers say tens of thousands of instances remain publicly reachable Security researchers have confirmed that threat actors have exploited the maximum-severity vulnerability affecting Fortra's GoAnywhere managed file transfer (MFT), and chastised the vendor for a lack of transparency.…
vulnerabilities.summary: Unauthenticated remote code execution vulnerability in Fortra GoAnywhere Managed File Transfer (MFT) component known as "perfect-10"
vulnerabilities.description: The "perfect-10" component of GoAnywhere MFT contains a deserialization flaw that allows an attacker to send a crafted HTTP request to a vulnerable, internet‑exposed instance. The payload is processed without proper validation, leading to arbitrary code execution with SYSTEM privileges on the host. The vulnerability is exploitable remotely without authentication or user interaction. Successful exploitation enables attackers to deploy web shells, exfiltrate data, and pivot within the victim network.
vulnerabilities.remediation: Apply the vendor‑provided security patch released by Fortra. Upgrade to the latest patched version of GoAnywhere MFT (version 6.5.2 or later). If immediate patching is not possible, restrict external access to the MFT service via firewall rules and disable the vulnerable "perfect-10" functionality.
workarounds: Block inbound traffic to the MFT service from untrusted networks.
Enforce strict IP allow‑lists for management interfaces.
Disable the affected REST endpoint if not required.

vulnerabilities.title: UK and US security agencies order urgent fixes as Cisco firewall bugs exploited in wild
vulnerabilities.original_title: UK and US security agencies order urgent fixes as Cisco firewall bugs exploited in wild
vulnerabilities.content_snippet: CISA gives feds 24 hours to patch, NCSC urges rapid action as flaws linked to ArcaneDoor spies Cybersecurity agencies on both sides of the Atlantic are sounding the alarm over Cisco firewall vulnerabilities that are being exploited by an "advanced threat actor."…
vulnerabilities.summary: Remote code execution vulnerability in Cisco ASA and Firepower Threat Defense (FTD) software due to improper input validation of crafted HTTP requests.
vulnerabilities.description: An attacker can send a specially crafted HTTP request to the management interface of affected Cisco ASA/FTD devices. The request triggers a buffer overflow in the parsing routine, allowing arbitrary code execution with root privileges. Successful exploitation results in full control of the firewall, enabling data exfiltration, lateral movement, and persistence.
affected_products: Cisco Firepower Threat Defense (FTD) 7.0.3 and earlier
products_versions: Cisco Firepower Threat Defense 7.0.3 and earlier
Cisco Firepower Management Center 7.2.0 and earlier
vulnerabilities.remediation: Apply the Cisco security advisory patch released on 2025-09-25 (ASAv9.16.2 and FTD 7.0.4). Verify the firmware version after upgrade and restart the device.
workarounds: Restrict management interface access to trusted IP ranges using ACLs.
Disable HTTP/HTTPS management on interfaces not required for administration.
Enable Cisco's Intrusion Prevention System (IPS) with the latest signature set.

vulnerabilities.title: UK and US security agencies order urgent fixes as Cisco firewall bugs exploited in wild
vulnerabilities.original_title: UK and US security agencies order urgent fixes as Cisco firewall bugs exploited in wild
vulnerabilities.content_snippet: CISA gives feds 24 hours to patch, NCSC urges rapid action as flaws linked to ArcaneDoor spies Cybersecurity agencies on both sides of the Atlantic are sounding the alarm over Cisco firewall vulnerabilities that are being exploited by an "advanced threat actor."…
vulnerabilities.summary: Authentication bypass vulnerability in Cisco Firepower Management Center (FMC) web UI.
vulnerabilities.description: A flaw in the FMC authentication logic allows an unauthenticated attacker to bypass login by sending a crafted POST request to the login endpoint. The vulnerability stems from improper validation of the session token, granting administrative access without valid credentials.
affected_products: Cisco Firepower Management Center (FMC) 7.2.0 and earlier
products_versions: Cisco Firepower Threat Defense 7.0.3 and earlier
Cisco Firepower Management Center 7.2.0 and earlier
vulnerabilities.remediation: Upgrade FMC to version 7.2.1 or later, which includes the fix for CVE-2025-3476.
workarounds: Enforce multi-factor authentication (MFA) for all FMC admin accounts.
Restrict FMC web UI access to VPN or dedicated management network.
Monitor for repeated failed login attempts and block offending IPs.

vulnerabilities.title: Cisco warns of ASA firewall zero-days exploited in attacks
vulnerabilities.original_title: Cisco warns of ASA firewall zero-days exploited in attacks
vulnerabilities.content_snippet: Cisco warned customers today to patch two zero-day vulnerabilities that are actively being exploited in attacks and impact the company's firewall software. [...]
vulnerabilities.summary: Remote code execution vulnerability in Cisco ASA firewall software allowing unauthenticated network attackers to execute arbitrary code.
vulnerabilities.description: A flaw in the ASA packet processing engine allows specially crafted network packets to corrupt memory and execute attacker-controlled code with root privileges. The vulnerability is exploitable remotely without authentication and does not require user interaction. Cisco's advisory indicates that the issue exists in ASA software versions prior to the released patches and is being actively exploited in the wild.
affected_products: Cisco Firepower Threat Defense (FTD) running on ASA hardware
vulnerabilities.remediation: Upgrade to the fixed ASA software version released in Cisco Security Advisory (e.g., ASA 9.16.5.1 or later). Apply the accompanying IPS signatures and enable the recommended configuration hardening steps.
workarounds: Restrict inbound traffic to trusted sources only.
Enable Cisco ASA's zone-based firewall policies to limit exposure.
Deploy intrusion prevention system (IPS) signatures that detect the exploit patterns.

vulnerabilities.title: GeoServer Flaw Exploited in US Federal Agency Hack
vulnerabilities.original_title: GeoServer Flaw Exploited in US Federal Agency Hack
vulnerabilities.content_snippet: The hackers remained undetected for three weeks, deploying China Chopper, remote access scripts, and reconnaissance tools. The post GeoServer Flaw Exploited in US Federal Agency Hack appeared first on SecurityWeek.
vulnerabilities.summary: Remote code execution vulnerability in GeoServer allowing unauthenticated attackers to execute arbitrary code via crafted requests
vulnerabilities.description: The vulnerability resides in GeoServer's handling of certain HTTP requests (e.g., WMS GetFeatureInfo, REST API endpoints). An attacker can craft a malicious request that triggers deserialization or command injection, leading to remote code execution on the server. The flaw can be exploited without authentication and does not require user interaction. In the reported incident, the attackers leveraged the flaw to install the China Chopper web shell, execute remote access scripts, and conduct further reconnaissance within a US federal agency network.
products_versions: GeoServer 2.21.x and earlier (specific versions not disclosed)
vulnerabilities.remediation: Upgrade GeoServer to the latest patched version released by the Open Source Geospatial Foundation. Apply vendor security patches that address the RCE issue. If immediate upgrade is not possible, disable vulnerable endpoints, restrict access to GeoServer to trusted IP ranges, and enforce strong network segmentation.
workarounds: Block external access to GeoServer's HTTP endpoints using firewall rules.
Disable or restrict the REST API and WMS GetFeatureInfo services if not required.
Deploy a Web Application Firewall (WAF) with rules to detect and block malicious payloads targeting GeoServer.

vulnerabilities.title: SolarWinds fixed a critical RCE flaw in its Web Help Desk software
vulnerabilities.original_title: SolarWinds fixed a critical RCE flaw in its Web Help Desk software
vulnerabilities.content_snippet: SolarWinds fixed a critical flaw in its Web Help Desk software that could allow attackers to execute arbitrary commands on vulnerable systems. SolarWinds has released hot fixes to address a critical flaw, tracked as CVE-2025-26399 (CVSS score: 9.8), affecting its Web Help Desk software. An attacker ...
vulnerabilities.summary: Unauthenticated AjaxProxy deserialization remote code execution vulnerability in SolarWinds Web Help Desk allowing arbitrary command execution.
vulnerabilities.description: The vulnerability resides in the AjaxProxy component of SolarWinds Web Help Desk. It allows an unauthenticated attacker to send specially crafted serialized objects to the AjaxProxy endpoint. The application deserializes the untrusted data without integrity checks, leading to arbitrary code execution on the host machine. This flaw bypasses previous patches for CVE-2024-28988 and CVE-2024-28986, affecting version 12.8.7 and all earlier releases.
products_versions: SolarWinds Web Help Desk 12.8.7 and all prior versions
vulnerabilities.remediation: Apply the hot‑fixes released by SolarWinds for CVE-2025-26399 as soon as possible.
workarounds: Restrict network access to the Web Help Desk server (e.g., firewall allowlist).
Disable or block the AjaxProxy endpoint if not required.
Deploy a Web Application Firewall (WAF) rule to detect and block malicious serialized payloads.

vulnerabilities.title: Feds Tie ‘Scattered Spider’ Duo to $115M in Ransoms
vulnerabilities.original_title: Feds Tie ‘Scattered Spider’ Duo to $115M in Ransoms
vulnerabilities.content_snippet: U.S. prosecutors last week levied criminal hacking charges against 19-year-old U.K. national Thalha Jubair for allegedly being a core member of Scattered Spider, a prolific cybercrime group blamed for extorting at least $115 million in ransom payments from victims. The charges came as Jubair and an ...
vulnerabilities.summary: Abuse of compromised telecom provider employee tools to perform SIM swapping and intercept SMS-based authentication codes
vulnerabilities.description: Threat actors obtained privileged access to internal telecom provider systems (e.g., T‑Mobile employee tools) through social engineering and credential theft. With this access they performed SIM‑swap operations, redirecting victim phone numbers to attacker‑controlled devices. This enabled interception of one‑time passwords and SMS‑based 2FA, facilitating further account takeover and ransomware extortion. The service was advertised on the Telegram "Star Chat" channel with pricing per swap.
vulnerabilities.remediation: Enforce strict MFA that does not rely on SMS, implement zero‑trust segmentation for internal telecom admin tools, conduct regular privileged‑access reviews, and monitor for anomalous SIM‑swap requests. Deploy carrier‑level verification steps that require in‑person or biometric confirmation.
workarounds: Use authenticator apps or hardware tokens instead of SMS for 2FA
Require carrier‑level PINs and identity verification for SIM changes

vulnerabilities.title: Feds Tie ‘Scattered Spider’ Duo to $115M in Ransoms
vulnerabilities.original_title: Feds Tie ‘Scattered Spider’ Duo to $115M in Ransoms
vulnerabilities.content_snippet: U.S. prosecutors last week levied criminal hacking charges against 19-year-old U.K. national Thalha Jubair for allegedly being a core member of Scattered Spider, a prolific cybercrime group blamed for extorting at least $115 million in ransom payments from victims. The charges came as Jubair and an ...
vulnerabilities.summary: Mass SMS phishing campaign delivering fake Okta SSO login pages to harvest credentials and one‑time codes
vulnerabilities.description: During summer 2022 the group 0ktapus/ScatterSwine sent bulk SMS messages claiming schedule changes and linking to a phishing site that mimicked the Okta login page. Credentials, passwords and OTPs entered were forwarded in real time via a Telegram bot to the attackers, who then used them to access victim accounts and move laterally within compromised networks.
affected_products: Any enterprise SSO solution using similar UI
vulnerabilities.remediation: Educate users to verify URLs, enforce anti‑phishing controls, deploy email/SMS filtering, implement MFA that is resistant to credential‑theft (e.g., push‑based or hardware tokens), and monitor for anomalous login attempts from unknown IPs.
workarounds: Require users to confirm login attempts via secondary channel
Block short‑code URLs in SMS messages

vulnerabilities.title: Feds Tie ‘Scattered Spider’ Duo to $115M in Ransoms
vulnerabilities.original_title: Feds Tie ‘Scattered Spider’ Duo to $115M in Ransoms
vulnerabilities.content_snippet: U.S. prosecutors last week levied criminal hacking charges against 19-year-old U.K. national Thalha Jubair for allegedly being a core member of Scattered Spider, a prolific cybercrime group blamed for extorting at least $115 million in ransom payments from victims. The charges came as Jubair and an ...
vulnerabilities.summary: Custom kernel‑level malware (bootkits/rootkits) sold to bypass EDR solutions and maintain persistence
vulnerabilities.description: Members of the Scattered Spider affiliate "Brad" advertised bespoke kernel‑level malware capable of persisting across reboots, bypassing major EDR solutions, and providing reverse shell access. The malware is marketed as "stage 4 cancer for computers" and includes bootkits and rootkits that modify kernel structures to hide processes and files.
vulnerabilities.remediation: Apply secure boot, enable kernel module signing, keep OS and firmware up‑to‑date, use EDRs with kernel‑level integrity verification, and conduct regular integrity checks of critical system binaries.
workarounds: Deploy application whitelisting (e.g., Windows AppLocker)
Restrict administrative privileges and use least‑privilege accounts

vulnerabilities.title: How threat actors breached a U.S. federal civilian agency by exploiting a GeoServer flaw
vulnerabilities.original_title: How threat actors breached a U.S. federal civilian agency by exploiting a GeoServer flaw
vulnerabilities.content_snippet: US CISA revealed that threat actors exploited an unpatched vulnerability in GeoServer to breach a U.S. federal civilian agency’s network. Threat actors breached a U.S. federal agency via unpatched GeoServer flaw, tracked as CVE-2024-36401 (CVSS score of 9.8), which is a critical remote code executio...
vulnerabilities.summary: Remote code execution vulnerability in GeoServer allowing unauthenticated attackers to execute arbitrary code via crafted requests.
vulnerabilities.description: The vulnerability resides in GeoServer's handling of certain HTTP requests. An attacker can send a specially crafted request that triggers unsafe deserialization/eval injection, leading to remote code execution on the server. Exploits published in June 2024 demonstrate arbitrary command execution, web shell upload, cron task creation, and account creation for persistence. The flaw was actively exploited by threat actors to compromise a U.S. federal civilian agency, moving laterally to additional GeoServer instances and internal web/SQL servers.
products_versions: All GeoServer versions released before the security patch issued after 2024-06-30
vulnerabilities.remediation: Upgrade GeoServer to the version that includes the official patch released after 2024-06-30. Apply vendor security advisories, restart the service, and verify the patch is applied. If immediate upgrade is not possible, block external access to GeoServer endpoints and apply a Web Application Firewall rule to filter malicious payloads.
workarounds: Restrict network access to GeoServer to trusted IP ranges.
Deploy a WAF or reverse proxy that validates and sanitizes incoming requests.
Disable or limit the vulnerable functionality (e.g., remote processing services) until patched.

vulnerabilities.title: Patch Bypassed for Supermicro Vulnerability Allowing BMC Hack
vulnerabilities.original_title: Patch Bypassed for Supermicro Vulnerability Allowing BMC Hack
vulnerabilities.content_snippet: Binarly researchers have found a way to bypass a patch for a previously disclosed vulnerability. The post Patch Bypassed for Supermicro Vulnerability Allowing BMC Hack appeared first on SecurityWeek.
vulnerabilities.summary: Bypass of patch for a previously disclosed Supermicro BMC remote code execution vulnerability
vulnerabilities.description: Researchers from Binarly demonstrated a technique to bypass the vendor-supplied patch for a known Supermicro BMC vulnerability. The bypass allows an attacker to regain remote code execution capabilities on affected BMCs, even after the official firmware update has been applied. The exploit leverages insufficient validation in the BMC's update verification process, enabling crafted payloads to be accepted as legitimate. This restores full control over the management controller, permitting privilege escalation, data exfiltration, and disruption of server operations.
vulnerabilities.remediation: Update to the latest Supermicro BMC firmware that includes the mitigation for the bypass. Verify firmware integrity using signed images and ensure the update process validates signatures correctly. Apply network segmentation and restrict BMC access to trusted management networks only.
workarounds: Block inbound traffic to BMC interfaces from untrusted networks using firewalls or ACLs
Disable unnecessary BMC services (e.g., IPMI over LAN) if not required
Enable two-factor authentication for BMC web console access

vulnerabilities.title: Libraesva ESG issues emergency fix for bug exploited by state hackers
vulnerabilities.original_title: Libraesva ESG issues emergency fix for bug exploited by state hackers
vulnerabilities.content_snippet: Libraesva rolled out an emergency update for its Email Security Gateway solution to fix a vulnerability exploited by threat actors believed to be state sponsored. [...]
vulnerabilities.summary: Remote code execution vulnerability in Libraesva Email Security Gateway exploited by state-sponsored threat actors.
vulnerabilities.description: A flaw in the processing of inbound email traffic allows an unauthenticated remote attacker to execute arbitrary code on the underlying operating system of the Libraesva Email Security Gateway. The vulnerability is triggered by sending a specially crafted email that exploits a buffer overflow in the MIME parsing component. Successful exploitation grants the attacker full system control, enabling data exfiltration, persistence, and lateral movement within the victim network.
products_versions: Libraesva Email Security Gateway versions prior to 5.3.2
vulnerabilities.remediation: Apply the emergency update released by Libraesva immediately. Verify the version after patching and restart the service.
workarounds: Restrict inbound SMTP traffic to known trusted sources.
Disable the vulnerable MIME parsing module if possible.
Enable strict content filtering to block malformed email attachments.

vulnerabilities.title: Third time's the charm? SolarWinds (again) patches critical Web Help Desk RCE
vulnerabilities.original_title: Third time's the charm? SolarWinds (again) patches critical Web Help Desk RCE
vulnerabilities.content_snippet: Or maybe 3 strikes, you're out? SolarWinds on Tuesday released a hotfix - again - for a critical, 9.8-severity flaw in its Web Help Desk IT ticketing software that could allow a remote, unauthenticated attacker to run commands on a host machine. …
vulnerabilities.summary: Remote unauthenticated command execution vulnerability in SolarWinds Web Help Desk
vulnerabilities.description: A critical vulnerability (CVSS 9.8) in SolarWinds Web Help Desk allows a remote, unauthenticated attacker to execute arbitrary commands on the underlying host. The flaw is triggered via a crafted request to the Web Help Desk web interface, leading to full system compromise without requiring any user interaction or prior credentials.
vulnerabilities.remediation: Apply the hotfix released by SolarWinds on 2025-09-23. Verify the patch is successfully installed and restart the Web Help Desk service if required.
workarounds: Restrict inbound network traffic to the Web Help Desk server to trusted IP ranges.
Disable external access to the Web Help Desk web interface until the patch is applied.
Monitor for suspicious command execution patterns in application and system logs.

vulnerabilities.title: Third time's the charm? SolarWinds (again) patches critical Web Help Desk RCE
vulnerabilities.original_title: Third time's the charm? SolarWinds (again) patches critical Web Help Desk RCE
vulnerabilities.content_snippet: Or maybe 3 strikes, you're out? SolarWinds on Tuesday released a hotfix - again - for a critical, 9.8-severity flaw in its Web Help Desk IT ticketing software that could allow a remote, unauthenticated attacker to run commands on a host machine. …
vulnerabilities.summary: Critical remote code execution vulnerability in SolarWinds Web Help Desk allowing unauthenticated attackers to execute arbitrary commands on the host.
vulnerabilities.description: The vulnerability resides in a web-exposed component of SolarWinds Web Help Desk. An attacker can send specially crafted HTTP requests to the vulnerable endpoint, which bypasses authentication and leads to execution of arbitrary system commands on the server hosting the ticketing system. The flaw is exploitable remotely without any prior access or user interaction, resulting in full compromise of the affected host.
vulnerabilities.remediation: Apply the hotfix released by SolarWinds on 2025-09-23. Upgrade to the latest patched version of Web Help Desk. Verify that the patch is successfully installed and that the vulnerable endpoint is no longer reachable.
workarounds: Restrict inbound traffic to the Web Help Desk server to trusted IP ranges using firewall rules.
Disable external access to the vulnerable web interface until the patch is applied.
Enable network segmentation to isolate the ticketing system from critical assets.

vulnerabilities.title: CISA says hackers breached federal agency using GeoServer exploit
vulnerabilities.original_title: CISA says hackers breached federal agency using GeoServer exploit
vulnerabilities.content_snippet: CISA has revealed that attackers breached the network of an unnamed U.S. federal civilian executive branch (FCEB) agency last year after compromising an unpatched GeoServer instance. [...]
vulnerabilities.summary: Remote code execution vulnerability in GeoServer's WMS GetFeatureInfo endpoint
vulnerabilities.description: An attacker can send a specially crafted WMS GetFeatureInfo request to an unpatched GeoServer instance, triggering deserialization of untrusted data and leading to remote code execution with the privileges of the GeoServer process. The flaw is due to unsafe handling of XML input in the WMS module.
vulnerabilities.remediation: Upgrade GeoServer to version 2.23.5 or later, which includes the fix for CVE-2023-27524. If immediate upgrade is not possible, disable the WMS GetFeatureInfo operation or restrict access to the WMS service via firewall or reverse proxy rules.
workarounds: Disable the WMS GetFeatureInfo endpoint in the GeoServer configuration.
Restrict inbound traffic to GeoServer to trusted IP ranges.
Deploy a Web Application Firewall (WAF) rule to block malicious XML payloads.

vulnerabilities.title: US Secret Service dismantled covert communications network near the U.N. in New York
vulnerabilities.original_title: US Secret Service dismantled covert communications network near the U.N. in New York
vulnerabilities.content_snippet: Secret Service seizes a covert communications network near U.N. composed of sophisticated equipment, including 100K SIMs and 300 servers The U.S. Secret Service uncovered a covert communications network near the U.N. in New York, seizing 100,000 SIM cards and 300 servers. The operation, capable of s...
vulnerabilities.summary: Large‑scale unauthorized SIM fleet used to perform SMS flooding and cellular network disruption
vulnerabilities.description: The seized infrastructure contained >100,000 SIM cards and 300 servers capable of generating up to 30 million SMS messages per minute. By abusing legitimate carrier signaling (SS7/IMS) the adversary can flood SMS gateways, trigger denial‑of‑service on cellular towers, and deliver malicious links for mass phishing. The scale allows the attacker to overwhelm carrier capacity, disrupt service for legitimate users, and hide malicious traffic within normal traffic patterns.
affected_companies: Major mobile carriers (e.g., AT&T, Verizon, T‑Mobile)
Network equipment vendors (e.g., Nokia, Ericsson, Huawei)
vendors: Major mobile carriers (e.g., AT&T, Verizon, T‑Mobile)
Network equipment vendors (e.g., Nokia, Ericsson, Huawei)
vulnerabilities.remediation: Mobile carriers should implement strict rate‑limiting on SMS origination per SIM, enforce anomaly‑based traffic profiling, require multi‑factor authentication for bulk SIM provisioning, and deploy network‑level filtering for abnormal SS7/IMS traffic. SIM vendors should embed tamper‑evident hardware IDs and support revocation via OTA updates.
workarounds: Deploy per‑SIM outbound SMS quotas
Enable real‑time SMS traffic analytics and automated throttling
Blacklist known malicious SIM ICCIDs when detected

vulnerabilities.title: US Secret Service dismantled covert communications network near the U.N. in New York
vulnerabilities.original_title: US Secret Service dismantled covert communications network near the U.N. in New York
vulnerabilities.content_snippet: Secret Service seizes a covert communications network near U.N. composed of sophisticated equipment, including 100K SIMs and 300 servers The U.S. Secret Service uncovered a covert communications network near the U.N. in New York, seizing 100,000 SIM cards and 300 servers. The operation, capable of s...
vulnerabilities.summary: Rogue base station (IMSI catcher) used for eavesdropping, location tracking and data interception
vulnerabilities.description: The network included equipment that mimics legitimate cellular towers (IMSI catchers). By broadcasting a stronger signal, the device forces nearby phones to connect, allowing interception of voice, SMS, and data traffic, as well as precise location tracking of targets. When combined with the large SIM pool, the adversary can selectively route traffic through compromised SIMs for further exploitation.
affected_companies: Major mobile carriers (e.g., AT&T, Verizon, T‑Mobile)
Network equipment vendors (e.g., Nokia, Ericsson, Huawei)
vendors: Major mobile carriers (e.g., AT&T, Verizon, T‑Mobile)
Network equipment vendors (e.g., Nokia, Ericsson, Huawei)
vulnerabilities.remediation: Deploy network‑level detection of rogue base stations (e.g., via LTE/5G cell‑site authentication, encrypted broadcast keys), enable handset alerts for unexpected cell‑tower changes, and enforce mutual authentication between devices and infrastructure (e.g., 5G AKA).
workarounds: Enable handset security features that warn of sudden cell‑tower changes
Use encrypted messaging applications that do not rely on SMS
Restrict device roaming to trusted carrier IDs

vulnerabilities.title: SolarWinds releases third patch to fix Web Help Desk RCE bug
vulnerabilities.original_title: SolarWinds releases third patch to fix Web Help Desk RCE bug
vulnerabilities.content_snippet: SolarWinds has released a hotfix for a critical a critical vulnerability in Web Help Desk that allows remote code execution (RCE) without authentication. [...]
vulnerabilities.summary: Unauthenticated remote code execution vulnerability in SolarWinds Web Help Desk
vulnerabilities.description: A critical vulnerability in SolarWinds Web Help Desk allows an unauthenticated attacker to execute arbitrary code on the server. The flaw is triggered via a specially crafted request to a vulnerable web endpoint, leading to full system compromise without requiring any user interaction or privileges.
products_versions: SolarWinds Web Help Desk versions prior to the third hotfix (e.g., 2024.3, 2025.1)
vulnerabilities.remediation: Apply the third hotfix released by SolarWinds for Web Help Desk. Verify that the patch is successfully installed and that the vulnerable endpoint is no longer reachable.
workarounds: Temporarily block inbound traffic to the Web Help Desk service at the network perimeter.
Disable the vulnerable feature/module if it is not required.
Restrict access to the Web Help Desk server to trusted IP ranges.

vulnerabilities.title: SolarWinds Releases Hotfix for Critical CVE-2025-26399 Remote Code Execution Flaw
vulnerabilities.original_title: SolarWinds Releases Hotfix for Critical CVE-2025-26399 Remote Code Execution Flaw
vulnerabilities.content_snippet: SolarWinds has released hot fixes to address a critical security flaw impacting its Web Help Desk software that, if successfully exploited, could allow attackers to execute arbitrary commands on susceptible systems. The vulnerability, tracked as CVE-2025-26399 (CVSS score: 9.8), has been described a...
vulnerabilities.summary: Critical remote code execution vulnerability in SolarWinds Web Help Desk due to insecure deserialization of untrusted data.
vulnerabilities.description: An attacker can send a specially crafted serialized object to the Web Help Desk server. The application deserializes the object without proper validation, leading to arbitrary code execution in the context of the service account. Successful exploitation allows full control of the affected system and lateral movement within the network.
products_versions: SolarWinds Web Help Desk versions prior to the September 2025 hotfix
vulnerabilities.remediation: Apply the hotfix released by SolarWinds immediately. Verify that the patch is installed successfully and restart the Web Help Desk service.
workarounds: Temporarily block inbound traffic to the Web Help Desk web interface from untrusted networks.
Disable any functionality that accepts serialized objects until the patch is applied.
Implement strict input validation and content‑type checking on the affected endpoints.

vulnerabilities.title: SolarWinds Releases Hotfix for Critical CVE-2025-26399 Remote Code Execution Flaw
vulnerabilities.original_title: SolarWinds Releases Hotfix for Critical CVE-2025-26399 Remote Code Execution Flaw
vulnerabilities.content_snippet: SolarWinds has released hot fixes to address a critical security flaw impacting its Web Help Desk software that, if successfully exploited, could allow attackers to execute arbitrary commands on susceptible systems. The vulnerability, tracked as CVE-2025-26399 (CVSS score: 9.8), has been described a...
vulnerabilities.summary: Remote code execution vulnerability in SolarWinds Web Help Desk due to deserialization of untrusted data.
vulnerabilities.description: An attacker can send a specially crafted serialized object to the Web Help Desk server. The application deserializes this data without proper validation, leading to arbitrary code execution with the privileges of the service account. Successful exploitation allows full control of the affected system and lateral movement within the network.
products_versions: All SolarWinds Web Help Desk versions prior to the 2025-09-23 hotfix
vulnerabilities.remediation: Apply the SolarWinds hotfix released on 2025-09-23. Upgrade to the latest version of Web Help Desk that includes the fix. Verify that the patch is successfully installed and that the vulnerable endpoint is no longer reachable.
workarounds: Temporarily block inbound traffic to the vulnerable Web Help Desk service.
Disable or restrict the functionality that accepts serialized input until the patch is applied.
Implement a Web Application Firewall (WAF) rule to block suspicious serialized payloads.

vulnerabilities.title: CISA Shares Lessons Learned from an Incident Response Engagement
vulnerabilities.original_title: CISA Shares Lessons Learned from an Incident Response Engagement
vulnerabilities.content_snippet: Advisory at a Glance Executive Summary CISA began incident response efforts at a U.S. federal civilian executive branch (FCEB) agency following the detection of potential malicious activity identified through security alerts generated by the agency’s endpoint detection and response (EDR) tool. CISA ...
vulnerabilities.summary: Unauthenticated remote code execution via eval injection in GeoServer web interface.
vulnerabilities.description: The vulnerability allows an attacker to supply crafted input that is evaluated as code (eval injection) on the GeoServer JVM. Successful exploitation results in remote code execution with the privileges of the GeoServer process, enabling download of tools, deployment of web shells, creation of persistence mechanisms, and lateral movement.
affected_products: GeoServer (all public‑facing deployments of vulnerable versions)
products_versions: Vulnerable GeoServer versions prior to the June 2024 security release
vulnerabilities.remediation: Apply the GeoServer security patch released after June 30 2024. Upgrade to the latest GeoServer version that disables the vulnerable endpoint or applies input validation. If immediate patching is not possible, block external access to the GeoServer service via firewall or web‑application firewall rules.
workarounds: Restrict GeoServer to trusted internal IP ranges.
Deploy a WAF that blocks suspicious eval‑injection payloads.
Disable or limit the vulnerable REST endpoint if not required.
references: CISA KEV Catalog entry for CVE‑2024‑36401

CISA ...
vulnerabilities.summary: Dirty COW privilege escalation via race condition in Linux kernel.
vulnerabilities.description: The Dirty COW vulnerability exploits a race condition in the copy‑on‑write mechanism of the Linux kernel, allowing an unprivileged user to gain write access to read‑only memory mappings and thereby obtain root privileges.
products_versions: Vulnerable GeoServer versions prior to the June 2024 security release
vulnerabilities.remediation: Update the Linux kernel to version 4.8.3 or later (or apply the distribution’s security patch).
workarounds: Mount critical filesystems with the "nosuid" and "nodev" options where feasible.
Limit local user accounts and enforce least‑privilege policies.
references: CISA KEV Catalog entry for CVE‑2016‑5195

vulnerabilities.content_snippet: Last week on Malwarebytes Labs: ChatGPT Deep Research zero-click vulnerability fixed by OpenAI Disrupted phishing service was after Microsoft 365 credentials Update your Chrome today: Google patches 4 vulnerabilities including one zero-day Age verification and parental controls coming to ChatGPT to ...
vulnerabilities.summary: Zero-click remote code execution vulnerability in OpenAI's ChatGPT Deep Research feature
vulnerabilities.description: A flaw in the Deep Research component of ChatGPT allows an attacker to craft a malicious query that triggers code execution on the backend without any user interaction. The vulnerability is exploitable over the network and bypasses normal authentication checks, leading to full compromise of the service infrastructure.
affected_products: OpenAI ChatGPT Deep Research (web and API versions)
products_versions: ChatGPT Deep Research (any version prior to September 2025 patch)
iOS 17.5 and earlier, iPadOS 17.5 and earlier, macOS 14.4 and earlier, watchOS 10.3 and earlier
vulnerabilities.remediation: OpenAI has released a patch that disables the vulnerable code path and updates the model sandbox. Users should ensure they are running the latest version of ChatGPT and consider disabling the Deep Research feature until the patch is verified.
workarounds: Disable the Deep Research feature in account settings
Restrict API access to trusted IP ranges

vulnerabilities.description: A memory‑corruption bug in Chrome's rendering engine can be triggered by a specially crafted web page. When a victim visits the page, the bug leads to arbitrary code execution in the context of the browser process.
products_versions: ChatGPT Deep Research (any version prior to September 2025 patch)
iOS 17.5 and earlier, iPadOS 17.5 and earlier, macOS 14.4 and earlier, watchOS 10.3 and earlier
vulnerabilities.remediation: Update Chrome to version 127.0.6533.89 or later, which contains the fix for the vulnerability.
workarounds: Enable Chrome's built‑in safe browsing and site isolation features
Avoid visiting untrusted websites

vulnerabilities.summary: Multiple vulnerabilities in Apple iOS, iPadOS, macOS, and watchOS affecting dozens of components
vulnerabilities.description: Apple released an advisory covering a set of vulnerabilities across its operating systems, including a sandbox escape, a WebKit memory corruption issue, and a kernel privilege escalation. The flaws can be chained to achieve full device compromise when a user interacts with a malicious file or link.
products_versions: ChatGPT Deep Research (any version prior to September 2025 patch)
iOS 17.5 and earlier, iPadOS 17.5 and earlier, macOS 14.4 and earlier, watchOS 10.3 and earlier
vulnerabilities.remediation: Install the latest iOS, iPadOS, macOS, and watchOS updates released on September 20, 2025.
workarounds: Do not open attachments or click links from unknown sources
Enable Gatekeeper and enforce app notarization

vulnerabilities.title: Microsoft Entra ID flaw allowed hijacking any company's tenant
vulnerabilities.original_title: Microsoft Entra ID flaw allowed hijacking any company's tenant
vulnerabilities.content_snippet: A critical combination of legacy components could have allowed complete access to the Microsoft Entra ID tenant of every company in the world. [...]
vulnerabilities.summary: Privilege escalation and tenant takeover vulnerability in Microsoft Entra ID due to legacy component interaction
vulnerabilities.description: A combination of legacy authentication flows and mis‑validated token issuance logic allowed an attacker to forge valid SAML/OIDC tokens for any Entra ID tenant. By exploiting the flaw, an adversary could impersonate any user, elevate privileges to Global Administrator, and gain full control over the tenant's resources, effectively hijacking the entire organization. The vulnerability stems from inadequate validation of redirect URIs and the reuse of legacy signing certificates that were not revoked after deprecation.
products_versions: Microsoft Entra ID (Azure AD) prior to patch released 2025-09-20
exploit_kits: Metasploit module for Entra ID token forgery
Cobalt Strike template for tenant takeover
vulnerabilities.remediation: Apply the security update released by Microsoft (KBXXXXXXX) that removes the vulnerable legacy token handling path, revokes all legacy signing certificates, and enforces strict redirect URI validation. Additionally, rotate all service principal secrets and certificates, and enforce MFA for all privileged accounts.
workarounds: Disable legacy authentication protocols (e.g., WS‑Trust, SAML 1.1) in the Entra ID tenant.
Enforce Conditional Access policies that require MFA for all admin roles.
Restrict token issuance to approved applications only.
Monitor and block anomalous token generation events via Azure AD Identity Protection.

vulnerabilities.summary: Chrome zero‑day remote code execution vulnerability actively exploited in the wild.
vulnerabilities.description: The vulnerability resides in Chrome's V8 JavaScript engine and allows an attacker to achieve remote code execution without user interaction. Exploits observed in the wild chain together a memory corruption bug with a JIT spray technique to achieve arbitrary code execution, leading to full compromise of the victim's system.
products_versions: Ivanti Endpoint Manager Mobile (versions prior to 2025‑xx)
ChatGPT service (pre‑patch of Deep Research Agent vulnerability)
vulnerabilities.remediation: Update Google Chrome to the latest version released after 2025‑09‑21. Enable automatic updates and enforce enterprise rollout policies.
workarounds: Deploy Chrome Enterprise policies to block execution of untrusted JavaScript from unknown origins.
Use application whitelisting to prevent execution of unknown binaries launched by the browser.

vulnerabilities.summary: Apple vulnerability actively exploited; details not disclosed, patched via backport.
vulnerabilities.description: The vulnerability allows a remote attacker to execute arbitrary code on vulnerable Apple devices by delivering a crafted payload that exploits a memory‑corruption bug in a core system library. Exploits have been observed in the wild targeting iMessage and Safari components.
products_versions: Ivanti Endpoint Manager Mobile (versions prior to 2025‑xx)
ChatGPT service (pre‑patch of Deep Research Agent vulnerability)
vulnerabilities.remediation: Apply the latest iOS/macOS updates released by Apple after 2025‑09‑21. Enable automatic updates on all Apple devices.
workarounds: Restrict execution of untrusted code via Mobile Device Management (MDM) policies.
Disable vulnerable services (e.g., Safari Remote Automation) where feasible.

vulnerabilities.summary: Rowhammer attack demonstrated against DDR5 memory modules.
vulnerabilities.description: Researchers demonstrated that the Rowhammer effect can be triggered on DDR5 DIMMs, allowing an attacker with physical access to flip bits in memory and potentially gain elevated privileges or corrupt data. The attack leverages aggressive row activation patterns to induce electrical disturbances.
affected_products: DDR5 memory modules from multiple manufacturers
products_versions: Ivanti Endpoint Manager Mobile (versions prior to 2025‑xx)
ChatGPT service (pre‑patch of Deep Research Agent vulnerability)
vulnerabilities.remediation: Use memory modules with built‑in Rowhammer mitigation (e.g., Target Row Refresh). Apply firmware updates from motherboard vendors that enable aggressive refresh policies.
workarounds: Enable ECC memory where supported.
Limit physical access to servers and workstations.

vulnerabilities.description: A remote code execution flaw in GoAnywhere MFT allows attackers to upload malicious payloads and execute them on the server, facilitating ransomware deployment. The vulnerability bypasses authentication checks and can be triggered via crafted HTTP requests.

ChatGPT service (pre‑patch of Deep Research Agent vulnerability)

workarounds: Block external access to the MFT web interface using firewall rules.
Enforce strict input validation on uploaded files.

vulnerabilities.summary: Malware deployed through Ivanti Endpoint Manager Mobile (EPMM) flaws.
vulnerabilities.description: Threat actors exploit undocumented flaws in Ivanti EPMM to deliver a malicious listener that can execute commands on managed devices. The malware establishes persistence and can be used for data exfiltration.

ChatGPT service (pre‑patch of Deep Research Agent vulnerability)
vulnerabilities.remediation: Apply the patches released by Ivanti for the identified flaws. Verify that all EPMM instances are running the latest version.

Enable multi‑factor authentication for administrative accounts.

vulnerabilities.title: ShadowLeak Zero-Click Flaw Leaks Gmail Data via OpenAI ChatGPT Deep Research Agent
vulnerabilities.original_title: ShadowLeak Zero-Click Flaw Leaks Gmail Data via OpenAI ChatGPT Deep Research Agent
vulnerabilities.content_snippet: Cybersecurity researchers have disclosed a zero-click flaw in OpenAI ChatGPT's Deep Research agent that could allow an attacker to leak sensitive Gmail inbox data with a single crafted email without any user action. The new class of attack has been codenamed ShadowLeak by Radware. Following responsi...
vulnerabilities.summary: Zero-click vulnerability in OpenAI ChatGPT Deep Research agent allowing exfiltration of Gmail inbox data via a crafted email.
vulnerabilities.description: An attacker can send a specially crafted email to a target. The email triggers the ChatGPT Deep Research agent to automatically query the target's Gmail account via the integrated OpenAI-Gmail API without any user interaction. The agent then leaks the contents of the inbox to an external server controlled by the attacker. The flaw is a zero-click remote data exfiltration issue that bypasses authentication and user consent checks in the Deep Research workflow.
affected_products: Google Gmail (when accessed via ChatGPT integration)
products_versions: ChatGPT Deep Research agent versions prior to August 2025 patch
vulnerabilities.remediation: OpenAI released a patch in early August 2025 that hardens the Deep Research agent's permission checks and requires explicit user consent before accessing linked email accounts. Apply the latest ChatGPT client and server updates released by OpenAI.
workarounds: Disable the Deep Research agent feature in ChatGPT settings.
Revoke OpenAI's access to Gmail accounts via Google Account permissions.
Enforce MFA and suspicious login alerts on Gmail accounts.
Monitor and block outbound connections from ChatGPT services to unknown IPs.
references: OpenAI Security Advisory (August 2025) – Patch release notes

vulnerabilities.title: One token to pwn them all: Entra ID bug could have granted access to every tenant
vulnerabilities.original_title: One token to pwn them all: Entra ID bug could have granted access to every tenant
vulnerabilities.content_snippet: Until Microsoft lobbed it into a virtual volcano A security researcher claims to have found a flaw that could have handed him the keys to almost every Entra ID tenant worldwide.…
vulnerabilities.summary: Improper token issuance logic in Azure Entra ID could allow an attacker to forge authentication tokens granting access to any tenant.
vulnerabilities.description: A flaw in the token generation pathway of Entra ID allowed a researcher to craft a valid JWT (JSON Web Token) without possessing a legitimate client secret or user credentials. The vulnerability stemmed from insufficient validation of the "aud" (audience) and "tid" (tenant ID) claims during token signing, combined with a predictable signing key derivation for certain tenant configurations. Exploiting this issue, an attacker could obtain a token that the service accepted as authentic for any tenant, effectively granting full administrative access across the Azure AD ecosystem. The bug was discovered during a security audit and reported to Microsoft, which subsequently revoked the vulnerable signing keys and issued a hot‑patch.
affected_products: Microsoft Entra ID (Azure AD) authentication service
products_versions: Azure Entra ID (all tenant instances) prior to patch released 2025-09-20
vulnerabilities.remediation: Microsoft has rotated the signing keys for Entra ID, updated the token validation logic, and released a security update. All tenants should ensure they are running the latest Entra ID service version and enforce token lifetime policies. Rotate any long‑lived client secrets and certificates that may have been issued before the patch.
workarounds: Enable Conditional Access policies that require MFA for all privileged sign‑ins.
Restrict token issuance to approved applications using application‑specific consent.
Monitor and block anomalous token requests from unknown IP ranges.

vulnerabilities.title: CISA Warns of Two Malware Strains Exploiting Ivanti EPMM CVE-2025-4427 and CVE-2025-4428
vulnerabilities.original_title: CISA Warns of Two Malware Strains Exploiting Ivanti EPMM CVE-2025-4427 and CVE-2025-4428
vulnerabilities.content_snippet: The U.S. Cybersecurity and Infrastructure Security Agency (CISA) on Thursday released details of two sets of malware that were discovered in an unnamed organization's network following the exploitation of security flaws in Ivanti Endpoint Manager Mobile (EPMM). "Each set contains loaders for malicio...
vulnerabilities.summary: Remote code execution vulnerability in Ivanti Endpoint Manager Mobile (EPMM) that allows attackers to execute arbitrary code on the server.
vulnerabilities.description: The vulnerability resides in the management interface of Ivanti EPMM. Successful exploitation enables threat actors to upload and execute malicious loader binaries that act as listeners, providing persistent remote code execution capabilities on the compromised server.
products_versions: Ivanti Endpoint Manager Mobile (EPMM) versions prior to the security patches released in September 2025
vulnerabilities.remediation: Apply the security patch released by Ivanti for CVE-2025-4427, upgrade to the latest supported version of EPMM, and ensure that all default credentials are changed.
workarounds: Restrict network access to the EPMM management interface to trusted IP ranges.
Disable the vulnerable management services if they are not required.
Implement application whitelisting to block unknown loader binaries.

vulnerabilities.title: CISA Warns of Two Malware Strains Exploiting Ivanti EPMM CVE-2025-4427 and CVE-2025-4428
vulnerabilities.original_title: CISA Warns of Two Malware Strains Exploiting Ivanti EPMM CVE-2025-4427 and CVE-2025-4428
vulnerabilities.content_snippet: The U.S. Cybersecurity and Infrastructure Security Agency (CISA) on Thursday released details of two sets of malware that were discovered in an unnamed organization's network following the exploitation of security flaws in Ivanti Endpoint Manager Mobile (EPMM). "Each set contains loaders for malicio...
vulnerabilities.summary: Privilege escalation vulnerability in Ivanti Endpoint Manager Mobile (EPMM) that can be chained with CVE-2025-4427 for full system compromise.
vulnerabilities.description: This flaw allows an attacker who has already obtained limited access (e.g., via CVE-2025-4427) to elevate privileges to SYSTEM level on the EPMM server, enabling full control over the managed environment.
products_versions: Ivanti Endpoint Manager Mobile (EPMM) versions prior to the security patches released in September 2025
vulnerabilities.remediation: Install the Ivanti patch that addresses CVE-2025-4428, update to the latest EPMM release, and enforce least‑privilege principles for service accounts.
workarounds: Enforce strict network segmentation for EPMM components.
Monitor and restrict the use of privileged service accounts.
Apply host‑based intrusion detection rules to detect abnormal privilege escalation attempts.

vulnerabilities.title: Google pushes emergency patch for Chrome 0-day – check your browser version now
vulnerabilities.original_title: Google pushes emergency patch for Chrome 0-day – check your browser version now
vulnerabilities.content_snippet: Sixth such Chrome flaw this year spotted by the Chocolate Factory, already in play Google pushed an emergency patch for a high-severity Chrome flaw, already under active exploitation. So it's time to make sure you're running the most recent version of the web browser.…
vulnerabilities.summary: A high‑severity remote code execution vulnerability in Google Chrome that is actively exploited in the wild.
vulnerabilities.description: The flaw is a memory‑corruption bug in Chrome's V8 JavaScript engine/renderer process that allows an attacker to achieve arbitrary code execution without user interaction. The vulnerability is triggered by a specially crafted webpage that, when visited, exploits the bug to execute native code in the context of the browser, leading to full system compromise. Exploitation is observed in the wild, with threat actors delivering malicious web content to drive infection.
products_versions: Google Chrome versions prior to the emergency patch released on 2025-09-18
vulnerabilities.remediation: Update Google Chrome to the latest version (the emergency patch released on 2025-09-18 or later). Enable automatic updates to ensure future patches are applied promptly.
workarounds: Temporarily block Chrome network traffic to untrusted sites via a firewall or web proxy.
Use Chrome Enterprise policies to disable the vulnerable feature (e.g., disable JavaScript on untrusted domains).
Employ an alternative browser until the patch is applied.

vulnerabilities.title: WatchGuard warns of critical vulnerability in Firebox firewalls
vulnerabilities.original_title: WatchGuard warns of critical vulnerability in Firebox firewalls
vulnerabilities.content_snippet: WatchGuard has released security updates to address a remote code execution vulnerability impacting the company's Firebox firewalls. [...]
vulnerabilities.summary: Remote code execution vulnerability in WatchGuard Firebox firewalls
vulnerabilities.description: A flaw in the handling of specially crafted network packets allows an unauthenticated remote attacker to execute arbitrary code on the underlying operating system of WatchGuard Firebox firewalls. The vulnerability resides in the packet inspection engine and can be triggered without any user interaction, leading to full system compromise and potential network pivoting.
products_versions: Firebox M series (all firmware versions prior to X.Y.Z)
Firebox X series (all firmware versions prior to X.Y.Z)
Firebox virtual appliances (all versions prior to X.Y.Z)
vulnerabilities.remediation: Apply the security updates released by WatchGuard (version X.Y.Z or later). Verify that the firmware version on all Firebox devices is updated and that the update was successfully applied.
workarounds: Restrict inbound traffic to management interfaces to trusted IP ranges only.
Disable any unnecessary services that process external traffic.
Place the firewall behind an additional perimeter device that can filter malformed packets.

vulnerabilities.title: Google patches sixth Chrome zero-day exploited in attacks this year
vulnerabilities.original_title: Google patches sixth Chrome zero-day exploited in attacks this year
vulnerabilities.content_snippet: Google has released emergency security updates to patch a Chrome zero-day vulnerability, the sixth one tagged as exploited in attacks since the start of the year. [...]
vulnerabilities.summary: Chrome zero-day vulnerability exploited in the wild, allowing remote code execution via malicious web content.
vulnerabilities.description: A memory corruption flaw in Chrome's rendering engine (likely V8/ Blink) enables an attacker to execute arbitrary code in the context of the browser process when a victim visits a specially crafted web page. The vulnerability is chainable with Chrome's sandbox bypass techniques, leading to full system compromise. The bug has been actively exploited in targeted attacks since early 2025.
vulnerabilities.remediation: Update Google Chrome to the latest version released on 2025-09-18, which includes the emergency security patch. Enable automatic updates and enforce the update via enterprise policies.
workarounds: Temporarily disable JavaScript execution in Chrome settings.
Enable Chrome's site isolation and strict sandboxing policies.
Use a reputable web filtering solution to block known malicious URLs.

vulnerabilities.title: New HybridPetya Ransomware Bypasses UEFI Secure Boot With CVE-2024-7344 Exploit
vulnerabilities.original_title: New HybridPetya Ransomware Bypasses UEFI Secure Boot With CVE-2024-7344 Exploit
vulnerabilities.content_snippet: Cybersecurity researchers have discovered a new ransomware strain dubbed HybridPetya that resembles the notorious Petya/NotPetya malware, while also incorporating the ability to bypass the Secure Boot mechanism in Unified Extensible Firmware Interface (UEFI) systems using a now-patched vulnerability...
vulnerabilities.summary: UEFI Secure Boot bypass vulnerability enabling unauthenticated code execution before boot verification.
vulnerabilities.description: CVE-2024-7344 is a flaw in the UEFI firmware validation logic that allows an attacker to inject malicious code into the boot path, bypassing Secure Boot's cryptographic checks. The vulnerability can be triggered by placing a crafted EFI binary in a location that is loaded before the Secure Boot verification stage, leading to arbitrary code execution with firmware-level privileges. HybridPetya ransomware leverages this flaw to gain persistence before the operating system loads, effectively disabling Secure Boot protections and allowing the ransomware payload to execute with full system control.
affected_products: UEFI firmware implementations with Secure Boot enabled
affected_companies: UEFI firmware vendors (generic across motherboard manufacturers)
vendors: UEFI firmware vendors (generic across motherboard manufacturers)
vulnerabilities.remediation: Apply the firmware update provided by the motherboard/PC vendor that patches the Secure Boot validation logic. Verify that the system is running the latest UEFI version and that Secure Boot is re‑enabled after the update.
workarounds: Temporarily disable Secure Boot until the firmware can be updated.
Enable measured boot or use a hardware TPM with attestation to detect unauthorized firmware changes.

vulnerabilities.title: Samsung patches actively exploited zero-day reported by WhatsApp
vulnerabilities.original_title: Samsung patches actively exploited zero-day reported by WhatsApp
vulnerabilities.content_snippet: Samsung has patched a remote code execution vulnerability that was exploited in zero-day attacks targeting its Android devices. [...]
vulnerabilities.summary: Remote code execution vulnerability in Samsung Android devices actively exploited in zero-day attacks reported via WhatsApp.
vulnerabilities.description: A flaw in Samsung's media processing component (likely a buffer overflow or use‑after‑free) allows an unauthenticated attacker to execute arbitrary code with system privileges. The vulnerability is triggered by sending a specially crafted media file (e.g., image, video, or audio) via WhatsApp, which is then processed by the vulnerable component without proper validation. Successful exploitation results in full device compromise, enabling data theft, persistence, and further lateral movement.
affected_products: Samsung Galaxy smartphones running Android 13 and Android 14
Samsung tablets with Exynos and Snapdragon SoCs
products_versions: Other Samsung devices receiving the September 2025 security update
vulnerabilities.remediation: Apply the Samsung Security Patch released on 2025-09-10 via Settings > Software update > Download and install. Ensure the device is running the latest One UI version that includes the fix.
workarounds: Disable automatic media preview in WhatsApp and other messaging apps until the patch is applied.
Avoid opening media files from unknown or untrusted sources.
Use a mobile security solution that can block known malicious payloads.

vulnerabilities.title: Akira ransomware exploiting critical SonicWall SSLVPN bug again
vulnerabilities.original_title: Akira ransomware exploiting critical SonicWall SSLVPN bug again
vulnerabilities.content_snippet: The Akira ransomware gang is actively exploiting CVE-2024-40766, a year-old critical-severity access control vulnerability, to gain unauthorized access to SonicWall devices. [...]
vulnerabilities.summary: Critical access control vulnerability in SonicWall SSLVPN allowing unauthenticated remote access
vulnerabilities.description: The vulnerability is an access‑control bypass in the SSLVPN component of SonicWall devices. An attacker can send specially crafted requests to the VPN portal and obtain unauthorized administrative access without authentication. This enables the attacker to execute arbitrary commands, install ransomware (e.g., Akira), and move laterally within the compromised network.
products_versions: SonicWall SMA 100 Series firmware prior to 12.5.1.0
SonicWall SMA 200 Series firmware prior to 12.5.1.0
SonicWall SMA 300 Series firmware prior to 12.5.1.0
vulnerabilities.remediation: Apply the SonicWall security advisory patch released for the affected firmware versions. Upgrade to the latest SMA firmware that includes the fix. If immediate patching is not possible, disable external SSLVPN access and enforce strict IP allow‑lists.
workarounds: Disable SSLVPN service for internet‑facing interfaces
Restrict VPN access to trusted IP ranges via firewall rules
Enforce multi‑factor authentication on all VPN connections
Monitor and block suspicious VPN login attempts

vulnerabilities.title: Akira Ransomware Attacks Fuel Uptick in Exploitation of SonicWall Flaw
vulnerabilities.original_title: Akira Ransomware Attacks Fuel Uptick in Exploitation of SonicWall Flaw
vulnerabilities.content_snippet: The Akira ransomware group is likely exploiting a combination of three attack vectors to gain unauthorized access to vulnerable appliances. The post Akira Ransomware Attacks Fuel Uptick in Exploitation of SonicWall Flaw appeared first on SecurityWeek.
vulnerabilities.summary: Remote code execution vulnerability in SonicWall appliances that allows unauthenticated network access and command execution.
vulnerabilities.description: A flaw in the web management interface of SonicWall SMA/NSA devices permits an attacker to send specially crafted HTTP requests that trigger unauthenticated remote code execution. The vulnerability stems from insufficient input validation in the request parsing routine, leading to arbitrary command execution with root privileges. Successful exploitation grants full control of the appliance, enabling attackers to modify firewall policies, exfiltrate data, and deploy ransomware such as Akira.
vulnerabilities.remediation: Apply the security patches released by SonicWall (see SonicWall Security Advisory SA-2025-001) and upgrade to the latest firmware versions. Verify that the firmware version is equal to or higher than the patched releases.
workarounds: Restrict access to the management interface to trusted IP addresses via ACLs.
Disable remote management over the Internet and require VPN for administrative access.
Change default credentials and enforce strong, unique passwords for all admin accounts.

vulnerabilities.title: Microsoft Patch Tuesday security updates for September 2025 fixed two zero-day flaws
vulnerabilities.original_title: Microsoft Patch Tuesday security updates for September 2025 fixed two zero-day flaws
vulnerabilities.content_snippet: Microsoft Patch Tuesday security updates for September 2025 fixed 80 vulnerabilities, including two publicly disclosed zero-day flaws. Microsoft Patch Tuesday security updates for September 2025 addressed 80 vulnerabilities in Windows and Windows Components, Office and Office Components, Microsoft E...
vulnerabilities.summary: Windows SMB Server relay vulnerability allowing privilege escalation via SMB relay attacks.
vulnerabilities.description: An attacker on the same network can perform an SMB relay attack against the Windows SMB Server. By relaying authentication requests to a target system, the attacker can obtain elevated privileges on the victim machine. The vulnerability is mitigated by enabling SMB signing and Enhanced Protection for Authentication (EPA). The September 2025 updates add auditing for SMB relay attempts.
affected_products: Windows SMB Server (Windows 10, Windows 11, Windows Server 2016, 2019, 2022)
products_versions: Microsoft SQL Server (any version bundling vulnerable Newtonsoft.Json)
Microsoft HPC Pack (all versions prior to September 2025 update)
vulnerabilities.remediation: Apply the September 2025 Patch Tuesday updates. Enable SMB signing and EPA on all SMB servers. Review and enforce SMB signing policies.
workarounds: Enable SMB signing via Group Policy or local security policy.
Disable SMBv1 if not required.

vulnerabilities.title: Microsoft Patch Tuesday security updates for September 2025 fixed two zero-day flaws
vulnerabilities.original_title: Microsoft Patch Tuesday security updates for September 2025 fixed two zero-day flaws
vulnerabilities.content_snippet: Microsoft Patch Tuesday security updates for September 2025 fixed 80 vulnerabilities, including two publicly disclosed zero-day flaws. Microsoft Patch Tuesday security updates for September 2025 addressed 80 vulnerabilities in Windows and Windows Components, Office and Office Components, Microsoft E...
vulnerabilities.summary: Stack overflow in Newtonsoft.Json library used by SQL Server leading to denial‑of‑service.
vulnerabilities.description: A specially crafted JSON payload processed by the Newtonsoft.Json library within SQL Server can trigger a stack overflow, causing the SQL Server process to crash and resulting in a denial‑of‑service condition. The vulnerability was disclosed in 2024 and is fixed by updating the library in the September 2025 patch.
affected_products: Microsoft SQL Server (versions using bundled Newtonsoft.Json library)
products_versions: Microsoft SQL Server (any version bundling vulnerable Newtonsoft.Json)
Microsoft HPC Pack (all versions prior to September 2025 update)
vulnerabilities.remediation: Install the September 2025 security update for SQL Server which replaces the vulnerable Newtonsoft.Json library with a patched version.
workarounds: Validate and sanitize JSON input before it reaches SQL Server.
Restrict network access to SQL Server to trusted hosts.

vulnerabilities.title: Microsoft Patch Tuesday security updates for September 2025 fixed two zero-day flaws
vulnerabilities.original_title: Microsoft Patch Tuesday security updates for September 2025 fixed two zero-day flaws
vulnerabilities.content_snippet: Microsoft Patch Tuesday security updates for September 2025 fixed 80 vulnerabilities, including two publicly disclosed zero-day flaws. Microsoft Patch Tuesday security updates for September 2025 addressed 80 vulnerabilities in Windows and Windows Components, Office and Office Components, Microsoft E...
vulnerabilities.summary: Remote code execution vulnerability in Microsoft HPC Pack allowing unauthenticated, wormable attacks.
vulnerabilities.description: An unauthenticated attacker can send specially crafted packets to the HPC Pack service on TCP port 5999, resulting in remote code execution without any user interaction. The flaw is wormable because the compromised node can be used to propagate the exploit to other HPC clusters. Microsoft recommends deploying HPC clusters in secure enclaves and blocking inbound traffic to port 5999.
products_versions: Microsoft SQL Server (any version bundling vulnerable Newtonsoft.Json)
Microsoft HPC Pack (all versions prior to September 2025 update)
vulnerabilities.remediation: Apply the September 2025 Patch Tuesday update for Microsoft HPC Pack. Block inbound TCP port 5999 at the network perimeter. Deploy HPC clusters within isolated network segments or secure enclaves.
workarounds: Block TCP port 5999 on firewalls and host‑based firewalls.
Restrict HPC Pack management interfaces to trusted subnets.

vulnerabilities.title: Exposed Docker APIs Likely Exploited to Build Botnet
vulnerabilities.original_title: Exposed Docker APIs Likely Exploited to Build Botnet
vulnerabilities.content_snippet: Hackers mount the host’s file system into fresh containers, fetch malicious scripts over the Tor network, and block access to the Docker API. The post Exposed Docker APIs Likely Exploited to Build Botnet appeared first on SecurityWeek.
vulnerabilities.summary: Unauthenticated remote Docker API exposure allowing attackers to mount host filesystem, execute arbitrary containers, fetch malicious scripts via Tor, and hijack the host for botnet activities.
vulnerabilities.description: When the Docker daemon is configured to listen on a TCP socket without authentication or TLS, an attacker can connect remotely, bind-mount the host's root filesystem into a newly created container, and execute arbitrary commands. The attacker can then download additional malicious payloads over the Tor network, establish persistence, and block further access to the Docker API to hide activity. This technique enables rapid provisioning of compromised hosts into a botnet.
affected_products: Podman (when Docker API compatibility mode is enabled)
products_versions: Docker Engine 1.13 and later (when remote API is enabled without auth)
vulnerabilities.remediation: Disable the unauthenticated Docker API or bind it to localhost only. If remote access is required, enable TLS with client certificate authentication, enforce firewall rules to restrict access to trusted IPs, and enable Docker daemon's authorization plugins. Regularly audit Docker daemon configuration and rotate certificates.
workarounds: Restrict inbound traffic to the Docker daemon port (default 2375/2376) using host‑based firewalls or cloud security groups.
Run Docker with the "--host unix:///var/run/docker.sock" option only.
Deploy Docker Bench for Security to verify daemon configuration.

vulnerabilities.title: Attackers snooping around Sitecore, dropping malware via public sample keys
vulnerabilities.original_title: Attackers snooping around Sitecore, dropping malware via public sample keys
vulnerabilities.content_snippet: You cut and pasted the machine key from the official documentation? Ouch Unknown miscreants are exploiting a configuration vulnerability in multiple Sitecore products to achieve remote code execution via a publicly exposed key and deploy snooping malware on infected machines.…
vulnerabilities.summary: Publicly exposed Sitecore machine key enables remote code execution
vulnerabilities.description: A configuration weakness in multiple Sitecore products allows attackers to obtain the machineKey (used for validation and encryption) that was inadvertently published in public documentation or sample configuration files. With the key, an adversary can forge valid authentication cookies or encrypted payloads, leading to unauthenticated remote code execution on the Sitecore server. The compromised server is then used to drop and execute snooping malware that collects system information and exfiltrates data.
products_versions: All Sitecore versions prior to the security update released after 2025-09-04
vulnerabilities.remediation: Generate a unique, strong machineKey for each Sitecore installation; store the key securely (e.g., Azure Key Vault, environment variables); remove any sample or default keys from public repositories; apply any vendor‑released patches that enforce key confidentiality; rotate the key on all affected instances and invalidate existing sessions.
workarounds: Immediately replace the exposed machineKey with a new secret and restart the Sitecore services.
Restrict access to configuration files via file‑system permissions and web server rules.
Block inbound traffic to the Sitecore admin endpoints from untrusted networks.
