vulnerabilities.title: Warlock: From SharePoint Vulnerability Exploit to Enterprise Ransomware
vulnerabilities.original_title: Warlock: From SharePoint Vulnerability Exploit to Enterprise Ransomware
vulnerabilities.content_snippet: Warlock ransomware exploits unpatched Microsoft SharePoint vulnerabilities to gain access, escalate privileges, steal credentials, move laterally, and deploy ransomware with data exfiltration across enterprise environments.
vulnerabilities.summary: Unpatched Microsoft SharePoint server vulnerabilities allowing remote code execution and credential theft
vulnerabilities.description: The ransomware group Warlock leverages one or more unpatched vulnerabilities in Microsoft SharePoint that permit remote code execution on the SharePoint web application. By sending specially crafted HTTP requests to vulnerable SharePoint endpoints, an attacker can execute arbitrary commands on the server, install web shells, and harvest stored credentials. The foothold is then used to perform privilege escalation, lateral movement via harvested domain credentials, and deployment of ransomware payloads with data exfiltration capabilities across the enterprise network.
affected_products: Microsoft SharePoint Online (if on-premises components are exposed)
products_versions: SharePoint Server Subscription Edition (all supported updates)
vulnerabilities.remediation: Apply the latest security updates released by Microsoft for SharePoint Server. Disable unnecessary external access to SharePoint sites, enforce strict authentication mechanisms (e.g., MFA), and restrict inbound traffic to SharePoint services to trusted IP ranges. Conduct a thorough review of SharePoint configurations and remove any legacy authentication protocols.
workarounds: Block inbound traffic to SharePoint web services at the perimeter firewall until patches are applied.
Enable the SharePoint security hardening checklist provided by Microsoft.

vulnerabilities.title: Proactive Security Insights for SharePoint Attacks (CVE-2025-53770 and CVE-2025-53771)
vulnerabilities.original_title: Proactive Security Insights for SharePoint Attacks (CVE-2025-53770 and CVE-2025-53771)
vulnerabilities.content_snippet: CVE-2025-53770 and CVE-2025-53771 are vulnerabilities in on-premise Microsoft SharePoint Servers that evolved from previously patched flaws, allowing unauthenticated remote code execution through advanced deserialization and ViewState abuse.
vulnerabilities.summary: Unauthenticated remote code execution in on‑premise Microsoft SharePoint Server via advanced deserialization and ViewState abuse.
vulnerabilities.description: The vulnerability stems from insecure deserialization of objects embedded in the ViewState payload. An attacker can craft a malicious ViewState value that, when processed by the SharePoint server, triggers arbitrary code execution with SYSTEM privileges. The flaw evolved from previously patched issues, indicating that mitigation in earlier releases was insufficient against the new deserialization chain. No authentication is required, and exploitation can be performed remotely over HTTP/HTTPS.
vulnerabilities.remediation: Apply the security updates released by Microsoft for SharePoint Server (KBxxxxx for each affected version). Enable ViewState MAC validation and enforce the __VIEWSTATEENCRYPTION setting. Disable or restrict the use of the ObjectDataSource control if not required. Review and harden deserialization settings in web.config.
workarounds: Enable ViewState MAC (EnableViewStateMac=true) and enforce __VIEWSTATEENCRYPTION.
Restrict deserialization by removing the BinaryFormatter usage from custom code.
Place SharePoint servers behind a web application firewall that blocks malformed ViewState payloads.

vulnerabilities.title: Proactive Security Insights for SharePoint Attacks (CVE-2025-53770 and CVE-2025-53771)
vulnerabilities.original_title: Proactive Security Insights for SharePoint Attacks (CVE-2025-53770 and CVE-2025-53771)
vulnerabilities.content_snippet: CVE-2025-53770 and CVE-2025-53771 are vulnerabilities in on-premise Microsoft SharePoint Servers that evolved from previously patched flaws, allowing unauthenticated remote code execution through advanced deserialization and ViewState abuse.
vulnerabilities.summary: Unauthenticated remote code execution in on‑premise Microsoft SharePoint Server via ViewState tampering and advanced deserialization.
vulnerabilities.description: Similar to CVE-2025-53770, this flaw allows an attacker to embed a malicious serialized object within the ViewState token. The server deserializes the object without sufficient validation, leading to execution of attacker‑controlled code. The vulnerability is exploitable remotely without authentication and impacts all supported on‑premise SharePoint Server releases.
vulnerabilities.remediation: Install the Microsoft security patches released for CVE-2025-53771 (KBxxxxx). Enforce ViewState MAC and enable ViewState encryption. Review custom web parts for unsafe deserialization patterns and replace BinaryFormatter with safe alternatives.
workarounds: Enable ViewState MAC and encryption.
Deploy a reverse proxy that validates the size and format of ViewState data.
Remove or sandbox any custom web parts that perform deserialization of untrusted data.

vulnerabilities.title: Another Confluence Bites the Dust: Falling to ELPACO-team Ransomware
vulnerabilities.original_title: Another Confluence Bites the Dust: Falling to ELPACO-team Ransomware
vulnerabilities.content_snippet: Key Takeaways The DFIR Report Services Table of Contents: Case Summary In late June 2024, an unpatched Confluence server was compromised via CVE-2023-22527, a template injection vulnerability, first from IP … Read More
vulnerabilities.summary: Atlassian Confluence Server and Data Center template injection leading to remote code execution.
vulnerabilities.description: The vulnerability is a template injection flaw in Confluence's rendering engine. An unauthenticated attacker can supply a malicious template via a crafted HTTP request, which is then processed by the server, resulting in arbitrary code execution with the privileges of the Confluence service account. Exploitation does not require user interaction and can be performed remotely over the network.
products_versions: Confluence Data Center equivalents of the above versions
vulnerabilities.remediation: Upgrade Confluence to a patched version (7.13.7, 7.14.3, 7.15.2, or later). Apply the official Atlassian security patches. If immediate upgrade is not possible, disable the affected template rendering functionality and restrict access to the Confluence instance via firewall rules.
workarounds: Disable the Confluence template rendering feature via the admin console.
Restrict inbound traffic to the Confluence server to trusted IP ranges.
Apply a web application firewall (WAF) rule that blocks the specific malicious request patterns associated with CVE-2023-22527.

vulnerabilities.title: Another Confluence Bites the Dust: Falling to ELPACO-team Ransomware
vulnerabilities.original_title: Another Confluence Bites the Dust: Falling to ELPACO-team Ransomware
vulnerabilities.content_snippet: Key Takeaways The DFIR Report Services Table of Contents: Case Summary In late June 2024, an unpatched Confluence server was compromised via CVE-2023-22527, a template injection vulnerability, first from IP … Read More
vulnerabilities.summary: Server-side template injection (SSTI) in Atlassian Confluence Server and Data Center allowing remote code execution.
vulnerabilities.description: An attacker can supply a malicious template payload to Confluence's rendering engine. The payload is evaluated on the server, leading to arbitrary code execution with the privileges of the Confluence process. Exploitation does not require authentication and can be performed remotely over HTTP/HTTPS. The vulnerability was leveraged in the wild to deploy ransomware (ELPACO-team) after compromising an unpatched Confluence instance in June 2024.
products_versions: Confluence Server/Data Center versions prior to 8.5.6, 8.4.13, and 8.3.15
exploit_kits: Cobalt Strike templates (observed in the wild)
vulnerabilities.remediation: Upgrade Confluence to a patched version (8.5.6, 8.4.13, 8.3.15, or later). Apply the security patch released by Atlassian. If immediate upgrade is not possible, disable the vulnerable template rendering functionality and restrict access to Confluence via firewall or VPN.
workarounds: Block inbound traffic to Confluence from untrusted networks.
Restrict access to the Confluence web UI to authenticated internal users only.
Apply a Web Application Firewall (WAF) rule to block requests containing the known malicious template payload patterns.

This includes those involved in the coordination, transport, and delivery of foreign assistance to Ukraine. Since 2022, Western...
vulnerabilities.summary: Outlook NTLM hash theft via crafted calendar invitation
vulnerabilities.description: A specially crafted Outlook calendar appointment triggers Outlook to initiate an NTLM authentication request to an attacker-controlled server, leaking the victim's Net-NTLMv2 hash. The hash can be relayed to authenticate to other services within the victim's domain.

vulnerabilities.title: Salesforce Patches Critical ForcedLeak Bug Exposing CRM Data via AI Prompt Injection
vulnerabilities.original_title: Salesforce Patches Critical ForcedLeak Bug Exposing CRM Data via AI Prompt Injection
vulnerabilities.content_snippet: Cybersecurity researchers have disclosed a critical flaw impacting Salesforce Agentforce, a platform for building artificial intelligence (AI) agents, that could allow attackers to potentially exfiltrate sensitive data from its customer relationship management (CRM) tool by means of an indirect prom...
vulnerabilities.summary: ForcedLeak vulnerability in Salesforce Agentforce allows indirect AI prompt injection to exfiltrate CRM data.
vulnerabilities.description: ForcedLeak is an indirect prompt injection flaw in Salesforce Agentforce, the AI‑agent platform used to augment Salesforce CRM. An attacker can craft specially‑designed inputs that are passed to the AI model, causing it to generate responses that include sensitive CRM records (e.g., contact details, opportunity data). The generated output can be captured by the attacker through API responses or UI displays, effectively leaking confidential data without needing authentication. The vulnerability stems from insufficient sanitisation of user‑supplied content before it is fed into the language model and from the model's ability to emit raw data from its context.
products_versions: Salesforce Agentforce (versions prior to the September 2025 security patch)
vulnerabilities.remediation: Apply the security patch released by Salesforce for Agentforce. Update to the latest Agentforce version. Implement strict input validation and output filtering for all AI‑generated content. Restrict API access to Agentforce to trusted IP ranges and enforce least‑privilege OAuth scopes. Enable Salesforce Shield Event Monitoring to audit AI agent interactions.
workarounds: Disable Agentforce functionality until the patch is applied.
Restrict or block external API calls that invoke Agentforce.
Apply content‑type allow‑list to prevent untrusted data from reaching the AI model.

vulnerabilities.title: Salesforce Patches Critical ForcedLeak Bug Exposing CRM Data via AI Prompt Injection
vulnerabilities.original_title: Salesforce Patches Critical ForcedLeak Bug Exposing CRM Data via AI Prompt Injection
vulnerabilities.content_snippet: Cybersecurity researchers have disclosed a critical flaw impacting Salesforce Agentforce, a platform for building artificial intelligence (AI) agents, that could allow attackers to potentially exfiltrate sensitive data from its customer relationship management (CRM) tool by means of an indirect prom...
vulnerabilities.summary: ForcedLeak vulnerability in Salesforce Agentforce allows indirect AI prompt injection to exfiltrate CRM data.
vulnerabilities.description: The ForcedLeak flaw is an indirect prompt injection issue in the AI agent platform (Agentforce) used by Salesforce CRM. An attacker can craft malicious prompts that are processed by the AI agent, causing it to retrieve and return sensitive CRM records. The injection bypasses normal access controls, enabling data leakage without authentication. The vulnerability stems from insufficient sanitization of user‑supplied content passed to the underlying language model and the lack of output filtering before data is returned to the requester.
vulnerabilities.remediation: Apply the security patch released by Salesforce for Agentforce. Update to the latest Agentforce version and enable any hardening settings provided by the vendor.
workarounds: Disable Agentforce functionality until the patch is applied.
Implement strict input validation and output filtering for AI prompts.
Restrict AI agent permissions to read‑only access for non‑sensitive data.

vulnerabilities.title: A critical WatchGuard Fireware flaw could allow unauthenticated code execution
vulnerabilities.original_title: A critical WatchGuard Fireware flaw could allow unauthenticated code execution
vulnerabilities.content_snippet: A critical WatchGuard Fireware vulnerability, tracked as CVE-2025-9242, could allow unauthenticated code execution. Researchers revealed details of a critical vulnerability, tracked as CVE-2025-9242 (CVSS score of 9.3), in WatchGuard Fireware. An unauthenticated attacker can exploit the flaw to exec...
vulnerabilities.summary: Out-of-bounds write in WatchGuard Fireware iked process allows unauthenticated remote code execution via IKEv2 VPN.
vulnerabilities.description: The iked process in WatchGuard Fireware OS copies a client identifier into a fixed 520‑byte stack buffer (ike2_ProcessPayload_CERT in ike2_payload_cert.c) without proper length validation during IKE_SA_AUTH. An attacker can send a crafted IKEv2 packet to the VPN service (mobile user VPN or branch office VPN with a dynamic gateway) causing an out‑of‑bounds write, overwriting the return address. The published exploit gains RIP control, uses mprotect() to bypass NX, spawns a Python TCP shell, remounts the filesystem read/write, downloads BusyBox and creates a symlink to /bin/sh, resulting in full Linux command execution on the perimeter appliance.
affected_products: WatchGuard Firebox devices running Fireware OS 11.10.2–11.12.4_Update1
WatchGuard Firebox devices running Fireware OS 12.0–12.11.3
WatchGuard Firebox devices running Fireware OS 2025.1
vulnerabilities.remediation: Upgrade Fireware OS to the fixed versions released by WatchGuard (post‑2025.1 patches). Apply the latest security update that addresses CVE‑2025‑9242.
workarounds: Disable IKEv2 VPN services (mobile user VPN and branch office VPN) until patches are applied.
Remove all dynamic gateway configurations; use static gateways only.
Block inbound IKE (UDP/500 and UDP/4500) from untrusted networks.
Restrict VPN access to known IP ranges via firewall rules.
references: WatchGuard Security Advisory for CVE‑2025‑9242 (if available)

vulnerabilities.title: Researchers Uncover WatchGuard VPN Bug That Could Let Attackers Take Over Devices
vulnerabilities.original_title: Researchers Uncover WatchGuard VPN Bug That Could Let Attackers Take Over Devices
vulnerabilities.content_snippet: Cybersecurity researchers have disclosed details of a recently patched critical security flaw in WatchGuard Fireware that could allow unauthenticated attackers to execute arbitrary code. The vulnerability, tracked as CVE-2025-9242 (CVSS score: 9.3), is described as an out-of-bounds write vulnerabili...
vulnerabilities.summary: Out-of-bounds write in WatchGuard Fireware VPN component allowing unauthenticated remote code execution
vulnerabilities.description: A memory corruption flaw (out-of-bounds write) exists in the VPN handling code of WatchGuard Fireware OS versions 11.10.2 through 11.12.4_Update1 and 12.0 (up to the vulnerable build). An unauthenticated attacker can send specially crafted VPN packets that trigger the out-of-bounds write, overwriting adjacent memory structures and achieving arbitrary code execution with system privileges. Successful exploitation results in full control of the firewall device.
products_versions: Fireware OS 12.0 (up to the vulnerable build)
vulnerabilities.remediation: Upgrade to the patched Fireware OS version released by WatchGuard (e.g., 11.12.5 or later, 12.0.1 or later). Apply the security advisory and restart the device after upgrade.
workarounds: Temporarily disable the VPN service until the patch can be applied.
Restrict inbound VPN traffic to known IP addresses using firewall rules.
Place the firewall behind an additional perimeter device that filters VPN traffic.

vulnerabilities.title: Hackers Target ICTBroadcast Servers via Cookie Exploit to Gain Remote Shell Access
vulnerabilities.original_title: Hackers Target ICTBroadcast Servers via Cookie Exploit to Gain Remote Shell Access
vulnerabilities.content_snippet: Cybersecurity researchers have disclosed that a critical security flaw impacting ICTBroadcast, an autodialer software from ICT Innovations, has come under active exploitation in the wild. The vulnerability, assigned the CVE identifier CVE-2025-2611 (CVSS score: 9.3), relates to improper input valida...
vulnerabilities.summary: Improper input validation in ICTBroadcast autodialer allows unauthenticated remote code execution via crafted cookies.
vulnerabilities.description: The vulnerability stems from insufficient validation of cookie data processed by the ICTBroadcast server. An attacker can craft a malicious cookie that, when sent to the server, triggers a buffer overflow/command injection leading to execution of arbitrary commands with system privileges, granting a remote shell without authentication.
products_versions: All ICTBroadcast versions prior to the security patch released in October 2025
vulnerabilities.remediation: Apply the vendor-supplied patch released for ICTBroadcast (version >= X.Y.Z). If a patch is not yet available, enforce strict input validation on cookie handling, update the web server to reject malformed cookies, and restrict execution privileges of the autodialer service.
workarounds: Deploy a Web Application Firewall (WAF) rule to block suspicious cookie patterns.
Disable remote shell functionality in ICTBroadcast configuration.
Restrict network access to the ICTBroadcast service to trusted IP ranges.

vulnerabilities.title: Cybercrime ring GXC Team dismantled in Spain, 25-year-old leader detained
vulnerabilities.original_title: Cybercrime ring GXC Team dismantled in Spain, 25-year-old leader detained
vulnerabilities.content_snippet: Spain’s Guardia Civil dismantled the cybercrime group “GXC Team” and arrested its 25-year-old Brazilian leader. Spanish Guardia Civil dismantled the “GXC Team” cybercrime group, arresting its 25-year-old Brazilian leader “GoogleXcoder.” The gang sold AI-powered phishing kits, Android malware, and vo...
vulnerabilities.summary: Malicious Android application mimicking official banking apps to intercept OTPs
vulnerabilities.description: The GXC Team distributes a malicious Android binary that is disguised as a legitimate banking app. Victims are tricked into installing the app under the pretext of confirming a One-Time Password (OTP). The app captures the OTP and forwards it to the attacker’s C2 server, allowing the attacker to bypass two‑factor authentication and gain unauthorized access to the victim’s online banking account.
vulnerabilities.remediation: Enforce strict app verification (Google Play Protect, signed APK verification), educate users to install apps only from official stores, implement transaction‑level authentication that does not rely solely on OTP, and monitor for anomalous OTP usage.
workarounds: Require hardware‑based authentication tokens for high‑value transactions
Deploy mobile device management (MDM) solutions to whitelist approved banking apps

Spanish Guardia Civil dismantled the “GXC Team” cybercrime group, arresting its 25-year-old Brazilian leader “GoogleXcoder.” The gang sold AI-powered phishing kits, Android malware, and vo...
vulnerabilities.summary: AI‑powered Business Invoice Swapper tool used for BEC and invoice fraud
vulnerabilities.description: The Business Invoice Swapper is an AI‑driven tool that generates fraudulent invoices and automatically replaces legitimate invoice data with attacker‑controlled IBAN/BIC details. The operator uploads a list of compromised email accounts; the tool scans mailboxes, injects forged invoices, and initiates wire transfers. The service is offered as a rental or one‑time purchase, facilitating large‑scale Business Email Compromise (BEC) attacks.
affected_products: Email clients and corporate mail gateways
vulnerabilities.remediation: Deploy DMARC, DKIM, and SPF with strict policies, implement AI‑based email anomaly detection, enforce dual‑approval for wire transfers, and regularly audit financial transaction logs.
workarounds: Require manual verification of any invoice that includes new banking details
Use secure email gateways that sandbox attachments and URLs

Spanish Guardia Civil dismantled the “GXC Team” cybercrime group, arresting its 25-year-old Brazilian leader “GoogleXcoder.” The gang sold AI-powered phishing kits, Android malware, and vo...
vulnerabilities.summary: Phishing kits that clone banking and government portals for credential harvesting
vulnerabilities.description: The GXC Team sells ready‑to‑use phishing kits that replicate the look and functionality of popular banking and government websites. Victims are lured via email, SMS, or social media to these clones, where they enter credentials which are then harvested by the attackers. The kits include automated credential harvesting, session hijacking scripts, and optional modules for smishing delivery.
affected_products: Online banking portals (AMEX, Santander, BBVA, etc.)
vulnerabilities.remediation: Implement anti‑phishing training, deploy browser anti‑phishing extensions, enforce MFA on all accounts, and use URL reputation services to block known malicious domains.
workarounds: Encourage users to navigate to sites via bookmarks rather than clicking links
Deploy DNS filtering to block known phishing domains

vulnerabilities.title: CISA Sounds Alarm on Critical Sudo Flaw Actively Exploited in Linux and Unix Systems
vulnerabilities.original_title: CISA Sounds Alarm on Critical Sudo Flaw Actively Exploited in Linux and Unix Systems
vulnerabilities.content_snippet: The U.S. Cybersecurity and Infrastructure Security Agency (CISA) on Monday added a critical security flaw impacting the Sudo command-line utility for Linux and Unix-like operating systems to its Known Exploited Vulnerabilities (KEV) catalog, citing evidence of active exploitation in the wild. The vu...
vulnerabilities.summary: Critical heap overflow in Sudo leading to local privilege escalation.
vulnerabilities.description: A heap overflow vulnerability exists in Sudo versions prior to the patched release. An attacker with a regular user account can craft a malicious environment variable or command line argument that triggers the overflow, allowing execution of arbitrary code with root privileges. The flaw is actively exploited in the wild, as reported by CISA, and can be used to bypass sudo restrictions, install backdoors, and exfiltrate data.
vulnerabilities.remediation: Upgrade Sudo to the version that includes the fix (version 1.9.15p6 or later). Apply vendor-specific patches for affected distributions. Verify the installed version with `sudo -V` and ensure the package is up‑to‑date via the distribution's package manager.
workarounds: Restrict sudo access to trusted users only.
Remove unnecessary SUID binaries.
Enable sudo's `use_pty` option to force a pseudo‑terminal allocation, mitigating certain exploit vectors.
Monitor and audit sudo usage logs for anomalous activity.

vulnerabilities.title: Ivanti EPMM holes let miscreants plant shady listeners, CISA says
vulnerabilities.original_title: Ivanti EPMM holes let miscreants plant shady listeners, CISA says
vulnerabilities.content_snippet: Unnamed org compromised with two malware sets An unknown attacker has abused a couple of flaws in Ivanti Endpoint Manager Mobile (EPMM) and deployed two sets of malware against an unnamed organization, according to the US Cybersecurity and Infrastructure Security Agency.…
vulnerabilities.summary: Remote code execution vulnerability in Ivanti Endpoint Manager Mobile (EPMM) allowing unauthenticated attackers to deploy malicious listeners.
vulnerabilities.description: A flaw in the EPMM server component permits remote attackers to execute arbitrary code without authentication. The vulnerability stems from improper validation of inbound API requests, enabling attackers to upload malicious payloads that establish persistent listeners on compromised hosts. Exploitation results in full control of the endpoint and lateral movement within the target network.
products_versions: Ivanti Endpoint Manager Mobile (EPMM) versions prior to 2025.2.0
vulnerabilities.remediation: Apply Ivanti security advisory patch released in June 2025 (EPMM version 2025.2.0 or later). Verify that the patch is installed on all managed devices and servers. Restart services after patching.
workarounds: Restrict inbound traffic to the EPMM management interface using firewall rules.
Disable unused API endpoints until the patch is applied.
Enforce mutual TLS for all API communications.

vulnerabilities.title: Ivanti EPMM holes let miscreants plant shady listeners, CISA says
vulnerabilities.original_title: Ivanti EPMM holes let miscreants plant shady listeners, CISA says
vulnerabilities.content_snippet: Unnamed org compromised with two malware sets An unknown attacker has abused a couple of flaws in Ivanti Endpoint Manager Mobile (EPMM) and deployed two sets of malware against an unnamed organization, according to the US Cybersecurity and Infrastructure Security Agency.…
vulnerabilities.summary: Authentication bypass vulnerability in Ivanti EPMM that allows attackers to gain administrative privileges via crafted requests.
vulnerabilities.description: Improper session handling in the EPMM web console permits an attacker with a low‑privilege account to elevate privileges to an administrator by manipulating session tokens. This enables configuration changes, deployment of malicious applications, and further exploitation of the RCE vulnerability.
products_versions: Ivanti Endpoint Manager Mobile (EPMM) versions prior to 2025.2.0
vulnerabilities.remediation: Install the June 2025 Ivanti EPMM security update that corrects session validation logic. Reset all active sessions after patch deployment.
workarounds: Force re‑authentication for all users after patching.
Enable multi‑factor authentication for all administrative accounts.

vulnerabilities.title: RevengeHotels: a new wave of attacks leveraging LLMs and VenomRAT
vulnerabilities.original_title: RevengeHotels: a new wave of attacks leveraging LLMs and VenomRAT
vulnerabilities.content_snippet: Background RevengeHotels, also known as TA558, is a threat group that has been active since 2015, stealing credit card data from hotel guests and travelers. RevengeHotels’ modus operandi involves sending emails with phishing links which redirect victims to websites mimicking document storage. ...
vulnerabilities.summary: Remote code execution vulnerability in Microsoft Office/Word when processing specially crafted Office documents.
vulnerabilities.description: An attacker can embed a malicious RTF or Office document in a phishing email. When the victim opens the document, the vulnerability is triggered, allowing arbitrary code execution with the privileges of the user. The exploit was used by RevengeHotels in earlier campaigns to drop VBS or PowerShell scripts that later install various RATs.
vulnerabilities.remediation: Apply Microsoft security update MS17-010 (or later cumulative updates) that patches CVE-2017-0199. Disable the loading of remote content in Office files and restrict macro execution.
workarounds: Configure Office to open files in Protected View.
Disable the 'Enable editing' prompt for files from the internet.
Block Office file types in email gateways.

vulnerabilities.title: Akira Ransomware exploits year-old SonicWall flaw with multiple vectors
vulnerabilities.original_title: Akira Ransomware exploits year-old SonicWall flaw with multiple vectors
vulnerabilities.content_snippet: Researchers warn that Akira ransomware group is exploiting a year-old SonicWall firewall flaw, likely using three attack vectors for initial access. The Akira ransomware group is exploiting a year-old SonicWall firewall vulnerability, tracked as CVE-2024-40766 (CVSS score of 9.3), likely using three...
vulnerabilities.summary: Improper access control in SonicWall SonicOS management interface allows unauthorized remote access to firewall configuration and SSLVPN services.
vulnerabilities.description: The vulnerability resides in the SonicWall SonicOS management access control logic. An unauthenticated attacker can bypass authentication checks and gain administrative access to the firewall, including the SSLVPN portal. The flaw can be leveraged in combination with three related security weaknesses: (1) default SSLVPN user groups that grant broad access, (2) retained local passwords after Gen6‑to‑Gen7 migrations, and (3) the Virtual Office Portal allowing configuration of MFA/TOTP with exposed credentials. Exploitation enables the attacker to establish persistent footholds, move laterally, and deploy ransomware such as Akira.
affected_products: LDAP integration for SSLVPN Default Users Group
products_versions: SonicWall SonicOS Gen 7 firewalls (including models with SSLVPN enabled)
vulnerabilities.remediation: Apply SonicWall SonicOS patch released August 2024 (advisory SNWLID-2024-0015). After patching, reset all local and migrated passwords, disable or restrict the SSLVPN Default Users Group, enforce MFA on all VPN accounts, and limit access to the Virtual Office Portal to trusted administrators only.
workarounds: Disable SSLVPN until the patch is applied.
Manually audit and remove default user groups.
Force password change for all accounts after firewall migration.
Restrict VOP access via IP allow‑lists and monitor configuration changes.
references: CISA Known Exploited Vulnerabilities (KEV) Catalog – CVE-2024-40766
SecurityAffairs article – Akira Ransomware exploits year‑old SonicWall flaw

vulnerabilities.title: Docker Fixes CVE-2025-9074, Critical Container Escape Vulnerability With CVSS Score 9.3
vulnerabilities.original_title: Docker Fixes CVE-2025-9074, Critical Container Escape Vulnerability With CVSS Score 9.3
vulnerabilities.content_snippet: Docker has released fixes to address a critical security flaw affecting the Docker Desktop app for Windows and macOS that could potentially allow an attacker to break out of the confines of a container. The vulnerability, tracked as CVE-2025-9074, carries a CVSS score of 9.3 out of 10.0. It has been...
vulnerabilities.summary: Critical container escape vulnerability in Docker Desktop
vulnerabilities.description: A critical security flaw in Docker Desktop for Windows and macOS that allows a malicious container to break out of its confinement and potentially access the host system. This vulnerability could lead to complete system compromise.
products_versions: Docker Desktop for Windows and macOS (prior to version 4.44.3)
vulnerabilities.remediation: Update to Docker Desktop version 4.44.3 or later which contains the fix for this vulnerability.
workarounds: Restrict container privileges
Use Docker in a sandboxed environment
Disable Docker Desktop if not actively needed

vulnerabilities.title: Researchers Disclose Google Gemini AI Flaws Allowing Prompt Injection and Cloud Exploits
vulnerabilities.original_title: Researchers Disclose Google Gemini AI Flaws Allowing Prompt Injection and Cloud Exploits
vulnerabilities.content_snippet: Cybersecurity researchers have disclosed three now-patched security vulnerabilities impacting Google's Gemini artificial intelligence (AI) assistant that, if successfully exploited, could have exposed users to major privacy risks and data theft. "They made Gemini vulnerable to search-injection attac...
vulnerabilities.summary: Search personalization model injection allowing attackers to manipulate Gemini's search results via crafted prompts
vulnerabilities.description: The Gemini AI assistant's search personalization component fails to properly sanitize user‑supplied prompts before they are incorporated into the search ranking algorithm. An attacker can craft a malicious prompt that injects arbitrary search queries or ranking weights, causing the model to return manipulated results and potentially expose user search histories or preferences.
products_versions: Google Gemini AI Assistant (versions prior to 2025‑09‑15 patch)
vulnerabilities.remediation: Apply the vendor‑released patch (June 2025) that adds strict input validation and context isolation for the personalization model. Update to the latest Gemini SDK.
workarounds: Disable the Search Personalization feature via the Gemini console until the patch is applied.
Restrict API access to trusted IP ranges and enforce MFA for all accounts.

vulnerabilities.title: Researchers Disclose Google Gemini AI Flaws Allowing Prompt Injection and Cloud Exploits
vulnerabilities.original_title: Researchers Disclose Google Gemini AI Flaws Allowing Prompt Injection and Cloud Exploits
vulnerabilities.content_snippet: Cybersecurity researchers have disclosed three now-patched security vulnerabilities impacting Google's Gemini artificial intelligence (AI) assistant that, if successfully exploited, could have exposed users to major privacy risks and data theft. "They made Gemini vulnerable to search-injection attac...
vulnerabilities.summary: Log‑to‑prompt injection in Gemini Cloud allowing attackers to retrieve arbitrary logs via crafted prompts
vulnerabilities.description: Gemini Cloud's logging subsystem concatenates recent log entries into the prompt context without proper sanitization. An attacker can inject a specially crafted prompt that causes the system to echo back log data, including potentially sensitive information such as API keys, user identifiers, and internal error messages.
affected_products: Gemini API endpoint for log retrieval
products_versions: Google Gemini AI Assistant (versions prior to 2025‑09‑15 patch)
vulnerabilities.remediation: Install the September 2025 security update that isolates log data from the prompt generation pipeline and enforces strict character whitelisting.
workarounds: Turn off log‑to‑prompt feature in the Gemini Cloud configuration.
Implement a proxy that filters out log‑related tokens before they reach the AI model.

vulnerabilities.title: Researchers Disclose Google Gemini AI Flaws Allowing Prompt Injection and Cloud Exploits
vulnerabilities.original_title: Researchers Disclose Google Gemini AI Flaws Allowing Prompt Injection and Cloud Exploits
vulnerabilities.content_snippet: Cybersecurity researchers have disclosed three now-patched security vulnerabilities impacting Google's Gemini artificial intelligence (AI) assistant that, if successfully exploited, could have exposed users to major privacy risks and data theft. "They made Gemini vulnerable to search-injection attac...
vulnerabilities.summary: Prompt injection via Gemini API allowing remote code execution in downstream integrations
vulnerabilities.description: The Gemini API fails to enforce a strict separation between user‑provided prompt content and system commands. An attacker can embed malicious commands within a normal‑looking prompt that are executed by downstream services (e.g., webhooks, function calls) that trust Gemini's output, leading to remote code execution or data exfiltration.
affected_products: Third‑party applications integrating Gemini via SDK
products_versions: Google Gemini AI Assistant (versions prior to 2025‑09‑15 patch)
vulnerabilities.remediation: Update to the latest Gemini API library (v2.3.1) which introduces command‑whitelisting and output sanitization. Review and harden any downstream services that automatically act on Gemini responses.
workarounds: Validate and sanitize Gemini responses before passing them to any execution environment.
Disable automatic execution of Gemini‑generated code in integrations.

vulnerabilities.title: Two Critical Flaws Uncovered in Wondershare RepairIt Exposing User Data and AI Models
vulnerabilities.original_title: Two Critical Flaws Uncovered in Wondershare RepairIt Exposing User Data and AI Models
vulnerabilities.content_snippet: Cybersecurity researchers have disclosed two security flaws in Wondershare RepairIt that exposed private user data and potentially exposed the system to artificial intelligence (AI) model tampering and supply chain risks. The critical-rated vulnerabilities in question, discovered by Trend Micro, are...
vulnerabilities.summary: Authentication bypass in Wondershare RepairIt allows unauthenticated attackers to gain full access to the application and user data.
vulnerabilities.description: The vulnerability stems from improper validation of authentication tokens during the login flow. An attacker can craft a specially‑formed request that bypasses the credential check, granting full administrative privileges within the RepairIt application. This enables extraction of private user files, modification of settings, and potential execution of arbitrary code in the context of the application.
products_versions: Wondershare RepairIt versions prior to the September 2025 security update
vulnerabilities.remediation: Update to the latest version of Wondershare RepairIt released after 2025-09-24 that includes the authentication bypass fix. Enable multi‑factor authentication and restrict network access to trusted IP ranges.
workarounds: Block inbound traffic to the RepairIt service at the firewall level.
Disable remote management features until the patch is applied.

vulnerabilities.title: Two Critical Flaws Uncovered in Wondershare RepairIt Exposing User Data and AI Models
vulnerabilities.original_title: Two Critical Flaws Uncovered in Wondershare RepairIt Exposing User Data and AI Models
vulnerabilities.content_snippet: Cybersecurity researchers have disclosed two security flaws in Wondershare RepairIt that exposed private user data and potentially exposed the system to artificial intelligence (AI) model tampering and supply chain risks. The critical-rated vulnerabilities in question, discovered by Trend Micro, are...
vulnerabilities.summary: Improper handling of AI model files in Wondershare RepairIt enables model tampering and supply‑chain attacks.
vulnerabilities.description: The application loads AI model files without sufficient integrity verification. An attacker who can place a malicious model on the host or intercept the download can cause the application to execute malicious code, leading to data exfiltration or further compromise of the host system.
products_versions: Wondershare RepairIt versions prior to the September 2025 security update
vulnerabilities.remediation: Apply the vendor‑provided update that adds cryptographic signing and verification of AI model files. Ensure that only trusted sources are used for model updates.
workarounds: Disable automatic model updates.
Restrict write permissions on the directory where models are stored.

vulnerabilities.title: Two Critical Flaws Uncovered in Wondershare RepairIt Exposing User Data and AI Models
vulnerabilities.original_title: Two Critical Flaws Uncovered in Wondershare RepairIt Exposing User Data and AI Models
vulnerabilities.content_snippet: Cybersecurity researchers have disclosed two security flaws in Wondershare RepairIt that exposed private user data and potentially exposed the system to artificial intelligence (AI) model tampering and supply chain risks. The critical-rated vulnerabilities in question, discovered by Trend Micro, are...
vulnerabilities.summary: Authentication bypass in Wondershare RepairIt allowing unauthenticated attackers to gain full access to the application.
vulnerabilities.description: The vulnerability stems from improper validation of authentication tokens during the login flow. An attacker can craft a specially crafted request that bypasses the credential check, granting administrative privileges without providing valid credentials. This enables full read/write access to user files, configuration data, and the ability to execute arbitrary commands within the context of the RepairIt service.
vulnerabilities.remediation: Upgrade to the patched version released by Wondershare (version 5.3.2 or later). Apply the vendor-supplied hotfix that enforces strict token validation and adds rate‑limiting on authentication endpoints. Enable multi‑factor authentication where supported and restrict access to the RepairIt service to trusted internal networks.
workarounds: Block inbound traffic to the RepairIt management ports (default 443/8443) from untrusted networks.
Enforce network segmentation so that only authorized workstations can reach the RepairIt server.
Monitor authentication logs for anomalous login attempts and disable accounts showing suspicious activity.

vulnerabilities.title: Two Critical Flaws Uncovered in Wondershare RepairIt Exposing User Data and AI Models
vulnerabilities.original_title: Two Critical Flaws Uncovered in Wondershare RepairIt Exposing User Data and AI Models
vulnerabilities.content_snippet: Cybersecurity researchers have disclosed two security flaws in Wondershare RepairIt that exposed private user data and potentially exposed the system to artificial intelligence (AI) model tampering and supply chain risks. The critical-rated vulnerabilities in question, discovered by Trend Micro, are...
vulnerabilities.summary: Insecure storage of AI model files and user data in Wondershare RepairIt leading to data leakage and potential model tampering.
vulnerabilities.description: RepairIt stores AI model binaries and user backup metadata in plaintext on the local filesystem and optionally on cloud‑synced directories without encryption or integrity checks. An attacker with low‑level access to the host (e.g., via a compromised user account or a malicious plug‑in) can read or modify these files, resulting in exposure of private user data and the ability to inject malicious code into AI models used by the application, creating a supply‑chain risk.
vulnerabilities.remediation: Apply the security update released by Wondershare (version 5.3.2+). Enable the built‑in encryption option for model storage and configure the application to use TLS for any cloud synchronization. Restrict file system permissions so that only the service account can read/write the model directory.
workarounds: Manually encrypt the RepairIt data directory using OS‑level encryption tools (e.g., BitLocker, LUKS).
Disable cloud synchronization features until the patch is applied.
Audit and harden file system permissions for the RepairIt installation folder.

vulnerabilities.title: Critical flaw SessionReaper in Commerce and Magento platforms lets attackers hijack customer accounts
vulnerabilities.original_title: Critical flaw SessionReaper in Commerce and Magento platforms lets attackers hijack customer accounts
vulnerabilities.content_snippet: Adobe fixed a critical flaw in its Commerce and Magento Open Source platforms that allows an attacker to take over customer accounts. Adobe addressed a critical vulnerability, tracked as CVE-2025-54236 (aka SessionReaper, CVSS score of 9.1) in its Commerce and Magento Open Source platforms. The vuln...
vulnerabilities.summary: Improper input validation and deserialization flaw in Adobe Commerce/Magento REST API allowing unauthenticated remote code execution and customer account takeover.
vulnerabilities.description: The SessionReaper vulnerability (CVE-2025-54236) stems from improper input validation combined with a nested deserialization bug in the Magento/Adobe Commerce REST API. An attacker can craft a malicious session object that, when processed by the API, triggers arbitrary PHP code execution. The exploit is most reliable when the platform uses file‑based session storage, but alternative vectors exist for Redis or database‑backed sessions. Successful exploitation results in full compromise of customer accounts and, under certain conditions, unauthenticated remote code execution on the underlying server.
products_versions: Custom Attributes Serializable module versions 0.1.0 to 0.4.0
vulnerabilities.remediation: Upgrade to a patched version of the affected product. Adobe has released fixes in the following versions: Adobe Commerce 2.4.9‑alpha2 and later, 2.4.8‑p2 and later, 2.4.7‑p7 and later, 2.4.6‑p12 and later, 2.4.5‑p14 and later, 2.4.4‑p15 and later; Adobe Commerce B2B 1.5.3‑alpha2 and later, 1.5.2‑p2 and later, 1.4.2‑p7 and later, 1.3.4‑p14 and later, 1.3.3‑p15 and later; Magento Open Source matching the same version matrix; Custom Attributes Serializable module 0.4.1 and later.
workarounds: Switch session storage to Redis or database instead of file‑based storage.
Restrict or disable unauthenticated access to the Commerce REST API.
Apply WAF rules that block suspicious serialized payloads.
Monitor and limit the size/structure of session data submitted via API.

vulnerabilities.title: Adobe Commerce Flaw CVE-2025-54236 Lets Hackers Take Over Customer Accounts
vulnerabilities.original_title: Adobe Commerce Flaw CVE-2025-54236 Lets Hackers Take Over Customer Accounts
vulnerabilities.content_snippet: Adobe has warned of a critical security flaw in its Commerce and Magento Open Source platforms that, if successfully exploited, could allow attackers to take control of customer accounts. The vulnerability, tracked as CVE-2025-54236 (aka SessionReaper), carries a CVSS score of 9.1 out of a maximum o...
vulnerabilities.summary: Improper input validation in Adobe Commerce and Magento Open Source allows attackers to hijack customer accounts (SessionReaper).
vulnerabilities.description: The vulnerability stems from insufficient validation of session‑related input parameters. An attacker can craft malicious requests that manipulate session handling logic, leading to the creation or takeover of a valid customer session. Once the session is compromised, the attacker gains full access to the victim's account, including personal data and purchase history, and can perform actions on behalf of the user.
vulnerabilities.remediation: Apply the security patch released by Adobe for CVE-2025-54236. Ensure all Adobe Commerce and Magento Open Source installations are updated to the latest supported version. Review and harden input validation for session‑related parameters.
workarounds: Implement a Web Application Firewall (WAF) rule to block malformed session parameters.
Enforce short session lifetimes and require re‑authentication for sensitive actions.
Monitor and invalidate suspicious sessions manually.

vulnerabilities.title: SIM-Swapper, Scattered Spider Hacker Gets 10 Years
vulnerabilities.original_title: SIM-Swapper, Scattered Spider Hacker Gets 10 Years
vulnerabilities.content_snippet: A 20-year-old Florida man at the center of a prolific cybercrime group known as “Scattered Spider” was sentenced to 10 years in federal prison today, and ordered to pay roughly $13 million in restitution to victims. Noah Michael Urban of Palm Coast, Fla. pleaded guilty in April 2025 to c...
vulnerabilities.summary: SIM‑swapping attacks enabled by phishing of telecom provider employees to gain control of victim phone numbers
vulnerabilities.description: Threat actors phish employees of mobile carriers to obtain internal credentials or convince them to issue SIM‑swap requests. Once the victim's phone number is ported to a device controlled by the attacker, they can intercept SMS‑based one‑time passwords (OTPs) and authentication codes, enabling further account takeover.
affected_products: Other US mobile carrier provisioning systems
vulnerabilities.remediation: Implement strict identity verification for SIM‑swap requests (e.g., in‑person verification, multi‑factor authentication for carrier staff), enforce carrier‑level PINs, monitor for unusual SIM change activity, and educate employees on social‑engineering resistance.
workarounds: Enable carrier‑provided PIN or password on the account
Use authentication methods that are not SMS‑based (e.g., hardware security keys, authenticator apps)
Set up alerts for SIM change or number porting events

vulnerabilities.title: SIM-Swapper, Scattered Spider Hacker Gets 10 Years
vulnerabilities.original_title: SIM-Swapper, Scattered Spider Hacker Gets 10 Years
vulnerabilities.content_snippet: A 20-year-old Florida man at the center of a prolific cybercrime group known as “Scattered Spider” was sentenced to 10 years in federal prison today, and ordered to pay roughly $13 million in restitution to victims. Noah Michael Urban of Palm Coast, Fla. pleaded guilty in April 2025 to c...
vulnerabilities.summary: SMS phishing (SMiShing) campaigns delivering fake Okta login pages to harvest credentials and OTPs
vulnerabilities.description: Attackers send SMS messages that appear to come from a trusted source (e.g., employer IT) containing a link to a counterfeit authentication page mimicking Okta. Victims enter their credentials and the OTP received via SMS, which the attacker captures and uses to log in to the real service.
vulnerabilities.remediation: Adopt phishing‑resistant MFA (e.g., FIDO2 security keys, push‑based authenticators), educate users to verify URLs, implement anti‑phishing email/SMS filters, and enforce conditional access policies that block logins from suspicious devices.
workarounds: Require hardware security keys for privileged accounts
Disable SMS as a second factor where possible
Deploy URL reputation and anti‑phishing tools

vulnerabilities.title: SIM-Swapper, Scattered Spider Hacker Gets 10 Years
vulnerabilities.original_title: SIM-Swapper, Scattered Spider Hacker Gets 10 Years
vulnerabilities.content_snippet: A 20-year-old Florida man at the center of a prolific cybercrime group known as “Scattered Spider” was sentenced to 10 years in federal prison today, and ordered to pay roughly $13 million in restitution to victims. Noah Michael Urban of Palm Coast, Fla. pleaded guilty in April 2025 to c...
vulnerabilities.summary: Insecure password‑reset process for court contractor allowing unauthorized password changes and email account compromise
vulnerabilities.description: A third‑party contractor handling password changes for a magistrate judge’s email account failed to verify the requestor’s identity. An attacker called the contractor, obtained a password‑reset, and accessed the judge’s sealed indictment email, demonstrating a lack of proper authentication and audit controls.
vulnerabilities.remediation: Implement multi‑factor authentication for all password‑reset requests, enforce strict identity verification (e.g., signed tickets, out‑of‑band verification), log and monitor all reset activities, and limit privileged access to sensitive accounts.
workarounds: Require manual approval by a second authorized individual for high‑risk accounts
Use dedicated, hardware‑based MFA for privileged email accounts

vulnerabilities.title: Juniper patched nine critical flaws in Junos Space
vulnerabilities.original_title: Juniper patched nine critical flaws in Junos Space
vulnerabilities.content_snippet: Juniper fixed nearly 220 flaws in Junos OS, Junos Space, and Security Director, including nine critical bugs in Junos Space. Juniper Networks released patches to address nearly 220 vulnerabilities in Junos OS, Junos Space, and Security Director, including nine critical flaws in Junos Space. One of t...
vulnerabilities.summary: Cross‑Site Scripting (XSS) in Juniper Junos Space allowing injection of malicious script tags that execute with administrative privileges.
vulnerabilities.description: Improper neutralization of user‑supplied input during web page generation permits an attacker to embed arbitrary <script> tags. When an authenticated administrator views the crafted page, the script runs in the context of the admin session, enabling arbitrary command execution, configuration changes, data exfiltration, or full system compromise.
affected_products: Juniper Networks Junos Space (all versions prior to 24.1R4)
vulnerabilities.remediation: Upgrade Junos Space to version 24.1R4 Patch V1 or later, which includes the fix for CVE-2025-59978.
workarounds: Apply strict input validation and output encoding on all user‑controlled fields.
Restrict administrative access to trusted networks and enforce multi‑factor authentication.
Disable unnecessary JavaScript features in the admin console if possible.
references: Juniper Security Advisory (Junos Space 24.1R4 Patch V1)

vulnerabilities.title: Juniper patched nine critical flaws in Junos Space
vulnerabilities.original_title: Juniper patched nine critical flaws in Junos Space
vulnerabilities.content_snippet: Juniper fixed nearly 220 flaws in Junos OS, Junos Space, and Security Director, including nine critical bugs in Junos Space. Juniper Networks released patches to address nearly 220 vulnerabilities in Junos OS, Junos Space, and Security Director, including nine critical flaws in Junos Space. One of t...
vulnerabilities.summary: Out‑of‑bounds write in GStreamer gst_parse_vorbis_setup_packet allowing memory corruption and potential code execution.
vulnerabilities.description: A missing bounds check in the gst_parse_vorbis_setup_packet function permits an attacker to supply a crafted Vorbis setup packet that overwrites up to 380 bytes of memory. This can lead to arbitrary code execution or denial‑of‑service in any application that parses untrusted media using the vulnerable GStreamer version.
vulnerabilities.remediation: Upgrade GStreamer to version 1.24.10 or later, which includes the fix for CVE-2024-47615.
workarounds: Avoid processing untrusted audio/video streams on systems running vulnerable GStreamer versions.
Deploy application‑level sandboxing for media parsing components.

vulnerabilities.title: Critical CVE-2025-5086 in DELMIA Apriso Actively Exploited, CISA Issues Warning
vulnerabilities.original_title: Critical CVE-2025-5086 in DELMIA Apriso Actively Exploited, CISA Issues Warning
vulnerabilities.content_snippet: The U.S. Cybersecurity and Infrastructure Security Agency (CISA) on Thursday added a critical security flaw impacting Dassault Systèmes DELMIA Apriso Manufacturing Operations Management (MOM) software to its Known Exploited Vulnerabilities (KEV) catalog, based on evidence of active exploitation. The...
vulnerabilities.summary: Critical remote code execution vulnerability in Dassault Systèmes DELMIA Apriso Manufacturing Operations Management software.
vulnerabilities.description: Improper input validation in the web service component of DELMIA Apriso allows unauthenticated attackers to craft specially crafted requests that trigger arbitrary code execution on the underlying server. Successful exploitation grants the attacker full control of the affected system, enabling data theft, manipulation of manufacturing processes, and disruption of operations.
products_versions: DELMIA Apriso versions prior to the vendor's September 2025 security update
vulnerabilities.remediation: Apply the security patch released by Dassault Systèmes for DELMIA Apriso. Upgrade to the latest supported version. Verify that the patch is successfully installed and that the vulnerable component is no longer present.
workarounds: Restrict network access to DELMIA Apriso servers to trusted IP ranges or VPN only.
Disable the vulnerable web service endpoint if not required.
Deploy a Web Application Firewall (WAF) with rules to block the malicious request patterns.

vulnerabilities.summary: Deserialization of untrusted data in Dassault Systèmes DELMIA Apriso allowing remote code execution.
vulnerabilities.description: A deserialization flaw exists in DELMIA Apriso versions released from 2020 through 2025. An attacker can send crafted serialized objects to the application, which are deserialized without proper validation, leading to arbitrary code execution on the affected system.
products_versions: Linux kernel versions prior to the fix (unspecified)
Android Runtime versions prior to the fix (unspecified)
vulnerabilities.remediation: Apply the security patch released by Dassault Systèmes for DELMIA Apriso. If a patch is not yet available, disable the vulnerable deserialization functionality and enforce strict input validation.
workarounds: Restrict network access to the DELMIA Apriso service to trusted IP ranges.
Deploy a web application firewall (WAF) with rules to block malicious serialized payloads.
Enable logging of deserialization errors and monitor for anomalous activity.

Android Runtime versions prior to the fix (unspecified)

workarounds: Apply kernel hardening configurations and limit local user privileges.

Android Runtime versions prior to the fix (unspecified)

vulnerabilities.title: CISA Orders Immediate Patch of Critical Sitecore Vulnerability Under Active Exploitation
vulnerabilities.original_title: CISA Orders Immediate Patch of Critical Sitecore Vulnerability Under Active Exploitation
vulnerabilities.content_snippet: Federal Civilian Executive Branch (FCEB) agencies are being advised to update their Sitecore instances by September 25, 2025, following the discovery of a security flaw that has come under active exploitation in the wild. The vulnerability, tracked as CVE-2025-53690, carries a CVSS score of 9.0 out ...
vulnerabilities.summary: Remote code execution vulnerability in Sitecore Experience Manager (XM) allowing attackers to execute arbitrary code on the server.
vulnerabilities.description: A flaw in the handling of specially crafted requests to Sitecore XM allows unauthenticated remote attackers to achieve code execution on the underlying web server. The vulnerability is exploitable over the network without any user interaction and impacts the confidentiality, integrity, and availability of the affected system. Active exploitation has been observed in the wild targeting federal civilian executive branch agencies.
vulnerabilities.remediation: Apply the official Sitecore security patch released by the vendor no later than September 25, 2025. Verify patch installation and restart the application services.
workarounds: Restrict inbound traffic to Sitecore servers using firewall rules or network segmentation.
Disable or block the vulnerable endpoint until the patch can be applied.
Deploy a Web Application Firewall (WAF) rule to filter malicious request patterns associated with the exploit.

vulnerabilities.title: Post-exploitation framework now also delivered via npm
vulnerabilities.original_title: Post-exploitation framework now also delivered via npm
vulnerabilities.content_snippet: Incident description The first version of the AdaptixC2 post-exploitation framework, which can be considered an alternative to the well-known Cobalt Strike, was made publicly available in early 2025. In spring of 2025, the framework was first observed being used for malicious means. In October 2025,...
vulnerabilities.summary: Malicious npm package https-proxy-utils uses post-install script to download and execute AdaptixC2 post‑exploitation framework on Windows, macOS, and Linux systems.
vulnerabilities.description: The package https-proxy-utils masquerades as a legitimate proxy utility. Its postinstall.js script executes on npm install, determines the host OS and architecture, downloads a payload from cloudcenter.top, and installs the AdaptixC2 agent. On Windows the agent is dropped as a DLL in C:\Windows\Tasks and loaded via DLL sideloading through a copied msdtc.exe. On macOS the agent is placed in ~/Library/LaunchAgents with a plist autorun entry. On Linux the binary is written to /tmp/.fonts-unix and made executable. Once installed, the AdaptixC2 framework provides remote command execution, file and process management, persistence, and network reconnaissance capabilities.
products_versions: All npm package versions that include the malicious https-proxy-utils package
Node.js versions that allow postinstall script execution (any recent version)
vulnerabilities.remediation: Remove the malicious package from all environments, delete the dropped files (DLL, executable, plist, etc.), and rotate any credentials that may have been accessed. Regenerate lockfiles and reinstall dependencies from trusted sources. Apply npm's built‑in security features (npm audit, npm ci with package‑lock verification) and enable two‑factor authentication for package publishing accounts.
workarounds: Block execution of postinstall scripts in npm by using the --ignore-scripts flag where feasible.
Restrict write permissions to system directories (e.g., C:\Windows\Tasks, /tmp, ~/Library/LaunchAgents) for non‑privileged users.
Monitor and alert on creation of files in these locations with unexpected hashes.

vulnerabilities.title: 200,000 Linux systems from Framework are shipped with signed UEFI components vulnerable to Secure Boot bypass
vulnerabilities.original_title: 200,000 Linux systems from Framework are shipped with signed UEFI components vulnerable to Secure Boot bypass
vulnerabilities.content_snippet: About 200K Linux systems from Framework shipped with signed UEFI components vulnerable to Secure Boot bypass, allowing bootkit installation and persistence. Firmware security company Eclypsium warns that about 200,000 Linux systems from Framework are shipped with signed UEFI components vulnerable to...
vulnerabilities.summary: Signed UEFI shell binaries shipped by Framework contain a diagnostic "mm" (memory modify) command that can overwrite the gSecurity2 security handler pointer, disabling Secure Boot signature verification and allowing persistent bootkit installation.
vulnerabilities.description: The Framework firmware includes a signed UEFI shell that provides a "mm" command for direct memory read/write. An attacker who can execute the shell (e.g., via physical access, pre‑boot environment, or compromised bootloader) can locate the global variable gSecurity2, which points to the Security Architectural Protocol used by LoadImage to verify module signatures. By using "mm" to write NULL or a no‑op function pointer to gSecurity2, the signature verification step is bypassed, effectively disabling Secure Boot while the UI still reports it as enabled. The attacker can then load unsigned bootkits or rootkits, drop a persistent startup.nsh script to repeat the bypass on each boot, and gain full pre‑OS control of the system.
affected_products: Framework laptops and tablets shipping with Framework firmware (various Intel 13th Gen and AMD Ryzen 7040 models)
UEFI shells signed with Framework's trusted certificates
products_versions: Framework devices with Intel 13th Gen firmware version prior to 3.08
Framework devices with AMD Ryzen 7040 firmware version prior to 3.16
Other Framework models awaiting firmware updates
vulnerabilities.remediation: Apply firmware updates released by Framework that remove the "mm" command or patch the gSecurity2 handling. Update the UEFI revocation database (DBX) to blacklist the vulnerable signed shells. Re‑sign custom Secure Boot keys if used, enable BIOS passwords, and enforce strict firmware signing policies. Verify that the firmware version on the device matches the fixed version (e.g., Intel 13th Gen 3.08, Ryzen 7040 3.16).
workarounds: Revoke the vulnerable Framework signing certificate via DBX before a firmware fix is available.
Disable execution of UEFI shells in the firmware configuration if possible.
Set a BIOS/UEFI password to restrict access to the pre‑boot environment.
references: Eclypsium research report on Framework UEFI shell vulnerability (2025)

vulnerabilities.title: Maverick: a new banking Trojan abusing WhatsApp in a mass-scale distribution
vulnerabilities.original_title: Maverick: a new banking Trojan abusing WhatsApp in a mass-scale distribution
vulnerabilities.content_snippet: A malware campaign was recently detected in Brazil, distributing a malicious LNK file using WhatsApp. It targets mainly Brazilians and uses Portuguese-named URLs. To evade detection, the command-and-control (C2) server verifies each download to ensure it originates from the malware itself. The whole...
vulnerabilities.summary: Remote code execution via malicious .LNK file delivered through WhatsApp that launches PowerShell with encoded commands
vulnerabilities.description: The campaign distributes a ZIP archive containing a malicious .LNK shortcut via WhatsApp messages. The shortcut executes cmd.exe with arguments that launch a PowerShell script. The script contacts a C2 server, downloads encrypted .NET assemblies and Donut‑generated shellcode, and loads them entirely in memory, achieving a fileless execution. No signature verification or sandbox evasion is performed, allowing the attacker to gain full control of the victim system, install persistence, capture credentials, and perform remote UI manipulation.
vulnerabilities.remediation: Block execution of .LNK files from untrusted sources; enforce strict application whitelisting (e.g., AppLocker, Windows Defender Application Control); disable PowerShell script execution for non‑administrative users; monitor and restrict outbound traffic to known malicious domains (sorvetenopote.com, casadecampoamazonas.com); apply latest Windows updates and .NET runtime patches; educate users about suspicious WhatsApp messages and ZIP attachments.
workarounds: Configure Group Policy to prevent shortcut (.lnk) execution from email or messaging clients.
Restrict PowerShell to Constrained Language Mode for standard users.
Deploy network‑level URL filtering to block the malicious C2 domains.

vulnerabilities.title: Attackers exploit valid logins in SonicWall SSL VPN compromise
vulnerabilities.original_title: Attackers exploit valid logins in SonicWall SSL VPN compromise
vulnerabilities.content_snippet: Huntress warns of widespread SonicWall SSL VPN breaches, with attackers using valid credentials to access multiple accounts rapidly. Cybersecurity firm Huntress warned of a widespread compromise of SonicWall SSL VPNs, with threat actors using valid credentials to access multiple customer accounts ra...
vulnerabilities.summary: Remote code execution vulnerability in SonicWall SSL VPN allowing attackers to execute arbitrary code and deploy ransomware.
vulnerabilities.description: The vulnerability allows unauthenticated remote attackers to send specially crafted packets to the SSL VPN service, leading to execution of arbitrary code with root privileges. Exploitation enables the deployment of ransomware such as Akira, lateral movement, and data exfiltration. The flaw was leveraged in a campaign observed in mid‑2025 targeting multiple organizations.
affected_products: SonicWall SSL VPN appliances (various models and firmware versions prior to vendor patch)
products_versions: SonicWall SSL VPN appliances (pre‑patch for CVE‑2024‑40766)
SonicWall firewalls with MySonicWall cloud backup enabled
vulnerabilities.remediation: Apply the vendor‑provided firmware update that patches CVE‑2024‑40766. After patching, reset all VPN credentials, enforce multi‑factor authentication, and review VPN access policies.
workarounds: Restrict VPN access to known IP ranges via firewall ACLs
Disable SSL VPN service if not required
Enforce strong, unique passwords and enable MFA

vulnerabilities.title: Attackers exploit valid logins in SonicWall SSL VPN compromise
vulnerabilities.original_title: Attackers exploit valid logins in SonicWall SSL VPN compromise
vulnerabilities.content_snippet: Huntress warns of widespread SonicWall SSL VPN breaches, with attackers using valid credentials to access multiple accounts rapidly. Cybersecurity firm Huntress warned of a widespread compromise of SonicWall SSL VPNs, with threat actors using valid credentials to access multiple customer accounts ra...
vulnerabilities.summary: Exposure of encrypted SonicWall firewall backup files via MySonicWall cloud service, allowing attackers to obtain credential material.
vulnerabilities.description: Attackers accessed the cloud backup repository and downloaded encrypted preference files containing VPN credentials, IPSec pre‑shared keys, and TOTP bindings. Although encrypted, the files can be brute‑forced or leveraged if the encryption key is weak, facilitating subsequent credential reuse across compromised VPN devices.
affected_products: SonicWall firewalls with MySonicWall cloud backup enabled
products_versions: SonicWall SSL VPN appliances (pre‑patch for CVE‑2024‑40766)
SonicWall firewalls with MySonicWall cloud backup enabled
vulnerabilities.remediation: Disable MySonicWall cloud backup for all firewalls, rotate all VPN credentials, regenerate IPSec pre‑shared keys, re‑enroll TOTP tokens, and import fresh preference files during a maintenance window. Verify that no backup files remain in the cloud service.
workarounds: Temporarily disable cloud backup until a secure implementation is verified
Implement strict IAM controls on MySonicWall accounts
Monitor for anomalous download activity from the backup service

vulnerabilities.title: Google warns of Brickstorm backdoor targeting U.S. legal and tech sectors
vulnerabilities.original_title: Google warns of Brickstorm backdoor targeting U.S. legal and tech sectors
vulnerabilities.content_snippet: China-linked actors used Brickstorm malware to spy on U.S. tech and legal firms, stealing data undetected for over a year, Google warns. Google Threat Intelligence Group (GTIG) observed the use of the Go-based backdoor BRICKSTORM to maintain persistence in U.S. organizations since March 2025. Target...
vulnerabilities.summary: Brickstorm (BRICKSTORM) Go-based backdoor with WebSocket C2, stealth persistence, credential theft, and lateral movement capabilities
vulnerabilities.description: BRICKSTORM is a Go‑based backdoor that establishes persistence on Linux/BSD appliances via edited startup scripts and enabled SSH (VAMI). It communicates with its C2 over WebSockets, uses delayed beaconing, mimics legitimate processes, and rotates domains through Cloudflare, Heroku, and dynamic DNS. The malware can act as a web server, manipulate the file system, upload/download files, execute arbitrary shell commands, and provide a SOCKS proxy for internal network traversal. A companion in‑memory Java servlet filter (BRICKSTEAL) is deployed on VMware vCenter to intercept HTTP Basic authentication and harvest high‑privilege credentials, which are then used to clone Windows domain controllers and extract NTDS.dit. Collected credentials are leveraged to access secret stores (e.g., Delinea Secret Server) and to exfiltrate email data via Microsoft Entra ID applications with mail.read or full_access_as_app scopes. After data collection, the actors remove the backdoor and rotate C2 infrastructure to evade forensic analysis.
affected_products: Microsoft Entra ID (Azure AD) Enterprise Applications
affected_companies: Various Linux and BSD distribution vendors
vendors: Various Linux and BSD distribution vendors
vulnerabilities.remediation: 1. Isolate and fully clean compromised systems; reinstall OS where feasible. 2. Rotate all privileged credentials, especially service accounts, VMware vCenter/ESXi accounts, and Azure AD application secrets. 3. Disable unnecessary SSH/VAMI access on appliances and enforce strong authentication (MFA, key‑based). 4. Apply latest OS and application patches, particularly for any disclosed zero‑day exploits. 5. Block outbound WebSocket traffic to unknown/unauthorized domains and monitor Cloudflare/Heroku/DNS traffic patterns. 6. Deploy endpoint detection and response (EDR) solutions with behavior‑based detection for WebSocket beaconing and unusual process spawning. 7. Use Mandiant’s published scanner script to hunt for BRICKSTORM artifacts.
workarounds: Restrict outbound network traffic to known C2 endpoints only.
Enforce network segmentation separating critical infrastructure (vCenter, AD) from internet‑facing services.
Disable or tightly control the use of Java servlet filters on web applications.
references: Google Threat Intelligence Group (GTIG) report, April 2024
Mandiant scanner script for BRICKSTORM (GitHub/official release)

vulnerabilities.title: ShadowV2 Botnet Exploits Misconfigured AWS Docker Containers for DDoS-for-Hire Service
vulnerabilities.original_title: ShadowV2 Botnet Exploits Misconfigured AWS Docker Containers for DDoS-for-Hire Service
vulnerabilities.content_snippet: Cybersecurity researchers have disclosed details of a new botnet that customers can rent access to conduct distributed denial-of-service (DDoS) attacks against targets of interest. The ShadowV2 botnet, according to Darktrace, predominantly targets misconfigured Docker containers on Amazon Web Servic...
vulnerabilities.summary: Exploitation of misconfigured Docker daemon on AWS EC2 instances allowing unauthorized remote code execution to deploy the ShadowV2 botnet for DDoS‑for‑Hire services.
vulnerabilities.description:
The ShadowV2 botnet targets AWS cloud servers where Docker is deployed with default or overly permissive configurations (e.g., Docker daemon listening on 0.0.0.0 without TLS, exposed Docker socket via bind mounts, or IAM roles granting unrestricted EC2/ECS access). Attackers can reach the Docker API over the public internet, pull a malicious Go‑based payload, and launch containers that become DDoS attack nodes. The compromised containers are used to provide a rentable DDoS‑for‑Hire service, amplifying the impact across multiple victim organizations.

Key technical points:
- No authentication on Docker daemon or exposed Docker socket enables unauthenticated remote code execution.
- The payload is a Go binary that installs a persistence mechanism (systemd service or Docker restart policy) and connects to C2 for command execution.
- Once inside the AWS VPC, the botnet can enumerate other EC2 instances, exploit IAM role trust relationships, and spread laterally.
- The botnet leverages AWS bandwidth and elasticity to sustain high‑volume DDoS attacks.
products_versions: AWS EC2 instances with exposed Docker daemon
vulnerabilities.remediation:
1. Disable unauthenticated remote access to the Docker daemon. Bind the Docker socket to localhost or protect it with TLS mutual authentication.
2. Enforce least‑privilege IAM policies; avoid attaching broad EC2/ECS permissions to instance roles.
3. Place Docker hosts in private subnets and restrict inbound traffic to required ports only.
4. Enable AWS GuardDuty and VPC Flow Logs to detect anomalous container activity.
5. Regularly audit Docker daemon configuration (daemon.json) and ensure the Docker socket is not mounted into containers.
6. Apply the latest Docker Engine security patches and enable Docker Content Trust.
7. Rotate credentials and rotate any exposed access keys immediately.
workarounds: Use SSH tunnels or VPNs to access Docker daemons instead of exposing them publicly.
Run Docker with the "--userland-proxy=false" flag and enforce firewall rules that block port 2375/2376 from the internet.

vulnerabilities.title: Securing the Future of AI
vulnerabilities.original_title: Securing the Future of AI
vulnerabilities.content_snippet: Artificial intelligence (AI) is advancing at a breathtaking pace. Once the domain of research labs and early adopters, it is now woven into daily workflows, customer interactions and business strategies. To help drive innovation and gain a competitive advantage, organizations across industries are r...
vulnerabilities.summary: Prompt injection vulnerability in AI models allowing attackers to manipulate model outputs via crafted inputs.
vulnerabilities.description: Attackers craft malicious prompts that are fed to AI systems (e.g., via APIs, chat interfaces) causing the model to execute unintended instructions, disclose sensitive data, or produce harmful content. The vulnerability stems from insufficient input validation and lack of prompt sanitization in AI pipelines.
vulnerabilities.remediation: Implement robust prompt sanitization, enforce strict input validation, employ model scanning for injection patterns, and apply runtime monitoring to detect anomalous responses.
workarounds: Restrict user-supplied prompts to predefined templates
Deploy a sandboxed execution environment for AI responses

vulnerabilities.summary: Data poisoning attacks against AI training pipelines that inject malicious data to corrupt model behavior.
vulnerabilities.description: Adversaries inject crafted samples into training data repositories, causing the resulting AI model to behave maliciously or produce biased outputs. The attack exploits trust in external data sources and insufficient data provenance checks.
vulnerabilities.remediation: Adopt data provenance verification, perform integrity checks on training data, use model scanning for backdoor signatures, and employ AI red teaming to test model robustness.
workarounds: Isolate training data pipelines from untrusted sources
Apply statistical anomaly detection on incoming data
