vulnerabilities.description: Attackers craft malicious instructions for AI agents that are built with low-code/no-code tools, causing the agents to execute unintended operations, exfiltrate data, or disrupt workflows. The vulnerability arises from inadequate policy enforcement and lack of runtime safeguards.
vulnerabilities.remediation: Enforce AI agent posture management policies, apply runtime security monitoring, restrict agent capabilities through least‑privilege configurations, and conduct regular AI red‑team exercises.
workarounds: Manually review agent instruction sets before deployment
Limit network access for agents to only required endpoints

vulnerabilities.title: Apple Backports Fix for CVE-2025-43300 Exploited in Sophisticated Spyware Attack
vulnerabilities.original_title: Apple Backports Fix for CVE-2025-43300 Exploited in Sophisticated Spyware Attack
vulnerabilities.content_snippet: Apple on Monday backported fixes for a recently patched security flaw that has been actively exploited in the wild. The vulnerability in question is CVE-2025-43300 (CVSS score: 8.8), an out-of-bounds write issue in the ImageIO component that could result in memory corruption when processing a malici...
vulnerabilities.summary: Out-of-bounds write in Apple ImageIO component leading to memory corruption when processing crafted image files.
vulnerabilities.description: The ImageIO component fails to properly validate image metadata lengths, allowing an attacker to craft a malicious image that triggers an out-of-bounds write. This results in memory corruption that can be leveraged for arbitrary code execution in the context of the vulnerable process. The vulnerability is exploitable when a victim opens or previews a malicious image file, which can be delivered via email, web, or other file‑transfer mechanisms.
vulnerabilities.remediation: Apply the Apple security update that backports the fix for CVE-2025-43300. Update all Apple devices to the latest OS version released after 2025-09-16.
workarounds: Avoid opening image files from untrusted sources.
Disable automatic image preview in email and web browsers.
Use sandboxing or content‑filtering solutions that block execution of untrusted image files.

vulnerabilities.title: Samsung Fixes Critical Zero-Day CVE-2025-21043 Exploited in Android Attacks
vulnerabilities.original_title: Samsung Fixes Critical Zero-Day CVE-2025-21043 Exploited in Android Attacks
vulnerabilities.content_snippet: Samsung has released its monthly security updates for Android, including a fix for a security vulnerability that it said has been exploited in zero-day attacks. The vulnerability, CVE-2025-21043 (CVSS score: 8.8), concerns an out-of-bounds write that could result in arbitrary code execution. "Out-of...
vulnerabilities.summary: Out-of-bounds write in libimagecodec.quram.so allows remote attackers to execute arbitrary code on Samsung Android devices.
vulnerabilities.description: The vulnerability resides in the libimagecodec.quram.so library used for image decoding on Samsung Android firmware. An out-of-bounds write condition can be triggered by supplying a crafted image file, leading to memory corruption and arbitrary code execution with the privileges of the affected process. The flaw is exploitable remotely without user interaction, and it has been observed in the wild as a zero‑day attack.
products_versions: Samsung Android firmware prior to SMR Sep-2025 Release 1
vulnerabilities.remediation: Update the device to the September 2025 Security Maintenance Release (SMR Sep-2025 Release 1) which patches libimagecodec.quram.so.
workarounds: Avoid opening image files from untrusted sources until the patch is applied.
Disable or restrict applications that use the vulnerable library, if possible.

vulnerabilities.title: AsyncRAT Exploits ConnectWise ScreenConnect to Steal Credentials and Crypto
vulnerabilities.original_title: AsyncRAT Exploits ConnectWise ScreenConnect to Steal Credentials and Crypto
vulnerabilities.content_snippet: Cybersecurity researchers have disclosed details of a new campaign that leverages ConnectWise ScreenConnect, a legitimate Remote Monitoring and Management (RMM) software, to deliver a fleshless loader that drops a remote access trojan (RAT) called AsyncRAT to steal sensitive data from compromised ho...
vulnerabilities.summary: Abuse of ConnectWise ScreenConnect RMM software to deliver a malicious VBScript loader that installs AsyncRAT on compromised hosts.
vulnerabilities.description: Threat actors compromise ConnectWise ScreenConnect instances (either via stolen credentials or exploitation of unpatched vulnerabilities) and use the legitimate remote access capabilities to execute a multi‑stage VBScript payload. The script acts as a loader that fetches and drops AsyncRAT, a remote access trojan capable of credential harvesting, keylogging, screenshot capture, and cryptocurrency theft. Because the delivery chain leverages trusted RMM software, the activity can bypass many traditional security controls and appear as legitimate remote sessions.
vulnerabilities.remediation: Update ConnectWise ScreenConnect to the latest patched version; enforce multi‑factor authentication for all RMM accounts; restrict RMM access to dedicated admin workstations; disable or tightly control VBScript execution on endpoints; implement application whitelisting; monitor and alert on unusual remote sessions and script execution.
workarounds: Block outbound traffic to known AsyncRAT C2 domains/IPs at the firewall.
Segment RMM tools onto a separate VLAN with strict egress filtering.
Enforce least‑privilege service accounts for ScreenConnect.

vulnerabilities.title: Microsoft Patch Tuesday, September 2025 Edition
vulnerabilities.original_title: Microsoft Patch Tuesday, September 2025 Edition
vulnerabilities.content_snippet: Microsoft Corp. today issued security updates to fix more than 80 vulnerabilities in its Windows operating systems and software. There are no known “zero-day” or actively exploited vulnerabilities in this month’s bundle from Redmond, which nevertheless includes patches for 13 flaws...
vulnerabilities.summary: Improper authentication in Windows NTLM allows an authorized attacker to elevate privileges over a network.
vulnerabilities.description: An attacker who can send specially crafted NTLM authentication packets to a vulnerable Windows host can bypass normal authentication checks and gain SYSTEM-level privileges. The flaw appears to require the attacker to have some form of authorized NTLM hash or credential, but the crafted packets enable privilege escalation without additional user interaction.
affected_products: All supported Windows client and server operating systems
products_versions: All supported Windows client and server OS versions (NTLM, SMB client, NTFS)
Android OS versions prior to September 2025 patches
iOS 18.6.2 and earlier, iPadOS 18.6.2/17.7.10, macOS Sequoia 15.6.1, macOS Sonoma 14.7.8, macOS Ventura 13.7.8
WhatsApp versions prior to September 2025 update
vulnerabilities.remediation: Install the September 2025 Patch Tuesday update from Microsoft that addresses CVE-2025-54918.
workarounds: Disable NTLM authentication where possible and enforce Kerberos.
Enforce SMB signing and use network segmentation to limit exposure of NTLM services.
Monitor for anomalous NTLM authentication attempts.

Disable SMBv1 if not required.

There are no known “zero-day” or actively exploited vulnerabilities in this month’s bundle from Redmond, which nevertheless includes patches for 13 flaws...
vulnerabilities.summary: Privilege escalation vulnerability in Windows SMB client allowing replay attacks.
vulnerabilities.description: An attacker with network access can capture legitimate SMB authentication traffic and replay it against a target host, resulting in privilege escalation and potential code execution on the victim system. The vulnerability was publicly disclosed prior to the September 2025 patch cycle.
affected_products: Microsoft Windows SMB client (all supported Windows versions)
vulnerabilities.remediation: Apply the September 2025 security update that patches CVE-2025-55234. Ensure SMB signing is enforced and consider disabling SMBv1.
workarounds: Enable SMB signing on both client and server.
Restrict SMB traffic to trusted networks.
Monitor for repeated SMB authentication attempts from the same source.
references: Krebsonsecurity article "Microsoft Patch Tuesday, September 2025 Edition"

vulnerabilities.title: Microsoft Patch Tuesday, September 2025 Edition
vulnerabilities.original_title: Microsoft Patch Tuesday, September 2025 Edition
vulnerabilities.content_snippet: Microsoft Corp. today issued security updates to fix more than 80 vulnerabilities in its Windows operating systems and software. There are no known “zero-day” or actively exploited vulnerabilities in this month’s bundle from Redmond, which nevertheless includes patches for 13 flaws...
vulnerabilities.summary: Remote code execution vulnerability in Windows NTFS driver.
vulnerabilities.description: The vulnerability can be triggered by a specially crafted file that, when opened or executed by a user, leads to arbitrary code execution in the context of the current user. Exploitation typically occurs via social engineering (malicious attachment or download).
affected_products: Microsoft Windows NTFS file system (all supported Windows versions)
vulnerabilities.remediation: Install the September 2025 cumulative update that includes the fix for CVE-2025-54916. Keep user education programs up to date to reduce the likelihood of opening malicious files.
workarounds: Block execution of files from untrusted sources using AppLocker or Windows Defender Application Control.
Enable Controlled Folder Access to limit where files can be written and executed.
references: Krebsonsecurity article "Microsoft Patch Tuesday, September 2025 Edition"

vulnerabilities.title: CISA sounds alarm over TP-Link wireless routers under attack
vulnerabilities.original_title: CISA sounds alarm over TP-Link wireless routers under attack
vulnerabilities.content_snippet: Plus: Google clears up Gmail concerns, NSA drops SBOM bomb, Texas sues PowerSchool, and more Infosec in brief The US Cybersecurity and Infrastructure Security Agency (CISA) has said two flaws in routers made by Chinese networking biz TP-Link are under active attack and need to be fixed – but there's...
vulnerabilities.summary: Unauthenticated remote code execution vulnerability in TP-Link wireless routers allowing attackers to execute arbitrary commands via the web management interface.
vulnerabilities.description: The router's embedded web server fails to properly validate input parameters in the HTTP GET/POST handling code. An attacker can craft a malicious request that triggers a buffer overflow or command injection, leading to full system compromise without authentication. The vulnerability is being actively exploited in the wild, as reported by CISA.
products_versions: Various models of TP-Link wireless routers released before 2025
vulnerabilities.remediation: Update the router firmware to the latest version released by TP-Link that patches the vulnerable component. If a patch is not yet available, disable remote management (WAN access to the web UI) and restrict access to trusted LAN hosts only.
workarounds: Disable WAN access to the router's web management interface.
Place the router behind a firewall that blocks inbound traffic to ports 80/443 from the internet.
Change default administrative credentials and use strong, unique passwords.

vulnerabilities.title: CISA sounds alarm over TP-Link wireless routers under attack
vulnerabilities.original_title: CISA sounds alarm over TP-Link wireless routers under attack
vulnerabilities.content_snippet: Plus: Google clears up Gmail concerns, NSA drops SBOM bomb, Texas sues PowerSchool, and more Infosec in brief The US Cybersecurity and Infrastructure Security Agency (CISA) has said two flaws in routers made by Chinese networking biz TP-Link are under active attack and need to be fixed – but there's...
vulnerabilities.summary: Authentication bypass vulnerability in TP-Link routers that allows attackers to obtain administrative access via crafted HTTP requests.
vulnerabilities.description: Improper session handling in the router's authentication module permits an attacker to bypass login checks by sending a specially crafted HTTP header. This grants administrative privileges without valid credentials. CISA reports active exploitation of this flaw.
products_versions: Various models of TP-Link wireless routers released before 2025
vulnerabilities.remediation: Apply the firmware update released by TP-Link that corrects the authentication logic. Until a patch is available, restrict access to the management interface to internal networks only and enforce strong passwords.
workarounds: Block inbound traffic to the router's management ports from untrusted networks.
Enable two-factor authentication if supported.

vulnerabilities.title: CISA sounds alarm over TP-Link wireless routers under attack
vulnerabilities.original_title: CISA sounds alarm over TP-Link wireless routers under attack
vulnerabilities.content_snippet: Plus: Google clears up Gmail concerns, NSA drops SBOM bomb, Texas sues PowerSchool, and more Infosec in brief The US Cybersecurity and Infrastructure Security Agency (CISA) has said two flaws in routers made by Chinese networking biz TP-Link are under active attack and need to be fixed – but there's...
vulnerabilities.summary: Denial-of-service vulnerability in TP-Link router firmware caused by malformed DHCP packets leading to device reboot.
vulnerabilities.description: The router's DHCP client does not properly validate packet lengths, allowing an attacker on the same LAN to send crafted DHCP requests that cause a null-pointer dereference, resulting in a crash and reboot of the device.
products_versions: Various models of TP-Link wireless routers released before 2025
vulnerabilities.remediation: Install the latest firmware from TP-Link that includes input validation for DHCP processing. As a temporary measure, enable DHCP snooping on upstream switches to filter malformed packets.
workarounds: Isolate the router on a separate VLAN and limit LAN access.
Monitor DHCP traffic for anomalies.

vulnerabilities.title: Popular Android VPN apps found to have security flaws and China links
vulnerabilities.original_title: Popular Android VPN apps found to have security flaws and China links
vulnerabilities.content_snippet: People use VPNs for different security and privacy reasons, to access content anonymously, or to bypass content controls and age verification by pretending to be in different places. But not all VPNs are created equal. A recent report has revealed that many of them might allow others to sniff your d...
vulnerabilities.summary: Hard‑coded Shadowsocks password used by multiple Android VPN apps allows any network eavesdropper to decrypt VPN traffic.
vulnerabilities.description: The examined Android VPN applications embed a static, hard‑coded password for the Shadowsocks proxy component. Shadowsocks is used as the transport layer for the VPN tunnel. Because the password is the same for all installations, any passive network observer positioned between the client and the VPN server can derive the symmetric key, decrypt the traffic, and read all user data transmitted through the VPN. This defeats the primary security purpose of the VPN and enables large‑scale credential harvesting.
affected_companies: Qihoo 360 (parent company linked to several providers)
vendors: Qihoo 360 (parent company linked to several providers)
vulnerabilities.remediation: Remove hard‑coded credentials. Implement a secure key‑exchange mechanism (e.g., TLS with certificate validation) for Shadowsocks or replace Shadowsocks with a standard, authenticated VPN protocol (OpenVPN, WireGuard, IKEv2). Rotate keys regularly and enforce per‑install unique secrets. Conduct a full code audit before release.
workarounds: Do not use VPN apps that rely on Shadowsocks for encryption.
Restrict network traffic to known VPN server IPs and block outbound Shadowsocks connections.
Use a reputable VPN service that employs modern TLS‑based protocols.

vulnerabilities.title: Popular Android VPN apps found to have security flaws and China links
vulnerabilities.original_title: Popular Android VPN apps found to have security flaws and China links
vulnerabilities.content_snippet: People use VPNs for different security and privacy reasons, to access content anonymously, or to bypass content controls and age verification by pretending to be in different places. But not all VPNs are created equal. A recent report has revealed that many of them might allow others to sniff your d...
vulnerabilities.summary: Blind in‑path/on‑path attack vulnerability in several Android VPN apps permits traffic manipulation when attacker shares the same network.
vulnerabilities.description: The VPN clients do not properly validate the integrity of the encrypted tunnel and accept unauthenticated packets from the network. An attacker on the same Wi‑Fi or cellular network can inject, modify, or drop packets (blind in‑path/on‑path attack), leading to traffic hijacking, credential theft, or denial of service. The flaw is exacerbated by the use of deprecated ciphers and lack of certificate pinning.
affected_products: All other apps sharing the same vulnerable networking stack
affected_companies: Qihoo 360 (parent company linked to several providers)
vendors: Qihoo 360 (parent company linked to several providers)
vulnerabilities.remediation: Implement authenticated encryption with integrity protection (AEAD) for all tunnel traffic. Use up‑to‑date cipher suites (e.g., AES‑GCM, ChaCha20‑Poly1305) and enforce strict certificate validation. Add replay protection and sequence number checks.
workarounds: Avoid using the affected VPN apps on untrusted networks (public Wi‑Fi).
Employ a secondary VPN layer (e.g., system‑wide VPN) that uses strong TLS.
Monitor for unexpected outbound connections to unknown IPs.

vulnerabilities.title: CISA Adds TP-Link and WhatsApp Flaws to KEV Catalog Amid Active Exploitation
vulnerabilities.original_title: CISA Adds TP-Link and WhatsApp Flaws to KEV Catalog Amid Active Exploitation
vulnerabilities.content_snippet: The U.S. Cybersecurity and Infrastructure Security Agency (CISA) on Tuesday added a high-severity security flaw impacting TP-Link TL-WA855RE Wi-Fi Ranger Extender products to its Known Exploited Vulnerabilities (KEV) catalog, citing evidence of active exploitation. The vulnerability, CVE-2020-24363 ...
vulnerabilities.summary: Missing authentication vulnerability in TP-Link TL-WA855RE Wi‑Fi Ranger Extender allowing unauthenticated attackers to gain administrative access.
vulnerabilities.description: The TL-WA855RE firmware fails to enforce authentication on certain management interfaces. An attacker who can reach the device over the network can send crafted HTTP requests to execute privileged commands, modify configuration, and potentially pivot to other devices on the LAN. The flaw is exploitable without credentials and does not require user interaction.
products_versions: TP-Link TL-WA855RE (all firmware versions prior to the security patch)
vulnerabilities.remediation: Update the device firmware to the version released by TP‑Link that includes authentication enforcement. If a patch is not yet available, disable remote management interfaces and restrict access to the extender to trusted LAN segments only.
workarounds: Disable remote web management in the extender's settings.
Place the extender behind a firewall and restrict inbound traffic to trusted IPs.
Change default administrative credentials and use strong, unique passwords.

vulnerabilities.title: SIM-Swapper, Scattered Spider Hacker Gets 10 Years
vulnerabilities.original_title: SIM-Swapper, Scattered Spider Hacker Gets 10 Years
vulnerabilities.content_snippet: A 20-year-old Florida man at the center of a prolific cybercrime group known as “Scattered Spider” was sentenced to 10 years in federal prison today, and ordered to pay roughly $13 million in restitution to victims. Noah Michael Urban of Palm Coast, Fla. pleaded guilty in April 2025 to c...
vulnerabilities.summary: SIM swapping attacks leveraging compromised carrier employee credentials to hijack victim phone numbers
vulnerabilities.description: Threat actors obtain internal credentials of mobile carrier employees (through phishing or credential reuse) and use them to request SIM porting for target phone numbers. Once the SIM is transferred, attackers gain control of SMS and voice channels, allowing them to intercept one-time passwords, perform account takeover, and authorize fraudulent transactions.
vulnerabilities.remediation: Mobile carriers should enforce strict multi‑factor authentication for internal tools, implement role‑based access controls, require a carrier‑specific PIN for SIM change requests, and monitor for anomalous port‑out activity. Victims should enable carrier‑level account PINs, use hardware security keys for MFA, and monitor for unexpected SIM changes.
workarounds: Set a unique PIN or password on carrier accounts and never share it.
Use authenticator apps or hardware tokens instead of SMS‑based MFA.
Enroll in carrier alerts for SIM swaps or number changes.

vulnerabilities.title: SIM-Swapper, Scattered Spider Hacker Gets 10 Years
vulnerabilities.original_title: SIM-Swapper, Scattered Spider Hacker Gets 10 Years
vulnerabilities.content_snippet: A 20-year-old Florida man at the center of a prolific cybercrime group known as “Scattered Spider” was sentenced to 10 years in federal prison today, and ordered to pay roughly $13 million in restitution to victims. Noah Michael Urban of Palm Coast, Fla. pleaded guilty in April 2025 to c...
vulnerabilities.summary: SMS phishing (SMiShing) using cloned Okta authentication pages to harvest credentials and OTPs
vulnerabilities.description: Adversaries send targeted SMS messages that appear to originate from a trusted source (e.g., IT department) containing a malicious link to a phishing site that mimics the victim's Okta login page. Victims enter their credentials and the SMS‑delivered one‑time passcode, which are captured by the attacker, enabling account takeover and further lateral movement.
affected_products: Any service relying on SMS OTP
vulnerabilities.remediation: Implement phishing‑resistant MFA (e.g., FIDO2 hardware keys), educate users to verify URLs, enforce domain‑based message authentication (DMARC, DKIM, SPF) for corporate communications, and deploy anti‑phishing email/SMS gateways. Organizations should also monitor for anomalous login attempts and enforce conditional access policies.
workarounds: Require users to confirm login attempts via a secondary channel (e.g., push notification).
Deploy URL rewriting or safe browsing tools that block known phishing domains.

vulnerabilities.title: GodRAT – New RAT targeting financial institutions
vulnerabilities.original_title: GodRAT – New RAT targeting financial institutions
vulnerabilities.content_snippet: Summary In September 2024, we detected malicious activity targeting financial (trading and brokerage) firms through the distribution of malicious .scr (screen saver) files disguised as financial documents via Skype messenger. The threat actor deployed a newly identified Remote Access Trojan (RAT) na...
vulnerabilities.summary: Remote execution of malicious .scr/.pif files delivered via Skype messenger
vulnerabilities.description: Attackers distribute malicious screen‑saver (.scr) and program‑information (.pif) files masquerading as financial documents through Skype. When a victim opens the file, a custom loader injects XOR‑decoded shellcode into its own process, which contacts a hard‑coded C2 server, downloads a second‑stage UPX‑packed GodRAT DLL and executes it, providing full remote access to the system.
affected_companies: Kaspersky (due to detection of AsyncRAT signatures)
vendors: Kaspersky (due to detection of AsyncRAT signatures)
products_versions: Valve.exe (any version signed with the expired 2015‑2018 certificate)
Google Chrome (any version storing passwords in Login Data)
Microsoft Edge (any version storing passwords in Login Data)
vulnerabilities.remediation: Block execution of .scr and .pif files via application control policies; disable or restrict file transfers in Skype; enforce strict execution policies (AppLocker, Windows Defender Application Control); monitor for unknown processes spawning from legitimate binaries such as curl.exe or cmd.exe.
workarounds: Configure Windows Defender SmartScreen to block unknown screen‑saver files
Educate users not to open unsolicited files received via instant messaging
references: Securelist article "GodRAT – New RAT targeting financial institutions" (2025-08-19)
MITRE ATT&CK T1204.002 – User Execution: Malicious File

vulnerabilities.title: GodRAT – New RAT targeting financial institutions
vulnerabilities.original_title: GodRAT – New RAT targeting financial institutions
vulnerabilities.content_snippet: Summary In September 2024, we detected malicious activity targeting financial (trading and brokerage) firms through the distribution of malicious .scr (screen saver) files disguised as financial documents via Skype messenger. The threat actor deployed a newly identified Remote Access Trojan (RAT) na...
vulnerabilities.summary: Abuse of an expired code‑signing certificate to load malicious DLL (SDL2.dll) via legitimate Valve.exe
vulnerabilities.description: The loader DLL (SDL2.dll) is signed with an expired DigiCert code‑signing certificate, allowing it to appear legitimate when loaded by the signed Valve.exe. This technique bypasses basic trust checks and enables the injection of image‑based shellcode that later downloads GodRAT.
affected_companies: Kaspersky (due to detection of AsyncRAT signatures)
vendors: Kaspersky (due to detection of AsyncRAT signatures)
products_versions: Valve.exe (any version signed with the expired 2015‑2018 certificate)
Google Chrome (any version storing passwords in Login Data)
Microsoft Edge (any version storing passwords in Login Data)
vulnerabilities.remediation: Revoke trust for expired certificates in the enterprise trust store; enforce certificate validity checks; monitor for unsigned or expired‑signed DLLs loaded by trusted processes.
workarounds: Enable Windows Defender Exploit Guard to block DLL loading from unexpected locations
Deploy application whitelisting that restricts Valve.exe to load only known good DLLs
references: Securelist article "GodRAT – New RAT targeting financial institutions" (2025-08-19)

vulnerabilities.title: GodRAT – New RAT targeting financial institutions
vulnerabilities.original_title: GodRAT – New RAT targeting financial institutions
vulnerabilities.content_snippet: Summary In September 2024, we detected malicious activity targeting financial (trading and brokerage) firms through the distribution of malicious .scr (screen saver) files disguised as financial documents via Skype messenger. The threat actor deployed a newly identified Remote Access Trojan (RAT) na...
vulnerabilities.summary: Hard‑coded XOR keys and static configuration strings in GodRAT shellcode enable easy reverse‑engineering and replay attacks
vulnerabilities.description: The first‑stage shellcode contains a hard‑coded XOR key ("OSEDBIU#IUSBDGKJS@SIHUDVNSO*SKJBKSDS#SFDBNXFCB") and a static configuration marker "godinfo". These static artifacts allow analysts to decode configuration data and potentially replay or spoof C2 communication.
affected_companies: Kaspersky (due to detection of AsyncRAT signatures)
vendors: Kaspersky (due to detection of AsyncRAT signatures)
products_versions: Valve.exe (any version signed with the expired 2015‑2018 certificate)
Google Chrome (any version storing passwords in Login Data)
Microsoft Edge (any version storing passwords in Login Data)
vulnerabilities.remediation: No direct remediation for the malware itself; defenders should focus on detection and blocking of the loader and its network traffic.
workarounds: Deploy network intrusion detection signatures that flag the specific XOR‑decoded configuration pattern
references: Securelist article "GodRAT – New RAT targeting financial institutions" (2025-08-19)

vulnerabilities.title: Threat Actors Deploy LummaC2 Malware to Exfiltrate Sensitive Data from Organizations
vulnerabilities.original_title: Threat Actors Deploy LummaC2 Malware to Exfiltrate Sensitive Data from Organizations
vulnerabilities.content_snippet: Summary The Federal Bureau of Investigation (FBI) and the Cybersecurity and Infrastructure Security Agency (CISA) are releasing this joint advisory to disseminate known tactics, techniques, and procedures (TTPs) and indicators of compromise (IOCs) associated with threat actors deploying the LummaC2 ...
vulnerabilities.summary: LummaC2 information stealer uses spearphishing attachments/links and obfuscated PowerShell payloads to infiltrate Windows systems and exfiltrate sensitive data.
vulnerabilities.description: The LummaC2 malware is delivered via spearphishing emails containing malicious attachments or links. Victims are tricked into solving a fake CAPTCHA, opening the Windows Run dialog, and pasting a Base64‑encoded PowerShell command. The PowerShell payload decrypts C2 domains, contacts them via HTTP POST, and receives JSON‑encoded commands. The malware can steal browser data, cryptocurrency wallets, MFA tokens, and other PII, optionally download additional payloads via LoadLibrary or rundll32.exe, take screenshots, and self‑delete. It runs primarily in memory to evade endpoint detection, uses custom string decryption, and includes a hostname/username check to avoid execution on attacker systems.
vulnerabilities.remediation: Block known malicious domains and IPs, apply hash‑based detection for LummaC2 binaries, enforce application allowlisting, disable PowerShell script execution for non‑administrative users, patch Windows and browsers, implement MFA, and conduct user security awareness training on phishing and suspicious CAPTCHAs.
workarounds: Restrict execution of PowerShell scripts signed by unknown publishers.
Disable the Windows Run dialog (Win+R) for standard users.
Implement network egress filtering to block unknown HTTP POST destinations.

vulnerabilities.title: CISA Flags Meteobridge CVE-2025-4008 Flaw as Actively Exploited in the Wild
vulnerabilities.original_title: CISA Flags Meteobridge CVE-2025-4008 Flaw as Actively Exploited in the Wild
vulnerabilities.content_snippet: The U.S. Cybersecurity and Infrastructure Security Agency (CISA) on Thursday added a high-severity security flaw impacting Smartbedded Meteobridge to its Known Exploited Vulnerabilities (KEV) catalog, citing evidence of active exploitation. The vulnerability, CVE-2025-4008 (CVSS score: 8.7), is a ca...
vulnerabilities.summary: Command injection vulnerability in the Meteobridge web interface allowing remote code execution.
vulnerabilities.description: An attacker can send specially crafted HTTP requests to the Meteobridge web interface, injecting arbitrary operating system commands. The injected commands are executed with the privileges of the web server process, leading to full system compromise and data exfiltration. The flaw is actively exploited in the wild as reported by CISA.
vulnerabilities.remediation: Apply the vendor-supplied patch as soon as it is released. If a patch is not yet available, upgrade to a version where the issue is fixed or disable the vulnerable web interface.
workarounds: Restrict network access to the Meteobridge web UI using firewall rules or VLAN segmentation.
Deploy a Web Application Firewall (WAF) with rules to block command injection payloads.
Enforce strict input validation on all parameters submitted to the web interface.

vulnerabilities.title: Chinese Hackers Exploit ArcGIS Server as Backdoor for Over a Year
vulnerabilities.original_title: Chinese Hackers Exploit ArcGIS Server as Backdoor for Over a Year
vulnerabilities.content_snippet: Threat actors with ties to China have been attributed to a novel campaign that compromised an ArcGIS system and turned it into a backdoor for more than a year. The activity, per ReliaQuest, is the handiwork of a Chinese state-sponsored hacking group called Flax Typhoon, which is also tracked as Ethe...
vulnerabilities.summary: ArcGIS Server remote code execution vulnerability used to install persistent backdoor
vulnerabilities.description: A vulnerability in the ArcGIS Server REST API endpoint allowed unauthenticated attackers to upload malicious web services and execute arbitrary code, establishing a persistent backdoor. The flaw was exploited for over a year, enabling data exfiltration and lateral movement within victim networks.
vulnerabilities.remediation: Apply the latest security patches from Esri (ArcGIS Server 10.9.2 or later). Disable unnecessary REST services, enforce strong authentication, and restrict access to the server to trusted networks.
workarounds: Block inbound traffic to ports used by ArcGIS Server (e.g., 6080, 6443)
Disable anonymous access to the REST API
Implement network segmentation to isolate ArcGIS Server

vulnerabilities.title: ShinyHunters Leak Data from Qantas, Vietnam Airlines and Other Major Firms
vulnerabilities.original_title: ShinyHunters Leak Data from Qantas, Vietnam Airlines and Other Major Firms
vulnerabilities.content_snippet: ShinyHunters and its affiliate hackers have leaked data from 6 firms, including Qantas and Vietnam Airlines, after claiming to breach 39 companies via a Salesforce vulnerability.
vulnerabilities.summary: Improper access control in Salesforce APIs allowing unauthenticated attackers to retrieve sensitive customer data
vulnerabilities.description: A vulnerability in Salesforce's API endpoint permits attackers to bypass authentication checks and enumerate or export data from compromised tenant instances. The flaw stems from insufficient validation of OAuth tokens and overly permissive default object permissions, enabling threat actors to query and download records without proper authorization. Exploitation can be performed remotely over the internet and does not require prior access or user interaction.
products_versions: All Salesforce cloud services prior to the October 2025 security patch
vulnerabilities.remediation: Apply the latest Salesforce security patches, enforce strict OAuth scopes, enable multi-factor authentication for all users, rotate all access tokens and client secrets, and review object‑level permissions to enforce least‑privilege access.
workarounds: Restrict API access to trusted IP ranges via network‑level firewalls or Salesforce IP allow‑list.
Disable unused API endpoints and integrations.
Implement anomaly‑based monitoring on API call volumes and patterns.

vulnerabilities.title: Malicious npm Packages Exploit Ethereum Smart Contracts to Target Crypto Developers
vulnerabilities.original_title: Malicious npm Packages Exploit Ethereum Smart Contracts to Target Crypto Developers
vulnerabilities.content_snippet: Cybersecurity researchers have discovered two new malicious packages on the npm registry that make use of smart contracts for the Ethereum blockchain to carry out malicious actions on compromised systems, signaling the trend of threat actors constantly on the lookout for new ways to distribute malwa...
vulnerabilities.summary: Malicious npm packages leverage Ethereum smart contracts to execute hidden malicious payloads on systems of crypto developers.
vulnerabilities.description: Two newly published npm packages contain obfuscated JavaScript that, when installed and executed, communicate with attacker‑controlled Ethereum smart contracts. The contracts deliver encrypted payloads and command‑and‑control instructions, allowing the attacker to download additional malware, exfiltrate cryptocurrency wallet files, and execute arbitrary code on the victim host. The malicious behavior is concealed behind blockchain transactions, making network‑based detection difficult. The attack chain starts with a typical supply‑chain compromise: a developer runs `npm install` on a project that lists the malicious package as a dependency, triggering the execution of the payload with the privileges of the user running the install.
affected_products: JavaScript projects that depend on the malicious packages
products_versions: All Node.js versions that can run the malicious JavaScript (typically Node.js >= 10)
Any npm client version that does not enforce package signing
vulnerabilities.remediation: Remove the malicious packages from all projects, purge them from lockfiles, and run a clean install from trusted sources. Rotate any compromised cryptocurrency credentials and private keys. Apply npm’s built‑in `npm audit` and `npm audit fix` to detect known malicious packages. Enable two‑factor authentication on npm accounts and enforce signed package publishing. Consider using a private npm registry or a package allowlist.
workarounds: Block access to the npm registry domains hosting the malicious packages via firewall or DNS filtering.
Use `npm ci` with a verified lockfile to prevent accidental installation of newly added dependencies.

vulnerabilities.title: Cybercrime group accessed Google Law Enforcement Request System (LERS)
vulnerabilities.original_title: Cybercrime group accessed Google Law Enforcement Request System (LERS)
vulnerabilities.content_snippet: Google found threat actors created a fake account in its Law Enforcement Request System (LERS) and shut it down. Google confirmed that threat actors gained access to its Law Enforcement Request System (LERS) platform by creating a fake account. The Google Law Enforcement Request System (LERS) is a s...
vulnerabilities.summary: Unauthorized creation of a fraudulent account in Google Law Enforcement Request System (LERS) allowing potential access to sensitive law enforcement data.
vulnerabilities.description: The threat actor group “Scattered Lapsus$ Hunters” leveraged social engineering to convince Google employees to create a fake user account within the LERS portal. The fabricated account was provisioned with the same privileges as legitimate law‑enforcement accounts, enabling the attackers to potentially submit fraudulent data requests, view or modify case data, and exfiltrate user information. The same group also accessed the FBI’s eCheck system and harvested authentication tokens from compromised Salesforce and Drift services, indicating a broader credential‑theft and token‑reuse campaign.
affected_products: Salesforce Data Loader (when linked to corporate accounts)
vulnerabilities.remediation: Implement strict identity verification for any new LERS account creation, enforce multi‑factor authentication (MFA) for all privileged accounts, adopt zero‑trust access controls, regularly audit and revoke unused service accounts, rotate authentication tokens frequently, and conduct employee security awareness training focused on social engineering.
workarounds: Disable automatic provisioning of LERS accounts from external sources until verification processes are hardened.
Enforce manual review and approval of all new law‑enforcement portal accounts.
Apply temporary IP allow‑list restrictions for LERS access.

vulnerabilities.title: SIM-Swapper, Scattered Spider Hacker Gets 10 Years
vulnerabilities.original_title: SIM-Swapper, Scattered Spider Hacker Gets 10 Years
vulnerabilities.content_snippet: A 20-year-old Florida man at the center of a prolific cybercrime group known as “Scattered Spider” was sentenced to 10 years in federal prison today, and ordered to pay roughly $13 million in restitution to victims. Noah Michael Urban of Palm Coast, Fla. pleaded guilty in April 2025 to c...
vulnerabilities.summary: SIM-swapping vulnerability enabling account takeover
vulnerabilities.description: SIM-swapping attacks exploit weaknesses in mobile carrier authentication processes, allowing attackers to redirect victims' phone numbers to SIM cards they control. This enables bypassing multi-factor authentication (MFA) protections and gaining unauthorized access to accounts.
products_versions: Various versions of corporate authentication systems
vulnerabilities.remediation: Enhance carrier authentication with additional verification steps, implement account recovery mechanisms independent of SMS, and use hardware-based authenticators where possible.
workarounds: Use authenticator apps instead of SMS for 2FA
Enable additional account recovery options
Monitor for unusual account activity
references: Cyberscoop reporting on Star Fraud group

vulnerabilities.title: SIM-Swapper, Scattered Spider Hacker Gets 10 Years
vulnerabilities.original_title: SIM-Swapper, Scattered Spider Hacker Gets 10 Years
vulnerabilities.content_snippet: A 20-year-old Florida man at the center of a prolific cybercrime group known as “Scattered Spider” was sentenced to 10 years in federal prison today, and ordered to pay roughly $13 million in restitution to victims. Noah Michael Urban of Palm Coast, Fla. pleaded guilty in April 2025 to c...
vulnerabilities.summary: Employee phishing vulnerability leading to credential theft
vulnerabilities.description: Attackers create phishing websites mimicking legitimate corporate authentication pages, tricking employees into entering credentials and one-time passcodes. This enables unauthorized access to corporate systems and sensitive data.
products_versions: Various versions of corporate authentication systems
vulnerabilities.remediation: Implement phishing-resistant authentication methods, conduct regular security awareness training, and deploy advanced email filtering solutions.
workarounds: Implement strict access controls
Monitor for unusual login attempts
Use multi-factor authentication with phishing-resistant methods
references: Krebsonsecurity article on Scattered Spider attacks

vulnerabilities.title: The Ongoing Fallout from a Breach at AI Chatbot Maker Salesloft
vulnerabilities.original_title: The Ongoing Fallout from a Breach at AI Chatbot Maker Salesloft
vulnerabilities.content_snippet: The recent mass-theft of authentication tokens from Salesloft, whose AI chatbot is used by a broad swath of corporate America to convert customer interaction into Salesforce leads, has left many companies racing to invalidate the stolen credentials before hackers can exploit them. Now Google warns t...
vulnerabilities.summary: Improper protection and management of OAuth authentication tokens in Salesloft Drift integration leading to mass token theft
vulnerabilities.description: Attackers compromised internal Salesloft systems and exfiltrated valid OAuth access tokens used for SSO integrations. The stolen tokens granted unrestricted access to connected SaaS services (Salesforce, Slack, Google Workspace, AWS S3, Azure, OpenAI, Snowflake, etc.). Because the tokens were not bound to short‑lived lifetimes, lacked proper revocation mechanisms, and were stored without sufficient encryption or usage monitoring, the threat actors were able to pivot across cloud environments, harvest additional credentials, and exfiltrate large volumes of data. The breach did not exploit a software bug in the downstream services but rather leveraged weak token lifecycle management and insufficient segregation of duties within Salesloft's integration platform.
affected_products: Third‑party integrations accessed via Salesloft tokens (Slack, Google Workspace, Amazon S3, Microsoft Azure, OpenAI, Snowflake, etc.)
vulnerabilities.remediation: Revoke all existing OAuth tokens issued by Salesloft Drift; force re‑authentication for all integrations; implement short‑lived, scope‑limited tokens; enforce token rotation policies; encrypt token storage at rest; enable MFA for token issuance; adopt zero‑trust principles for API access; conduct a comprehensive token audit and implement anomaly detection on token usage.
workarounds: Temporarily disable Salesloft Drift integrations with high‑risk services until tokens are rotated.
Block API calls from Salesloft IP ranges to critical SaaS endpoints until token revocation is confirmed.
references: Google Threat Intelligence Group advisory (UNC6395) August 2025

vulnerabilities.summary: Local privilege escalation in VMware Tools and Aria Operations allowing a non‑admin user to gain root on the same VM.
vulnerabilities.description: A flaw in the guest service discovery components of VMware Tools and Aria Operations can be triggered by a malicious local actor with non‑administrative privileges on a VM that has VMware Tools installed and SDMP enabled. The exploit escalates the attacker’s privileges to root on the same VM, providing full control over the guest operating system.

The vulnerability stems from improper handling of privileged operations within the VMware Tools and Aria Operations services, enabling escalation to full control of the host and potentially the underlying virtual infrastructure.

vulnerabilities.title: Cookies and how to bake them: what they are for, associated risks, and what session hijacking has to do with it
vulnerabilities.original_title: Cookies and how to bake them: what they are for, associated risks, and what session hijacking has to do with it
vulnerabilities.content_snippet: When you visit almost any website, you’ll see a pop-up asking you to accept, decline, or customize the cookies it collects. Sometimes, it just tells you that cookies are in use by default. We randomly checked 647 websites, and 563 of them displayed cookie notifications. Most of the time, users...
vulnerabilities.summary: Missing Secure, HttpOnly, and SameSite cookie attributes allowing session hijacking via XSS, sniffing, MitM, and cookie tossing
vulnerabilities.description: When cookies that store Session IDs are set without the Secure flag, they are transmitted over HTTP and can be intercepted. Lack of HttpOnly allows JavaScript access, enabling theft via XSS. Absence of SameSite permits cross‑site request forgery. Attackers can capture or manipulate these cookies to hijack user sessions.
affected_products: Web applications using cookies for session management
affected_companies: Web framework providers (e.g., Django, Rails, ASP.NET, Laravel)
vendors: Web framework providers (e.g., Django, Rails, ASP.NET, Laravel)
vulnerabilities.remediation: Set Secure, HttpOnly, and SameSite=Lax or Strict on all session cookies. Enforce HTTPS site-wide with HSTS. Use the __Host- prefix for critical cookies.
workarounds: Force HTTPS via reverse proxy
Implement server‑side session storage and avoid client‑side session IDs

vulnerabilities.original_title: Cookies and how to bake them: what they are for, associated risks, and what session hijacking has to do with it

vulnerabilities.summary: Session fixation due to failure to regenerate Session ID after authentication
vulnerabilities.description: An attacker forces a victim to use a pre‑determined Session ID (e.g., via a crafted URL). If the application does not issue a new Session ID after the user authenticates, the attacker can reuse the known ID to hijack the authenticated session.
affected_products: Web frameworks that do not rotate session IDs on login
affected_companies: Web framework providers (e.g., Django, Rails, ASP.NET, Laravel)
vendors: Web framework providers (e.g., Django, Rails, ASP.NET, Laravel)
vulnerabilities.remediation: Regenerate a fresh, cryptographically random Session ID immediately after successful login and invalidate the old one.
workarounds: Implement server‑side session fixation protection libraries
Validate Session ID format and reject known attacker‑supplied IDs

Sometimes, it just tells you that cookies are in use by default. We randomly checked 647 websites, and 563 of them displayed cookie notifications. Most of the time, users...
vulnerabilities.summary: Predictable Session ID generation allowing brute‑force or guessing attacks
vulnerabilities.description: Session IDs generated with predictable algorithms (e.g., sequential numbers, inclusion of IP address) can be enumerated by an attacker who collects a sample set, enabling session takeover without needing to steal a cookie.
affected_products: Any web application that uses weak random generators for Session IDs
affected_companies: Web framework providers (e.g., Django, Rails, ASP.NET, Laravel)
vendors: Web framework providers (e.g., Django, Rails, ASP.NET, Laravel)
vulnerabilities.remediation: Generate Session IDs using a cryptographically secure random number generator (CSPRNG) with sufficient entropy (at least 128 bits).
workarounds: Enforce short session lifetimes and rotate IDs frequently

vulnerabilities.summary: Cross‑Site Scripting (XSS) enabling theft of Session ID cookies
vulnerabilities.description: An attacker injects malicious JavaScript into a vulnerable page. The script runs in the victim's browser and reads cookies (including Session IDs) that are not protected by HttpOnly, sending them to the attacker.
affected_products: Web applications that do not properly sanitize user input
affected_companies: Web framework providers (e.g., Django, Rails, ASP.NET, Laravel)
vendors: Web framework providers (e.g., Django, Rails, ASP.NET, Laravel)
vulnerabilities.remediation: Implement strict input validation and output encoding, deploy a Content Security Policy (CSP), and set HttpOnly on session cookies.
workarounds: Use a web application firewall (WAF) to block known XSS payloads

affected_companies: Web framework providers (e.g., Django, Rails, ASP.NET, Laravel)
vendors: Web framework providers (e.g., Django, Rails, ASP.NET, Laravel)
vulnerabilities.remediation: Implement per‑session CSRF tokens and enforce SameSite=Lax/Strict on authentication cookies.
workarounds: Require re‑authentication for sensitive actions

vulnerabilities.description: When a site uses HTTP, cookies (including Session IDs) are sent in clear text. An attacker on the same network can capture these packets and reuse the Session ID to hijack the session.
affected_products: Websites that serve content over HTTP
affected_companies: Web framework providers (e.g., Django, Rails, ASP.NET, Laravel)
vendors: Web framework providers (e.g., Django, Rails, ASP.NET, Laravel)

Disable plain‑HTTP traffic via firewall rules

vulnerabilities.description: An attacker intercepts traffic and either presents a self‑signed certificate or downgrades HTTPS to HTTP (SSL stripping). The victim's browser may accept the certificate, allowing the attacker to read cookies in transit.
affected_products: Any web service that does not enforce HSTS or certificate pinning
affected_companies: Web framework providers (e.g., Django, Rails, ASP.NET, Laravel)
vendors: Web framework providers (e.g., Django, Rails, ASP.NET, Laravel)

workarounds: Use VPN on untrusted networks

vulnerabilities.summary: Cookie tossing via subdomain takeover allowing attacker‑controlled Session ID overwrite
vulnerabilities.description: If a subdomain is compromised, an attacker can set a cookie with the same name as the main domain's Session cookie (e.g., Session_id) using a broader Domain attribute. The browser sends both cookies, and the server may accept the attacker’s value, leading to session takeover.
affected_products: Websites with shared parent domain and insecure cookie Domain attributes
affected_companies: Web framework providers (e.g., Django, Rails, ASP.NET, Laravel)
vendors: Web framework providers (e.g., Django, Rails, ASP.NET, Laravel)
vulnerabilities.remediation: Use the __Host- prefix for critical cookies, avoid setting a Domain attribute, and regularly audit subdomains.
workarounds: Restrict cookie scope to exact host
Implement server‑side validation of Session IDs

Sometimes, it just tells you that cookies are in use by default. We randomly checked 647 websites, and 563 of them displayed cookie notifications. Most of the time, users...
vulnerabilities.summary: Exposure of Session ID in URL query parameters when cookies are disabled
vulnerabilities.description: When cookies are unavailable, some sites embed the Session ID in the URL. URLs can be logged, cached, or leaked via Referer headers, making the Session ID discoverable to attackers.
affected_products: Web applications that fallback to URL‑based session tracking
affected_companies: Web framework providers (e.g., Django, Rails, ASP.NET, Laravel)
vendors: Web framework providers (e.g., Django, Rails, ASP.NET, Laravel)
vulnerabilities.remediation: Avoid URL‑based session identifiers; enforce cookie‑only session handling and set the Secure flag.
workarounds: Implement URL rewriting to strip session parameters before logging
Use POST requests for sensitive actions

vulnerabilities.title: Operation Zero Disco: Threat actors targets Cisco SNMP flaw to drop Linux rootkits
vulnerabilities.original_title: Operation Zero Disco: Threat actors targets Cisco SNMP flaw to drop Linux rootkits
vulnerabilities.content_snippet: Hackers exploit Cisco SNMP flaw CVE-2025-20352 in “Zero Disco” attacks to deploy Linux rootkits on outdated systems, researchers report. Trend Micro researchers disclosed details of a new campaign, tracked as Operation Zero Disco, that exploited a recently disclosed security flaw impacting Cisco IOS...
vulnerabilities.summary: Stack overflow in Cisco IOS/IOS XE SNMP subsystem allowing remote authenticated attackers to cause DoS or achieve root code execution.
vulnerabilities.description: The vulnerability resides in the SNMP daemon of Cisco IOS and IOS XE. A crafted SNMP packet triggers a stack overflow, corrupting memory and allowing an attacker with valid SNMP credentials to execute arbitrary code with root privileges. Exploitation works over both IPv4 and IPv6. The flaw can also be used to cause a denial‑of‑service condition with lower privileges. The vulnerability is present on any device where SNMP is enabled and not properly restricted.
products_versions: Cisco IOS and IOS XE versions prior to the patch released for CVE-2025-20352
Cisco Catalyst 9400, 9300, and 3750G series switches with SNMP enabled
Legacy Linux distributions lacking modern EDR/ASLR protections
vulnerabilities.remediation: Upgrade to the Cisco IOS/IOS XE versions that contain the fix released in the Cisco Security Advisory for CVE-2025-20352. If immediate upgrade is not possible, disable SNMP or restrict SNMP access to trusted management hosts using ACLs, enforce strong community strings or SNMPv3 authentication, and monitor for anomalous SNMP traffic.
workarounds: Disable SNMP on devices that do not require it.
Restrict SNMP access to specific IP addresses via ACLs.
Use SNMPv3 with authentication and encryption instead of SNMPv1/v2c.
Implement network‑based intrusion detection for malformed SNMP packets.
references: Cisco Security Advisory for CVE-2025-20352 (link not provided in article)
Trend Micro research report on Operation Zero Disco (link not provided)

Trend Micro researchers disclosed details of a new campaign, tracked as Operation Zero Disco, that exploited a recently disclosed security flaw impacting Cisco IOS...
vulnerabilities.summary: Telnet authentication bypass vulnerability in Cisco IOS that can be leveraged for arbitrary memory read/write.
vulnerabilities.description: The Telnet flaw allows an attacker to bypass authentication and gain arbitrary memory read/write capabilities. In the Zero Disco campaign the flaw was modified to complement the SNMP exploit, enabling the attackers to manipulate device memory and install persistent rootkits.
affected_products: Cisco Catalyst switches vulnerable to the Telnet flaw
products_versions: Cisco IOS and IOS XE versions prior to the patch released for CVE-2025-20352
Cisco Catalyst 9400, 9300, and 3750G series switches with SNMP enabled
Legacy Linux distributions lacking modern EDR/ASLR protections
vulnerabilities.remediation: Apply the Cisco IOS patches that address CVE-2017-3881. Disable Telnet services where possible and replace with SSH with strong authentication.
workarounds: Disable Telnet on all devices.
Restrict management access to trusted hosts via ACLs.
Use SSH with key‑based authentication.
references: Cisco advisory for CVE-2017-3881 (link not provided)
Trend Micro research report on Operation Zero Disco

vulnerabilities.title: Hackers Deploy Linux Rootkits via Cisco SNMP Flaw in 'Zero Disco' Attacks
vulnerabilities.original_title: Hackers Deploy Linux Rootkits via Cisco SNMP Flaw in 'Zero Disco' Attacks
vulnerabilities.content_snippet: Cybersecurity researchers have disclosed details of a new campaign that exploited a recently disclosed security flaw impacting Cisco IOS Software and IOS XE Software to deploy Linux rootkits on older, unprotected systems. The activity, codenamed Operation Zero Disco by Trend Micro, involves the weap...
vulnerabilities.summary: Stack overflow in Cisco IOS and IOS XE SNMP implementation allowing remote code execution.
vulnerabilities.description: A stack overflow exists in the Simple Network Management Protocol (SNMP) handling code of Cisco IOS and IOS XE. An unauthenticated attacker who can send specially crafted SNMP packets to a vulnerable device can overwrite memory, achieve arbitrary code execution, and install a Linux rootkit on the underlying operating system of older, unprotected devices. The vulnerability is exploited in the wild as part of the Operation Zero Disco campaign, which leverages the flaw to gain persistent footholds on network infrastructure.
vulnerabilities.remediation: Apply the Cisco security advisory patch for CVE-2025-20352. Upgrade affected devices to the latest IOS/IOS XE releases that include the fix. If immediate patching is not possible, disable SNMP v1/v2c, restrict SNMP access to trusted management hosts via ACLs, and enforce strong community strings or switch to SNMPv3 with authentication and encryption.
workarounds: Disable SNMP services on devices that do not require them.
Restrict SNMP traffic to management subnets using firewall or ACL rules.
Enable SNMPv3 with authentication and encryption and disable v1/v2c.

vulnerabilities.title: Hackers Deploy Linux Rootkits via Cisco SNMP Flaw in "Zero Disco' Attacks
vulnerabilities.original_title: Hackers Deploy Linux Rootkits via Cisco SNMP Flaw in "Zero Disco' Attacks
vulnerabilities.content_snippet: Cybersecurity researchers have disclosed details of a new campaign that exploited a recently disclosed security flaw impacting Cisco IOS Software and IOS XE Software to deploy Linux rootkits on older, unprotected systems. The activity, codenamed Operation Zero Disco by Trend Micro, involves the weap...
vulnerabilities.summary: Stack overflow in Cisco IOS/IOS XE Simple Network Management Protocol (SNMP) implementation allowing remote code execution.
vulnerabilities.description: A stack overflow exists in the SNMP daemon of Cisco IOS and IOS XE. An attacker can send a crafted SNMP packet that overwrites the stack, enabling execution of arbitrary code with root privileges on the device. The vulnerability is exploited in the Operation Zero Disco campaign to install Linux rootkits on vulnerable, unpatched Cisco devices, which are then used as footholds for further lateral movement within target networks.
products_versions: Cisco IOS (all versions prior to the security patch released in 2025)
Cisco IOS XE (all versions prior to the security patch released in 2025)
vulnerabilities.remediation: Apply the Cisco security advisory patch for CVE-2025-20352, upgrade to the latest IOS/IOS XE releases, and verify that the patch is correctly installed.
workarounds: Disable SNMP on devices that do not require it.
Restrict SNMP access to trusted management stations using ACLs.
Implement network segmentation to isolate management traffic.

vulnerabilities.title: OneLogin Bug Let Attackers Use API Keys to Steal OIDC Secrets and Impersonate Apps
vulnerabilities.original_title: OneLogin Bug Let Attackers Use API Keys to Steal OIDC Secrets and Impersonate Apps
vulnerabilities.content_snippet: A high-severity security flaw has been disclosed in the One Identity OneLogin Identity and Access Management (IAM) solution that, if successfully exploited, could expose sensitive OpenID Connect (OIDC) application client secrets under certain circumstances. The vulnerability, tracked as CVE-2025-593...
vulnerabilities.summary: API keys can be used to retrieve OIDC client secrets, allowing attackers to impersonate applications in One Identity OneLogin IAM.
vulnerabilities.description: The vulnerability resides in the OneLogin API endpoint that handles OIDC client secret retrieval. An attacker possessing a valid API key can invoke the endpoint to enumerate and extract client secrets for registered OIDC applications. With the stolen secret, the attacker can generate valid JWTs and impersonate the affected applications, potentially gaining unauthorized access to downstream services that trust the OIDC provider. The flaw is exploitable remotely over HTTPS without requiring user interaction.
affected_products: One Identity OneLogin Identity and Access Management (IAM)
products_versions: All OneLogin IAM versions prior to the patch released on 2025-10-01
vulnerabilities.remediation: Apply the vendor-supplied patch released on 2025-10-01. Rotate all OIDC client secrets immediately after patching. Revoke any compromised API keys and issue new keys with least‑privilege scopes. Review and tighten API key permissions to restrict access to secret‑retrieval endpoints.
workarounds: Revoke all existing API keys and generate new keys with minimal scopes.
Disable the OIDC client secret retrieval endpoint if not required.
Enforce short‑lived client secrets and rotate them regularly.

vulnerabilities.title: Cisco Warns of Actively Exploited SNMP Vulnerability Allowing RCE or DoS in IOS Software
vulnerabilities.original_title: Cisco Warns of Actively Exploited SNMP Vulnerability Allowing RCE or DoS in IOS Software
vulnerabilities.content_snippet: Cisco has warned of a high-severity security flaw in IOS Software and IOS XE Software that could allow a remote attacker to execute arbitrary code or trigger a denial-of-service (DoS) condition under specific circumstances. The company said the vulnerability, CVE-2025-20352 (CVSS score: 7.7), has be...
vulnerabilities.summary: SNMP processing flaw in Cisco IOS and IOS XE that allows remote code execution or denial‑of‑service.
vulnerabilities.description: The vulnerability resides in the SNMP daemon of Cisco IOS and IOS XE. A specially crafted SNMP packet can trigger a buffer overflow or improper memory handling, leading to arbitrary code execution with root privileges on the device or causing the SNMP process to crash, resulting in a denial‑of‑service condition. The flaw is exploitable remotely over UDP/161 without authentication.
products_versions: All Cisco IOS and IOS XE releases prior to the patch (specific versions not disclosed in the article)
vulnerabilities.remediation: Upgrade to the Cisco‑released patched versions of IOS/IOS XE as listed in the security advisory. Apply the latest software release that includes the fix for CVE‑2025‑20352.
workarounds: Disable SNMP if not required.
Restrict UDP/161/162 traffic to trusted management hosts using ACLs or firewall rules.
Enable SNMPv3 with authentication and encryption and limit community strings.
Monitor for abnormal SNMP traffic and rate‑limit SNMP packets.

vulnerabilities.title: Cisco Warns of Actively Exploited SNMP Vulnerability Allowing RCE or DoS in IOS Software
vulnerabilities.original_title: Cisco Warns of Actively Exploited SNMP Vulnerability Allowing RCE or DoS in IOS Software
vulnerabilities.content_snippet: Cisco has warned of a high-severity security flaw in IOS Software and IOS XE Software that could allow a remote attacker to execute arbitrary code or trigger a denial-of-service (DoS) condition under specific circumstances. The company said the vulnerability, CVE-2025-20352 (CVSS score: 7.7), has be...
vulnerabilities.summary: High‑severity SNMP processing flaw in Cisco IOS and IOS XE that allows remote code execution or denial‑of‑service.
vulnerabilities.description: A flaw in the SNMP implementation of Cisco IOS and IOS XE allows an attacker to send specially crafted SNMP packets that trigger a memory corruption condition. Depending on the packet content, the vulnerability can be leveraged to execute arbitrary code with root privileges on the device or to cause a crash leading to a denial‑of‑service. The issue is exploitable remotely over the network without prior authentication, though the attacker must be able to reach the SNMP service (default UDP/161). Cisco observed active exploitation in the wild shortly after the vulnerability was disclosed.
vulnerabilities.remediation: Upgrade affected devices to the Cisco IOS/IOS XE versions that contain the fix as described in the Cisco Security Advisory. Apply the recommended configuration changes, such as disabling unused SNMP services or limiting SNMP access to trusted hosts.
workarounds: Disable SNMP on affected devices if it is not required.
Restrict SNMP access to trusted management stations using ACLs.
Enable SNMPv3 with authentication and encryption instead of community‑based SNMPv1/v2c.

vulnerabilities.title: U.S. CISA adds Oracle, Windows, Kentico, and Apple flaws to its Known Exploited Vulnerabilities catalog
vulnerabilities.original_title: U.S. CISA adds Oracle, Windows, Kentico, and Apple flaws to its Known Exploited Vulnerabilities catalog
vulnerabilities.content_snippet: U.S. Cybersecurity and Infrastructure Security Agency (CISA) adds Oracle, Windows, Kentico, and Apple flaws to its Known Exploited Vulnerabilities catalog. The U.S. Cybersecurity and Infrastructure Security Agency (CISA) added Oracle, Windows, Kentico, and Apple flaws to its Known Exploited Vulnerab...
vulnerabilities.summary: Apple JavaScriptCore vulnerability allowing arbitrary code execution when processing malicious web content.
vulnerabilities.description: An attacker can craft malicious web content that triggers a flaw in the JavaScriptCore engine, leading to remote code execution on the victim device. The vulnerability is present in multiple Apple products and has been actively exploited in the wild, prompting its inclusion in the CISA KEV catalog.
products_versions: Kentico Xperience CMS (all supported versions with Staging Sync Server)
Microsoft Windows SMB Client (Windows 10, Server 2019, Server 2022)
vulnerabilities.remediation: Apply the latest Apple security updates that address JavaScriptCore vulnerabilities. Ensure devices are running the most recent OS versions.
workarounds: Disable JavaScript execution in browsers when possible.
Use content filtering solutions to block malicious web content.

vulnerabilities.title: U.S. CISA adds Oracle, Windows, Kentico, and Apple flaws to its Known Exploited Vulnerabilities catalog
vulnerabilities.original_title: U.S. CISA adds Oracle, Windows, Kentico, and Apple flaws to its Known Exploited Vulnerabilities catalog
vulnerabilities.content_snippet: U.S. Cybersecurity and Infrastructure Security Agency (CISA) adds Oracle, Windows, Kentico, and Apple flaws to its Known Exploited Vulnerabilities catalog. The U.S. Cybersecurity and Infrastructure Security Agency (CISA) added Oracle, Windows, Kentico, and Apple flaws to its Known Exploited Vulnerab...
vulnerabilities.summary: Kentico Xperience Staging Sync Server digest password authentication bypass allowing unauthenticated attackers to gain administrative access.
vulnerabilities.description: Improper handling of digest password authentication in the Staging Sync Server enables attackers to bypass authentication checks and obtain full administrative control over the CMS instance.
products_versions: Kentico Xperience CMS (all supported versions with Staging Sync Server)
Microsoft Windows SMB Client (Windows 10, Server 2019, Server 2022)
vulnerabilities.remediation: Apply the security patch released by Kentico for the affected versions of Xperience CMS.
workarounds: Disable the Staging Sync Server feature until patches are applied.
Enforce strong password policies and monitor for unauthorized access attempts.

vulnerabilities.title: U.S. CISA adds Oracle, Windows, Kentico, and Apple flaws to its Known Exploited Vulnerabilities catalog
vulnerabilities.original_title: U.S. CISA adds Oracle, Windows, Kentico, and Apple flaws to its Known Exploited Vulnerabilities catalog
vulnerabilities.content_snippet: U.S. Cybersecurity and Infrastructure Security Agency (CISA) adds Oracle, Windows, Kentico, and Apple flaws to its Known Exploited Vulnerabilities catalog. The U.S. Cybersecurity and Infrastructure Security Agency (CISA) added Oracle, Windows, Kentico, and Apple flaws to its Known Exploited Vulnerab...
vulnerabilities.summary: Kentico Xperience Staging Sync Server authentication bypass when no password type is specified, allowing unauthenticated administrative access.
vulnerabilities.description: A flaw in the password handling logic of the Staging Sync Server permits authentication bypass when the password type is omitted, granting attackers full control over the CMS environment.
products_versions: Kentico Xperience CMS (all supported versions with Staging Sync Server)
Microsoft Windows SMB Client (Windows 10, Server 2019, Server 2022)
vulnerabilities.remediation: Install the Kentico-provided patch that corrects the password handling logic.
workarounds: Temporarily disable the Staging Sync Server functionality.
Restrict network access to the CMS management interfaces.

vulnerabilities.title: U.S. CISA adds Oracle, Windows, Kentico, and Apple flaws to its Known Exploited Vulnerabilities catalog
vulnerabilities.original_title: U.S. CISA adds Oracle, Windows, Kentico, and Apple flaws to its Known Exploited Vulnerabilities catalog
vulnerabilities.content_snippet: U.S. Cybersecurity and Infrastructure Security Agency (CISA) adds Oracle, Windows, Kentico, and Apple flaws to its Known Exploited Vulnerabilities catalog. The U.S. Cybersecurity and Infrastructure Security Agency (CISA) added Oracle, Windows, Kentico, and Apple flaws to its Known Exploited Vulnerab...
vulnerabilities.summary: Microsoft Windows SMB Client improper access control vulnerability that can lead to privilege escalation.
vulnerabilities.description: The SMB client fails to enforce proper access controls, allowing remote attackers to manipulate SMB requests and gain elevated privileges on the victim system.
products_versions: Kentico Xperience CMS (all supported versions with Staging Sync Server)
Microsoft Windows SMB Client (Windows 10, Server 2019, Server 2022)
vulnerabilities.remediation: Apply the Microsoft security update released in June 2025 that resolves the SMB client access control issue.
workarounds: Disable SMBv1 and restrict SMB traffic using firewall rules.
Enforce network segmentation to limit SMB exposure.

vulnerabilities.title: U.S. CISA adds Oracle, Windows, Kentico, and Apple flaws to its Known Exploited Vulnerabilities catalog
vulnerabilities.original_title: U.S. CISA adds Oracle, Windows, Kentico, and Apple flaws to its Known Exploited Vulnerabilities catalog
vulnerabilities.content_snippet: U.S. Cybersecurity and Infrastructure Security Agency (CISA) adds Oracle, Windows, Kentico, and Apple flaws to its Known Exploited Vulnerabilities catalog. The U.S. Cybersecurity and Infrastructure Security Agency (CISA) added Oracle, Windows, Kentico, and Apple flaws to its Known Exploited Vulnerab...
vulnerabilities.summary: Oracle E-Business Suite Runtime UI Server-Side Request Forgery (SSRF) vulnerability allowing unauthenticated attackers to access internal resources.
vulnerabilities.description: An unauthenticated attacker can craft specially crafted requests to the Runtime UI component, causing the server to initiate arbitrary HTTP requests to internal services, potentially exposing sensitive data.
products_versions: Kentico Xperience CMS (all supported versions with Staging Sync Server)
Microsoft Windows SMB Client (Windows 10, Server 2019, Server 2022)
vulnerabilities.remediation: Apply the out‑of‑band security patch released by Oracle for E‑Business Suite versions 12.2.3 through 12.2.14.
workarounds: Restrict outbound network traffic from the E‑Business Suite servers.
Implement a web application firewall (WAF) to block malicious request patterns.

vulnerabilities.title: Five New Exploited Bugs Land in CISA's Catalog — Oracle and Microsoft Among Targets
vulnerabilities.original_title: Five New Exploited Bugs Land in CISA's Catalog — Oracle and Microsoft Among Targets
vulnerabilities.content_snippet: The U.S. Cybersecurity and Infrastructure Security Agency (CISA) on Monday added five security flaws to its Known Exploited Vulnerabilities (KEV) Catalog, officially confirming a recently disclosed vulnerability impacting Oracle E-Business Suite (EBS) has been weaponized in real-world attacks. The s...
vulnerabilities.summary: Improper input validation in Oracle E-Business Suite leading to remote code execution.
vulnerabilities.description: A vulnerability in Oracle E-Business Suite (EBS) allows an attacker to send specially crafted requests that bypass authentication and execute arbitrary code on the server. The flaw has been weaponized in the wild, with threat actors exploiting it to gain unauthorized access to enterprise data and systems.
products_versions: Oracle E-Business Suite (specific versions not disclosed)
vulnerabilities.remediation: Apply the security patch released by Oracle for CVE-2025-61884. Ensure all EBS instances are updated to the latest supported version.
workarounds: Restrict inbound network traffic to EBS servers to trusted IP ranges.
Deploy a Web Application Firewall (WAF) with rules to block malicious payloads.
Monitor for anomalous authentication attempts and unusual process creation.

vulnerabilities.title: New Oracle E-Business Suite Bug Could Let Hackers Access Data Without Login
vulnerabilities.original_title: New Oracle E-Business Suite Bug Could Let Hackers Access Data Without Login
vulnerabilities.content_snippet: Oracle on Saturday issued a security alert warning of a fresh security flaw impacting its E-Business Suite that it said could allow unauthorized access to sensitive data. The vulnerability, tracked as CVE-2025-61884, carries a CVSS score of 7.5, indicating high severity. It affects versions from 12....
vulnerabilities.summary: Unauthenticated remote code execution vulnerability in Oracle E-Business Suite allowing data access without login
vulnerabilities.description: A flaw in the Oracle E-Business Suite (versions 12.2.3 through 12.2.14) permits an unauthenticated attacker to bypass authentication mechanisms and directly access sensitive data. The vulnerability is exploitable over the network with minimal complexity, requiring no prior credentials or user interaction. Exploitation likely involves crafted HTTP requests that trigger insecure handling of session tokens or improper access control checks, resulting in unauthorized data disclosure and potential modification.
vulnerabilities.remediation: Apply the official Oracle security patch released in the advisory for CVE-2025-61884. Verify patch installation via Oracle's patch verification tools. If immediate patching is not possible, restrict external access to the E-Business Suite web interface, enforce strong network segmentation, and enable multi-factor authentication for all privileged accounts.
workarounds: Block inbound traffic to the E-Business Suite application servers from untrusted networks using firewall rules.
Disable or restrict the vulnerable web modules until the patch is applied.
Enforce strict input validation and web application firewall (WAF) rules to block malformed requests.

vulnerabilities.title: U.S. CISA adds Grafana flaw to its Known Exploited Vulnerabilities catalog
vulnerabilities.original_title: U.S. CISA adds Grafana flaw to its Known Exploited Vulnerabilities catalog
vulnerabilities.content_snippet: U.S. Cybersecurity and Infrastructure Security Agency (CISA) adds Grafana flaw to its Known Exploited Vulnerabilities catalog. The U.S. Cybersecurity and Infrastructure Security Agency (CISA) added Grafana flaw, tracked as CVE-2021-43798 (CVSS score 7.5), to its Known Exploited Vulnerabilities (KEV)...
vulnerabilities.summary: Directory traversal vulnerability in Grafana allowing remote attackers to read arbitrary files via crafted plugin path URLs.
vulnerabilities.description: Grafana versions 8.0.0‑beta1 through 8.3.0 (excluding patched releases) fail to properly sanitize the plugin identifier supplied in the URL path /public/plugins/<plugin-id>/. An attacker can craft a request such as https://<grafana_host>/public/plugins/../../../../etc/passwd to traverse directories and retrieve files outside the intended plugin directory. This enables disclosure of configuration files, credentials, or other sensitive data stored on the server. The vulnerability does not affect Grafana Cloud deployments.
vulnerabilities.remediation: Upgrade Grafana to a patched version: 8.0.7, 8.1.8, 8.2.7, or 8.3.1 (or later). Apply any security patches released by Grafana Labs.
workarounds: Restrict access to the /public/plugins/ path using a web application firewall (WAF) or reverse proxy rules that block path traversal patterns (e.g., "..", "%2e%2e").
Disable or remove unused plugins.
Configure the web server to enforce a strict directory whitelist for the plugins endpoint.
Limit network exposure of Grafana instances (e.g., firewall rules, VPN access only).

vulnerabilities.title: Severe Framelink Figma MCP Vulnerability Lets Hackers Execute Code Remotely
vulnerabilities.original_title: Severe Framelink Figma MCP Vulnerability Lets Hackers Execute Code Remotely
vulnerabilities.content_snippet: Cybersecurity researchers have disclosed details of a now-patched vulnerability in the popular figma-developer-mcp Model Context Protocol (MCP) server that could allow attackers to achieve code execution. The vulnerability, tracked as CVE-2025-53967 (CVSS score: 7.5), is a command injection bug stem...
vulnerabilities.summary: Command injection vulnerability in Figma's Model Context Protocol (MCP) server allowing remote code execution.
vulnerabilities.description: The MCP server processes user‑provided data without proper sanitisation. An attacker can craft a malicious request that is concatenated into a system command, leading to arbitrary command execution on the host running the MCP service. Successful exploitation results in full remote code execution, enabling the attacker to compromise the underlying system, exfiltrate data, or pivot to other services.
products_versions: All figma-developer-mcp MCP server versions prior to the October 2025 security patch
vulnerabilities.remediation: Apply the vendor‑released patch that adds proper input validation and command sanitisation. Update to the latest version of the MCP server. Verify that the patch is deployed across all environments.
workarounds: Restrict network access to the MCP service to trusted IP ranges.
Deploy a web application firewall (WAF) with rules to block suspicious command‑injection payloads.
Run the MCP service with the least privileges necessary.

vulnerabilities.title: Apple Updates iOS and macOS to Prevent Malicious Font Attacks
vulnerabilities.original_title: Apple Updates iOS and macOS to Prevent Malicious Font Attacks
vulnerabilities.content_snippet: The vulnerability could lead to a denial-of-service condition or memory corruption when a malicious font is processed. The post Apple Updates iOS and macOS to Prevent Malicious Font Attacks appeared first on SecurityWeek.
