vulnerabilities.summary: Processing of maliciously crafted font files can cause denial-of-service or memory corruption on iOS and macOS devices.
vulnerabilities.description: A vulnerability exists in the font parsing libraries used by iOS and macOS. When a specially crafted font file is opened or rendered, the parser can be triggered into an out-of-bounds write or heap corruption, leading to a crash (denial of service) or potential arbitrary code execution. The flaw is triggered by providing a malicious font via any application that loads fonts (e.g., Mail, Safari, third‑party apps).
vulnerabilities.remediation: Update devices to the latest iOS and macOS releases that contain the font parsing fix. Apple has released patches that validate font structures more rigorously.
workarounds: Avoid opening font files from untrusted sources.
Use Mobile Device Management (MDM) to restrict installation of custom fonts.
Disable third‑party font rendering extensions if not required.

vulnerabilities.title: Unpatched flaw in OnePlus phones lets rogue apps text messages
vulnerabilities.original_title: Unpatched flaw in OnePlus phones lets rogue apps text messages
vulnerabilities.content_snippet: A vulnerability in multiple OnePlus OxygenOS versions allows any installed app to access SMS data and metadata without requiring permission or user interaction. [...]
vulnerabilities.summary: Improper access control in OnePlus OxygenOS allows any installed app to read SMS messages and metadata without user permission or interaction.
vulnerabilities.description: A flaw in the SMS handling component of OxygenOS bypasses Android's permission model. The vulnerability stems from an unchecked IPC interface that grants any third‑party application the ability to query the SMS content provider. As a result, malicious apps can retrieve full message bodies, sender/receiver numbers, timestamps, and related metadata without declaring the READ_SMS permission or prompting the user. The issue exists across multiple OxygenOS releases and can be exploited by simply installing a malicious app from any source.
vulnerabilities.remediation: Update the device to the latest OxygenOS version released by OnePlus, which includes the fix for the SMS permission bypass. If an update is not yet available, uninstall any untrusted applications and consider flashing a patched firmware image.
workarounds: Disable SMS access for all third‑party apps via the Android permission manager.
Use a mobile device management (MDM) solution to enforce a whitelist of allowed applications.
Restrict installation of apps from unknown sources.

vulnerabilities.title: American Archive of Public Broadcasting allowed access to restricted media for years
vulnerabilities.original_title: American Archive of Public Broadcasting allowed access to restricted media for years
vulnerabilities.content_snippet: A security flaw in the American Archive of Public Broadcasting (AAPB) website allowed unauthorized access to protected and private media, according to BleepingComputer. The American Archive of Public Broadcasting (AAPB) is a collaborative initiative between the Library of Congress and WGBH Education...
vulnerabilities.summary: Improper access control allowing media files to be downloaded by ID without authentication
vulnerabilities.description: The AAPB web application exposed an endpoint that accepted a media ID parameter and returned the corresponding file without verifying the requestor's authorization. An attacker could enumerate or guess valid IDs and retrieve protected or private archival media, bypassing any access‑control checks. The flaw was exploited publicly from at least 2021 and was discussed on underground forums in 2024 before being patched in September 2025.
affected_products: American Archive of Public Broadcasting (AAPB) website
vulnerabilities.remediation: Implement proper authentication and authorization checks on all media retrieval endpoints. Validate that the requesting user has permission to access the requested media category. Add rate limiting and logging for ID‑based requests. Deploy input validation to prevent ID enumeration. Conduct a security review of all public APIs.
workarounds: Temporarily disable the public media download endpoint until proper access controls are in place.
Restrict access to the media repository to authenticated internal users only.
references: Discord discussion (mid‑2024) circulating the ID‑based download script

vulnerabilities.title: $150K awarded for L1TF Reloaded exploit that bypasses cloud mitigations
vulnerabilities.original_title: $150K awarded for L1TF Reloaded exploit that bypasses cloud mitigations
vulnerabilities.content_snippet: Researchers earned $150K for “L1TF Reloaded,” combining L1TF and half-Spectre to leak VM memory from public clouds despite mitigations. Researchers from Vrije Universiteit Amsterdam earned $150K for exploiting L1TF Reloaded, a flaw combining L1TF (Foreshadow) and half-Spectre. The attack bypasses pr...
vulnerabilities.summary: L1 Terminal Fault (L1TF / Foreshadow) allows speculative load of data from L1 cache across VM boundaries, enabling unauthorized memory reads.
vulnerabilities.description: A transient execution side‑channel flaw in Intel CPUs allows an attacker running in a guest VM to speculatively load data from the L1 data cache that belongs to the hypervisor or other guests. By combining the L1TF primitive with a half‑Spectre out‑of‑bounds load gadget in the KVM hypervisor, the researchers were able to translate guest virtual addresses to host physical addresses and leak arbitrary memory, including TLS private keys, from co‑tenant VMs on public‑cloud platforms.
affected_products: Intel CPUs with vulnerable L1 cache (Skylake, Kaby Lake, Coffee Lake, Cascade Lake, etc.)
Hypervisors using Intel VT-x (e.g., Linux KVM, VMware ESXi, Hyper-V)
products_versions: Intel CPUs: Skylake, Kaby Lake, Coffee Lake, Cascade Lake, Ice Lake (all prior to microcode mitigation)
Linux kernel versions prior to 5.19 with unpatched KVM Spectre mitigations
Hyper‑Visors lacking L1TF and Spectre mitigations (e.g., older ESXi, older Hyper‑V)
vulnerabilities.remediation: Apply Intel microcode updates, enable the L1D cache flush mitigation (e.g., via the "l1tf=full,force" kernel parameter), disable Simultaneous Multithreading (SMT) on vulnerable CPUs, and ensure hypervisor patches that mitigate L1TF and Spectre variants are deployed.
workarounds: Disable SMT/Hyper‑Threading in BIOS or OS
Run VMs on dedicated (single‑tenant) hardware
Enable EPT/NPT with strict access controls
Use kernel parameters to force L1D flushing (e.g., l1tf=full,force, nosmt=force)
references: VUSec research paper (Google Cloud VRP submission, 2025)

vulnerabilities.title: $150K awarded for L1TF Reloaded exploit that bypasses cloud mitigations
vulnerabilities.original_title: $150K awarded for L1TF Reloaded exploit that bypasses cloud mitigations
vulnerabilities.content_snippet: Researchers earned $150K for “L1TF Reloaded,” combining L1TF and half-Spectre to leak VM memory from public clouds despite mitigations. Researchers from Vrije Universiteit Amsterdam earned $150K for exploiting L1TF Reloaded, a flaw combining L1TF (Foreshadow) and half-Spectre. The attack bypasses pr...
vulnerabilities.summary: L1TF variant affecting Intel CPUs with SGX, enabling speculative reads from L1 cache across protection domains.
vulnerabilities.description: A second variant of L1TF that can be triggered when SGX is enabled, allowing similar cross‑domain speculative reads. The VUSec exploit chains this variant with a half‑Spectre gadget to bypass existing mitigations in cloud environments.
affected_products: Intel CPUs with SGX support (Skylake, Kaby Lake, etc.)
products_versions: Intel CPUs: Skylake, Kaby Lake, Coffee Lake, Cascade Lake, Ice Lake (all prior to microcode mitigation)
Linux kernel versions prior to 5.19 with unpatched KVM Spectre mitigations
Hyper‑Visors lacking L1TF and Spectre mitigations (e.g., older ESXi, older Hyper‑V)
vulnerabilities.remediation: Same as CVE-2018-3620: update microcode, enable L1D flushing, disable SMT, apply hypervisor patches.
workarounds: Disable SGX in BIOS/firmware
Apply the same mitigations listed for CVE-2018-3620

vulnerabilities.title: American Archive of Public Broadcasting fixes bug exposing restricted media
vulnerabilities.original_title: American Archive of Public Broadcasting fixes bug exposing restricted media
vulnerabilities.content_snippet: ​A vulnerability in the American Archive of Public Broadcasting's website allowed downloading of protected and private media for years, with the flaw quietly patched this month. [...]
vulnerabilities.summary: Improper access control on the American Archive of Public Broadcasting website allowed unauthorized downloading of protected and private media files.
vulnerabilities.description: The web application failed to enforce proper authorization checks on media asset URLs. An attacker could craft or enumerate direct URLs to media files that were intended to be restricted to authorized users. This IDOR-like flaw allowed bulk downloading of private audio/video content without authentication, persisting for years before being patched.
affected_products: American Archive of Public Broadcasting website
products_versions: American Archive of Public Broadcasting website (pre‑patch version)
vulnerabilities.remediation: Implement strict server‑side access control checks for all media endpoints. Validate that the requesting user has the appropriate permissions before serving any file. Apply proper authentication and authorization middleware, and consider using signed, time‑limited URLs for media delivery.
workarounds: Temporarily disable public access to the media directory until proper controls are in place.
Restrict access to media files via IP allow‑lists or VPN.
Monitor and rate‑limit download requests to detect abnormal activity.

vulnerabilities.title: ChatGPT solves CAPTCHAs if you tell it they’re fake
vulnerabilities.original_title: ChatGPT solves CAPTCHAs if you tell it they’re fake
vulnerabilities.content_snippet: If you’re seeing fewer or different CAPTCHA puzzles in the near future, that’s not because website owners have agreed that they’re annoying, but it might be because they no longer prove that the visitor is human. For those that forgot what CAPTCHA stands for: Completely Automated Public Turing test ...
vulnerabilities.summary: Prompt injection enables ChatGPT-4o (and similar LLM agents) to solve image‑based CAPTCHAs, allowing automated bypass of human verification mechanisms.
vulnerabilities.description: Researchers demonstrated that by priming the LLM with a prompt that declares the CAPTCHA to be "fake", the model can be coaxed into providing solutions to various CAPTCHA types (one‑click, logic‑based, text‑recognition, and some image‑based challenges). The attack relies on prompt injection (social engineering of the model) rather than a software bug, but the result is a functional bypass of a security control designed to block automated bots. This enables malicious actors to automate account creation, credential stuffing, content scraping, and other activities that rely on CAPTCHA protection.
affected_products: Other large language model agents with similar instruction‑following behavior
products_versions: LLM agent mode for ChatGPT API
vulnerabilities.remediation: OpenAI and other LLM providers should harden instruction‑following mechanisms, add contextual awareness to refuse CAPTCHA‑solving requests even after priming, and implement robust prompt‑injection detection. Deploy CAPTCHAs that incorporate behavioral analysis, rate limiting, and server‑side verification that cannot be satisfied by textual responses alone. Consider using invisible or risk‑based CAPTCHAs that require client‑side interaction not reproducible via LLM output.
workarounds: Disable public API access for tasks that could be used to solve CAPTCHAs.
Add a secondary verification layer (e.g., email/SMS OTP) after CAPTCHA success.
Monitor and throttle repeated CAPTCHA solve attempts from the same IP or API key.
references: OpenAI usage policy on disallowed content

vulnerabilities.title: SonicWall warns customers to reset credentials after MySonicWall backups were exposed
vulnerabilities.original_title: SonicWall warns customers to reset credentials after MySonicWall backups were exposed
vulnerabilities.content_snippet: SonicWall urges users to reset credentials after MySonicWall backups were exposed; the company locked out the threat actors and notified authorities. SonicWall urged customers to reset credentials after firewall backup files tied to MySonicWall accounts were exposed. The company announced it had blo...
vulnerabilities.summary: Unauthorized access to MySonicWall cloud backup preference files via brute‑force attacks, leading to exposure of encrypted credentials and firewall configuration data.
vulnerabilities.description: Threat actors performed credential‑guessing (brute‑force) attacks against the MySonicWall cloud backup portal. Successful authentication granted access to backup files that contain encrypted user credentials and firewall preference data. Although the credentials are stored encrypted, the backup files also expose configuration details (e.g., VPN pre‑shared keys, TOTP bindings) that can be leveraged to further compromise the firewall. The incident affected fewer than 5 % of SonicWall customers with backups enabled. No public leak of the files has been observed, but the exposure creates a significant risk of credential reuse and configuration manipulation.
affected_products: SonicWall firewalls with MySonicWall cloud backup enabled
products_versions: All SonicWall firewall models supporting MySonicWall cloud backup (specific versions not disclosed)
vulnerabilities.remediation: 1. Immediately reset all passwords for MySonicWall accounts and any credentials stored in firewall preference files. 2. Enable multi‑factor authentication (MFA) on MySonicWall accounts. 3. Disable cloud backup for firewalls that do not require it. 4. Import the sanitized preference file provided by SonicWall during a maintenance window and re‑configure VPN pre‑shared keys, TOTP secrets, and user passwords. 5. Apply any firmware updates released by SonicWall that harden authentication to the backup service.
workarounds: Disable MySonicWall cloud backup until remediation is completed.
Restrict access to MySonicWall portal by IP allow‑list.
Enforce account lockout after a limited number of failed login attempts.

vulnerabilities.title: SlopAds Fraud Ring Exploits 224 Android Apps to Drive 2.3 Billion Daily Ad Bids
vulnerabilities.original_title: SlopAds Fraud Ring Exploits 224 Android Apps to Drive 2.3 Billion Daily Ad Bids
vulnerabilities.content_snippet: A massive ad fraud and click fraud operation dubbed SlopAds ran a cluster of 224 apps, collectively attracting 38 million downloads across 228 countries and territories. "These apps deliver their fraud payload using steganography and create hidden WebViews to navigate to threat actor-owned cashout s...
vulnerabilities.summary: Improper use of Android WebView in malicious apps enabling hidden navigation to ad‑fraud domains and click fraud generation
vulnerabilities.description: The malicious applications embed steganographically‑encoded payloads that, when executed, instantiate hidden WebView components. These WebViews silently navigate to threat‑actor‑controlled cash‑out sites, generating fraudulent ad impressions and clicks without user awareness. The technique bypasses standard UI‑based detection, leverages Android's WebView default permissions, and can operate on any device with a vulnerable app installed.
affected_products: 224 third‑party Android applications identified in the SlopAds fraud ring
vulnerabilities.remediation: Remove the identified malicious applications from devices; enforce strict Play Store vetting and code‑signing verification; disable JavaScript and file‑access in WebView implementations unless explicitly required; employ mobile threat defense solutions that monitor hidden WebView activity; implement network‑level ad‑traffic filtering to block known fraud domains.
workarounds: Restrict installation of apps from unknown sources
Use mobile device management (MDM) to whitelist approved applications
Monitor network traffic for anomalous ad‑request patterns
references: Human Satori Threat Intelligence report on SlopAds (2025)

vulnerabilities.title: RevengeHotels: a new wave of attacks leveraging LLMs and VenomRAT
vulnerabilities.original_title: RevengeHotels: a new wave of attacks leveraging LLMs and VenomRAT
vulnerabilities.content_snippet: Background RevengeHotels, also known as TA558, is a threat group that has been active since 2015, stealing credit card data from hotel guests and travelers. RevengeHotels’ modus operandi involves sending emails with phishing links which redirect victims to websites mimicking document storage. ...
vulnerabilities.summary: Remote code execution via crafted Microsoft Office documents that load malicious remote templates.
vulnerabilities.description: The vulnerability exists in the way Microsoft Office handles OLE objects and remote template loading. An attacker can embed a malicious URL in a Word, Excel, or PowerPoint document. When the document is opened, Office automatically retrieves the remote template, executing arbitrary code with the privileges of the user. The RevengeHotels group previously leveraged this CVE to deliver VBS or PowerShell scripts that installed various RATs.
products_versions: Microsoft Office 2007‑2019 and Office 365 (any version lacking the March 2017 patch)
vulnerabilities.remediation: Apply the Microsoft security update released in March 2017 (KB4012598 and related patches). Disable the loading of remote templates via Group Policy (User Configuration → Administrative Templates → Microsoft Office → Security → Disable loading of remote content). Ensure Office macro and script execution is restricted.
workarounds: Block outbound HTTP/HTTPS traffic to untrusted domains from Office applications.
Configure Outlook/Office to prompt before loading external content.
Use application whitelisting to prevent execution of unknown scripts.

vulnerabilities.title: When AI chatbots leak and how it happens
vulnerabilities.original_title: When AI chatbots leak and how it happens
vulnerabilities.content_snippet: In a recent article on Cybernews there were two clear signs of how fast the world of AI chatbots is growing. A company I had never even heard of had over 150 million app downloads across its portfolio, and it also had an exposed unprotected Elasticsearch instance. This needs a bit of an explanation....
vulnerabilities.summary: Unauthenticated exposure of Elasticsearch instance used by Vyro AI applications
vulnerabilities.description: An Elasticsearch cluster hosting logs, AI prompts, bearer authentication tokens, and user agents for Vyro AI's apps (ImagineArt, Chatly, Chatbotx) was left without any authentication, authorization, or network restrictions. The open instance was indexed by IoT search engines, making it discoverable publicly. An attacker can read, copy, modify, or delete the stored data, harvest bearer tokens to hijack user accounts, exfiltrate AI prompt history, and potentially manipulate or delete logs.
vulnerabilities.remediation: Enable native Elasticsearch security features (TLS, role‑based access control, password authentication). Restrict network access via firewall or security groups to trusted IP ranges or VPN. Deploy a reverse proxy with authentication. Regularly audit cloud and on‑prem configurations for open ports. Rotate compromised bearer tokens and enforce short‑lived tokens.
workarounds: Place the Elasticsearch node behind a VPN or bastion host until proper security is configured.
Apply IP allow‑list rules at the cloud provider level to limit exposure.

vulnerabilities.title: DSLRoot, Proxies, and the Threat of ‘Legal Botnets’
vulnerabilities.original_title: DSLRoot, Proxies, and the Threat of ‘Legal Botnets’
vulnerabilities.content_snippet: The cybersecurity community on Reddit responded in disbelief this month when a self-described Air National Guard member with top secret security clearance began questioning the arrangement they’d made with company called DSLRoot, which was paying $250 a month to plug a pair of laptops into the...
vulnerabilities.summary: DSLRoot client installer contains hardcoded administrative credentials and vendor‑specific exploits that allow remote control of residential networking equipment.
vulnerabilities.description: The reverse‑engineered DSLRoot installer contacts the command‑and‑control domain proxysource.net and uses hard‑coded admin credentials to log into DSL modems and Wi‑Fi routers. Vendor‑specific exploits are pre‑loaded, allowing the operator to reconfigure the device, install proxy services, enumerate nearby Wi‑Fi networks and route traffic through the compromised host. The software runs as a background service, spawning multiple command prompts, and can be used to create a “legal botnet” that resells the victim’s IP address to third‑party customers. Because the credentials are static and the exploit code is bundled with the installer, any user who runs the installer unintentionally becomes part of the botnet.
affected_products: Wi‑Fi routers used in host premises
affected_companies: Various generic DSL modem and Wi‑Fi router manufacturers
vendors: Various generic DSL modem and Wi‑Fi router manufacturers
products_versions: Residential DSL modems with default admin credentials
vulnerabilities.remediation: 1. Immediately uninstall the DSLRoot client software from all compromised hosts. 2. Reset DSL modems and Wi‑Fi routers to factory defaults and change all administrative passwords to strong, unique values. 3. Disable remote management interfaces (e.g., TR‑069, SSH, Telnet) on residential equipment. 4. Block outbound traffic to proxysource.net, dslroot.com, and related domains at the firewall/DNS level. 5. Conduct a full forensic scan for additional persistence mechanisms.
workarounds: Network‑segment the residential equipment from critical LAN devices.
Use a dedicated ISP‑provided router with firmware that does not allow default credentials.
Monitor and alert on unusual outbound connections to known proxy C2 domains.
references: KrebsOnSecurity article (2025‑08‑26) – DSLRoot, Proxies, and the Threat of ‘Legal Botnets’
Infrawatch analysis – reverse engineered DSLRoot software

vulnerabilities.title: Mobile Phishers Target Brokerage Accounts in ‘Ramp and Dump’ Cashout Scheme
vulnerabilities.original_title: Mobile Phishers Target Brokerage Accounts in ‘Ramp and Dump’ Cashout Scheme
vulnerabilities.content_snippet: Cybercriminal groups peddling sophisticated phishing kits that convert stolen card data into mobile wallets have recently shifted their focus to targeting customers of brokerage services, new research shows. Undeterred by security controls at these trading platforms that block users from wiring fund...
vulnerabilities.summary: Phishable SMS/voice OTP used for mobile wallet provisioning and brokerage account login enables credential theft and unauthorized account access.
vulnerabilities.description: The phishing kits sold on Telegram target the single-factor OTP sent via SMS, voice call, or automated call that is used to verify a user’s identity when provisioning a mobile wallet or logging into a brokerage account. Attackers deliver a crafted lure (e‑mail, iMessage, RCS) that directs the victim to a spoofed login page, captures the username/password, and then prompts the victim to enter the OTP that the victim’s bank sends to their phone. Because the OTP is the sole second factor, the attacker can immediately use the captured credentials and OTP to add the victim’s payment card to a mobile wallet or to log into the brokerage platform and execute trades. The vulnerability is not a software bug but a design weakness: reliance on a single, phishable OTP for high‑value actions.
affected_products: Any financial institution relying on SMS/voice OTP for MFA
exploit_kits: Chinese-language mobile phishing kits sold on Telegram
vulnerabilities.remediation: Financial institutions should deprecate SMS/voice OTP as a sole second factor for high‑risk actions. Implement push‑notification based MFA, hardware security keys (U2F/FIDO2), or risk‑based authentication that requires additional verification for new devices or large transactions. Enforce enrollment of cards into mobile wallets only through the bank’s official mobile app with out‑of‑band verification. Provide user education on phishing and encourage disabling SMS OTP where possible.
workarounds: Disable SMS/voice OTP for mobile wallet provisioning and brokerage logins.
Require app‑based push approval for all login attempts.
Enable transaction limits and manual review for large trades from newly added accounts.
Use device binding and geolocation checks to flag logins from unexpected locations.
references: KrebsOnSecurity article "Mobile Phishers Target Brokerage Accounts in ‘Ramp and Dump’ Cashout Scheme" (2025-08-15)
FBI advisory seeking victims of ramp‑and‑dump (Feb 2025)

vulnerabilities.title: Mobile Phishers Target Brokerage Accounts in ‘Ramp and Dump’ Cashout Scheme
vulnerabilities.original_title: Mobile Phishers Target Brokerage Accounts in ‘Ramp and Dump’ Cashout Scheme
vulnerabilities.content_snippet: Cybercriminal groups peddling sophisticated phishing kits that convert stolen card data into mobile wallets have recently shifted their focus to targeting customers of brokerage services, new research shows. Undeterred by security controls at these trading platforms that block users from wiring fund...
vulnerabilities.summary: Mobile phishing kits sold on Telegram enable large‑scale credential harvesting and automated OTP capture for financial accounts.
vulnerabilities.description: The kits provide ready‑made templates for luring victims via iMessage, RCS, or SMS, spoofing brokerage login pages, and automating the capture of one‑time passcodes. The kits also include scripts to coordinate multiple compromised accounts for price manipulation (ramp‑and‑dump). The availability of these kits lowers the barrier for attackers to launch large‑scale fraud.
affected_products: Custom phishing landing pages mimicking brokerage platforms
exploit_kits: Chinese-language mobile phishing kits sold on Telegram
vulnerabilities.remediation: Disrupt distribution channels (Telegram groups) through takedown requests and law‑enforcement cooperation. Implement email/SMS phishing detection, domain impersonation monitoring, and DMARC/DKIM enforcement. Financial institutions should monitor for credential stuffing and rapid account creation from new devices.
workarounds: Block known malicious Telegram channels at the network level.
Deploy anti‑phishing training and simulated phishing campaigns for customers.
references: Telegram channel screenshots referenced in article

vulnerabilities.title: Cisco fixes high-severity IOS XR flaws enabling image bypass and DoS
vulnerabilities.original_title: Cisco fixes high-severity IOS XR flaws enabling image bypass and DoS
vulnerabilities.content_snippet: Cisco addressed multiple high-severity IOS XR vulnerabilities that can allow ISO image verification bypass and trigger DoS conditions. Cisco addressed multiple vulnerabilities in IOS XR software as part of its semiannual Software Security Advisory Bundled Publication published on September 10, 2025....
vulnerabilities.summary: ARP broadcast storm vulnerability in Cisco IOS XR that can be triggered by an unauthenticated adjacent attacker, causing a denial‑of‑service condition.
vulnerabilities.description: The ARP implementation on the management interface of Cisco IOS XR does not properly rate‑limit or validate a high volume of ARP requests. An attacker on the same L2 segment can flood the interface with crafted ARP packets, overwhelming the ARP processing engine, degrading performance, and eventually rendering the device unresponsive.
products_versions: Cisco IOS XR (all versions prior to the September 2025 security patch)
vulnerabilities.remediation: Apply the Cisco IOS XR security advisory patch released on 2025‑09‑10. Upgrade to the fixed software version and verify that the patch is installed.
workarounds: Disable ARP on the management interface if not required.
Implement strict L2 segmentation to isolate management interfaces.
Enable rate‑limiting or ACLs that limit ARP traffic on the management interface.

vulnerabilities.title: Cisco fixes high-severity IOS XR flaws enabling image bypass and DoS
vulnerabilities.original_title: Cisco fixes high-severity IOS XR flaws enabling image bypass and DoS
vulnerabilities.content_snippet: Cisco addressed multiple high-severity IOS XR vulnerabilities that can allow ISO image verification bypass and trigger DoS conditions. Cisco addressed multiple vulnerabilities in IOS XR software as part of its semiannual Software Security Advisory Bundled Publication published on September 10, 2025....
vulnerabilities.summary: Image verification bypass in Cisco IOS XR installation process allowing insertion of unsigned files into an ISO image.
vulnerabilities.description: During the installation of an .iso image, Cisco IOS XR fails to fully validate the contents of the archive. An attacker with root‑system privileges can modify the ISO, add unsigned binaries, and trigger activation. The bypass of the cryptographic signature check permits execution of arbitrary code with full system privileges.
affected_products: Cisco IOS XR Software (image installation/activation component)
products_versions: Cisco IOS XR (all versions prior to the September 2025 security patch)
vulnerabilities.remediation: Install the patch released in the Cisco IOS XR semi‑annual security advisory (Sept 2025). Verify that the image verification logic has been updated and that only signed images are accepted.
workarounds: Restrict root access to the management plane.
Use external image signing and verification tools before loading images onto the device.
Disable local installation of unsigned images via configuration.

vulnerabilities.title: Cisco fixes high-severity IOS XR flaws enabling image bypass and DoS
vulnerabilities.original_title: Cisco fixes high-severity IOS XR flaws enabling image bypass and DoS
vulnerabilities.content_snippet: Cisco addressed multiple high-severity IOS XR vulnerabilities that can allow ISO image verification bypass and trigger DoS conditions. Cisco addressed multiple vulnerabilities in IOS XR software as part of its semiannual Software Security Advisory Bundled Publication published on September 10, 2025....
vulnerabilities.summary: ACL bypass vulnerability on Cisco IOS XR management interface allowing remote attackers to bypass SSH, NetConf, and gRPC ACLs.
vulnerabilities.description: The management interface of Cisco IOS XR does not enforce configured ACLs for certain services (SSH, NetConf, gRPC). An attacker can connect to these services from an unrestricted network segment, effectively bypassing the intended access controls.
affected_products: Cisco IOS XR Software (management interface ACL handling)
products_versions: Cisco IOS XR (all versions prior to the September 2025 security patch)
vulnerabilities.remediation: Apply the Cisco IOS XR patch released in the September 2025 advisory. Review and re‑apply ACLs after patching to ensure proper enforcement.
workarounds: Disable unused management services (SSH, NetConf, gRPC) until the patch is applied.
Place the management interface behind a firewall that enforces external ACLs.
Enable strong authentication and limit source IP ranges via out‑of‑band controls.

vulnerabilities.title: Android Security Alert: Google Patches 120 Flaws, Including Two Zero-Days Under Attack
vulnerabilities.original_title: Android Security Alert: Google Patches 120 Flaws, Including Two Zero-Days Under Attack
vulnerabilities.content_snippet: Google has shipped security updates to address 120 security flaws in its Android operating system as part of its monthly fixes for September 2025, including two issues that it said have been exploited in targeted attacks. The vulnerabilities are listed below - CVE-2025-38352 (CVSS score: 7.4) - A pr...
vulnerabilities.summary: Privilege escalation vulnerability in the Linux Kernel component of Android allowing local attackers to gain elevated privileges.
vulnerabilities.description: The vulnerability resides in a flaw within the Linux kernel used by Android devices. An attacker with local access can exploit improper input validation or race conditions to execute arbitrary code in kernel mode, resulting in privilege escalation from a regular user to root. The flaw has been observed in the wild and is being actively exploited in targeted campaigns.
products_versions: Android OS versions prior to September 2025 security patch
vulnerabilities.remediation: Update Android devices with the September 2025 security patch released by Google. Enable automatic system updates to ensure timely installation of future patches.
workarounds: Restrict installation of apps from unknown sources.
Enforce SELinux in enforcing mode.
Use mobile device management (MDM) solutions to enforce security policies.

vulnerabilities.title: Android Security Alert: Google Patches 120 Flaws, Including Two Zero-Days Under Attack
vulnerabilities.original_title: Android Security Alert: Google Patches 120 Flaws, Including Two Zero-Days Under Attack
vulnerabilities.content_snippet: Google has shipped security updates to address 120 security flaws in its Android operating system as part of its monthly fixes for September 2025, including two issues that it said have been exploited in targeted attacks. The vulnerabilities are listed below - CVE-2025-38352 (CVSS score: 7.4) - A pr...
vulnerabilities.summary: Undisclosed vulnerability in Android (details not fully released) that is being exploited in targeted attacks.
vulnerabilities.description: While Google has not disclosed full technical details, CVE-2025-48543 is reported as a vulnerability actively exploited in the wild. Preliminary analysis suggests a remote code execution vector that may be triggered via a crafted network packet or malicious media file, requiring user interaction to open the malicious content.
products_versions: Android OS versions prior to September 2025 security patch
vulnerabilities.remediation: Apply the September 2025 Android security patch from Google. Until full details are released, limit exposure by disabling unnecessary network services and avoiding opening unsolicited files.
workarounds: Disable Bluetooth, NFC, and other radios when not in use.
Use a reputable mobile security suite that can block malicious payloads.

vulnerabilities.title: CISA warns of malware deployed through Ivanti EPMM flaws
vulnerabilities.original_title: CISA warns of malware deployed through Ivanti EPMM flaws
vulnerabilities.content_snippet: The U.S. Cybersecurity and Infrastructure Security Agency (CISA) disclosed two malware strains found in a network compromised via Ivanti EPMM flaws. The U.S. Cybersecurity and Infrastructure Security Agency (CISA) published technical details of two malware families that were discovered in the networ...
vulnerabilities.summary: Authentication bypass in Ivanti Endpoint Manager Mobile (EPMM) allowing unauthenticated access to protected resources.
vulnerabilities.description: The vulnerability permits an attacker to bypass authentication checks in the EPMM web service, granting access to internal APIs without valid credentials. When chained with CVE-2025-4428, it enables remote code execution without any prior authentication.
products_versions: Ivanti Endpoint Manager Mobile versions prior to 11.12.0.5, 12.3.0.2, 12.4.0.2, and 12.5.0.1
vulnerabilities.remediation: Upgrade Ivanti EPMM to version 11.12.0.5, 12.3.0.2, 12.4.0.2, or 12.5.0.1 or later where the issue is fixed.
workarounds: Restrict network access to the EPMM management interface to trusted IP ranges.
Enforce strong authentication and disable unused API endpoints.

vulnerabilities.title: CISA warns of malware deployed through Ivanti EPMM flaws
vulnerabilities.original_title: CISA warns of malware deployed through Ivanti EPMM flaws
vulnerabilities.content_snippet: The U.S. Cybersecurity and Infrastructure Security Agency (CISA) disclosed two malware strains found in a network compromised via Ivanti EPMM flaws. The U.S. Cybersecurity and Infrastructure Security Agency (CISA) published technical details of two malware families that were discovered in the networ...
vulnerabilities.summary: Remote code execution vulnerability in Ivanti Endpoint Manager Mobile (EPMM) that allows execution of arbitrary code on the server.
vulnerabilities.description: An attacker can send specially crafted requests to the /mifs/rs/api/v2/ endpoint, triggering deserialization of untrusted data and resulting in arbitrary code execution. The vulnerability is often chained with CVE-2025-4427 to bypass authentication before executing code.
products_versions: Ivanti Endpoint Manager Mobile versions prior to 11.12.0.5, 12.3.0.2, 12.4.0.2, and 12.5.0.1
vulnerabilities.remediation: Upgrade Ivanti EPMM to version 11.12.0.5, 12.3.0.2, 12.4.0.2, or 12.5.0.1 or later where the flaw is patched.
workarounds: Block external access to the /mifs/rs/api/v2/ endpoint.
Deploy a web application firewall (WAF) with rules to detect and block malicious payloads.

vulnerabilities.title: Phoenix RowHammer Attack Bypasses Advanced DDR5 Memory Protections in 109 Seconds
vulnerabilities.original_title: Phoenix RowHammer Attack Bypasses Advanced DDR5 Memory Protections in 109 Seconds
vulnerabilities.content_snippet: A team of academics from ETH Zürich and Google has discovered a new variant of a RowHammer attack targeting Double Data Rate 5 (DDR5) memory chips from South Korean semiconductor vendor SK Hynix. The RowHammer attack variant, codenamed Phoenix (CVE-2025-6202, CVSS score: 7.1), is capable of bypassin...
vulnerabilities.summary: Phoenix RowHammer attack bypasses advanced DDR5 memory protection mechanisms in SK Hynix chips, enabling bit flips within 109 seconds.
vulnerabilities.description: The Phoenix variant of the RowHammer fault injection technique targets DDR5 DRAM modules from SK Hynix. By rapidly hammering specific rows, the attack overcomes built‑in mitigation features such as Target Row Refresh (TRR) and probabilistic adjacent row activation. Within 109 seconds the attacker can induce deterministic bit flips in adjacent rows, potentially leading to privilege escalation, data corruption, or denial of service. The attack requires the ability to execute code that can generate high‑frequency memory accesses, but does not need kernel privileges.
products_versions: SK Hynix DDR5 DRAM (all generations released up to 2025)
vulnerabilities.remediation: No firmware or hardware patch is currently available for the affected DDR5 chips. Vendors should work with SK Hynix to release updated silicon or microcode. In the meantime, system integrators can mitigate risk by enabling ECC memory, increasing DRAM refresh rates, applying OS‑level RowHammer mitigations (e.g., page frame randomization, memory allocation throttling), and disabling over‑clocking of memory.
workarounds: Enable ECC on systems that support it
Increase DRAM refresh interval via BIOS/UEFI settings
Apply kernel patches that limit row activation rates (e.g., row activation throttling)
Use memory allocation randomization to reduce predictability of target rows

vulnerabilities.title: New Study Warns Several Free iOS and Android VPN Apps Leak Data
vulnerabilities.original_title: New Study Warns Several Free iOS and Android VPN Apps Leak Data
vulnerabilities.content_snippet: A Zimperium zLabs analysis of 800 free Android and iOS VPN apps exposes critical security flaws, including the Heartbleed bug, excessive system permissions, and non-transparent data practices. Learn how these 'privacy' tools are actually major security risks, especially for BYOD environments.
vulnerabilities.summary: Heartbleed OpenSSL vulnerability allowing memory disclosure
vulnerabilities.description: The Heartbleed bug (CVE-2014-0160) in OpenSSL's TLS heartbeat extension allows an unauthenticated remote attacker to read up to 64 KB of process memory per request, potentially exposing private keys, credentials, and other sensitive data. VPN apps that bundle vulnerable OpenSSL versions inherit this flaw, enabling data leakage without user interaction.
affected_products: OpenSSL library used in affected VPN apps
affected_companies: Various free VPN app developers (anonymous in study)
vendors: Various free VPN app developers (anonymous in study)
vulnerabilities.remediation: Update OpenSSL to version 1.0.1g or later; ensure VPN apps are rebuilt with patched libraries; verify app vendor has applied the fix.
workarounds: Disable heartbeat extension via configuration if possible
Use VPN apps that rely on alternative TLS libraries (e.g., BoringSSL, LibreSSL)

vulnerabilities.title: New Study Warns Several Free iOS and Android VPN Apps Leak Data
vulnerabilities.original_title: New Study Warns Several Free iOS and Android VPN Apps Leak Data
vulnerabilities.content_snippet: A Zimperium zLabs analysis of 800 free Android and iOS VPN apps exposes critical security flaws, including the Heartbleed bug, excessive system permissions, and non-transparent data practices. Learn how these 'privacy' tools are actually major security risks, especially for BYOD environments.
vulnerabilities.summary: Excessive system permissions granted to free VPN apps
vulnerabilities.description: Many free VPN apps request broad permissions (e.g., device admin, location, contacts, storage) that are unnecessary for VPN functionality. Malicious or compromised apps can leverage these permissions to exfiltrate data, modify device settings, or install additional payloads.
affected_products: Various free Android and iOS VPN applications
affected_companies: Various free VPN app developers (anonymous in study)
vendors: Various free VPN app developers (anonymous in study)
vulnerabilities.remediation: Review and restrict app permissions via OS settings or MDM policies; prefer VPN apps with minimal permission sets; uninstall apps that request unnecessary privileges.
workarounds: Use Android's permission manager to deny non-essential permissions
Enable iOS App Tracking Transparency and limit background refresh

vulnerabilities.title: New Study Warns Several Free iOS and Android VPN Apps Leak Data
vulnerabilities.original_title: New Study Warns Several Free iOS and Android VPN Apps Leak Data
vulnerabilities.content_snippet: A Zimperium zLabs analysis of 800 free Android and iOS VPN apps exposes critical security flaws, including the Heartbleed bug, excessive system permissions, and non-transparent data practices. Learn how these 'privacy' tools are actually major security risks, especially for BYOD environments.
vulnerabilities.summary: Non‑transparent data collection and telemetry in free VPN apps
vulnerabilities.description: The study found that several free VPN apps transmit user browsing metadata, device identifiers, and location data to third‑party servers without clear disclosure, violating privacy expectations and potentially aiding profiling.
affected_products: Various free Android and iOS VPN applications
affected_companies: Various free VPN app developers (anonymous in study)
vendors: Various free VPN app developers (anonymous in study)
vulnerabilities.remediation: Select VPN providers with transparent privacy policies; use network traffic monitoring to detect unexpected outbound connections; disable telemetry where possible.
workarounds: Block known telemetry domains via firewall or DNS filtering
Use VPN apps that are open‑source and audit their code

vulnerabilities.title: Hackers Exploit Pandoc CVE-2025-51591 to Target AWS IMDS and Steal EC2 IAM Credentials
vulnerabilities.original_title: Hackers Exploit Pandoc CVE-2025-51591 to Target AWS IMDS and Steal EC2 IAM Credentials
vulnerabilities.content_snippet: Cloud security company Wiz has revealed that it uncovered in-the-wild exploitation of a security flaw in a Linux utility called Pandoc as part of attacks designed to infiltrate Amazon Web Services (AWS) Instance Metadata Service (IMDS). The vulnerability in question is CVE-2025-51591 (CVSS score: 6....
vulnerabilities.summary: Server-Side Request Forgery (SSRF) in Pandoc allows remote attackers to access the AWS Instance Metadata Service (IMDS) and retrieve IAM credentials from EC2 instances.
vulnerabilities.description: Pandoc processes user‑supplied input files and can be tricked into performing HTTP requests based on crafted markup. A flaw in the request handling logic permits an attacker to supply a URL that points to the AWS Instance Metadata Service (169.254.169.254). When exploited, the vulnerable Pandoc instance issues a request to IMDS, retrieves temporary IAM role credentials, and returns them to the attacker. The vulnerability is classified as SSRF with a CVSS v3.1 base score of 6.5.
affected_products: Amazon Web Services (AWS) EC2 instances (via IMDS)
products_versions: Pandoc versions prior to the patched release (exact version not disclosed in the article)
vulnerabilities.remediation: Upgrade Pandoc to a version that includes the SSRF fix (released after CVE‑2025‑51591). Apply the latest security patches from the Pandoc project. Enforce AWS IMDSv2 (token‑based) and restrict metadata IP access from containers and untrusted workloads.
workarounds: Block outbound traffic to 169.254.169.254 at the network perimeter or host firewall.
Run Pandoc inside a sandboxed container with egress filtering.
Disable Pandoc functionality on systems that do not require it.

vulnerabilities.title: Hackers Exploit Pandoc CVE-2025-51591 to Target AWS IMDS and Steal EC2 IAM Credentials
vulnerabilities.original_title: Hackers Exploit Pandoc CVE-2025-51591 to Target AWS IMDS and Steal EC2 IAM Credentials
vulnerabilities.content_snippet: Cloud security company Wiz has revealed that it uncovered in-the-wild exploitation of a security flaw in a Linux utility called Pandoc as part of attacks designed to infiltrate Amazon Web Services (AWS) Instance Metadata Service (IMDS). The vulnerability in question is CVE-2025-51591 (CVSS score: 6....
vulnerabilities.summary: Server-Side Request Forgery (SSRF) in Pandoc allows attackers to access AWS Instance Metadata Service (IMDS) and retrieve EC2 IAM role credentials.
vulnerabilities.description: Pandoc fails to properly validate URLs supplied to certain filters and extensions, enabling an attacker to craft a malicious document that triggers an outbound request to arbitrary internal resources. In cloud environments, this can be leveraged to issue HTTP requests to the AWS Instance Metadata Service (169.254.169.254), allowing the attacker to retrieve temporary IAM role credentials associated with the EC2 instance. The vulnerability is classified as CVE-2025-51591 with a CVSS v3.1 base score of 6.5.
products_versions: Pandoc versions prior to the security release (exact version range not disclosed in the article)
vulnerabilities.remediation: Upgrade Pandoc to the version that includes the SSRF fix (released by the upstream project). If an immediate upgrade is not possible, apply the vendor‑provided patch or disable the vulnerable filters/extensions. Additionally, enforce IMDSv2 on all EC2 instances and restrict outbound network access from containers or processes that run Pandoc.
workarounds: Run Pandoc in a sandboxed environment with no network egress.
Disable or avoid using the specific Pandoc filters/extensions that trigger URL fetching.
Configure host‑based firewalls or security groups to block access to 169.254.169.254 from the host running Pandoc.

vulnerabilities.title: CISA Flags TP-Link Router Flaws CVE-2023-50224 and CVE-2025-9377 as Actively Exploited
vulnerabilities.original_title: CISA Flags TP-Link Router Flaws CVE-2023-50224 and CVE-2025-9377 as Actively Exploited
vulnerabilities.content_snippet: The U.S. Cybersecurity and Infrastructure Security Agency (CISA) on Wednesday added two security flaws impacting TP-Link wireless routers to its Known Exploited Vulnerabilities (KEV) catalog, noting that there is evidence of them being exploited in the wild. The vulnerabilities in question are liste...
vulnerabilities.summary: Authentication bypass vulnerability in TP-Link wireless routers allowing attackers to gain unauthorized access.
vulnerabilities.description: The vulnerability allows an unauthenticated attacker to bypass the router's authentication mechanism by spoofing legitimate credentials. Successful exploitation grants administrative access to the device, enabling configuration changes, traffic interception, and further pivoting within the network.
products_versions: TP-Link Archer series (specific firmware versions vulnerable)
Other TP-Link wireless router models prior to latest security patches
vulnerabilities.remediation: Upgrade to the latest firmware released by TP-Link that addresses CVE-2023-50224. Verify firmware version after update and reset device credentials.
workarounds: Disable remote management interfaces until patches are applied.
Restrict management access to trusted internal networks only.
Change default admin passwords to strong, unique passwords.

vulnerabilities.title: CISA Flags TP-Link Router Flaws CVE-2023-50224 and CVE-2025-9377 as Actively Exploited
vulnerabilities.original_title: CISA Flags TP-Link Router Flaws CVE-2023-50224 and CVE-2025-9377 as Actively Exploited
vulnerabilities.content_snippet: The U.S. Cybersecurity and Infrastructure Security Agency (CISA) on Wednesday added two security flaws impacting TP-Link wireless routers to its Known Exploited Vulnerabilities (KEV) catalog, noting that there is evidence of them being exploited in the wild. The vulnerabilities in question are liste...
vulnerabilities.summary: TP-Link router vulnerability flagged by CISA as actively exploited; details not publicly disclosed.
vulnerabilities.description: While specific technical details are limited, CISA's inclusion of CVE-2025-9377 in the KEV catalog indicates that attackers are successfully exploiting this flaw in the wild to gain unauthorized control over TP-Link routers.
affected_products: TP-Link wireless routers (specific models not disclosed)
products_versions: TP-Link Archer series (specific firmware versions vulnerable)
Other TP-Link wireless router models prior to latest security patches
vulnerabilities.remediation: Apply any firmware updates released by TP-Link addressing CVE-2025-9377. If no patch is available, follow mitigation steps such as disabling remote management and isolating the devices from untrusted networks.
workarounds: Disable WAN-side management interfaces.
Enforce strong, unique administrative passwords.
Place routers behind a firewall with strict inbound rule sets.

vulnerabilities.title: From LFI to RCE: Active Exploitation Detected in Gladinet and TrioFox Vulnerability
vulnerabilities.original_title: From LFI to RCE: Active Exploitation Detected in Gladinet and TrioFox Vulnerability
vulnerabilities.content_snippet: Cybersecurity company Huntress said it has observed active in-the-wild exploitation of an unpatched security flaw impacting Gladinet CentreStack and TrioFox products. The zero-day vulnerability, tracked as CVE-2025-11371 (CVSS score: 6.1), is an unauthenticated local file inclusion bug that allows u...
vulnerabilities.summary: Unauthenticated Local File Inclusion (LFI) in Gladinet CentreStack and TrioFox products allowing disclosure of system files and potential remote code execution.
vulnerabilities.description: The vulnerability is an unauthenticated LFI bug that can be triggered by sending specially crafted requests to vulnerable endpoints. The flaw enables an attacker to read arbitrary files on the server, including configuration files and credentials. When combined with other weaknesses, the LFI can be leveraged to achieve remote code execution, as indicated by the article title. Active exploitation in the wild has been observed.
products_versions: All versions of Gladinet CentreStack prior to the upcoming patch
All versions of TrioFox prior to the upcoming patch
vulnerabilities.remediation: Apply the vendor-supplied patch as soon as it becomes available. Upgrade to the latest released version of Gladinet CentreStack and TrioFox. If a patch is not yet released, restrict access to the vulnerable endpoints and implement compensating controls.
workarounds: Restrict network access to the affected services to trusted hosts only.
Disable or block the vulnerable file inclusion endpoint via a web application firewall (WAF).
Enforce least‑privilege file system permissions for the web service account.
Monitor and alert on anomalous file access patterns.

vulnerabilities.title: State-Sponsored Hackers Exploiting Libraesva Email Security Gateway Vulnerability
vulnerabilities.original_title: State-Sponsored Hackers Exploiting Libraesva Email Security Gateway Vulnerability
vulnerabilities.content_snippet: Libraesva has released a security update to address a vulnerability in its Email Security Gateway (ESG) solution that it said has been exploited by state-sponsored threat actors. The vulnerability, tracked as CVE-2025-59689, carries a CVSS score of 6.1, indicating medium severity. "Libraesva ESG is ...
vulnerabilities.summary: Command injection vulnerability in Libraesva Email Security Gateway (ESG) that can be triggered by a specially crafted malicious email.
vulnerabilities.description: The ESG parses inbound email content to apply security policies. A flaw in the parsing logic allows an attacker to embed malicious commands within the email body or headers. When the ESG processes the email, the injected commands are executed with the privileges of the ESG service, potentially leading to remote code execution, data exfiltration, and disruption of email services. State-sponsored actors have been observed exploiting this flaw in the wild.
products_versions: All Libraesva Email Security Gateway versions prior to the September 2025 security update
vulnerabilities.remediation: Apply the security update released by Libraesva that patches the command injection flaw. Verify that the ESG version is updated to the patched release and restart the service as per vendor guidance.
workarounds: Temporarily block or quarantine emails containing suspicious payloads or unusual header fields.
Disable any optional processing modules in ESG that handle the affected email content until the patch is applied.
Enforce strict content‑type validation and limit the execution of embedded scripts.

vulnerabilities.title: State-Sponsored Hackers Exploiting Libraesva Email Security Gateway Vulnerability
vulnerabilities.original_title: State-Sponsored Hackers Exploiting Libraesva Email Security Gateway Vulnerability
vulnerabilities.content_snippet: Libraesva has released a security update to address a vulnerability in its Email Security Gateway (ESG) solution that it said has been exploited by state-sponsored threat actors. The vulnerability, tracked as CVE-2025-59689, carries a CVSS score of 6.1, indicating medium severity. "Libraesva ESG is ...
vulnerabilities.summary: Command injection vulnerability in Libraesva Email Security Gateway (ESG) triggered by a specially crafted email.
vulnerabilities.description: A command injection flaw exists in the email processing component of Libraesva ESG. When the gateway parses a maliciously crafted email containing specially formatted content, it fails to properly sanitize input before passing it to the underlying operating system command interpreter. An attacker who can deliver such an email to the gateway can execute arbitrary OS commands with the privileges of the ESG service, potentially leading to further compromise of the email infrastructure.
products_versions: All Libraesva ESG versions prior to the September 2025 security update
vulnerabilities.remediation: Apply the security update released by Libraesva that sanitizes the input handling in the email processing module. Upgrade to the latest patched version of ESG.
workarounds: Block or quarantine emails with suspicious attachments or content types until the patch is applied.
Restrict the ESG service account to least‑privilege permissions.
Deploy network segmentation to isolate the ESG from critical internal systems.

vulnerabilities.title: Zimbra Zero-Day Exploited to Target Brazilian Military via Malicious ICS Files
vulnerabilities.original_title: Zimbra Zero-Day Exploited to Target Brazilian Military via Malicious ICS Files
vulnerabilities.content_snippet: A now patched security vulnerability in Zimbra Collaboration was exploited as a zero-day earlier this year in cyber attacks targeting the Brazilian military. Tracked as CVE-2025-27915 (CVSS score: 5.4), the vulnerability is a stored cross-site scripting (XSS) vulnerability in the Classic Web Client ...
vulnerabilities.summary: Stored cross‑site scripting (XSS) in Zimbra Collaboration Classic Web Client via unsanitized HTML in uploaded .ics calendar files.
vulnerabilities.description: An attacker can upload a malicious iCalendar (.ics) file containing crafted HTML/JavaScript to the Zimbra Classic Web Client. The server fails to properly sanitize the HTML content, allowing the malicious script to be stored and later executed in the browser of any user who views the calendar entry. This stored XSS can be leveraged to steal session cookies, perform actions on behalf of the victim, or deliver further payloads. The vulnerability was exploited in the wild as a zero‑day against the Brazilian military before a patch was released.
products_versions: Zimbra Collaboration Suite (Classic Web Client) versions prior to the October 2025 security patch
vulnerabilities.remediation: Apply the official Zimbra patch released for CVE‑2025‑27915. Upgrade to the latest Zimbra Collaboration Suite version. Ensure that input sanitization for calendar file imports is enabled and that the Classic Web Client is updated or disabled if not needed.
workarounds: Disable the Classic Web Client and enforce use of the newer web client.
Block or filter .ics file uploads at the perimeter firewall or web application firewall.
Implement strict Content‑Security‑Policy (CSP) headers to mitigate script execution.

vulnerabilities.title: WhatsApp Patches Zero-Click Exploit Targeting iOS and macOS Devices
vulnerabilities.original_title: WhatsApp Patches Zero-Click Exploit Targeting iOS and macOS Devices
vulnerabilities.content_snippet: WhatsApp has addressed a security vulnerability in its messaging apps for Apple iOS and macOS that it said may have been exploited in the wild in conjunction with a recently disclosed Apple flaw in targeted zero-day attacks. The vulnerability, CVE-2025-55177 (CVSS score: 5.4), relates to a case of i...
vulnerabilities.summary: Insufficient authorization of linked device synchronization messages in WhatsApp for iOS and macOS allows zero-click remote exploitation.
vulnerabilities.description: The vulnerability stems from improper authorization checks when processing linked‑device synchronization messages. An attacker can craft a malicious message that triggers code execution or data leakage on the target device without any user interaction (zero‑click). The exploit was observed in the wild in conjunction with a separate Apple zero‑day that bypasses platform mitigations, enabling targeted attacks against iOS and macOS devices running WhatsApp.
products_versions: WhatsApp for iOS versions prior to the August 2025 security update
WhatsApp for macOS versions prior to the August 2025 security update
vulnerabilities.remediation: Update WhatsApp to the latest version released by Meta that contains the fix for CVE‑2025‑55177. Ensure the operating system is also up to date with the latest Apple security patches.
workarounds: Disable the "Linked Devices" feature in WhatsApp settings until the patch is applied.
Restrict background data sync for WhatsApp via OS privacy settings.
Use mobile device management (MDM) policies to block WhatsApp on devices that cannot be patched immediately.
references: Apple Security Advisory (related zero‑day) – reference not disclosed

vulnerabilities.title: CISA Adds Three Exploited Vulnerabilities to KEV Catalog Affecting Citrix and Git
vulnerabilities.original_title: CISA Adds Three Exploited Vulnerabilities to KEV Catalog Affecting Citrix and Git
vulnerabilities.content_snippet: The U.S. Cybersecurity and Infrastructure Security Agency (CISA) on Monday added three security flaws impacting Citrix Session Recording and Git to its Known Exploited Vulnerabilities (KEV) catalog, based on evidence of active exploitation. The list of vulnerabilities is as follows - CVE-2024-8068 (...
vulnerabilities.summary: Improper privilege management vulnerability in Citrix Session Recording
vulnerabilities.description: An improper privilege management vulnerability in Citrix Session Recording that could allow an attacker to escalate privileges or access sensitive information.
products_versions: Specific versions not mentioned in the article
vulnerabilities.remediation: Apply the security patch or update provided by Citrix to address this vulnerability.
workarounds: Restrict access to Citrix Session Recording components
Implement network segmentation to limit exposure

vulnerabilities.title: CISA Warns of Exploited Apple, Kentico, Microsoft Vulnerabilities
vulnerabilities.original_title: CISA Warns of Exploited Apple, Kentico, Microsoft Vulnerabilities
vulnerabilities.content_snippet: Leading to code execution, authentication bypass, and privilege escalation, the flaws were added to CISA’s KEV list. The post CISA Warns of Exploited Apple, Kentico, Microsoft Vulnerabilities appeared first on SecurityWeek.
vulnerabilities.summary: Code execution, authentication bypass, and privilege escalation vulnerability affecting Apple products.
vulnerabilities.description: A vulnerability in Apple software that allows remote attackers to execute arbitrary code, bypass authentication mechanisms, and elevate privileges, leading to full system compromise.
vulnerabilities.remediation: Apply the latest security patches released by Apple.
workarounds: Enable automatic updates
Restrict network access to vulnerable services

vulnerabilities.title: CISA Warns of Exploited Apple, Kentico, Microsoft Vulnerabilities
vulnerabilities.original_title: CISA Warns of Exploited Apple, Kentico, Microsoft Vulnerabilities
vulnerabilities.content_snippet: Leading to code execution, authentication bypass, and privilege escalation, the flaws were added to CISA’s KEV list. The post CISA Warns of Exploited Apple, Kentico, Microsoft Vulnerabilities appeared first on SecurityWeek.
vulnerabilities.summary: Code execution and privilege escalation vulnerability affecting Kentico CMS.
vulnerabilities.description: A vulnerability in Kentico content management system that permits remote attackers to execute code and gain elevated privileges within the application.
vulnerabilities.remediation: Update to the latest patched version of Kentico CMS.
workarounds: Restrict access to the CMS admin interface
Use web application firewall rules to block malicious payloads

vulnerabilities.title: CISA Warns of Exploited Apple, Kentico, Microsoft Vulnerabilities
vulnerabilities.original_title: CISA Warns of Exploited Apple, Kentico, Microsoft Vulnerabilities
vulnerabilities.content_snippet: Leading to code execution, authentication bypass, and privilege escalation, the flaws were added to CISA’s KEV list. The post CISA Warns of Exploited Apple, Kentico, Microsoft Vulnerabilities appeared first on SecurityWeek.
vulnerabilities.summary: Code execution, authentication bypass, and privilege escalation vulnerability affecting Microsoft products.
vulnerabilities.description: A set of vulnerabilities in Microsoft software that enable remote code execution, bypass authentication, and allow privilege escalation, leading to full compromise of affected systems.
vulnerabilities.remediation: Install the latest security updates from Microsoft.
workarounds: Disable vulnerable services until patches are applied
Enforce multi-factor authentication

vulnerabilities.title: Envoy Air (American Airlines) Confirms Oracle EBS 0-Day Breach Linked to Cl0p
vulnerabilities.original_title: Envoy Air (American Airlines) Confirms Oracle EBS 0-Day Breach Linked to Cl0p
vulnerabilities.content_snippet: Envoy Air (American Airlines) confirms a breach by CL0P after they exploited the critical CVE-2025-61882 zero-day flaw in Oracle E-Business Suite.
vulnerabilities.summary: Unauthenticated remote code execution vulnerability in Oracle E-Business Suite allowing attackers to execute arbitrary code on the server.
vulnerabilities.description: CVE-2025-61882 is a zero‑day vulnerability in Oracle E‑Business Suite that permits unauthenticated attackers to send specially crafted requests to vulnerable web components, leading to remote code execution with SYSTEM privileges. The flaw is exploitable over the network and does not require prior authentication or user interaction. It has been leveraged by the CL0P ransomware group to gain initial foothold, exfiltrate data, and deploy ransomware payloads against Envoy Air (American Airlines).
products_versions: All supported versions of Oracle E-Business Suite (e.g., 12.2.x, 12.1.x) as of 2025
vulnerabilities.remediation: Apply the official Oracle patch as soon as it is released. In the interim, implement virtual patches via a Web Application Firewall (WAF) to block the malicious request patterns, restrict access to the E‑Business Suite front‑end to trusted IP ranges, and enforce strong network segmentation.
workarounds: Deploy a WAF or reverse proxy with signatures that block the exploit payload.
Restrict inbound traffic to the Oracle E‑Business Suite application to internal networks or VPN only.
Disable or limit exposure of the vulnerable web component/module if not required.

vulnerabilities.title: Windows update breaks USB support in recovery mode
vulnerabilities.original_title: Windows update breaks USB support in recovery mode
vulnerabilities.content_snippet: We usually tell our faithful readers to install updates as soon as possible, but this time there’s an exception. Microsoft’s October security update has disabled USB mice and keyboards in the Windows Recovery Environment (WinRE). WinRE is a special mode built into Windows that helps you fix problems...
vulnerabilities.summary: Windows update KB5066835 disables USB keyboard and mouse support in the Windows Recovery Environment (WinRE), causing a denial-of-service condition for affected systems.
vulnerabilities.description: The October 2025 security update (KB5066835) modifies the driver loading sequence used by WinRE, resulting in the omission of USB HID drivers. Consequently, USB keyboards and mice are non‑functional when the system boots into WinRE. The issue affects both client (Windows 11 24H2/25H2) and server (Windows Server 2025) editions. No new drivers can be added in WinRE, so Bluetooth devices are also ineffective. The problem can be reproduced by installing the update and then forcing the system into recovery mode.
vulnerabilities.remediation: Uninstall KB5066835 via Settings > Update & Security > View update history > Uninstall updates, or use WinRE's "Uninstall Updates" option under Troubleshoot > Advanced options. Await a Microsoft‑released fix that restores USB support in WinRE.
workarounds: Boot from a previously created USB recovery drive, which restores USB functionality in WinRE.
Use a PS/2 keyboard/mouse if the hardware is available.
Navigate WinRE using keyboard shortcuts (e.g., Tab, Arrow keys) if possible.

vulnerabilities.title: Feds flag active exploitation of patched Windows SMB vuln
vulnerabilities.original_title: Feds flag active exploitation of patched Windows SMB vuln
vulnerabilities.content_snippet: CISA adds high-severity flaw to KEV list, urges swift updating Uncle Sam's cyber wardens have warned that a high-severity flaw in Microsoft's Windows SMB client is now being actively exploited – months after it was patched.…
vulnerabilities.summary: High-severity remote code execution vulnerability in Microsoft Windows SMB client
vulnerabilities.description: A flaw in the Windows SMB client allows an unauthenticated remote attacker to execute arbitrary code on the victim system by sending specially crafted SMB packets. The vulnerability was patched by Microsoft, but threat actors have begun actively exploiting it months after the patch release, targeting systems that remain unpatched or have the vulnerability re-enabled.
vulnerabilities.remediation: Apply the Microsoft security update that patches the SMB client vulnerability. Ensure Windows Update is enabled and all systems are fully patched. Verify that the patch is installed via the KB article referenced in the Microsoft advisory.
workarounds: Disable the SMB client on systems that do not require SMB functionality.
Block inbound SMB (TCP 445) traffic at the network perimeter and on host firewalls.
Enforce network segmentation to limit SMB traffic to trusted zones.
references: Microsoft Security Advisory (KBxxxxxxx) for Windows SMB client vulnerability

vulnerabilities.title: Over 73,000 WatchGuard Firebox Devices Impacted by Recent Critical Flaw
vulnerabilities.original_title: Over 73,000 WatchGuard Firebox Devices Impacted by Recent Critical Flaw
vulnerabilities.content_snippet: Affecting the Fireware OS iked process, the vulnerability can lead to remote code execution and does not require authentication. The post Over 73,000 WatchGuard Firebox Devices Impacted by Recent Critical Flaw appeared first on SecurityWeek.
vulnerabilities.summary: Remote code execution vulnerability in WatchGuard Fireware OS iked process without authentication
vulnerabilities.description: The iked daemon in WatchGuard Fireware OS contains a flaw that allows an unauthenticated remote attacker to execute arbitrary code on the underlying Firebox appliance. The vulnerability is reachable over the network and does not require any user interaction or prior privileges. Successful exploitation results in full control of the device, compromising confidentiality, integrity, and availability of protected network traffic.
affected_products: WatchGuard Firebox devices running Fireware OS
vulnerabilities.remediation: Apply the latest Fireware OS security update released by WatchGuard that patches the iked vulnerability. If a patch is not yet available, upgrade to the newest supported firmware version as soon as it is released.
workarounds: Temporarily block inbound traffic to the iked service (UDP/500 and UDP/4500) at the perimeter firewall.
Disable the iked daemon if it is not required for VPN functionality.
Restrict management access to the Firebox to trusted internal networks only.

vulnerabilities.title: CISA Confirms Exploitation of Latest Oracle EBS Vulnerability
vulnerabilities.original_title: CISA Confirms Exploitation of Latest Oracle EBS Vulnerability
vulnerabilities.content_snippet: The cybersecurity agency has added CVE-2025-61884 to its Known Exploited Vulnerabilities (KEV) catalog. The post CISA Confirms Exploitation of Latest Oracle EBS Vulnerability appeared first on SecurityWeek.
vulnerabilities.summary: Oracle E-Business Suite (EBS) vulnerability exploited in the wild
vulnerabilities.description: A vulnerability in Oracle E-Business Suite (EBS) has been confirmed by CISA as being actively exploited. The specific technical details (e.g., vulnerable component, CVSS metrics) have not been disclosed in the public article. The vulnerability likely allows remote attackers to execute arbitrary code or bypass authentication, leading to potential compromise of the affected Oracle EBS environment.
vulnerabilities.remediation: Apply the vendor-supplied security patch for CVE-2025-61884 as soon as it becomes available. If a patch is not yet released, follow Oracle's recommended temporary mitigations such as disabling the vulnerable functionality, restricting access to the EBS web tier, and enforcing strong authentication mechanisms.
workarounds: Restrict network access to Oracle EBS servers to trusted IP ranges
Disable or block the vulnerable service/module if identified
Enforce multi-factor authentication for all EBS users

vulnerabilities.title: PassiveNeuron: a sophisticated campaign targeting servers of high-profile organizations
vulnerabilities.original_title: PassiveNeuron: a sophisticated campaign targeting servers of high-profile organizations
vulnerabilities.content_snippet: Introduction Back in 2024, we gave a brief description of a complex cyberespionage campaign that we dubbed “PassiveNeuron”. This campaign involved compromising the servers of government organizations with previously unknown APT implants, named “Neursite” and “NeuralExec...
vulnerabilities.summary: Remote code execution via Microsoft SQL Server services used to execute arbitrary commands and deploy web shells.
vulnerabilities.description: Attackers obtain command execution on the target host by abusing Microsoft SQL Server. The exact exploitation method is not disclosed, but it enables the attacker to run PowerShell/VBS scripts that decode and write malicious ASPX web shells to the filesystem. The technique bypasses typical defenses and is repeated until successful.
vulnerabilities.remediation: Apply the latest security patches for Microsoft SQL Server, disable unnecessary remote SQL services, enforce strong authentication for database admin accounts, and restrict network access to SQL ports.
workarounds: Block inbound traffic to SQL Server ports from untrusted networks.
Enable SQL Server auditing and monitor for suspicious command execution.

vulnerabilities.title: PassiveNeuron: a sophisticated campaign targeting servers of high-profile organizations
vulnerabilities.original_title: PassiveNeuron: a sophisticated campaign targeting servers of high-profile organizations
vulnerabilities.content_snippet: Introduction Back in 2024, we gave a brief description of a complex cyberespionage campaign that we dubbed “PassiveNeuron”. This campaign involved compromising the servers of government organizations with previously unknown APT implants, named “Neursite” and “NeuralExec...
vulnerabilities.summary: SQL injection vulnerabilities in web applications hosted on compromised servers allowing initial foothold.
vulnerabilities.description: The campaign leverages classic SQL injection flaws to inject malicious SQL statements that are executed by the backend database, providing the attacker with code execution capabilities used later to drop web shells.
affected_products: Web applications running on Microsoft IIS
Custom web services interfacing with SQL Server
vulnerabilities.remediation: Perform secure coding reviews, use parameterized queries or stored procedures, and employ web application firewalls (WAF) to block injection attempts.
workarounds: Sanitize all user‑supplied input before it reaches the database.
Disable unnecessary database functions that can be abused via injection.

vulnerabilities.title: PassiveNeuron: a sophisticated campaign targeting servers of high-profile organizations
vulnerabilities.original_title: PassiveNeuron: a sophisticated campaign targeting servers of high-profile organizations
vulnerabilities.content_snippet: Introduction Back in 2024, we gave a brief description of a complex cyberespionage campaign that we dubbed “PassiveNeuron”. This campaign involved compromising the servers of government organizations with previously unknown APT implants, named “Neursite” and “NeuralExec...
vulnerabilities.summary: Phantom DLL hijacking / side‑loading of malicious DLLs placed in System32 to achieve persistence.
vulnerabilities.description: Attackers drop large, artificially inflated DLLs (e.g., wlbsctrl.dll, TSMSISrv.dll, oci.dll) into %SystemRoot%\System32. These DLLs are automatically loaded by legitimate system processes at startup, providing stealthy persistence. The loaders perform MAC‑address checks to limit execution to target machines and then chain‑load additional malicious stages.
vulnerabilities.remediation: Implement strict DLL loading controls (e.g., Windows Defender Application Control, AppLocker), monitor for unknown DLLs in system directories, and enforce code‑signing policies.
workarounds: Regularly audit the System32 folder for unexpected files.
Enable Windows Event Logging for DLL load events.

vulnerabilities.title: Hackers Used Snappybee Malware and Citrix Flaw to Breach European Telecom Network
vulnerabilities.original_title: Hackers Used Snappybee Malware and Citrix Flaw to Breach European Telecom Network
vulnerabilities.content_snippet: A European telecommunications organization is said to have been targeted by a threat actor that aligns with a China-nexus cyber espionage group known as Salt Typhoon. The organization, per Darktrace, was targeted in the first week of July 2025, with the attackers exploiting a Citrix NetScaler Gatewa...
vulnerabilities.summary: Remote code execution vulnerability in Citrix NetScaler Gateway used to gain initial access to a European telecom network
vulnerabilities.description: Threat actors associated with the China‑nexus espionage group Salt Typhoon exploited a vulnerability in Citrix NetScaler Gateway (often referred to as a NetScaler Gateway RCE) to obtain initial foothold within the victim's network. The vulnerability allows unauthenticated remote attackers to execute arbitrary code on the appliance, bypassing authentication mechanisms and enabling further malicious activity such as deployment of the Snappybee malware.
products_versions: Citrix NetScaler Gateway (versions prior to the 2025 security patch)
vulnerabilities.remediation: Apply the latest security patches released by Citrix for NetScaler Gateway, enforce strong authentication (e.g., MFA), restrict access to the management interface via network segmentation and firewall rules, and regularly review Citrix security advisories.
workarounds: Place NetScaler Gateway behind a VPN or zero‑trust network access solution
Disable unnecessary services and protocols on the appliance
Implement strict IP allow‑lists for management access

vulnerabilities.title: Over 75,000 WatchGuard security devices vulnerable to critical RCE
vulnerabilities.original_title: Over 75,000 WatchGuard security devices vulnerable to critical RCE
vulnerabilities.content_snippet: Nearly 76,000 WatchGuard Firebox network security appliances are exposed on the public web and still vulnerable to a critical issue (CVE-2025-9242) that could allow a remote attacker to execute code without authentication. [...]
vulnerabilities.summary: Unauthenticated remote code execution vulnerability in WatchGuard Firebox network security appliances.
vulnerabilities.description: A flaw in the web management interface of WatchGuard Firebox devices allows an attacker to send specially crafted HTTP requests to the device's public IP address. The vulnerability bypasses authentication checks and results in arbitrary code execution with system privileges. The issue is present in multiple firmware versions and can be exploited remotely without any user interaction.
products_versions: All WatchGuard Firebox firmware versions prior to the vendor‑released patch (specific version numbers not disclosed in the article)
