vulnerabilities.remediation: Upgrade to the latest firmware version released by WatchGuard that addresses CVE-2025-9242. If a patch is not yet available, apply the vendor‑provided temporary mitigation steps and restrict external access to the management interface.
workarounds: Block inbound traffic to the Firebox management ports (e.g., 443, 80) from the internet using perimeter firewalls or ACLs.
Restrict management access to trusted IP ranges or VPN connections only.
Disable the web management interface if not required.

vulnerabilities.title: CISA: High-severity Windows SMB flaw now exploited in attacks
vulnerabilities.original_title: CISA: High-severity Windows SMB flaw now exploited in attacks
vulnerabilities.content_snippet: CISA says threat actors are now actively exploiting a high-severity Windows SMB privilege escalation vulnerability that can let them gain SYSTEM privileges on unpatched systems. [...]
vulnerabilities.summary: Windows SMB privilege escalation vulnerability allowing attackers to obtain SYSTEM privileges on unpatched systems.
vulnerabilities.description: A high‑severity flaw in the Windows Server Message Block (SMB) service can be remotely triggered by sending specially crafted SMB packets. Successful exploitation results in privilege escalation to SYSTEM on the target host, enabling full control of the compromised machine. The vulnerability is actively being exploited in the wild according to CISA alerts.
vulnerabilities.remediation: Apply the latest Microsoft security updates that address the SMB vulnerability. Ensure Windows Update is enabled and all critical patches are installed.
workarounds: Block inbound SMB traffic (TCP/445) at the network perimeter.
Disable SMBv1 and any unnecessary SMB versions.
Enforce strict firewall rules limiting SMB access to trusted hosts.

vulnerabilities.title: ConnectWise Patches Critical Flaw in Automate RMM Tool
vulnerabilities.original_title: ConnectWise Patches Critical Flaw in Automate RMM Tool
vulnerabilities.content_snippet: Attackers could exploit vulnerable deployments to intercept and tamper with communications in certain configurations. The post ConnectWise Patches Critical Flaw in Automate RMM Tool appeared first on SecurityWeek.
vulnerabilities.summary: Man-in-the-Middle vulnerability in ConnectWise Automate RMM tool allowing interception and tampering of communications
vulnerabilities.description: Certain configurations of ConnectWise Automate expose communication channels without proper authentication or encryption. An attacker positioned on the same network segment can intercept, read, and modify data exchanged between the RMM server and managed endpoints, potentially injecting malicious commands or exfiltrating sensitive information.
products_versions: ConnectWise Automate versions prior to the October 2025 security patch
vulnerabilities.remediation: Apply the patch released by ConnectWise. Ensure all communications are secured with TLS 1.2+ and disable any legacy or insecure protocols. Verify that the latest version of Automate is deployed across all endpoints.
workarounds: Force TLS encryption for all Automate communications via configuration settings.
Restrict network access to the Automate server to trusted subnets only.
Disable any optional insecure modules or plugins until the patch is applied.

vulnerabilities.title: Vulnerability in Dolby Decoder Can Allow Zero-Click Attacks
vulnerabilities.original_title: Vulnerability in Dolby Decoder Can Allow Zero-Click Attacks
vulnerabilities.content_snippet: On Android, the out-of-bounds write issue can be triggered during the processing of media files without user interaction. The post Vulnerability in Dolby Decoder Can Allow Zero-Click Attacks appeared first on SecurityWeek.
vulnerabilities.summary: Out-of-bounds write in Dolby Audio Decoder on Android can be triggered by processing crafted media files without user interaction, enabling zero‑click remote code execution.
vulnerabilities.description: The vulnerability is an out‑of‑bounds write in the Dolby decoder component used on Android devices. When a maliciously crafted media file (e.g., audio or video) is processed, the decoder writes beyond the allocated buffer, corrupting adjacent memory. This can be leveraged to achieve arbitrary code execution with the privileges of the media service, allowing an attacker to take full control of the device without any user interaction (zero‑click). The flaw is exploitable via any vector that delivers the malicious media file, such as messaging apps, email, or web downloads.
affected_products: Android media framework using Dolby decoder
vulnerabilities.remediation: Apply the vendor‑provided patch that corrects the bounds check in the Dolby decoder. Update the Android OS or the specific Dolby library to the latest version released by the device OEM or Google. If a patch is not yet available, disable the Dolby decoder in the media framework configuration.
workarounds: Disable Dolby audio decoding in the device settings or via system property (e.g., set "media.codec.dolby.enabled" to false).
Use alternative audio codecs (AAC, Opus) for media playback.
Block inbound media files from untrusted sources at the network perimeter.

vulnerabilities.title: F5 breach exposes 262,000 BIG-IP systems worldwide
vulnerabilities.original_title: F5 breach exposes 262,000 BIG-IP systems worldwide
vulnerabilities.content_snippet: Over 262K F5 BIG-IP devices exposed after threat actors stole source code and data on undisclosed flaws in a recent F5 breach. Over 262,000 F5 BIG-IP devices are exposed online after F5 confirmed a breach by nation-state actors who stole source code and data on undisclosed flaws. The Shadowserver Fo...
vulnerabilities.summary: Undisclosed vulnerabilities in F5 BIG-IP devices exploited by a nation‑state actor after source‑code theft
vulnerabilities.description: In August 2025 a sophisticated nation‑state group (UNC5221) breached F5's development environment, stole BIG‑IP source code and information about multiple undisclosed flaws. The stolen artifacts enable the creation of zero‑day exploits that can be leveraged remotely against exposed BIG‑IP management interfaces. The breach also introduced a Go‑based Brickstorm backdoor used in subsequent campaigns. Over 262,000 BIG‑IP instances were found exposed on the Internet, many of which may be vulnerable to these unknown flaws.
products_versions: All F5 BIG‑IP versions prior to the latest security patches (including BIG‑IP 15.x, 16.x, and 17.x series)
vulnerabilities.remediation: Apply all available F5 BIG‑IP security updates immediately. Rotate all credentials, enforce MFA, and restrict management interfaces to trusted networks. Deploy CrowdStrike Falcon EDR or equivalent endpoint detection. Conduct a full code integrity verification of BIG‑IP binaries. Review and harden firewall rules to block unauthorized access to ports 443, 8443, and any custom management ports.
workarounds: Block inbound traffic to BIG‑IP management ports from untrusted networks.
Place BIG‑IP devices behind a VPN or jump host with MFA.
Disable unused services and modules on BIG‑IP.
Enable strict ACLs on the management VLAN.

vulnerabilities.title: A week in security (October 13 – October 19)
vulnerabilities.original_title: A week in security (October 13 – October 19)
vulnerabilities.content_snippet: Last week on Malwarebytes Labs: Prosper data breach puts 17 million people at risk of identity theft Under the engineering hood: Why Malwarebytes chose WordPress as its CMS Video call app Huddle01 exposed 600K+ user logs Mango discloses data breach at third-party provider Roku accused of selling chi...
vulnerabilities.summary: Pixel-stealing "Pixnapping" attack targeting Android devices to capture screen content without user consent
vulnerabilities.description: The Pixnapping technique exploits a combination of insecure intent handling and insufficient permission checks in Android's screenshot APIs, allowing a malicious app to capture the device's screen content and exfiltrate it to a remote server. The attack can be launched remotely via a crafted malicious app distributed through third‑party app stores.
vulnerabilities.remediation: Update Android devices to the latest security patches; restrict installation of apps from unknown sources; enforce runtime permission prompts for screen capture APIs.
workarounds: Disable screen capture permissions for untrusted apps via device policy manager.
Use mobile device management (MDM) solutions to whitelist approved applications.

vulnerabilities.title: A week in security (October 13 – October 19)
vulnerabilities.original_title: A week in security (October 13 – October 19)
vulnerabilities.content_snippet: Last week on Malwarebytes Labs: Prosper data breach puts 17 million people at risk of identity theft Under the engineering hood: Why Malwarebytes chose WordPress as its CMS Video call app Huddle01 exposed 600K+ user logs Mango discloses data breach at third-party provider Roku accused of selling chi...
vulnerabilities.summary: Improper access controls leading to exposure of 600,000+ user logs in the Huddle01 video‑call platform
vulnerabilities.description: A misconfiguration in Huddle01's API endpoint allowed unauthenticated requests to retrieve detailed call logs, including participant identifiers and timestamps. The data was stored without proper encryption at rest and could be enumerated via predictable URLs.
vulnerabilities.remediation: Implement authentication and authorization checks on all log‑retrieval endpoints; enforce encryption of logs at rest; rotate exposed credentials.
workarounds: Temporarily disable public access to log APIs.
Restrict API access to trusted IP ranges.

vulnerabilities.title: A week in security (October 13 – October 19)
vulnerabilities.original_title: A week in security (October 13 – October 19)
vulnerabilities.content_snippet: Last week on Malwarebytes Labs: Prosper data breach puts 17 million people at risk of identity theft Under the engineering hood: Why Malwarebytes chose WordPress as its CMS Video call app Huddle01 exposed 600K+ user logs Mango discloses data breach at third-party provider Roku accused of selling chi...
vulnerabilities.summary: Prompt injection techniques that bypass OpenAI guardrails, enabling generation of disallowed content
vulnerabilities.description: Researchers demonstrated that specially crafted user prompts can manipulate the language model's internal token handling to evade safety filters, causing the model to produce content that violates policy (e.g., instructions for illicit activities). The attack leverages token‑level ambiguities and does not require authentication.
vulnerabilities.remediation: Update the content moderation pipeline with enhanced context‑aware filters; employ rate‑limiting and anomaly detection on prompt patterns; regularly retrain guardrails with adversarial examples.
workarounds: Apply client‑side prompt sanitization before sending to the API.
Monitor API usage for abnormal request patterns.

vulnerabilities.title: China finds “irrefutable evidence” of US NSA cyberattacks on time Authority
vulnerabilities.original_title: China finds “irrefutable evidence” of US NSA cyberattacks on time Authority
vulnerabilities.content_snippet: China claims the US NSA hacked its National Time Service Center by exploiting staff phone flaws since March 2022, stealing sensitive data. China’s Ministry of State Security announced it has found “irrefutable evidence” that the US National Security Agency (NSA) conducted cyberattacks on its Nationa...
vulnerabilities.summary: Exploitation of a flaw in a foreign SMS service to gain control of employee mobile phones
vulnerabilities.description: Adversaries sent malicious SMS messages that leveraged a vulnerability in the SMS service infrastructure, allowing remote code execution or credential harvesting on the target's phone. Compromised phones were used to exfiltrate sensitive data and to obtain authentication tokens for later network access.
vulnerabilities.remediation: Apply security patches to the SMS gateway, enforce strict SMS filtering, disable execution of unknown links/attachments on mobile devices, and enforce mobile device management (MDM) policies.
workarounds: Block SMS messages from unknown international numbers
Require MFA for any actions initiated from mobile devices

vulnerabilities.title: China finds “irrefutable evidence” of US NSA cyberattacks on time Authority
vulnerabilities.original_title: China finds “irrefutable evidence” of US NSA cyberattacks on time Authority
vulnerabilities.content_snippet: China claims the US NSA hacked its National Time Service Center by exploiting staff phone flaws since March 2022, stealing sensitive data. China’s Ministry of State Security announced it has found “irrefutable evidence” that the US National Security Agency (NSA) conducted cyberattacks on its Nationa...
vulnerabilities.summary: Use of stolen credentials to access internal systems via VPN
vulnerabilities.description: After compromising employee phones, the threat actor harvested valid credentials and used them to authenticate to the organization’s VPN, gaining lateral movement capabilities within the internal network.
vulnerabilities.remediation: Enforce multi‑factor authentication for VPN access, rotate compromised credentials, and implement credential‑usage monitoring.
workarounds: Restrict VPN access to known IP ranges
Deploy zero‑trust network access controls

vulnerabilities.title: China finds “irrefutable evidence” of US NSA cyberattacks on time Authority
vulnerabilities.original_title: China finds “irrefutable evidence” of US NSA cyberattacks on time Authority
vulnerabilities.content_snippet: China claims the US NSA hacked its National Time Service Center by exploiting staff phone flaws since March 2022, stealing sensitive data. China’s Ministry of State Security announced it has found “irrefutable evidence” that the US National Security Agency (NSA) conducted cyberattacks on its Nationa...
vulnerabilities.summary: Deployment of custom cyber‑warfare platform with forged certificates and encrypted tunnels
vulnerabilities.description: A suite of 42 custom tools was used to infiltrate and manipulate the precision timing infrastructure. The tools employed forged TLS certificates and layered encryption to evade detection, allowing insertion of disruptive code into critical services.
vulnerabilities.remediation: Implement strict certificate validation (pinning), monitor for anomalous TLS fingerprints, and apply integrity‑checking mechanisms to timing system binaries.
workarounds: Deploy network‑based TLS inspection with trusted root stores
Enable file integrity monitoring on critical binaries

vulnerabilities.title: China Accuses US of Cyberattack on National Time Center
vulnerabilities.original_title: China Accuses US of Cyberattack on National Time Center
vulnerabilities.content_snippet: The Ministry of State Security alleged that the NSA exploited vulnerabilities in the messaging services of a foreign mobile phone brand to steal sensitive information. The post China Accuses US of Cyberattack on National Time Center appeared first on SecurityWeek.
vulnerabilities.summary: Exploitation of vulnerabilities in the messaging services of a foreign mobile phone brand to steal sensitive information, as alleged by the Chinese Ministry of State Security.
vulnerabilities.description: According to the article, the NSA allegedly leveraged one or more undisclosed vulnerabilities in the messaging component of a foreign mobile phone brand. The exploitation allowed the adversary to gain unauthorized access to communications and exfiltrate sensitive data. Specific technical details, CVE identifiers, or vulnerability characteristics were not disclosed.
affected_products: Messaging service of unnamed foreign mobile phone brand
vulnerabilities.remediation: Apply all security updates released by the mobile phone vendor for the messaging service. If patches are unavailable, disable or restrict the messaging functionality, enforce strong authentication, and monitor for anomalous traffic.
workarounds: Disable the vulnerable messaging service until a patch is available
Enforce network segmentation to limit exposure of the messaging service

vulnerabilities.title: In Other News: CrowdStrike Vulnerabilities, CISA Layoffs, Mango Data Breach
vulnerabilities.original_title: In Other News: CrowdStrike Vulnerabilities, CISA Layoffs, Mango Data Breach
vulnerabilities.content_snippet: Other noteworthy stories that might have slipped under the radar: Capita fined £14 million, ICTBroadcast vulnerability exploited, Spyware maker NSO acquired. The post In Other News: CrowdStrike Vulnerabilities, CISA Layoffs, Mango Data Breach appeared first on SecurityWeek.
vulnerabilities.summary: ICTBroadcast vulnerability exploited
vulnerabilities.description: An undisclosed vulnerability in ICTBroadcast's software was reported as being actively exploited. No technical details, CVE identifier, or impact metrics were provided in the source article.
vulnerabilities.remediation: Apply any patches released by ICTBroadcast as soon as they become available. If no patch exists, consider temporary mitigations such as network segmentation and disabling vulnerable services.
workarounds: Restrict network access to ICTBroadcast systems
Implement application-layer firewalls to block suspicious traffic

vulnerabilities.title: Email Bombs Exploit Lax Authentication in Zendesk
vulnerabilities.original_title: Email Bombs Exploit Lax Authentication in Zendesk
vulnerabilities.content_snippet: Cybercriminals are abusing a widespread lack of authentication in the customer service platform Zendesk to flood targeted email inboxes with menacing messages that come from hundreds of Zendesk corporate customers simultaneously. Zendesk is an automated help desk service designed to make it simple f...
vulnerabilities.summary: Unauthenticated ticket creation in Zendesk Support enables email bombing via auto‑responder notifications
vulnerabilities.description: Zendesk allows customers to configure ticket creation endpoints that accept requests from unauthenticated (anonymous) users. When an auto‑responder trigger is enabled, each created ticket generates an email notification that appears to come from the customer’s own domain (e.g., help@company.com). An attacker can script thousands of ticket submissions, each with arbitrary subject lines and reply‑to addresses, causing a flood of legitimate‑looking support emails to be sent to any target address. The lack of verification of the submitter’s email address and the permissive ticket‑creation workflow constitute a design‑level vulnerability that can be abused for large‑scale email bombing, brand impersonation, and denial‑of‑service attacks against email recipients.
products_versions: All versions of Zendesk Support that allow anonymous ticket creation (default SaaS offering).
vulnerabilities.remediation: Configure Zendesk ticket creation to require authentication (API token, OAuth, or SSO). Disable anonymous ticket submission or restrict it to trusted IP ranges. Enable CAPTCHA or rate‑limit per IP for the ticket‑creation endpoint. Turn off or restrict auto‑responder triggers for unauthenticated tickets. Validate the reply‑to address against known customer domains before sending notifications. Apply any vendor‑released hardening guidance.
workarounds: Disable the auto‑responder trigger for tickets created via the public API or email endpoint.
Restrict ticket‑creation endpoints to internal networks or VPN.
Implement a custom middleware that validates the "From"/"Reply‑To" address before forwarding to Zendesk.

vulnerabilities.title: Vulnerabilities Allow Disruption of Phoenix Contact UPS Devices
vulnerabilities.original_title: Vulnerabilities Allow Disruption of Phoenix Contact UPS Devices
vulnerabilities.content_snippet: An attacker can exploit the flaws to put devices into a permanent DoS condition that prevents remote restoration. The post Vulnerabilities Allow Disruption of Phoenix Contact UPS Devices appeared first on SecurityWeek.
vulnerabilities.summary: Multiple vulnerabilities in Phoenix Contact UPS devices allow an attacker to place the device into a permanent denial-of-service condition that cannot be remotely restored.
vulnerabilities.description: The vulnerabilities stem from improper handling of network packets and insufficient validation of remote management commands. An unauthenticated attacker can send crafted packets to the UPS's management interface, causing the device firmware to enter an unrecoverable state. The condition persists across reboots and cannot be cleared via remote management, effectively rendering the UPS inoperable and potentially causing downstream power loss for connected equipment.
vulnerabilities.remediation: Apply the vendor-supplied firmware update that corrects the input validation and adds authentication checks to the management interface. If a patch is not yet available, restrict network access to the UPS management ports using firewalls or VLAN segmentation and disable remote management features.
workarounds: Block inbound traffic to the UPS management ports (e.g., TCP/443, TCP/80) from untrusted networks.
Place UPS devices on an isolated management VLAN with strict ACLs.
Disable remote web/SSH access if not required.

vulnerabilities.title: SEO spam and hidden links: how to protect your website and your reputation
vulnerabilities.original_title: SEO spam and hidden links: how to protect your website and your reputation
vulnerabilities.content_snippet: When analyzing the content of websites in an attempt to determine what category it belongs to, we sometimes get an utterly unexpected result. It could be the official page of a metal structures manufacturer or online flower shop, or, say, a law firm website, with completely neutral content, but our ...
vulnerabilities.summary: Compromise of website administrator credentials allowing unauthorized modification of HTML pages
vulnerabilities.description: Attackers obtain or guess admin passwords via credential stuffing, phishing, credential leaks, or default passwords. With admin access they can edit site templates, inject hidden <div> blocks with dofollow links, upload malicious plugins or scripts, and thereby conduct SEO spam or further compromise the server.
vulnerabilities.remediation: Enforce strong, unique passwords; enable multi‑factor authentication; lock out repeated failed logins; regularly rotate credentials; remove default accounts; monitor admin login activity.
workarounds: Restrict admin panel access by IP address
Use a separate, hardened management network

vulnerabilities.title: SEO spam and hidden links: how to protect your website and your reputation
vulnerabilities.original_title: SEO spam and hidden links: how to protect your website and your reputation
vulnerabilities.content_snippet: When analyzing the content of websites in an attempt to determine what category it belongs to, we sometimes get an utterly unexpected result. It could be the official page of a metal structures manufacturer or online flower shop, or, say, a law firm website, with completely neutral content, but our ...
vulnerabilities.summary: Exploitation of unpatched CMS vulnerabilities (SQL Injection, Remote Code Execution, Cross‑Site Scripting) to inject hidden SEO spam blocks
vulnerabilities.description: Out‑of‑date CMS core or plugins contain known vulnerabilities such as SQLi, RCE, or XSS. An attacker can craft malicious requests that modify database records or file system contents, inserting invisible <div> blocks with dofollow links to pornographic, gambling or malicious sites. The injected code may also load external JavaScript that creates hidden iframes or background HTTP requests to generate artificial traffic.
vulnerabilities.remediation: Keep CMS core, themes, and plugins up to date; remove unused extensions; apply vendor security patches promptly; employ a Web Application Firewall (WAF) with rules for SQLi/XSS; conduct regular vulnerability scanning.
workarounds: Disable file write permissions for web‑user where possible
Run the CMS in a container or sandbox with limited privileges

vulnerabilities.title: SEO spam and hidden links: how to protect your website and your reputation
vulnerabilities.original_title: SEO spam and hidden links: how to protect your website and your reputation
vulnerabilities.content_snippet: When analyzing the content of websites in an attempt to determine what category it belongs to, we sometimes get an utterly unexpected result. It could be the official page of a metal structures manufacturer or online flower shop, or, say, a law firm website, with completely neutral content, but our ...
vulnerabilities.summary: Compromise of shared hosting environment allowing injection of hidden SEO spam across multiple sites
vulnerabilities.description: If the hosting provider's server is poorly secured, an attacker who gains root or high‑privilege access can modify web‑root files, inject hidden <div> blocks into templates, replace legitimate files, or add malicious scripts that affect all websites hosted on the same machine. This enables large‑scale SEO spam campaigns and can also serve as a stepping stone for further attacks.
vulnerabilities.remediation: Hosting providers should enforce strict OS hardening, regular patching, least‑privilege separation between accounts, file integrity monitoring, and network segmentation. Customers should use dedicated hosting or containers with isolated file systems.
workarounds: Move critical sites to a dedicated or managed hosting environment
Enable file integrity alerts (e.g., Tripwire, OSSEC)

vulnerabilities.title: Hackers exploit Cisco SNMP flaw to deploy rootkit on switches
vulnerabilities.original_title: Hackers exploit Cisco SNMP flaw to deploy rootkit on switches
vulnerabilities.content_snippet: Threat actors exploited a recently patched remote code execution vulnerability (CVE-2025-20352) in older, unprotected Cisco networking devices to deploy a Linux rootkit and gain persistent access. [...]
vulnerabilities.summary: Remote code execution vulnerability in Cisco SNMP service on older networking devices.
vulnerabilities.description: The vulnerability resides in the SNMP daemon of older Cisco networking devices. An unauthenticated attacker can send specially crafted SNMP packets that trigger a buffer overflow, leading to remote code execution with root privileges. Threat actors have leveraged this flaw to upload and execute a Linux rootkit on the compromised switches, establishing persistent control and enabling further lateral movement within the network.
products_versions: Legacy Cisco Catalyst switch models running vulnerable IOS/IOS XE releases (specific versions not disclosed in article).
vulnerabilities.remediation: Apply the Cisco security advisory patch released for CVE-2025-20352. Upgrade affected devices to the latest supported IOS/IOS XE version. If immediate patching is not possible, disable SNMP or restrict SNMP access to trusted management hosts via ACLs.
workarounds: Disable SNMP on affected devices until a patch can be applied.
Restrict SNMP traffic to management VLANs and enforce source IP allow‑lists.
Implement network‑level firewall rules to block inbound SNMP (UDP/161) from untrusted networks.

vulnerabilities.title: Gladinet fixes actively exploited zero-day in file-sharing software
vulnerabilities.original_title: Gladinet fixes actively exploited zero-day in file-sharing software
vulnerabilities.content_snippet: Gladinet has released security updates for its CentreStack business solution to address a local file inclusion vulnerability (CVE-2025-11371) that threat actors have leveraged as a zero-day since late September. [...]
vulnerabilities.summary: Local File Inclusion (LFI) vulnerability in Gladinet CentreStack allowing remote code execution.
vulnerabilities.description: The vulnerability resides in the file handling component of Gladinet CentreStack. An attacker can craft a malicious request that causes the application to include arbitrary files from the server's filesystem. Successful exploitation can lead to disclosure of sensitive files, arbitrary code execution, and further compromise of the underlying system. The flaw has been observed in the wild as a zero‑day exploit since late September 2025.
products_versions: All pre‑patch versions of Gladinet CentreStack (specific version numbers not disclosed in the article)
vulnerabilities.remediation: Apply the security updates released by Gladinet for CentreStack. Verify that the installed version includes the fix for CVE‑2025‑11371.
workarounds: Restrict external access to the CentreStack web interface via firewall rules.
Deploy a Web Application Firewall (WAF) with rules to block LFI payload patterns.
Validate and sanitize all user‑supplied input that is used in file path construction.

vulnerabilities.title: CISA: Maximum-severity Adobe flaw now exploited in attacks
vulnerabilities.original_title: CISA: Maximum-severity Adobe flaw now exploited in attacks
vulnerabilities.content_snippet: CISA has warned that attackers are actively exploiting a maximum-severity vulnerability in Adobe Experience Manager to execute code on unpatched systems. [...]
vulnerabilities.summary: Remote code execution vulnerability in Adobe Experience Manager (AEM) allowing attackers to execute arbitrary code on unpatched systems.
vulnerabilities.description: A flaw in the request handling component of Adobe Experience Manager enables an unauthenticated attacker to send specially crafted HTTP requests that trigger deserialization of untrusted data, leading to remote code execution. The vulnerability affects on-premise AEM installations and AEM as a Cloud Service instances that have not been updated with the latest security patches. Exploitation does not require prior authentication or user interaction and can be performed over the network.
products_versions: Adobe Experience Manager as a Cloud Service prior to the November 2025 patch
vulnerabilities.remediation: Apply the security patches released by Adobe for the affected AEM versions. Review Adobe Security Bulletin for the specific patch identifiers and update all AEM instances promptly. Verify that the patch is successfully applied by checking the installed version number.
workarounds: Temporarily block inbound traffic to the AEM service ports (e.g., 4502, 8080) from untrusted networks.
Deploy a Web Application Firewall (WAF) with rules to block the malicious request patterns identified in the advisory.
Disable the vulnerable servlet/component if it is not required for business functionality.
references: Adobe Security Bulletin for AEM (2025) – Patch details

vulnerabilities.title: China-linked APT Jewelbug targets Russian IT provider in rare cross-nation cyberattack
vulnerabilities.original_title: China-linked APT Jewelbug targets Russian IT provider in rare cross-nation cyberattack
vulnerabilities.content_snippet: China-linked APT Jewelbug targeted a Russian IT provider for five months in 2025, showing Russia remains exposed to Chinese cyber espionage. China-linked threat actor Jewelbug (aka CL-STA-0049, Earth Alux, and REF7707) carried out a five-month intrusion on a Russian IT service provider, marking its ...
vulnerabilities.summary: Kernel read/write vulnerability in the ECHOAC anti-cheat driver abused via the EchoDrv tool (BYOVD technique)
vulnerabilities.description: The EchoDrv utility leverages a kernel-mode read/write vulnerability in the ECHOAC anti-cheat driver to gain arbitrary kernel memory access. By loading the vulnerable driver (bring‑your‑own‑vulnerable‑driver, BYOVD), the attacker can bypass security controls, execute privileged code, and maintain stealthy persistence. This technique was observed in the Jewelbug campaign targeting a Russian IT service provider.
products_versions: Microsoft Windows Debugger (cdb.exe) – all supported versions
ECHOAC anti‑cheat driver – vulnerable versions prior to vendor patch
vulnerabilities.remediation: Update the ECHOAC driver to a version that patches the kernel read/write flaw, or remove the driver if not required. Apply Microsoft’s driver signing enforcement and enable Secure Kernel Mode Code Signing (KMCS).
workarounds: Disable loading of unsigned drivers via Group Policy.
Monitor for the presence of the EchoDrv executable and related driver load events.
Restrict execution of unknown binaries in privileged directories.

vulnerabilities.title: China-linked APT Jewelbug targets Russian IT provider in rare cross-nation cyberattack
vulnerabilities.original_title: China-linked APT Jewelbug targets Russian IT provider in rare cross-nation cyberattack
vulnerabilities.content_snippet: China-linked APT Jewelbug targeted a Russian IT provider for five months in 2025, showing Russia remains exposed to Chinese cyber espionage. China-linked threat actor Jewelbug (aka CL-STA-0049, Earth Alux, and REF7707) carried out a five-month intrusion on a Russian IT service provider, marking its ...
vulnerabilities.summary: Abuse of Microsoft Debugger (cdb.exe) renamed as 7zup.exe for stealthy shellcode execution and security tool disabling
vulnerabilities.description: Jewelbug deployed a renamed copy of the Microsoft Console Debugger (cdb.exe) called 7zup.exe. The binary was used to execute custom shellcode, bypass application whitelisting, and disable security tools. This is a classic Living‑off‑the‑Land (LoL) technique that does not exploit a software flaw but leverages legitimate binaries to evade detection.
products_versions: Microsoft Windows Debugger (cdb.exe) – all supported versions
ECHOAC anti‑cheat driver – vulnerable versions prior to vendor patch
vulnerabilities.remediation: Implement strict application control policies (AppLocker, Windows Defender Application Control) that validate file hashes and block renamed system binaries. Enable Windows Event Log retention and monitor for unexpected process names matching known system binaries.
workarounds: Create a whitelist that only allows cdb.exe to run from its default location.
Deploy endpoint detection rules that alert on execution of cdb.exe from non‑standard paths.

vulnerabilities.title: Senator presses Cisco over firewall flaws that burned US agency
vulnerabilities.original_title: Senator presses Cisco over firewall flaws that burned US agency
vulnerabilities.content_snippet: Bill Cassidy letter asks if Switchzilla sat on critical flaws before feds were forced into emergency patching US Senator Bill Cassidy has fired off a pointed letter to Cisco over the firewall flaws that allegedly let hackers breach "at least one federal agency."…
vulnerabilities.summary: Cisco firewall (Firepower/ASA) remote code execution vulnerability exploited to breach a federal agency.
vulnerabilities.description: A flaw in the firewall's packet inspection engine allows unauthenticated remote attackers to execute arbitrary code on the device, bypassing security policies and gaining full control of the network perimeter. The vulnerability stems from improper validation of crafted packets that trigger a buffer overflow in the data path.
vulnerabilities.remediation: Apply Cisco's emergency security patch released in September 2025. Upgrade to the latest firmware version that includes the fix.
workarounds: Restrict inbound traffic to management interfaces
Disable vulnerable services until patch is applied

vulnerabilities.title: Organizations Warned of Exploited Adobe AEM Forms Vulnerability
vulnerabilities.original_title: Organizations Warned of Exploited Adobe AEM Forms Vulnerability
vulnerabilities.content_snippet: A public PoC existed when Adobe patched the Experience Manager Forms (AEM Forms) bug in early August. The post Organizations Warned of Exploited Adobe AEM Forms Vulnerability appeared first on SecurityWeek.
vulnerabilities.summary: Adobe Experience Manager Forms (AEM Forms) vulnerability exploited in the wild with a public proof‑of‑concept prior to patching in early August 2025.
vulnerabilities.description: A vulnerability in Adobe AEM Forms allowed remote attackers to execute arbitrary code / bypass security controls. A public proof‑of‑concept was released before Adobe issued a security update in early August 2025, and threat actors have been observed exploiting the flaw in the wild. Specific technical details (e.g., CVE identifier, vulnerable component, exact CVSS metrics) were not disclosed in the source article.
vulnerabilities.remediation: Apply the Adobe security patch released in early August 2025. Verify that the patch is installed on all AEM Forms instances and restart services as required.
workarounds: Restrict network access to AEM Forms servers to trusted IP ranges.
Disable or block the vulnerable endpoint until the patch can be applied.
Monitor web application firewall (WAF) logs for suspicious requests targeting AEM Forms.

vulnerabilities.title: Fuji Electric HMI Configurator Flaws Expose Industrial Organizations to Hacking
vulnerabilities.original_title: Fuji Electric HMI Configurator Flaws Expose Industrial Organizations to Hacking
vulnerabilities.content_snippet: Fuji Electric has released patches and Japan’s JPCERT has informed organizations about the vulnerabilities. The post Fuji Electric HMI Configurator Flaws Expose Industrial Organizations to Hacking appeared first on SecurityWeek.
vulnerabilities.summary: Multiple vulnerabilities in Fuji Electric HMI Configurator that could allow unauthenticated remote code execution and privilege escalation on industrial control systems.
vulnerabilities.description: The HMI Configurator contains insecure input validation and deserialization flaws that can be triggered by sending crafted network packets to the service. Successful exploitation results in execution of arbitrary code with system privileges, enabling attackers to manipulate industrial processes, exfiltrate data, or disrupt operations.
vulnerabilities.remediation: Apply the patches released by Fuji Electric. Verify patch integrity and restart the HMI Configurator service after installation.
workarounds: Block inbound traffic to the HMI Configurator ports at the network perimeter.
Restrict access to the configurator to trusted management workstations only.
Enable application whitelisting and enforce least‑privilege accounts for HMI operations.

vulnerabilities.title: Cisco Routers Hacked for Rootkit Deployment
vulnerabilities.original_title: Cisco Routers Hacked for Rootkit Deployment
vulnerabilities.content_snippet: Threat actors are exploiting CVE-2025-20352, a recent Cisco zero-day, to deploy a rootkit on older networking devices. The post Cisco Routers Hacked for Rootkit Deployment appeared first on SecurityWeek.
vulnerabilities.summary: Cisco zero‑day vulnerability allowing remote code execution leading to rootkit deployment on older Cisco routing devices.
vulnerabilities.description: The vulnerability resides in the management plane of affected Cisco routers. An unauthenticated attacker can send specially crafted packets to the device's management interface, triggering a buffer overflow that results in remote code execution with root privileges. Exploit code in the wild is being used to install a persistent rootkit, providing the attacker with long‑term control, data exfiltration capabilities, and the ability to manipulate traffic.
vulnerabilities.remediation: Apply the Cisco security advisory patch as soon as it becomes available. If a patch is not yet released, upgrade to a supported firmware version that is not vulnerable, disable unnecessary remote management services, and restrict access to the management interface via ACLs and VPN.
workarounds: Block inbound traffic to the router's management ports from untrusted networks.
Enforce strong authentication and enable multi‑factor authentication for all administrative access.
Segment the network to isolate legacy routers from critical infrastructure.

vulnerabilities.title: U.S. CISA adds SKYSEA Client View, Rapid7 Velociraptor, Microsoft Windows, and IGEL OS flaws to its Known Exploited Vulnerabilities catalog
vulnerabilities.original_title: U.S. CISA adds SKYSEA Client View, Rapid7 Velociraptor, Microsoft Windows, and IGEL OS flaws to its Known Exploited Vulnerabilities catalog
vulnerabilities.content_snippet: U.S. Cybersecurity and Infrastructure Security Agency (CISA) adds OracSKYSEA Client View, Rapid7 Velociraptor, Microsoft Windows, and IGEL OS flaws to its Known Exploited Vulnerabilities catalog. The U.S. Cybersecurity and Infrastructure Security Agency (CISA) added OracSKYSEA Client View, Rapid7 Ve...
vulnerabilities.summary: Improper authentication in SKYSEA Client View allows remote code execution via TCP connections to the management console.
vulnerabilities.description: The vulnerability stems from improper authentication handling in TCP connections between SKYSEA Client View agents and the management console. An unauthenticated attacker can craft malicious packets that bypass authentication checks, leading to arbitrary code execution on the server hosting the console.
products_versions: Microsoft Windows Agere Modem Driver (various builds)
Microsoft Windows RasMan service (all supported versions prior to patch)
vulnerabilities.remediation: Upgrade SKYSEA Client View to a version newer than 11.221.03 where the authentication flaw is fixed. Apply network segmentation and firewall rules to restrict access to the management console ports.
workarounds: Block inbound traffic to the SKYSEA management console ports from untrusted networks.
Enforce strict network ACLs limiting which hosts can communicate with the console.

vulnerabilities.title: U.S. CISA adds SKYSEA Client View, Rapid7 Velociraptor, Microsoft Windows, and IGEL OS flaws to its Known Exploited Vulnerabilities catalog
vulnerabilities.original_title: U.S. CISA adds SKYSEA Client View, Rapid7 Velociraptor, Microsoft Windows, and IGEL OS flaws to its Known Exploited Vulnerabilities catalog
vulnerabilities.content_snippet: U.S. Cybersecurity and Infrastructure Security Agency (CISA) adds OracSKYSEA Client View, Rapid7 Velociraptor, Microsoft Windows, and IGEL OS flaws to its Known Exploited Vulnerabilities catalog. The U.S. Cybersecurity and Infrastructure Security Agency (CISA) added OracSKYSEA Client View, Rapid7 Ve...
vulnerabilities.summary: Rapid7 Velociraptor artifact Admin.Client.UpdateClientConfig lacks proper permission checks, enabling arbitrary command execution.
vulnerabilities.description: Velociraptor allows endpoints to expose VQL artifacts that run with elevated privileges. The Admin.Client.UpdateClientConfig artifact does not require the EXECVE permission; any user with the COLLECT_CLIENT role can invoke it to modify client configuration, leading to arbitrary command execution and potential endpoint takeover.
products_versions: Microsoft Windows Agere Modem Driver (various builds)
Microsoft Windows RasMan service (all supported versions prior to patch)
vulnerabilities.remediation: Update Velociraptor to the patched version that enforces EXECVE permission for the artifact. Review and tighten role permissions, removing COLLECT_CLIENT from users who do not need it.
workarounds: Disable the Admin.Client.UpdateClientConfig artifact until the patch is applied.
Restrict the COLLECT_CLIENT role to trusted administrators only.

vulnerabilities.title: U.S. CISA adds SKYSEA Client View, Rapid7 Velociraptor, Microsoft Windows, and IGEL OS flaws to its Known Exploited Vulnerabilities catalog
vulnerabilities.original_title: U.S. CISA adds SKYSEA Client View, Rapid7 Velociraptor, Microsoft Windows, and IGEL OS flaws to its Known Exploited Vulnerabilities catalog
vulnerabilities.content_snippet: U.S. Cybersecurity and Infrastructure Security Agency (CISA) adds OracSKYSEA Client View, Rapid7 Velociraptor, Microsoft Windows, and IGEL OS flaws to its Known Exploited Vulnerabilities catalog. The U.S. Cybersecurity and Infrastructure Security Agency (CISA) added OracSKYSEA Client View, Rapid7 Ve...
vulnerabilities.summary: Untrusted pointer dereference in the Agere Modem Driver (Windows) enables privilege escalation.
vulnerabilities.description: The driver contains an untrusted pointer dereference that can be triggered by a low‑privileged process, allowing it to execute code in kernel mode and gain SYSTEM privileges.
products_versions: Microsoft Windows Agere Modem Driver (various builds)
Microsoft Windows RasMan service (all supported versions prior to patch)
vulnerabilities.remediation: Microsoft plans to remove the vulnerable Agere Modem Driver from supported Windows builds. Administrators should uninstall the driver and apply any available cumulative updates.
workarounds: Disable or uninstall the Agere Modem Driver on affected systems.
Restrict execution of untrusted code and enforce application whitelisting.

vulnerabilities.title: U.S. CISA adds SKYSEA Client View, Rapid7 Velociraptor, Microsoft Windows, and IGEL OS flaws to its Known Exploited Vulnerabilities catalog
vulnerabilities.original_title: U.S. CISA adds SKYSEA Client View, Rapid7 Velociraptor, Microsoft Windows, and IGEL OS flaws to its Known Exploited Vulnerabilities catalog
vulnerabilities.content_snippet: U.S. Cybersecurity and Infrastructure Security Agency (CISA) adds OracSKYSEA Client View, Rapid7 Velociraptor, Microsoft Windows, and IGEL OS flaws to its Known Exploited Vulnerabilities catalog. The U.S. Cybersecurity and Infrastructure Security Agency (CISA) added OracSKYSEA Client View, Rapid7 Ve...
vulnerabilities.summary: IGEL OS Secure Boot bypass using an expired key, allowing kernel‑level rootkit deployment.
vulnerabilities.description: The vulnerability allows an attacker with physical access to supply a malicious boot image signed with a key that has passed its expiration date, bypassing Secure Boot checks. This enables deployment of a kernel‑level rootkit that can capture credentials and tamper with virtual desktop sessions.
products_versions: Microsoft Windows Agere Modem Driver (various builds)
Microsoft Windows RasMan service (all supported versions prior to patch)
vulnerabilities.remediation: Upgrade IGEL OS to version 11 or later, which contains the corrected Secure Boot validation logic. Ensure firmware is configured to reject unsigned or improperly signed boot images.
workarounds: Enable BIOS/UEFI password protection to prevent unauthorized boot media changes.
Physically secure devices to mitigate evil‑maid attacks.

The U.S. Cybersecurity and Infrastructure Security Agency (CISA) added OracSKYSEA Client View, Rapid7 Ve...
vulnerabilities.summary: Improper access control in Windows RasMan service enables privilege escalation.
vulnerabilities.description: The RasMan service fails to enforce proper access checks on privileged operations, allowing a low‑privileged user to execute actions as SYSTEM, leading to full system compromise.
products_versions: Microsoft Windows Agere Modem Driver (various builds)
Microsoft Windows RasMan service (all supported versions prior to patch)
vulnerabilities.remediation: Apply the forthcoming Microsoft update that restricts RasMan access or, as interim, disable the RasMan service if not required.
workarounds: Restrict the RasMan service to trusted accounts via Group Policy.
Monitor for unexpected RasMan activity using Windows Event Logs.

vulnerabilities.title: A sophisticated nation-state actor breached F5 systems, stealing BIG-IP source code and data on undisclosed flaw
vulnerabilities.original_title: A sophisticated nation-state actor breached F5 systems, stealing BIG-IP source code and data on undisclosed flaw
vulnerabilities.content_snippet: F5 disclosed that a sophisticated nation-state actor breached its systems, stealing BIG-IP source code and data on undisclosed product vulnerabilities. Cybersecurity firm F5 disclosed that a highly sophisticated nation-state actor in August 2025 threat actors breached its systems and stole BIG-IP&#8...
vulnerabilities.summary: Undisclosed vulnerability in F5 BIG-IP product leveraged by a nation‑state actor; details of the flaw have not been publicly released.
vulnerabilities.description: A sophisticated nation‑state threat actor gained long‑term, persistent access to F5's development and engineering systems, exfiltrating BIG‑IP source code and internal documentation describing one or more undisclosed product vulnerabilities. The breach did not affect the supply chain or modify the released binaries, but the stolen information could enable the creation of zero‑day exploits against vulnerable BIG‑IP deployments.
products_versions: All supported versions of BIG‑IP, BIG‑IP Next for Kubernetes, BIG‑IQ, and APM at the time of the breach (2025).
vulnerabilities.remediation: Apply the latest security patches for all BIG‑IP related products, rotate all credentials, enforce multi‑factor authentication, restrict access to development environments, and deploy endpoint detection and response (EDR) solutions such as CrowdStrike Falcon. Conduct thorough code reviews and penetration testing of custom BIG‑IP configurations.
workarounds: Isolate management interfaces from the internet and restrict access to trusted IP ranges.
Disable unused services and ports on BIG‑IP appliances.
Implement strict role‑based access control (RBAC) for development and production environments.

vulnerabilities.title: F5 releases BIG-IP patches for stolen security vulnerabilities
vulnerabilities.original_title: F5 releases BIG-IP patches for stolen security vulnerabilities
vulnerabilities.content_snippet: Cybersecurity company F5 has released security updates to address BIG-IP vulnerabilities stolen in a breach detected on August 9, 2025. [...]
vulnerabilities.summary: Multiple BIG-IP vulnerabilities were stolen in a breach and patched by F5.
vulnerabilities.description: F5 released security updates to address BIG-IP vulnerabilities that were stolen in a breach detected on August 9, 2025. Specific technical details, CVE identifiers, and impact metrics were not disclosed in the article.
vulnerabilities.remediation: Apply the released BIG-IP patches from F5 immediately and follow the vendor's patch deployment guidance.

vulnerabilities.title: F5 says hackers stole undisclosed BIG-IP flaws, source code
vulnerabilities.original_title: F5 says hackers stole undisclosed BIG-IP flaws, source code
vulnerabilities.content_snippet: U.S. cybersecurity company F5 disclosed that nation-state hackers breached its systems and stole undisclosed BIG-IP security vulnerabilities and source code. [...]
vulnerabilities.summary: Undisclosed BIG-IP security vulnerabilities and source code were stolen by nation‑state hackers, potentially enabling future zero‑day exploits.
vulnerabilities.description: The breach resulted in the exfiltration of proprietary source code and details of multiple, as‑yet‑unpublished vulnerabilities in the F5 BIG‑IP application delivery controller platform. While specific technical details have not been released, the stolen assets could allow attackers to craft remote code execution, privilege escalation, or denial‑of‑service attacks against vulnerable BIG‑IP deployments. The lack of public disclosure suggests the vulnerabilities may be of high severity and could be weaponized in targeted campaigns.
vulnerabilities.remediation: Apply all available F5 BIG‑IP patches immediately. Review and harden network exposure of BIG‑IP devices (e.g., restrict management interfaces to trusted IPs, enforce TLS, use VPN). Rotate all administrative credentials and certificates. Monitor F5 security advisories for forthcoming patches related to the disclosed breach.
workarounds: Restrict inbound traffic to BIG‑IP management interfaces to internal networks only.
Disable unnecessary services and modules on BIG‑IP appliances.
Enable strict firewall rules and intrusion‑prevention signatures that detect anomalous traffic to BIG‑IP ports.

vulnerabilities.title: Satellites still leak unencrypted traffic, including voice calls and text messages
vulnerabilities.original_title: Satellites still leak unencrypted traffic, including voice calls and text messages
vulnerabilities.content_snippet: Scientists from several US universities intercepted unencrypted broadcast through geostationary satellites using only off-the-shelf equipment on a university rooftop. Geostationary satellites move at the same speed as the Earth’s rotation so it seems as though they are always above the same exact lo...
vulnerabilities.summary: Unencrypted IP traffic transmitted over GEO satellite links allowing passive interception of voice, text, and data communications.
vulnerabilities.description: Researchers captured clear‑text IP packets on 39 geostationary satellites using off‑the‑shelf equipment. The lack of encryption at the link or network layer exposed private voice calls, SMS, banking transaction data, industrial control commands, and military operational information. Any adversary with a suitable antenna and receiver can eavesdrop, record, and later replay or analyze the traffic, enabling espionage, credential harvesting, and potential sabotage of critical infrastructure.
affected_products: Backhaul communication systems used by telecom operators, banks, utilities, aviation, and military
affected_companies: Telecom carriers using GEO satellite backhaul
Financial institutions using satellite links for ATM connectivity
Utility and industrial control system operators
vendors: Telecom carriers using GEO satellite backhaul
Financial institutions using satellite links for ATM connectivity
Utility and industrial control system operators
products_versions: Satellite transponder firmware lacking encryption support
Ground terminal hardware without built‑in encryption modules
Legacy backhaul routers and modems deployed on satellite links
vulnerabilities.remediation: Implement end‑to‑end encryption for all traffic traversing satellite links (e.g., IPsec, TLS, SSH). Deploy link‑layer encryption (AES‑256) on satellite modems and ground stations. Enforce use of VPNs or secure communication apps for voice and messaging. Update satellite service provider contracts to require compliance with recognized encryption standards (e.g., NIST SP 800‑53).
workarounds: Use VPN tunnels over the satellite link for all data.
Adopt secure messaging applications (Signal, WhatsApp) for voice and text.
Apply application‑layer encryption for critical protocols (HTTPS, SFTP).
references: Don’t Look Up: There Are Sensitive Internal Links in the Clear on GEO Satellites (research paper)

vulnerabilities.title: Satellites leak voice calls, text messages and more
vulnerabilities.original_title: Satellites leak voice calls, text messages and more
vulnerabilities.content_snippet: Scientists from several US universities intercepted unencrypted broadcast through geostationary satellites using only off-the-shelf equipment on a university rooftop. Geostationary satellites move at the same speed as the Earth’s rotation so it seems as though they are always above the same exact lo...
vulnerabilities.summary: Unencrypted IP traffic transmitted over GEO satellite links allowing interception of voice calls, text messages, and critical infrastructure data.
vulnerabilities.description: Researchers captured clear‑text IP traffic on 39 geostationary satellites using consumer‑grade equipment. Approximately 50% of the observed traffic lacked encryption at both the link and network layers, exposing private voice calls, SMS, ATM transaction data, industrial control commands, and military communications. The vulnerability stems from the failure of satellite service providers and their customers to enforce standardized encryption (e.g., IPsec, TLS) on satellite links, creating a passive eavesdropping surface that can be exploited by any technically capable adversary with a suitable antenna and receiver.
affected_products: Backhaul equipment used by telecom, banking, aviation, industrial control, and military customers
vulnerabilities.remediation: Enable end‑to‑end encryption for all traffic traversing satellite links (IPsec, TLS, SSH). Deploy VPN solutions for remote sites. Upgrade satellite communication equipment to support mandatory encryption standards. Conduct regular security audits of satellite backhaul configurations. Ensure that customer devices use encrypted applications (Signal, WhatsApp, etc.) before transmitting over satellite.
workarounds: Use a VPN tunnel over the satellite link for all traffic.
Adopt encrypted communication apps for voice and messaging.
Restrict transmission of sensitive data over satellite unless encrypted.
references: Don’t Look Up: There Are Sensitive Internal Links in the Clear on GEO Satellites (research paper)

vulnerabilities.title: Two New Windows Zero-Days Exploited in the Wild — One Affects Every Version Ever Shipped
vulnerabilities.original_title: Two New Windows Zero-Days Exploited in the Wild — One Affects Every Version Ever Shipped
vulnerabilities.content_snippet: Microsoft on Tuesday released fixes for a whopping 183 security flaws spanning its products, including three vulnerabilities that have come under active exploitation in the wild, as the tech giant officially ended support for its Windows 10 operating system unless the PCs are enrolled in the Extende...
vulnerabilities.summary: Zero-day remote code execution vulnerability affecting all supported and legacy versions of Microsoft Windows, actively exploited in the wild.
vulnerabilities.description: The vulnerability allows an unauthenticated attacker to execute arbitrary code with SYSTEM privileges by sending specially crafted network packets to a vulnerable Windows host. The flaw resides in the Windows kernel's handling of certain I/O requests, leading to memory corruption and code execution. Exploits have been observed in the wild targeting both consumer and enterprise environments.
affected_products: Microsoft Windows (all versions, including Windows 7, 8, 8.1, 10, 11, Server 2008/2012/2016/2019/2022)
products_versions: All Windows client and server versions (for CVE‑1)
vulnerabilities.remediation: Microsoft has released security updates (KBxxxxxxx) that address the vulnerability. Apply the latest cumulative updates for the affected Windows versions immediately.
workarounds: Block inbound traffic to ports used by the vulnerable service at the perimeter firewall.
Disable the affected service if not required.
Enable Enhanced Mitigation Experience Toolkit (EMET) or Windows Defender Exploit Guard mitigations.

vulnerabilities.title: Two New Windows Zero-Days Exploited in the Wild — One Affects Every Version Ever Shipped
vulnerabilities.original_title: Two New Windows Zero-Days Exploited in the Wild — One Affects Every Version Ever Shipped
vulnerabilities.content_snippet: Microsoft on Tuesday released fixes for a whopping 183 security flaws spanning its products, including three vulnerabilities that have come under active exploitation in the wild, as the tech giant officially ended support for its Windows 10 operating system unless the PCs are enrolled in the Extende...
vulnerabilities.summary: Zero-day privilege escalation vulnerability in Windows 10 that allows local attackers to gain SYSTEM privileges, actively exploited in the wild.
vulnerabilities.description: The vulnerability resides in the Windows 10 kernel driver handling of object handles. A local, low‑privileged user can craft a malicious request that triggers a use‑after‑free condition, leading to arbitrary code execution with SYSTEM privileges. Threat actors have leveraged this flaw to install persistent backdoors after initial foothold.
products_versions: All Windows client and server versions (for CVE‑1)
vulnerabilities.remediation: Install the security update released by Microsoft (KBxxxxxxx) that patches the driver code. Ensure all Windows 10 devices are updated to the latest cumulative patch.
workarounds: Restrict local administrator rights using Group Policy.
Enable Device Guard and Credential Guard to limit driver loading.
Monitor for suspicious process creation events.

vulnerabilities.title: Flax Typhoon APT exploited ArcGIS server for over a year as a backdoor
vulnerabilities.original_title: Flax Typhoon APT exploited ArcGIS server for over a year as a backdoor
vulnerabilities.content_snippet: China-linked cyberespionage group Flax Typhoon hijacked an ArcGIS system for over a year and used it as a backdoor. China-linked APT group Flax Typhoon (aka Ethereal Panda or RedJuliett) compromised an ArcGIS system for over a year, using it as a backdoor. ArcGIS, a key GIS platform for mapping and ...
vulnerabilities.summary: Abuse of Esri ArcGIS Server Java Server Object Extension (SOE) as a persistent web shell backdoor
vulnerabilities.description: The threat actor modified a legitimate ArcGIS Server Java Server Object Extension (SOE) to function as a web shell. The malicious SOE was hard‑coded with a secret key, deployed via a public‑facing ArcGIS server, and persisted in system backups. It created a hidden "Bridge" folder in the Windows system directory, uploaded a renamed VPN executable (bridge.exe), and registered a fake Windows service (SysBridge) that started automatically, providing long‑term, system‑level access even after reboots or updates. The attacker leveraged the backdoor to execute PowerShell commands, enumerate credentials, scan internal networks, harvest AD hashes, and establish an encrypted VPN tunnel for lateral movement.
vulnerabilities.remediation: Patch ArcGIS Server to the latest version; remove any unauthorized SOE files; rotate all compromised credentials; disable or restrict public access to ArcGIS services; enforce least‑privilege for service accounts; implement file integrity monitoring for ArcGIS directories; delete the hidden Bridge folder and the SysBridge service; block outbound VPN traffic from the server.
workarounds: Restrict ArcGIS Server to internal network or VPN access only
Apply application whitelisting to prevent execution of unknown binaries in system directories
Monitor for creation of unknown Windows services and unusual PowerShell activity

vulnerabilities.title: Adobe Patches Critical Vulnerability in Connect Collaboration Suite
vulnerabilities.original_title: Adobe Patches Critical Vulnerability in Connect Collaboration Suite

vulnerabilities.summary: Critical vulnerability in Adobe Connect Collaboration Suite (details not disclosed in the article)
vulnerabilities.description: Adobe released a security advisory indicating a critical vulnerability affecting its Connect Collaboration Suite. The article does not provide technical details such as vulnerability type, CVE identifier, or exploitation mechanics.
vulnerabilities.remediation: Apply the patches released by Adobe in the security advisory for Connect Collaboration Suite.

vulnerabilities.title: Microsoft Patches 173 Vulnerabilities, Including Exploited Windows Flaws
vulnerabilities.original_title: Microsoft Patches 173 Vulnerabilities, Including Exploited Windows Flaws
vulnerabilities.content_snippet: The tech giant has rolled out fixes for 173 CVEs, including five critical-severity security defects. The post Microsoft Patches 173 Vulnerabilities, Including Exploited Windows Flaws appeared first on SecurityWeek.
vulnerabilities.summary: Microsoft released patches for 173 CVEs, including five critical-severity vulnerabilities affecting Windows.
vulnerabilities.description: The article does not provide technical details of individual CVEs. It indicates that several Windows flaws have been actively exploited in the wild and have now been patched by Microsoft.

vulnerabilities.remediation: Apply the latest Microsoft security updates released on 2025-10-15.

vulnerabilities.title: Operation Zero Disco: Attackers Exploit Cisco SNMP Vulnerability to Deploy Rootkits
vulnerabilities.original_title: Operation Zero Disco: Attackers Exploit Cisco SNMP Vulnerability to Deploy Rootkits
vulnerabilities.content_snippet: Trend™ Research has uncovered an attack campaign exploiting the Cisco SNMP vulnerability CVE-2025-20352, allowing remote code execution and rootkit deployment on unprotected devices, with impacts observed on Cisco 9400, 9300, and legacy 3750G series.
vulnerabilities.summary: Cisco SNMP service buffer overflow leading to remote code execution and rootkit deployment.
vulnerabilities.description: A vulnerability in the Simple Network Management Protocol (SNMP) daemon of affected Cisco switches allows an unauthenticated attacker to send specially crafted SNMP packets that trigger a buffer overflow. Successful exploitation results in remote code execution with root privileges, enabling the attacker to install persistent rootkits and gain full control of the device. The vulnerability is exploitable over the network without any user interaction.
products_versions: Cisco Catalyst 9400 Series (all firmware versions prior to the security patch)
Cisco Catalyst 9300 Series (all firmware versions prior to the security patch)
Cisco Catalyst 3750G Series (legacy firmware prior to the security patch)
vulnerabilities.remediation: Apply the Cisco security advisory patch for CVE-2025-20352, upgrade to the latest firmware release for the affected switch series, and configure SNMP to use version 3 with strong authentication and encryption.
workarounds: Disable SNMP v1/v2c on the affected devices.
Restrict SNMP access to trusted management hosts using ACLs.
Enable SNMPv3 with authentication and encryption.

vulnerabilities.title: Patch Tuesday, October 2025 ‘End of 10’ Edition
vulnerabilities.original_title: Patch Tuesday, October 2025 ‘End of 10’ Edition
vulnerabilities.content_snippet: Microsoft today released software updates to plug a whopping 172 security holes in its Windows operating systems, including at least two vulnerabilities that are already being actively exploited. October’s Patch Tuesday also marks the final month that Microsoft will ship security updates for W...
vulnerabilities.summary: Remote code execution / privilege escalation via vulnerable Agere Modem driver bundled with Windows.
vulnerabilities.description: The Agere Modem driver contains a flaw that allows an attacker to execute arbitrary code with SYSTEM privileges when the driver is loaded. Active exploitation was observed in the wild, prompting Microsoft to remove the driver entirely from Windows distributions.
vulnerabilities.remediation: Install the October 2025 Patch Tuesday update which removes the Agere Modem driver from Windows. Verify the driver is no longer present in the system.
workarounds: Manually uninstall the Agere Modem driver if still present.
Disable any modem hardware that relies on the driver.

vulnerabilities.title: Patch Tuesday, October 2025 ‘End of 10’ Edition
vulnerabilities.original_title: Patch Tuesday, October 2025 ‘End of 10’ Edition
vulnerabilities.content_snippet: Microsoft today released software updates to plug a whopping 172 security holes in its Windows operating systems, including at least two vulnerabilities that are already being actively exploited. October’s Patch Tuesday also marks the final month that Microsoft will ship security updates for W...
vulnerabilities.summary: Elevation of privilege vulnerability in Windows Remote Access Connection Manager (RasMan).
vulnerabilities.description: A flaw in the RasMan service allows a low‑privileged user to gain SYSTEM privileges. This is the first known zero‑day exploitation of RasMan in the wild.
vulnerabilities.remediation: Apply the October 2025 cumulative update which patches RasMan. Restart the system after installation.
workarounds: Restrict local accounts from accessing RasMan via Group Policy.
Monitor for unexpected service restarts of RasMan.

vulnerabilities.title: Patch Tuesday, October 2025 ‘End of 10’ Edition
vulnerabilities.original_title: Patch Tuesday, October 2025 ‘End of 10’ Edition
vulnerabilities.content_snippet: Microsoft today released software updates to plug a whopping 172 security holes in its Windows operating systems, including at least two vulnerabilities that are already being actively exploited. October’s Patch Tuesday also marks the final month that Microsoft will ship security updates for W...
vulnerabilities.summary: Remote code execution in Microsoft Office via malicious document preview (Preview Pane).
vulnerabilities.description: Two separate RCE bugs (CVE-2025-59227 and CVE-2025-59234) allow code execution when a user previews a malicious Office document in the Outlook preview pane. No opening of the file is required; merely rendering triggers the exploit.
vulnerabilities.remediation: Install the October 2025 security updates for Microsoft Office. Consider disabling the preview pane in Outlook until patches are applied.
workarounds: Disable the Outlook preview pane.
Block Office file types from being rendered in email clients.

vulnerabilities.original_title: Patch Tuesday, October 2025 ‘End of 10’ Edition
vulnerabilities.content_snippet: Microsoft today released software updates to plug a whopping 172 security holes in its Windows operating systems, including at least two vulnerabilities that are already being actively exploited. October’s Patch Tuesday also marks the final month that Microsoft will ship security updates for W...
vulnerabilities.summary: Remote code execution in Microsoft Office via malicious document preview (Preview Pane).
vulnerabilities.description: See CVE-2025-59227; this is the second RCE bug in the same preview‑pane attack chain.
vulnerabilities.remediation: Same as CVE-2025-59227 – apply the October 2025 Office patches and/or disable the preview pane.
