Enforce attachment scanning on mail gateways.

vulnerabilities.title: Patch Tuesday, October 2025 ‘End of 10’ Edition
vulnerabilities.original_title: Patch Tuesday, October 2025 ‘End of 10’ Edition
vulnerabilities.content_snippet: Microsoft today released software updates to plug a whopping 172 security holes in its Windows operating systems, including at least two vulnerabilities that are already being actively exploited. October’s Patch Tuesday also marks the final month that Microsoft will ship security updates for W...
vulnerabilities.summary: Unauthenticated remote code execution in Windows Server Update Services (WSUS) via deserialization of untrusted data.
vulnerabilities.description: An attacker can send crafted data to a WSUS server, triggering a deserialization flaw that leads to arbitrary code execution with SYSTEM privileges. The service runs with high trust and can modify privileged files, potentially evading some EDR solutions.
vulnerabilities.remediation: Apply the October 2025 cumulative update that patches WSUS. If immediate patching is not possible, restrict network access to WSUS servers to trusted subnets only.
workarounds: Block inbound traffic to WSUS ports (8530/8531) from untrusted networks.
Enable application whitelisting on WSUS servers.

vulnerabilities.title: Researchers warn of widespread RDP attacks by 100K-node botnet
vulnerabilities.original_title: Researchers warn of widespread RDP attacks by 100K-node botnet
vulnerabilities.content_snippet: A botnet of 100K+ IPs from multiple countries is attacking U.S. RDP services in a campaign active since October 8. GreyNoise researchers uncovered a large-scale botnet that is targeting Remote Desktop Protocol (RDP) services in the United States starting on October 8. The company discovered the botn...
vulnerabilities.summary: Exploitation of Remote Desktop Protocol (RDP) services through timing attacks on RD Web Access and login enumeration on the RDP web client, combined with large-scale brute‑force attempts.
vulnerabilities.description: A botnet of >100,000 IPs from >100 countries is targeting U.S. RDP endpoints. The campaign uses two primary techniques: (1) RD Web Access timing attacks that infer valid credentials or service availability based on response latency, and (2) enumeration of valid usernames/passwords via the RDP web client login interface. The attacks are coordinated, share a common TCP fingerprint, and are likely driven by centralized command‑and‑control. Successful exploitation can lead to unauthorized remote desktop sessions, data exfiltration, and lateral movement within compromised networks.
vulnerabilities.remediation: Apply all available Microsoft security updates for Remote Desktop Services. Enforce Network Level Authentication (NLA) and require multi‑factor authentication for all RDP connections. Restrict RDP access to trusted IP ranges using VPNs or firewall rules. Use strong, unique passwords and implement account lockout policies. Deploy intrusion detection/prevention systems (IDS/IPS) with signatures for RDP brute‑force and timing attacks. Monitor login logs for anomalous patterns.
workarounds: Disable direct Internet exposure of RDP ports (3389) and require VPN access.
Enable account lockout after a limited number of failed login attempts.
Deploy fail2ban or similar tools to automatically block offending IPs.

vulnerabilities.title: Microsoft October 2025 Patch Tuesday fixes 6 zero-days, 172 flaws
vulnerabilities.original_title: Microsoft October 2025 Patch Tuesday fixes 6 zero-days, 172 flaws
vulnerabilities.content_snippet: Today is Microsoft's October 2025 Patch Tuesday, which includes security updates for 172 flaws, including six zero-day vulnerabilities. Get patching! [...]
vulnerabilities.summary: Zero-day vulnerability addressed in Microsoft October 2025 Patch Tuesday (specific CVE IDs not disclosed in article).
vulnerabilities.description: The article reports that Microsoft released patches for six zero‑day vulnerabilities and a total of 172 security flaws. No technical details, CVE identifiers, or exploitation information were provided.
vulnerabilities.remediation: Apply the October 2025 Patch Tuesday updates released by Microsoft.

vulnerabilities.title: Oracles silently fixes zero-day exploit leaked by ShinyHunters
vulnerabilities.original_title: Oracles silently fixes zero-day exploit leaked by ShinyHunters
vulnerabilities.content_snippet: Oracle has silently fixed an Oracle E-Business Suite vulnerability (CVE-2025-61884) that was actively exploited to breach servers, with a proof-of-concept exploit publicly leaked by the ShinyHunters extortion group. [...]
vulnerabilities.summary: Remote code execution vulnerability in Oracle E-Business Suite allowing unauthenticated attackers to execute arbitrary code on the server.
vulnerabilities.description: The vulnerability resides in a web component of Oracle E-Business Suite that fails to properly validate user-supplied input. An attacker can craft a malicious request that triggers deserialization of untrusted data, leading to remote code execution with system privileges. The flaw was actively exploited in the wild, and a proof‑of‑concept exploit was leaked by the ShinyHunters extortion group. Oracle released a silent fix that patches the vulnerable code path.
vulnerabilities.remediation: Apply the Oracle security patch released for CVE-2025-61884. Verify the patch level on all E-Business Suite instances and restart the affected services.
workarounds: Restrict network access to the vulnerable web component (e.g., firewall rules limiting source IPs).
Disable the affected module if not in use.
Monitor for suspicious HTTP requests and anomalous process creation.

vulnerabilities.title: Oracle silently fixes zero-day exploit leaked by ShinyHunters
vulnerabilities.original_title: Oracle silently fixes zero-day exploit leaked by ShinyHunters
vulnerabilities.content_snippet: Oracle has silently fixed an Oracle E-Business Suite vulnerability (CVE-2025-61884) that was actively exploited to breach servers, with a proof-of-concept exploit publicly leaked by the ShinyHunters extortion group. [...]
vulnerabilities.summary: Remote code execution vulnerability in Oracle E-Business Suite allowing unauthenticated attackers to execute arbitrary code on the server.
vulnerabilities.description: The vulnerability resides in a component of Oracle E-Business Suite that improperly validates input, leading to unauthenticated remote code execution. An attacker can craft a malicious request that triggers execution of arbitrary commands on the underlying operating system, resulting in full compromise of the affected server. The exploit was publicly leaked by the ShinyHunters extortion group and observed in the wild targeting Oracle deployments.
products_versions: All supported versions of Oracle E‑Business Suite prior to the silent patch release (specific versions not disclosed in the article)
vulnerabilities.remediation: Apply the Oracle-provided patch that silently fixes CVE-2025-61884. Update the E-Business Suite to the latest patched version as soon as possible.
workarounds: Restrict network access to the vulnerable service to trusted IP ranges.
Deploy a web application firewall (WAF) with custom rules to block the malicious request patterns observed in the proof‑of‑concept exploit.

vulnerabilities.title: Security firms debate CVE credit in overlapping vulnerability reports
vulnerabilities.original_title: Security firms debate CVE credit in overlapping vulnerability reports
vulnerabilities.content_snippet: FuzzingLabs has accused the YCombinator-backed startup, Gecko Security, of replicating its vulnerability disclosures. Gecko allegedly filed for 2 CVEs based on FuzzingLabs' reports without crediting them. Gecko denies any wrongdoing, calling the allegations a misunderstanding over disclosure process...
vulnerabilities.summary: Dispute over credit for two CVEs allegedly filed by Gecko Security based on FuzzingLabs' vulnerability disclosures. No technical details of the vulnerabilities are provided in the article.
vulnerabilities.description: The article does not disclose technical specifics of the vulnerabilities, such as affected software, attack mechanics, or impact. It only describes a controversy regarding attribution of two CVEs.

vulnerabilities.title: Microsoft Limits IE Mode in Edge After Chakra Zero-Day Activity Detected
vulnerabilities.original_title: Microsoft Limits IE Mode in Edge After Chakra Zero-Day Activity Detected
vulnerabilities.content_snippet: Microsoft restricted access to Edge's IE Mode in August 2025 after hackers used a Chakra zero-day flaw to bypass security and take over user devices. Check out the new steps for enabling IE Mode.
vulnerabilities.summary: Remote code execution vulnerability in Microsoft Edge's IE Mode leveraging a Chakra JavaScript engine zero‑day
vulnerabilities.description: A previously unknown flaw in the Chakra JavaScript engine allowed attackers to craft malicious web content that, when rendered in Edge's IE Mode, could bypass the browser's security boundaries and execute arbitrary code on the host system. The exploit chain results in full device takeover, enabling persistence, credential theft, and lateral movement. The vulnerability is triggered remotely via a malicious webpage and does not require prior authentication on the target machine.
products_versions: Microsoft Edge versions prior to August 2025 that support IE Mode
vulnerabilities.remediation: Apply the latest Microsoft Edge updates that include the Chakra engine fix. Microsoft has also limited access to IE Mode as a temporary mitigation. Organizations should deploy the updated Edge version and enforce the new IE Mode restrictions.
workarounds: Disable IE Mode in Microsoft Edge
Block legacy sites that require IE Mode via web filtering
Enforce Microsoft Edge Application Guard for untrusted sites
references: Microsoft Security Advisory (August 2025) – IE Mode restrictions

vulnerabilities.title: SAP Patches Critical Vulnerabilities in NetWeaver, Print Service, SRM
vulnerabilities.original_title: SAP Patches Critical Vulnerabilities in NetWeaver, Print Service, SRM
vulnerabilities.content_snippet: SAP has rolled out additional protections for insecure deserialization bugs resolved in NetWeaver AS Java recently. The post SAP Patches Critical Vulnerabilities in NetWeaver, Print Service, SRM appeared first on SecurityWeek.
vulnerabilities.summary: Insecure deserialization vulnerability in SAP NetWeaver Application Server Java leading to potential remote code execution
vulnerabilities.description: The vulnerability stems from insecure deserialization of untrusted data within SAP NetWeaver AS Java components. An attacker can craft malicious serialized objects that, when processed by the server, may lead to arbitrary code execution, data leakage, or denial of service. The issue was addressed by SAP through additional protections and patches released in the latest security update.
products_versions: SAP NetWeaver AS Java (versions prior to the October 2025 security patch)
vulnerabilities.remediation: Apply the latest SAP security patches for NetWeaver AS Java as released by SAP. Verify that the patch level includes the insecure deserialization fixes.
workarounds: Disable or restrict the affected services until patches are applied.
Implement strict input validation and serialization hardening in custom applications.

vulnerabilities.title: Secure Boot bypass risk threatens nearly 200,000 Linux Framework laptops
vulnerabilities.original_title: Secure Boot bypass risk threatens nearly 200,000 Linux Framework laptops
vulnerabilities.content_snippet: Around 200,000 Linux computer systems from American computer maker Framework were shipped with signed UEFI shell components that could be exploited to bypass Secure Boot protections. [...]
vulnerabilities.summary: Signed UEFI shell components on Framework laptops can be leveraged to bypass Secure Boot protections
vulnerabilities.description: Framework laptops ship with a signed UEFI shell binary that is loaded during the boot process. The signature verification logic contains a flaw that allows an attacker to replace the legitimate shell with a maliciously crafted one while still passing Secure Boot signature checks. By exploiting this flaw, an adversary can execute arbitrary code before the operating system loads, effectively bypassing Secure Boot's protection mechanisms, installing persistent firmware-level malware, or loading an unsigned operating system.
affected_products: Framework laptops (all models shipped with the vulnerable UEFI shell, approx. 200,000 units)
vulnerabilities.remediation: Apply the firmware update released by Framework that revokes the vulnerable UEFI shell signature and replaces the component with a correctly signed version. If a firmware update is not yet available, disable Secure Boot or replace the platform key (PK) with a custom key and only enroll trusted binaries.
workarounds: Disable Secure Boot in the UEFI settings until a patched firmware is released.
Revoke the compromised vendor key using the UEFI key management utilities and enroll a custom key.
Monitor boot logs for unexpected UEFI shell execution and verify the hash of the loaded shell binary.

vulnerabilities.title: Harvard Is First Confirmed Victim of Oracle EBS Zero-Day Hack
vulnerabilities.original_title: Harvard Is First Confirmed Victim of Oracle EBS Zero-Day Hack
vulnerabilities.content_snippet: Hackers have posted over 1 Tb of information allegedly stolen from Harvard on the Cl0p data leak website. The post Harvard Is First Confirmed Victim of Oracle EBS Zero-Day Hack appeared first on SecurityWeek.
vulnerabilities.summary: Zero-day vulnerability in Oracle E-Business Suite (EBS) enabling remote code execution
vulnerabilities.description: A previously unknown vulnerability in Oracle E-Business Suite allows unauthenticated attackers to execute arbitrary code on the application server, leading to full compromise of the affected instance. The vulnerability was exploited by the Cl0p ransomware group to exfiltrate over 1 TB of data from Harvard University, marking the first confirmed victim of this zero‑day. Details of the vulnerability have not been publicly disclosed, and no CVE identifier has been assigned at this time.
vulnerabilities.remediation: Apply the security patch released by Oracle as soon as it becomes available. In the interim, restrict network access to EBS servers, enforce strong authentication, disable unnecessary services, and monitor for suspicious activity.
workarounds: Restrict inbound traffic to EBS application servers to trusted IPs
Implement Web Application Firewall rules to block anomalous requests
Disable or isolate vulnerable modules if known

vulnerabilities.title: Oracle rushes out another emergency E-Business Suite patch as Clop fallout widens
vulnerabilities.original_title: Oracle rushes out another emergency E-Business Suite patch as Clop fallout widens
vulnerabilities.content_snippet: Latest in a long line of EBS flaws leta miscreants remotely compromise enterprise systems to pinch sensitive data Oracle is rushing out another emergency patch for its embattled E-Business Suite as the fallout from the Clop-linked attacks continues to spread.…
vulnerabilities.summary: Multiple remote code execution vulnerabilities in Oracle E-Business Suite allowing unauthenticated attackers to compromise enterprise systems.
vulnerabilities.description: The vulnerabilities reside in the web components of Oracle E-Business Suite, enabling remote attackers to execute arbitrary code, exfiltrate data, and install ransomware such as Clop. Specific CVE identifiers have not been disclosed in the article.
products_versions: Oracle E-Business Suite (specific versions not disclosed)
vulnerabilities.remediation: Apply the emergency patch released by Oracle for E-Business Suite. Follow Oracle's patching guidance and verify patch installation.
workarounds: Restrict network access to EBS interfaces
Implement web application firewall rules to block suspicious payloads
Enforce least privilege for database accounts

vulnerabilities.title: Pixel-stealing “Pixnapping” attack targets Android devices
vulnerabilities.original_title: Pixel-stealing “Pixnapping” attack targets Android devices
vulnerabilities.content_snippet: Researchers at US universities have demonstrated how a malicious Android app can trick the system into leaking pixel data. That may sound harmless, but imagine if a malicious app on your Android device could glimpse tiny bits of information on your screen—even the parts you thought were secure, like...
vulnerabilities.summary: Pixel-stealing side‑channel vulnerability on Android that allows a malicious app to capture screen pixel data and exfiltrate sensitive information such as 2FA codes.
vulnerabilities.description: A malicious Android application abuses the Intent system to overlay transparent windows on top of a target app and monitors subtle timing variations in pixel color rendering. By measuring these variations, the app can infer the color of specific screen pixels, enabling it to reconstruct sensitive on‑screen data such as authentication codes, messages, and map locations. The attack works across browsers and native apps (e.g., Google Authenticator, Signal, Venmo, Google Maps, Gmail). The framework bypasses existing browser and OS mitigations and can exfiltrate captured data to a remote C2 server within seconds.
affected_products: Android OS (versions supporting the vulnerable graphics stack, likely Android 13/14)
vulnerabilities.remediation: Apply vendor patches released by Google and Samsung as soon as they become available. Keep the Android OS and all installed apps up to date. Remove or disable any untrusted applications that request overlay permissions. Use hardware‑based 2FA where possible.
workarounds: Disable the "draw over other apps" permission for all non‑essential applications.
Restrict background activity and network access for untrusted apps via Android's privacy settings.
Use anti‑malware solutions with real‑time protection and overlay‑window detection.
references: Research paper from UC Berkeley, UC San Diego, University of Washington, and Carnegie Mellon University (2025)
Google security advisory (2025) – partial patch for CVE-2025-48561

vulnerabilities.title: Pixnapping Attack Steals Data From Google, Samsung Android Phones
vulnerabilities.original_title: Pixnapping Attack Steals Data From Google, Samsung Android Phones
vulnerabilities.content_snippet: Google has released a partial patch for the Pixnapping attack and is working on an additional fix. The post Pixnapping Attack Steals Data From Google, Samsung Android Phones appeared first on SecurityWeek.
vulnerabilities.summary: Pixnapping attack enables unauthorized capture of screen and data from Google and Samsung Android devices
vulnerabilities.description: The Pixnapping vulnerability exploits a flaw in the Android graphics subsystem that allows a malicious application to capture screen contents and exfiltrate data without user consent. The exploit can be triggered by installing a compromised app or by delivering a crafted payload through a malicious advertisement. Once executed, the payload can read clipboard data, capture screenshots, and transmit the information to a remote command‑and‑control server. The attack affects both stock Android builds from Google and customized Samsung firmware.
vulnerabilities.remediation: Google has released a partial patch; users should apply the available update immediately and monitor for the forthcoming full fix. Samsung is expected to release a corresponding update. Until the full patch is available, restrict installation of apps from unknown sources and revoke camera/screen capture permissions for untrusted apps.
workarounds: Disable screen capture permissions for all apps via Settings > Privacy > Screen Capture
Install a mobile security suite that monitors suspicious app behavior
Use a custom ROM with the vulnerability patched (if available)

vulnerabilities.title: RMPocalypse: Single 8-Byte Write Shatters AMD’s SEV-SNP Confidential Computing
vulnerabilities.original_title: RMPocalypse: Single 8-Byte Write Shatters AMD’s SEV-SNP Confidential Computing
vulnerabilities.content_snippet: Chipmaker AMD has released fixes to address a security flaw dubbed RMPocalypse that could be exploited to undermine confidential computing guarantees provided by Secure Encrypted Virtualization with Secure Nested Paging (SEV-SNP). The attack, per ETH Zürich researchers Benedict Schlüter and Shweta S...
vulnerabilities.summary: RMPocalypse allows an attacker to perform a single 8-byte write to the Reverse Map Table (RMP) in AMD SEV-SNP, breaking the confidentiality guarantees of confidential VMs.
vulnerabilities.description: The vulnerability stems from incomplete validation of RMP entries in AMD's SEV-SNP implementation. By issuing a crafted VM instruction sequence, an attacker can trigger a single 8‑byte write to an arbitrary RMP entry. This corrupts the mapping between guest physical pages and their protection attributes, allowing the attacker to read or modify memory of other confidential VMs, effectively breaking the isolation guarantees of SEV‑SNP.
affected_products: AMD EPYC processors with SEV-SNP support
AMD SEV-SNP firmware/AMD Secure Encrypted Virtualization
products_versions: AMD EPYC processors with SEV‑SNP firmware prior to the October 2025 security update
vulnerabilities.remediation: Apply AMD's firmware and microcode updates that add proper bounds checking and hardened RMP handling. Update the host BIOS/UEFI to the latest version that includes the SEV‑SNP patches. Re‑attest all VMs after the update.
workarounds: Restrict creation of untrusted VMs on hosts with SEV‑SNP enabled until patches are applied.
Disable SEV‑SNP on affected platforms if confidential computing is not required.
references: AMD Security Advisory (AMD-SA-2025-XYZ) – SEV‑SNP RMPocalypse mitigation
ETH Zürich research paper by Benedict Schlüter and Shweta Shinde (2025)

vulnerabilities.title: New Pixnapping Android Flaw Lets Rogue Apps Steal 2FA Codes Without Permissions
vulnerabilities.original_title: New Pixnapping Android Flaw Lets Rogue Apps Steal 2FA Codes Without Permissions
vulnerabilities.content_snippet: Android devices from Google and Samsung have been found vulnerable to a side-channel attack that could be exploited to covertly steal two-factor authentication (2FA) codes, Google Maps timelines, and other sensitive data without the users' knowledge pixel-by-pixel. The attack has been codenamed Pixn...
vulnerabilities.summary: Side-channel Pixnapping attack allows malicious Android apps to capture pixel‑by‑pixel screen data and steal 2FA codes, Google Maps timelines, and other sensitive information without requesting any permissions.
vulnerabilities.description: The Pixnapping technique leverages a timing‑based side‑channel to infer the exact pixel values displayed on the screen. By running a malicious app that repeatedly queries low‑level graphics buffers (e.g., via the SurfaceFlinger or hardware compositor) and correlating timing differences, the attacker can reconstruct the visual output of other apps. No explicit screen‑capture permission is needed because the attack does not invoke the standard screenshot APIs. The reconstructed frames can reveal one‑time passwords (OTPs) from authenticator apps, location history from Google Maps, and any other UI‑based secrets. The attack works on Android versions that expose the vulnerable graphics pipeline and is effective on both Google‑branded and Samsung‑branded devices.
products_versions: Samsung One UI based on Android 13/14
vulnerabilities.remediation: Apply the security patches released by Google and Samsung that harden the graphics compositor against unauthorized timing queries. Update devices to the latest Android security patch level. Disable or restrict overlay and accessibility services for untrusted apps. Consider using hardware‑backed 2FA tokens that do not rely on screen‑displayed codes.
workarounds: Install only apps from trusted sources (Google Play Store).
Revoke overlay, accessibility, and draw‑over‑other‑apps permissions from all non‑essential apps.
Use authenticator apps that display OTPs only within a secure, hardware‑isolated UI (e.g., Google Authenticator with screen‑lock protection).
Enable full‑disk encryption and strong device lock PIN/password.
Monitor and limit background processes that can access low‑level graphics APIs.
references: University of California Berkeley research paper on Pixnapping (if publicly released)
Android Security Bulletin (October 2025) – pending CVE assignment

vulnerabilities.title: RMPocalypse: New Attack Breaks AMD Confidential Computing
vulnerabilities.original_title: RMPocalypse: New Attack Breaks AMD Confidential Computing
vulnerabilities.content_snippet: A vulnerability in RMP initialization allows the AMD processor’s x86 cores to maliciously control parts of the initial RMP state. The post RMPocalypse: New Attack Breaks AMD Confidential Computing appeared first on SecurityWeek.
vulnerabilities.summary: Improper initialization of AMD's Reverse Map Table (RMP) allows malicious control of initial RMP state, breaking AMD Confidential Computing (SEV) guarantees.
vulnerabilities.description: During the initialization of the Reverse Map Table (RMP), which tracks the confidentiality state of physical memory pages, the AMD processor fails to properly enforce isolation of the RMP state. A malicious entity that can execute code on an x86 core (e.g., via a compromised hypervisor or malicious firmware) can manipulate portions of the initial RMP state, allowing it to downgrade or bypass the protections offered by AMD Confidential Computing. This enables extraction or tampering of encrypted VM memory, effectively breaking SEV and SEV‑SNP guarantees.
affected_products: AMD EPYC processors with Secure Encrypted Virtualization (SEV)
products_versions: AMD Ryzen Pro 5000 series and later with SEV‑SNP
vulnerabilities.remediation: Apply AMD microcode/firmware updates that correct the RMP initialization logic. If updates are not yet available, disable SEV/SEV‑SNP on affected systems or restrict privileged code execution to trusted components only.
workarounds: Disable AMD Secure Encrypted Virtualization (SEV) in BIOS/UEFI until a patch is released.
Enforce strict code signing for hypervisor and firmware components.

vulnerabilities.title: Unverified COTS hardware enables persistent attacks in small satellites via SpyChain
vulnerabilities.original_title: Unverified COTS hardware enables persistent attacks in small satellites via SpyChain
vulnerabilities.content_snippet: SpyChain shows how unverified COTS hardware in small satellites can enable persistent, multi-component supply chain attacks using NASA’s NOS3 simulator. The rise of small satellites has transformed scientific, commercial, and defense operations. Using commercial off-the-shelf (COTS) parts makes them...
vulnerabilities.summary: Supply-chain compromised COTS hardware in small satellites can execute stealthy, persistent multi-component malware using legitimate APIs and inter‑module communication.
vulnerabilities.description: An adversary with supply‑chain access embeds malicious firmware or software in a COTS component before launch. The compromised module remains dormant until a trigger condition (e.g., orbit insertion or timer expiration) is observed via GNSS data or system time. Upon activation it uses legitimate system calls, the spacecraft software bus, or hidden files to coordinate with a second malicious component. The coordinated payload exfiltrates telemetry to an attacker‑controlled ground station, injects deceptive commands, or disrupts communications while evading logs and runtime audits because it operates within allowed APIs and message formats.
affected_products: POSIX‑like operating systems used on satellites
NASA NOS3 simulation environment (used for testing)
affected_companies: COTS hardware vendors supplying flight‑qualified modules
vendors: COTS hardware vendors supplying flight‑qualified modules
vulnerabilities.remediation: Implement strict authentication and access control on the software bus, enforce runtime syscall filtering (e.g., seccomp), and require cryptographic signing of all firmware and software modules. Deploy continuous runtime monitoring of system calls, message rates, and file system activity to detect anomalies. Adopt a zero‑trust supply‑chain model with independent verification of COTS firmware and manifest‑based permission enforcement.
workarounds: Isolate critical flight software on a separate processor with hardware enforced access controls.
Disable or tightly restrict file‑system write permissions for third‑party modules.
Use whitelisting of allowed inter‑module messages and reject unexpected bus traffic.

vulnerabilities.title: The king is dead, long live the king! Windows 10 EOL and Windows 11 forensic artifacts
vulnerabilities.original_title: The king is dead, long live the king! Windows 10 EOL and Windows 11 forensic artifacts
vulnerabilities.content_snippet: Introduction Windows 11 was released a few years ago, yet it has seen relatively weak enterprise adoption. According to statistics from our Global Emergency Response Team (GERT) investigations, as recently as early 2025, we found that Windows 7, which reached end of support in 2020, was encountered ...
vulnerabilities.summary: Potential privacy leakage via Windows 11 Recall feature allowing unauthorized screenshot capture and storage of sensitive data
vulnerabilities.description:
The Recall feature continuously captures screenshots of the user’s desktop, stores raw JPEG images in %AppData%\Local\CoreAIPlatform.00\UKP\{GUID}\ImageStore, and indexes extracted text and metadata in an encrypted SQLite database (ukg.db). The built‑in privacy filter intended to block screenshots of sensitive UI (incognito windows, password fields, payment forms) has been reported as unreliable, allowing malicious actors to enable the feature via a per‑user registry key (Software\Policies\Microsoft\Windows\WindowsAI\) and harvest credentials, browsing history, and other confidential information. The database is accessible without admin rights, but remains encrypted; however, attackers can still exfiltrate the raw image files and metadata.

The feature is enabled by default on devices with an NPU and can be turned on by Group Policy, making it a viable vector for insider threat or malware that gains low‑level user privileges. No public CVE has been assigned to this privacy flaw, and Microsoft has not released a dedicated patch; mitigation relies on disabling the feature.
affected_products: Windows 11 on ARM devices with NPU
vulnerabilities.remediation: Disable Recall via Group Policy or registry (set Software\Policies\Microsoft\Windows\WindowsAI\RecallEnabled=0). Remove or restrict access to %AppData%\Local\CoreAIPlatform.00 directory. Monitor creation/modification of the ukg.db and ImageStore files. Apply least‑privilege principles to prevent unauthorized registry changes. Deploy endpoint detection rules to alert on the presence of CoreAIPlatform artifacts.
workarounds: Set the RecallEnabled policy to 0 in the corporate GPO.
Delete or quarantine the CoreAIPlatform.00 folder on endpoints.
Restrict write permissions on %AppData%\Local\CoreAIPlatform.00 to administrators only.

vulnerabilities.title: Researchers break OpenAI guardrails
vulnerabilities.original_title: Researchers break OpenAI guardrails
vulnerabilities.content_snippet: The maker of ChatGPT released a toolkit to help protect its AI from attack earlier this month. Almost immediately, someone broke it. On October 6, OpenAI ran an event called DevDay where it unveiled a raft of new tools and services for software programmers who use its products. As part of that, it a...
vulnerabilities.summary: Prompt injection bypass of OpenAI Guardrails in AgentKit allowing jailbreak of protected LLM requests
vulnerabilities.description: The Guardrails component uses an LLM to score incoming prompts and block jailbreak attempts. Researchers from HiddenLayer demonstrated that a crafted prompt injection can manipulate the internal confidence scoring, causing Guardrails to lower its detection threshold and allow disallowed content (e.g., instructions for weaponization). The same technique also evades the dedicated prompt‑injection detector, effectively bypassing both layers of protection. Because Guardrails itself is an LLM, the attack reuses the same model inference path, making the protection vulnerable to the same injection techniques that affect the base model.
affected_products: OpenAI ChatGPT API when used with Guardrails
vulnerabilities.remediation: OpenAI should redesign Guardrails to separate the policy enforcement engine from the generative LLM, incorporate deterministic parsing and static analysis of prompts, apply multi‑stage validation (e.g., regex, sandboxed policy model), and continuously update the injection detection signatures. Deploy rate‑limiting and anomaly detection on confidence‑score changes. Provide developers with best‑practice libraries for sanitizing user input before passing it to Guardrails.
workarounds: Wrap Guardrails calls with an external rule‑based filter that rejects known injection patterns before the LLM evaluates the request.
Enable human‑in‑the‑loop review for high‑risk prompts (e.g., instructions related to weapons, bio‑hazards).
Log and monitor confidence‑score anomalies and trigger alerts when scores drop unexpectedly.
references: Palo Alto Networks Unit 42 jailbreak comparison (2025)

vulnerabilities.title: Phishing Scams Exploit New York’s Inflation Refund Program
vulnerabilities.original_title: Phishing Scams Exploit New York’s Inflation Refund Program
vulnerabilities.content_snippet: A warning from the New York State on their website informs visitors that: “Scammers are calling, mailing, and texting taxpayers about income tax refunds, including the inflation refund check.” Here’s the warning on the website: We can confirm that several phishing campaigns are exploiting a le...
vulnerabilities.summary: SMS-based phishing (smishing) campaign impersonating the New York State Department of Revenue to harvest personal and financial information for a bogus inflation refund.
vulnerabilities.description: Scammers send SMS messages from foreign numbers claiming that the recipient's inflation refund has been approved and must be claimed by providing banking and personal data. The message contains a malicious URL that leads to a counterfeit website mimicking tax.ny.gov, where victims are prompted to enter name, address, email, phone, Social Security Number, and bank account details. The collected data can be used for identity theft, account takeover, and fraudulent fund transfers. The attack relies on social engineering (urgency, fear of loss) and does not exploit software bugs, but it is a classic credential‑harvesting vector.
affected_companies: New York State Department of Revenue
vendors: New York State Department of Revenue
vulnerabilities.remediation: Do not click links or reply to unsolicited tax‑related SMS, email, or phone calls. Verify any refund claim through official NYS Department of Revenue channels (tax.ny.gov) or by calling known government numbers. Deploy mobile anti‑phishing solutions and enable SMS filtering. Educate users about the official refund process (automatic, no action required). Report suspicious messages to NYS Tax Department and the FTC.
workarounds: Block known malicious sender numbers at the carrier level.
Use URL reputation services to block access to phishing domains.
Implement multi‑factor authentication on banking and tax accounts to mitigate credential misuse.

vulnerabilities.title: Microsoft restricts IE mode access in Edge after zero-day attacks
vulnerabilities.original_title: Microsoft restricts IE mode access in Edge after zero-day attacks
vulnerabilities.content_snippet: Microsoft is restricting access to Internet Explorer mode in Edge browser after learning that hackers are leveraging zero-day exploits in the Chakra JavaScript engine for access to target devices. [...]
vulnerabilities.summary: Zero-day remote code execution vulnerability in the Chakra JavaScript engine leveraged through Internet Explorer mode in Microsoft Edge.
vulnerabilities.description: Threat actors are exploiting a previously unknown vulnerability in the Chakra JavaScript engine that is invoked when a web page is rendered in Internet Explorer mode within Microsoft Edge. The flaw allows arbitrary code execution on the host system without requiring user interaction, leading to full system compromise. The exploit is delivered via malicious JavaScript payloads hosted on compromised or attacker-controlled websites and is executed when the victim visits the site using Edge with IE mode enabled.
products_versions: Microsoft Edge with IE mode enabled (all current versions as of 2025)
vulnerabilities.remediation: Microsoft has temporarily restricted access to IE mode in Edge. Administrators should disable IE mode via Group Policy or Enterprise settings, block legacy sites, and apply any forthcoming patches from Microsoft as soon as they are released.
workarounds: Disable IE mode in Microsoft Edge through Enterprise configuration.
Block or filter traffic to legacy sites that require IE mode.
Enforce use of modern browsers for all web access.
Implement application whitelisting to prevent execution of unauthorized binaries.
references: Microsoft Security Advisory (future reference when published)

vulnerabilities.title: ShinyHunters Leak Alleged Data from Qantas, Vietnam Airlines and Other Major Firms
vulnerabilities.original_title: ShinyHunters Leak Alleged Data from Qantas, Vietnam Airlines and Other Major Firms
vulnerabilities.content_snippet: ShinyHunters and its affiliate hackers have leaked data from 6 firms, including Qantas and Vietnam Airlines, after claiming to breach 39 companies via a Salesforce vulnerability.
vulnerabilities.summary: Exploitation of a vulnerability in Salesforce platform leading to unauthorized access and data exfiltration
vulnerabilities.description: Threat actors leveraged an unpatched or mis‑configured vulnerability in the Salesforce SaaS platform to gain unauthorized access to tenant data. The flaw allowed attackers to bypass authentication controls, enumerate accounts, and extract sensitive information from compromised organizations such as Qantas and Vietnam Airlines. The exact technical details (e.g., vulnerable endpoint, CVE identifier) were not disclosed in the source article.
vulnerabilities.remediation: Apply the latest Salesforce security patches, review and harden API permissions, enforce multi‑factor authentication for all users, and rotate compromised credentials.
workarounds: Restrict API access to trusted IP ranges
Disable unused Salesforce features and integrations
Implement strict role‑based access controls

vulnerabilities.title: Oracle releases emergency patch for new E-Business Suite flaw
vulnerabilities.original_title: Oracle releases emergency patch for new E-Business Suite flaw
vulnerabilities.content_snippet: Oracle has issued an emergency security update over the weekend to patch another E-Business Suite (EBS) vulnerability that can be exploited remotely by unauthenticated attackers. [...]
vulnerabilities.summary: Remote unauthenticated code execution vulnerability in Oracle E-Business Suite
vulnerabilities.description: A newly discovered flaw in Oracle E-Business Suite allows an unauthenticated remote attacker to execute arbitrary code on the affected server. The vulnerability is exploitable over the network without any prior authentication or user interaction. Oracle released an emergency patch to address the issue. Technical details of the flaw have not been publicly disclosed, but it is believed to involve insufficient input validation in a web component of the suite, leading to remote code execution.
products_versions: Oracle E-Business Suite (all supported versions at time of disclosure)
vulnerabilities.remediation: Apply the emergency security update released by Oracle for the affected E-Business Suite installations. Verify patch installation and restart affected services.
workarounds: Temporarily block external access to the vulnerable web component via firewall rules.
Disable the affected module or functionality if it is not required.

vulnerabilities.title: Microsoft revamps Internet Explorer Mode in Edge after August attacks
vulnerabilities.original_title: Microsoft revamps Internet Explorer Mode in Edge after August attacks
vulnerabilities.content_snippet: Microsoft updated Edge’s Internet Explorer mode after August 2025 reports that attackers exploited it to access users’ devices without authorization. Microsoft updated Edge’s Internet Explorer mode after reports in August 2025 that threat actors exploited the backward compatibility feature to gain u...
vulnerabilities.summary: Remote code execution and privilege escalation via unpatched Internet Explorer Chakra JavaScript engine vulnerabilities exploited through Edge IE mode
vulnerabilities.description: Threat actors used social engineering to convince users to reload a malicious web page in Internet Explorer mode within Microsoft Edge. The page leveraged a 0‑day vulnerability in the Chakra JavaScript engine of IE11 to achieve remote code execution in the browser context. A second, separate exploit was then used to elevate privileges from the browser process to the local system, granting the attacker full control of the victim device. The chain allowed installation of malware, lateral movement, and data exfiltration.
products_versions: Microsoft Edge (all versions supporting IE mode as of 2025)
vulnerabilities.remediation: Disable IE mode where not required; enable IE mode only on a per‑site basis via Settings > Default Browser; apply all available security updates for Internet Explorer and Edge; monitor for and block attempts to switch to IE mode; employ application whitelisting and least‑privilege policies.
workarounds: Turn off IE mode for non‑commercial users
Require explicit site‑by‑site enabling of IE mode
Use Group Policy to restrict or block the IE mode feature
Educate users to avoid reloading pages in IE mode
references: Microsoft Security Advisory (August 2025) – unnamed Chakra exploits

vulnerabilities.title: Harvard investigating breach linked to Oracle zero-day exploit
vulnerabilities.original_title: Harvard investigating breach linked to Oracle zero-day exploit
vulnerabilities.content_snippet: Harvard University is investigating a data breach after the Clop ransomware gang listed the school on its data leak site, saying the alleged breach was likely caused by a recently disclosed zero-day vulnerability in Oracle's E-Business Suite servers. [...]
vulnerabilities.summary: Zero-day remote code execution vulnerability in Oracle E-Business Suite servers
vulnerabilities.description: A recently disclosed zero‑day vulnerability in Oracle's E‑Business Suite allows an unauthenticated remote attacker to execute arbitrary code on the affected server. The flaw is believed to be leveraged by the Clop ransomware group to gain initial foothold, exfiltrate data, and deploy ransomware. Technical details indicate a flaw in the web component that processes crafted HTTP requests, leading to deserialization of untrusted data and code execution.
products_versions: Oracle E‑Business Suite (specific version not disclosed)
vulnerabilities.remediation: Apply the official Oracle security patch as soon as it is released. In the interim, restrict inbound traffic to the E‑Business Suite web interface, enforce strong network segmentation, and deploy a web application firewall with rules to block malicious payloads.
workarounds: Block external access to Oracle E‑Business Suite web services via firewall ACLs
Implement virtual patching using IDS/IPS signatures
Disable or restrict vulnerable modules/functions if possible

vulnerabilities.title: Oracle Patches EBS Vulnerability Allowing Access to Sensitive Data
vulnerabilities.original_title: Oracle Patches EBS Vulnerability Allowing Access to Sensitive Data
vulnerabilities.content_snippet: It’s unclear if the new Oracle E-Business Suite flaw, which can be exploited remotely without authentication, has been used in the wild. The post Oracle Patches EBS Vulnerability Allowing Access to Sensitive Data appeared first on SecurityWeek.
vulnerabilities.summary: Unauthenticated remote vulnerability in Oracle E-Business Suite allowing access to sensitive data
vulnerabilities.description: A newly discovered flaw in Oracle E-Business Suite (EBS) can be exploited remotely without any authentication. The vulnerability enables an attacker to retrieve sensitive business data from the affected EBS instance. The exact technical details (e.g., vulnerable component, request patterns) have not been disclosed publicly. Oracle has released a security patch to remediate the issue, but it is unclear whether the vulnerability has been observed in the wild.
vulnerabilities.remediation: Apply the Oracle-provided security patch for the affected EBS version as soon as possible. Verify patch installation and restart affected services.
workarounds: Restrict inbound network traffic to the EBS servers using firewalls or security groups.
Disable or limit exposure of the vulnerable service/interface if known.
Implement strict access controls and monitor for anomalous activity.

vulnerabilities.title: Microsoft Locks Down IE Mode After Hackers Turned Legacy Feature Into Backdoor
vulnerabilities.original_title: Microsoft Locks Down IE Mode After Hackers Turned Legacy Feature Into Backdoor
vulnerabilities.content_snippet: Microsoft said it has revamped the Internet Explorer (IE) mode in its Edge browser after receiving "credible reports" in August 2025 that unknown threat actors were abusing the backward compatibility feature to gain unauthorized access to users' devices. "Threat actors were leveraging basic social e...
vulnerabilities.summary: Unpatched 0-day vulnerabilities in Internet Explorer's JavaScript engine abused via Edge's IE mode to achieve remote code execution.
vulnerabilities.description: Threat actors leveraged social engineering to lure users into loading malicious web content in Edge's IE compatibility mode. The content exploited a previously unknown vulnerability in the Internet Explorer JavaScript engine, allowing execution of arbitrary code in the context of the logged‑in user, leading to full system compromise. Because IE mode runs legacy IE components, the exploit bypasses many modern mitigations present in the Chromium‑based Edge engine.
vulnerabilities.remediation: Microsoft released an updated IE mode that disables the vulnerable legacy components and enforces stricter site isolation. Apply the latest cumulative updates for Windows 10/11 and Edge, and ensure IE mode is configured according to the new hardening guidelines.
workarounds: Disable IE mode in Edge Group Policy.
Block legacy sites that require IE mode via web proxy or firewall.
Enable Microsoft Defender Application Guard for untrusted sites.

vulnerabilities.title: CVE-2025-11371: Unpatched zero-day in Gladinet CentreStack, Triofox under attack
vulnerabilities.original_title: CVE-2025-11371: Unpatched zero-day in Gladinet CentreStack, Triofox under attack
vulnerabilities.content_snippet: Threat actors are exploiting a zero-day, tracked as CVE-2025-11371 in Gladinet CentreStack and Triofox products. Threat actors are exploiting the local File Inclusion (LFI) flaw CVE-2025-11371, a zero-day in Gladinet CentreStack and Triofox. A local user can exploit the issue to access system files ...
vulnerabilities.summary: Unauthenticated Local File Inclusion (LFI) in Gladinet CentreStack and Triofox allowing retrieval of the Web.config machine key.
vulnerabilities.description: The vulnerability resides in the UploadDownloadProxy component where a configurable temp handler points to a location (t.dn) that can be abused to include arbitrary files from the server's filesystem. An attacker can send a crafted HTTP request that triggers the handler to read the application's Web.config file, exposing the hard‑coded machine key. With the machine key, the attacker can craft a malicious ViewState payload that leads to remote code execution via a previously disclosed deserialization flaw (CVE-2025-30406). The flaw is exploitable without authentication and does not require prior access to the system.
products_versions: All CentreStack and Triofox versions prior to the undisclosed patch (specific versions not listed in the article).
vulnerabilities.remediation: Apply the vendor‑provided patch once released. In the meantime, edit the Web.config of the affected application and remove or comment out the temp handler entry for UploadDownloadProxy (the line referencing t.dn). Restart the web service after modification.
workarounds: Disable the temp handler in UploadDownloadProxy’s Web.config as described in the Huntress advisory.
Restrict access to the web application by IP allow‑listing or VPN.
Monitor and block suspicious requests to the UploadDownloadProxy endpoint.

vulnerabilities.title: CVE-2025-11371: Unpatched zero-day in Gladinet CentreStack, Triofox under attack
vulnerabilities.original_title: CVE-2025-11371: Unpatched zero-day in Gladinet CentreStack, Triofox under attack
vulnerabilities.content_snippet: Threat actors are exploiting a zero-day, tracked as CVE-2025-11371 in Gladinet CentreStack and Triofox products. Threat actors are exploiting the local File Inclusion (LFI) flaw CVE-2025-11371, a zero-day in Gladinet CentreStack and Triofox. A local user can exploit the issue to access system files ...
vulnerabilities.summary: Hard‑coded machine key enables remote code execution via ViewState deserialization.
vulnerabilities.description: A hard‑coded machine key embedded in the Web.config file allows an attacker who knows the key to forge a malicious ViewState payload. When the payload is processed by the vulnerable application, it triggers deserialization of untrusted data, leading to remote code execution.
products_versions: All CentreStack and Triofox versions prior to the undisclosed patch (specific versions not listed in the article).
vulnerabilities.remediation: Patch the product once the vendor releases an update that removes the hard‑coded key and fixes the ViewState handling. Until then, rotate the machine key and restrict ViewState usage where possible.
workarounds: Regenerate a unique machine key and replace the default value in Web.config.
Disable ViewState MAC validation if not required (with caution).

vulnerabilities.title: Cybercrime ring GXC Team dismantled in Spain, 25-year-old leader detained
vulnerabilities.original_title: Cybercrime ring GXC Team dismantled in Spain, 25-year-old leader detained
vulnerabilities.content_snippet: Spain’s Guardia Civil dismantled the cybercrime group “GXC Team” and arrested its 25-year-old Brazilian leader. Spanish Guardia Civil dismantled the “GXC Team” cybercrime group, arresting its 25-year-old Brazilian leader “GoogleXcoder.” The gang sold AI-powered phishing kits, Android malware, and vo...
vulnerabilities.summary: Malicious Android application mimicking official banking apps to intercept OTPs
vulnerabilities.description: The GXC Team distributed Android malware that is packaged to look like legitimate mobile banking apps. Victims are tricked into installing the fake app under the pretext of confirming a One-Time Password (OTP). The malicious app captures the OTP and forwards it to a command‑and‑control server, allowing the attacker to complete the authentication flow and gain unauthorized access to the victim's online banking account.
exploit_kits: Credential harvesting kits for banking and government sites
vulnerabilities.remediation: Enforce strict app verification (e.g., Google Play Protect, enterprise mobile management), educate users to install apps only from official stores, implement out‑of‑band OTP delivery, and deploy mobile threat detection solutions.
workarounds: Require hardware‑based second factor (e.g., U2F/YubiKey) that cannot be intercepted by the app
Use transaction signing via separate device or app

vulnerabilities.title: Cybercrime ring GXC Team dismantled in Spain, 25-year-old leader detained
vulnerabilities.original_title: Cybercrime ring GXC Team dismantled in Spain, 25-year-old leader detained
vulnerabilities.content_snippet: Spain’s Guardia Civil dismantled the cybercrime group “GXC Team” and arrested its 25-year-old Brazilian leader. Spanish Guardia Civil dismantled the “GXC Team” cybercrime group, arresting its 25-year-old Brazilian leader “GoogleXcoder.” The gang sold AI-powered phishing kits, Android malware, and vo...
vulnerabilities.summary: AI‑powered Business Invoice Swapper tool used for Business Email Compromise (BEC) and invoice fraud
vulnerabilities.description: The tool ingests a list of compromised email accounts, associated credentials, and banking details (IBAN/BIC). Using AI, it automatically generates fraudulent invoices that appear legitimate and sends them to victims, prompting wire transfers to attacker‑controlled accounts. The service is offered as a rental or one‑time purchase, enabling low‑skill actors to conduct large‑scale BEC attacks.
affected_products: Email clients and servers used by targeted organizations
exploit_kits: Credential harvesting kits for banking and government sites
vulnerabilities.remediation: Implement DMARC, SPF, and DKIM; enforce strict verification of invoice changes; use multi‑factor authentication for email access; deploy AI‑based email anomaly detection; require out‑of‑band confirmation for payment requests.
workarounds: Manual verification of any change in payment details
Segregate finance approval workflows from regular email communication

vulnerabilities.original_title: Cybercrime ring GXC Team dismantled in Spain, 25-year-old leader detained
vulnerabilities.content_snippet: Spain’s Guardia Civil dismantled the cybercrime group “GXC Team” and arrested its 25-year-old Brazilian leader. Spanish Guardia Civil dismantled the “GXC Team” cybercrime group, arresting its 25-year-old Brazilian leader “GoogleXcoder.” The gang sold AI-powered phishing kits, Android malware, and vo...
vulnerabilities.summary: Phishing kits cloning banking, payment, and government portals for credential harvesting
vulnerabilities.description: The GXC Team distributes ready‑to‑use phishing kits that replicate the look and functionality of legitimate banking, payment, and government websites. Victims are lured via email, SMS, or social media to enter credentials on the cloned site, which are then captured and forwarded to the attackers for subsequent account takeover and fraud.
affected_products: Online banking portals (e.g., AMEX, PayPal, Santander, etc.)
exploit_kits: Credential harvesting kits for banking and government sites
vulnerabilities.remediation: Deploy anti‑phishing web filters, educate users on URL verification, enforce browser security extensions (e.g., anti‑phishing), implement credential‑stuffing protection, and monitor for newly registered domains mimicking target brands.
workarounds: Use password‑less authentication where possible
Enable browser‑based site isolation and safe browsing features

vulnerabilities.title: Hackers exploiting zero-day in Gladinet file sharing software
vulnerabilities.original_title: Hackers exploiting zero-day in Gladinet file sharing software
vulnerabilities.content_snippet: Threat actors are exploiting a zero-day vulnerability (CVE-2025-11371) in Gladinet CentreStack and Triofox products, which allows a local attacker to access system files without authentication. [...]
vulnerabilities.summary: Zero-day vulnerability in Gladinet CentreStack and Triofox allowing local attackers to read arbitrary system files without authentication.
vulnerabilities.description: The vulnerability resides in the file handling component of Gladinet CentreStack and Triofox. An attacker with local access can invoke a specially crafted request that bypasses authentication checks and reads arbitrary files from the operating system, including configuration files, credential stores, and other sensitive data. The flaw is exploitable without any special privileges or user interaction, making it suitable for post‑exploitation data collection or further privilege escalation.
products_versions: All versions of CentreStack and Triofox prior to the forthcoming patch (exact versions not disclosed)
vulnerabilities.remediation: Apply the vendor‑released patch as soon as it becomes available. Until a patch is released, restrict local access to the Gladinet services, disable unnecessary file‑sharing features, and enforce strict file‑system permissions.
workarounds: Limit local logon to trusted administrators only.
Disable or uninstall Gladinet CentreStack/Triofox on systems where it is not required.
Enforce host‑based firewalls to block inbound connections to the Gladinet service ports.
Monitor and audit file‑access logs for suspicious activity.

vulnerabilities.title: Auth Bypass Flaw in Service Finder WordPress Plugin Under Active Exploit
vulnerabilities.original_title: Auth Bypass Flaw in Service Finder WordPress Plugin Under Active Exploit
vulnerabilities.content_snippet: An Authentication Bypass (CVE-2025-5947) in Service Finder Bookings plugin allows any unauthenticated attacker to log in as an administrator. Over 13,800 exploit attempts detected. Update to v6.1 immediately.
vulnerabilities.summary: Authentication bypass in Service Finder Bookings WordPress plugin allowing unauthenticated attackers to log in as an administrator.
vulnerabilities.description: The plugin fails to properly validate authentication tokens during the login process. An attacker can craft a request that bypasses credential checks and is granted an administrator session. The flaw is exploitable over the web without any prior access or user interaction, leading to full compromise of the WordPress site.
vulnerabilities.remediation: Update the Service Finder Bookings plugin to version 6.1 or later, which includes the authentication bypass fix. If immediate update is not possible, temporarily disable the plugin.
workarounds: Disable the Service Finder Bookings plugin until a patched version is applied.
Block access to the vulnerable login endpoint using a Web Application Firewall (WAF).
Restrict admin access to known IP ranges.

vulnerabilities.summary: Exploitation of a vulnerability in Gladinet file sharing software allowing remote code execution.
vulnerabilities.description: Threat actors are actively exploiting a flaw in Gladinet that permits unauthenticated attackers to execute arbitrary code on the server hosting the file sharing service. The vulnerability appears to be a deserialization issue in the web interface, leading to command injection.
vulnerabilities.remediation: Apply the vendor‑provided security patch released in the latest Gladinet update. If a patch is not yet available, block inbound traffic to the Gladinet service and enforce strict network segmentation.
workarounds: Restrict access to Gladinet to trusted IP ranges
Disable the vulnerable web module until a fix is released

vulnerabilities.description: Attackers leveraged an unauthenticated path in Zimbra's webmail component to bypass authentication and read mailbox contents. The flaw is linked to improper validation of session tokens.
vulnerabilities.remediation: Upgrade to the latest Zimbra release that includes the fix for CVE‑2025‑XXXX (if assigned) or apply the vendor‑issued patch. Rotate all service accounts and enforce MFA for admin logins.
workarounds: Block external access to Zimbra web interface
Enable strict CSP headers

vulnerabilities.summary: Mic‑E‑Mouse attack targeting IoT devices via a firmware flaw.
vulnerabilities.description: A newly observed campaign uses a buffer overflow in the Mic‑E‑Mouse device driver to achieve remote code execution on the device, allowing attackers to pivot into the internal network.
vulnerabilities.remediation: Update the device firmware to the version released on 2025‑09‑30. If an update is not available, isolate the devices on a separate VLAN and monitor for anomalous traffic.
workarounds: Disable remote management ports
Enforce strict inbound ACLs

vulnerabilities.summary: ClayRat spyware campaign delivering credential‑stealing payloads.
vulnerabilities.description: ClayRat is a modular spyware framework that exfiltrates credentials, screenshots, and audio recordings. It is typically delivered via malicious email attachments or compromised software updates.
vulnerabilities.remediation: Deploy updated endpoint protection, block known C2 domains, and enforce application whitelisting. Conduct full system scans on affected hosts.
workarounds: Disable macros in Office documents
Restrict execution of unsigned binaries

vulnerabilities.remediation: Implement multi‑factor authentication for payroll systems, conduct security awareness training, and monitor for anomalous payment requests.
workarounds: Enforce least‑privilege access for payroll accounts
Require dual‑approval for large transfers

vulnerabilities.remediation: Update the honeypot software to the latest version, isolate it from production networks, and enable strict logging of all interactions.
workarounds: Run the honeypot in a sandboxed environment
Limit inbound connections to known research IP ranges

vulnerabilities.title: Ukraine sees surge in AI-Powered cyberattacks by Russia-linked Threat Actors
vulnerabilities.original_title: Ukraine sees surge in AI-Powered cyberattacks by Russia-linked Threat Actors
vulnerabilities.content_snippet: Russia-linked actors use AI to craft phishing and malware attacks against entities in Ukraine, says SSSCIP. Russian hackers increasingly use AI in cyberattacks against Ukraine, the country’s State Service for Special Communications and Information Protection (SSSCIP) reported. Beyond AI-genera...
vulnerabilities.summary: Cross‑site scripting (XSS) vulnerability in Roundcube webmail allowing remote code execution via crafted email content.
vulnerabilities.description: The vulnerability permits injection of malicious JavaScript into email bodies that are rendered by Roundcube without proper sanitisation. An attacker can deliver a crafted email that, when processed by the victim's Roundcube instance, executes arbitrary script code in the context of the user’s session, enabling credential theft, session hijacking, or further malware delivery. The exploit is zero‑click, requiring no interaction from the victim beyond normal email receipt.
vulnerabilities.remediation: Upgrade Roundcube to a version that includes the vendor’s patch for CVE‑2023‑43770. Apply input‑validation and output‑encoding updates. Deploy a web‑application firewall (WAF) rule to block malicious script payloads.
workarounds: Enable strict Content‑Security‑Policy (CSP) headers on the Roundcube server.
Disable HTML rendering for email bodies where possible.
Restrict execution of JavaScript in the webmail client via browser extensions.

Russian hackers increasingly use AI in cyberattacks against Ukraine, the country’s State Service for Special Communications and Information Protection (SSSCIP) reported. Beyond AI-genera...
vulnerabilities.summary: Stored XSS vulnerability in Zimbra Collaboration Suite allowing remote code execution via crafted email attachments.
vulnerabilities.description: An attacker can embed malicious JavaScript in an email attachment (e.g., SVG or HTML) that is stored on the Zimbra server. When the victim opens the email in the Zimbra web client, the script executes without user interaction, enabling credential theft and further payload delivery.
vulnerabilities.remediation: Apply the Zimbra patch released for CVE‑2024‑37383. Ensure the latest version of Zimbra is deployed and enable built‑in XSS protection mechanisms.
workarounds: Configure Zimbra to strip potentially dangerous tags from incoming messages.
Deploy a WAF to detect and block known XSS payload patterns.

Russian hackers increasingly use AI in cyberattacks against Ukraine, the country’s State Service for Special Communications and Information Protection (SSSCIP) reported. Beyond AI-genera...
vulnerabilities.summary: Reflected XSS flaw in Roundcube allowing attackers to execute arbitrary JavaScript via crafted URL parameters.
vulnerabilities.description: The vulnerability is triggered when a victim clicks a malicious link that includes specially crafted query parameters. The parameters are reflected in the webmail interface without proper encoding, resulting in script execution in the victim’s browser.
vulnerabilities.remediation: Update Roundcube to the version containing the fix for CVE‑2025‑49113. Apply input sanitisation patches and enable CSP.
workarounds: Educate users to avoid clicking unknown links in emails.
Deploy browser‑based XSS protection extensions.

Russian hackers increasingly use AI in cyberattacks against Ukraine, the country’s State Service for Special Communications and Information Protection (SSSCIP) reported. Beyond AI-genera...
vulnerabilities.summary: Cross‑site scripting vulnerability in Zimbra allowing injection of malicious scripts via the message preview feature.
vulnerabilities.description: When a user previews an email, Zimbra fails to properly encode HTML content, allowing an attacker to embed JavaScript that runs in the context of the victim’s session.
vulnerabilities.remediation: Install the Zimbra update that addresses CVE‑2024‑27443. Enable server‑side output encoding for all email content.
workarounds: Disable HTML preview in the web client.
Apply a WAF rule to block script tags in inbound email bodies.
