vulnerabilities.summary: Stored XSS vulnerability in Roundcube that can be leveraged to deliver ransomware via malicious SVG files.
vulnerabilities.description: Attackers embed malicious SVG payloads in email attachments. When the SVG is rendered by Roundcube’s preview engine, the embedded script executes automatically, dropping ransomware onto the victim’s system without any user interaction.
vulnerabilities.remediation: Upgrade Roundcube to the patched version that sanitises SVG content. Configure the server to block SVG rendering or enforce strict CSP.
workarounds: Block SVG attachments at the mail gateway.
Enforce sandboxed rendering of SVG files in the client.

vulnerabilities.title: Cisco, Fortinet, Palo Alto Networks Devices Targeted in Coordinated Campaign
vulnerabilities.original_title: Cisco, Fortinet, Palo Alto Networks Devices Targeted in Coordinated Campaign
vulnerabilities.content_snippet: GreyNoise has discovered that attacks exploiting Cisco, Fortinet, and Palo Alto Networks vulnerabilities are launched from the same infrastructure. The post Cisco, Fortinet, Palo Alto Networks Devices Targeted in Coordinated Campaign appeared first on SecurityWeek.
vulnerabilities.summary: Attacks exploiting vulnerabilities in Cisco, Fortinet, and Palo Alto Networks devices observed in a coordinated campaign.
vulnerabilities.description: GreyNoise identified that attacks leveraging vulnerabilities in Cisco, Fortinet, and Palo Alto Networks products are being launched from the same command‑and‑control infrastructure, indicating a coordinated threat actor campaign targeting network infrastructure devices. Specific CVE identifiers were not disclosed in the source article.
vulnerabilities.remediation: Apply all available vendor security patches and firmware updates for the affected devices, enforce strong authentication, segment management networks, and block known malicious IP ranges associated with the campaign.
workarounds: Restrict inbound management traffic to trusted IPs
Disable unused services and ports on the devices
Implement network‑based intrusion detection/prevention signatures for known exploit patterns

vulnerabilities.title: From Detection to Patch: Fortra Reveals Full Timeline of CVE-2025-10035 Exploitation
vulnerabilities.original_title: From Detection to Patch: Fortra Reveals Full Timeline of CVE-2025-10035 Exploitation
vulnerabilities.content_snippet: Fortra on Thursday revealed the results of its investigation into CVE-2025-10035, a critical security flaw in GoAnywhere Managed File Transfer (MFT) that's assessed to have come under active exploitation since at least September 11, 2025. The company said it began its investigation on September 11 f...
vulnerabilities.summary: Critical remote code execution vulnerability in GoAnywhere Managed File Transfer (MFT) allowing unauthenticated attackers to execute arbitrary code on the server.
vulnerabilities.description: The vulnerability resides in the file transfer handling component of GoAnywhere MFT. A specially crafted request can trigger unsafe deserialization/command injection, leading to full system compromise. Exploitation has been observed in the wild since at least 2025-09-11, with threat actors leveraging the flaw to gain persistent access, exfiltrate data, and pivot within victim networks.
vulnerabilities.remediation: Apply the official patch released by Fortra as soon as possible. Verify that the installed version includes the fix for CVE-2025-10035.
workarounds: Temporarily disable external file transfer services until the patch is applied.
Restrict access to the MFT server to trusted IP ranges using firewall rules.
Enable multi-factor authentication for all administrative accounts.

vulnerabilities.title: Juniper Networks Patches Critical Junos Space Vulnerabilities
vulnerabilities.original_title: Juniper Networks Patches Critical Junos Space Vulnerabilities
vulnerabilities.content_snippet: Patches were rolled out for more than 200 vulnerabilities in Junos Space and Junos Space Security Director, including nine critical-severity flaws. The post Juniper Networks Patches Critical Junos Space Vulnerabilities appeared first on SecurityWeek.
vulnerabilities.summary: Multiple vulnerabilities in Junos Space and Junos Space Security Director addressed by Juniper patch release
vulnerabilities.description: Juniper Networks released patches for more than 200 vulnerabilities affecting Junos Space and Junos Space Security Director, including nine critical‑severity flaws. The specific CVE identifiers, CVSS metrics, and technical details were not disclosed in the source article.
affected_products: Juniper Networks Junos Space Security Director
vulnerabilities.remediation: Apply the latest Junos Space and Junos Space Security Director patches released by Juniper Networks. Verify patch installation via the Juniper management console.
workarounds: No known workarounds; immediate patching is recommended.

vulnerabilities.title: ZDI Drops 13 Unpatched Ivanti Endpoint Manager Vulnerabilities
vulnerabilities.original_title: ZDI Drops 13 Unpatched Ivanti Endpoint Manager Vulnerabilities
vulnerabilities.content_snippet: The unpatched vulnerabilities allow attackers to execute arbitrary code remotely and escalate their privileges. The post ZDI Drops 13 Unpatched Ivanti Endpoint Manager Vulnerabilities appeared first on SecurityWeek.
vulnerabilities.summary: Multiple unpatched vulnerabilities in Ivanti Endpoint Manager that allow remote code execution and privilege escalation.
vulnerabilities.description: ZDI reported 13 separate vulnerabilities in Ivanti Endpoint Manager that are currently unpatched. The flaws can be exploited remotely without authentication to execute arbitrary code on the target system and subsequently elevate privileges to a higher level, potentially gaining full control of the endpoint. Specific technical details (e.g., vulnerable components, memory corruption, injection vectors) were not disclosed in the article.
vulnerabilities.remediation: Monitor Ivanti security advisories and apply official patches as soon as they are released. Until patches are available, restrict network access to the management interface, enforce strong authentication, and employ application whitelisting.
workarounds: Disable external access to the Ivanti Endpoint Manager console.
Enforce network segmentation to limit exposure of the management server.
Enable multi-factor authentication for all administrative accounts.

vulnerabilities.title: Sophisticated Malware Deployed in Oracle EBS Zero-Day Attacks
vulnerabilities.original_title: Sophisticated Malware Deployed in Oracle EBS Zero-Day Attacks
vulnerabilities.content_snippet: Google researchers believe exploitation may have started as early as July 10 and the campaign hit dozens of organizations. The post Sophisticated Malware Deployed in Oracle EBS Zero-Day Attacks appeared first on SecurityWeek.
vulnerabilities.summary: Zero-day vulnerability in Oracle E-Business Suite (EBS) exploited by sophisticated malware.
vulnerabilities.description: Researchers observed a campaign that began as early as 2025-07-10 targeting Oracle EBS with a previously unknown (zero‑day) vulnerability. The exploit delivers sophisticated malware capable of persisting within the EBS environment, exfiltrating data, and executing further lateral movement. No public CVE identifier has been assigned at the time of reporting.
vulnerabilities.remediation: Apply any security patches released by Oracle for EBS immediately. If patches are not yet available, restrict network access to EBS servers, enforce strong authentication, and monitor for anomalous activity.
workarounds: Block inbound traffic to EBS web interfaces from untrusted networks.
Enforce multi‑factor authentication for all privileged accounts.
Deploy host‑based intrusion detection systems (HIDS) to monitor EBS processes.

vulnerabilities.title: CL0P-Linked Hackers Breach Dozens of Organizations Through Oracle Software Flaw
vulnerabilities.original_title: CL0P-Linked Hackers Breach Dozens of Organizations Through Oracle Software Flaw
vulnerabilities.content_snippet: Dozens of organizations may have been impacted following the zero-day exploitation of a security flaw in Oracle's E-Business Suite (EBS) software since August 9, 2025, Google Threat Intelligence Group (GTIG) and Mandiant said in a new report released Thursday. "We're still assessing the scope of thi...
vulnerabilities.summary: Zero-day remote code execution vulnerability in Oracle E-Business Suite (EBS) allowing unauthenticated attackers to execute arbitrary code on affected servers.
vulnerabilities.description: A previously unknown flaw in Oracle E-Business Suite (EBS) web components enables an attacker to send specially crafted HTTP requests that trigger unauthenticated remote code execution. The vulnerability has been actively exploited in the wild since at least 2025-08-09, with threat actors linked to the CL0P ransomware group leveraging the flaw to gain footholds in multiple organizations. Exploitation results in full system compromise, allowing data exfiltration, lateral movement, and deployment of ransomware payloads.
vulnerabilities.remediation: Apply the Oracle Security Patch for the identified EBS vulnerability as soon as it is released. If a patch is not yet available, implement the temporary mitigations listed below and monitor Oracle security advisories for updates.
workarounds: Restrict inbound traffic to EBS web servers to trusted IP ranges using firewall rules.
Disable or block the vulnerable web endpoints until a patch is applied.
Deploy a Web Application Firewall (WAF) with custom rules to detect and block the malicious request patterns.
Enforce strong network segmentation and limit lateral movement.

vulnerabilities.title: ClayRat campaign uses Telegram and phishing sites to distribute Android spyware
vulnerabilities.original_title: ClayRat campaign uses Telegram and phishing sites to distribute Android spyware
vulnerabilities.content_snippet: ClayRat Android spyware targets Russian users via fake Telegram channels and phishing sites posing as popular apps like WhatsApp and YouTube. The ClayRat Android spyware campaign targets Russian users via fake Telegram channels and phishing sites posing as popular apps like Google Photos, WhatsApp, ...
vulnerabilities.summary: Abuse of Android's default SMS handler role to bypass runtime permission prompts and gain unrestricted SMS read/write access
vulnerabilities.description: ClayRat requests to become the default SMS handler on the device. When granted, it bypasses the standard runtime permission model, allowing it to read, send, intercept, and modify SMS messages without further user consent. This enables mass propagation via automatically generated SMS messages to all contacts and provides a covert channel for exfiltrating sensitive data such as OTPs, two‑factor codes, and personal communications.
vulnerabilities.remediation: Do not grant unknown applications the default SMS handler role. Install apps only from trusted sources (Google Play Store) and enable Play Protect. Keep Android OS and security patches up to date. Enforce strict permission policies via enterprise mobility management (EMM) solutions.
workarounds: Revoke default SMS handler permission from suspicious apps via Settings > Apps > Default apps.
Use a dedicated SMS app from a reputable vendor and lock the default handler setting.
Monitor and block outbound SMS traffic from unknown applications.

vulnerabilities.title: Fake VPN and streaming app drops malware that drains your bank account
vulnerabilities.original_title: Fake VPN and streaming app drops malware that drains your bank account
vulnerabilities.content_snippet: Security researchers are warning Android users to delete a fake VPN and streaming app that can let criminals take over their phones and drain their bank accounts. The app, Mobdro Pro IP TV + VPN, was discovered by researchers at Cleafy to be a malicious sideloaded app, not a legitimate VPN. Their an...
vulnerabilities.summary: Malicious Android application 'Mobdro Pro IP TV + VPN' sideloaded onto devices installs the Klopatra banking Trojan and remote-access tool, enabling credential theft and unauthorized financial transactions.
vulnerabilities.description: The threat actor distributes a fake VPN/IPTV application via unofficial download sites. When a user sideloads the APK, the app requests extensive permissions (device control, Accessibility Services, install other apps). Upon installation, it silently drops the Klopatra banking Trojan, which gains remote access, monitors UI interactions, captures banking credentials, and can initiate fraudulent transactions. The infection chain relies on social engineering, lack of Play Store vetting, and Android's permission model that allows apps to request high‑privilege capabilities if the user consents.
affected_products: Android operating system (all versions supporting sideloaded apps)
Mobdro Pro IP TV + VPN (malicious APK)
vulnerabilities.remediation: Remove the malicious application immediately. Perform a full device scan with reputable mobile anti‑malware software. Factory reset the device if compromise is suspected. Change all banking passwords from a trusted device. Ensure the Android OS and all apps are updated to the latest security patches. Disable installation from unknown sources.
workarounds: Block installation of apps from unknown sources via device policy.
Restrict Accessibility Service permissions to trusted apps only.
Use mobile device management (MDM) solutions to enforce app whitelisting.

vulnerabilities.title: Closing the Cloud Security Gap
vulnerabilities.original_title: Closing the Cloud Security Gap
vulnerabilities.content_snippet: Insights From the 2025 Unit 42 Global Incident Response Report The main tenet of cloud security is simple: Apply the same rigorous cybersecurity best practices you use elsewhere. But that’s easier said than done. Since the emergence of cloud technology, organizations have been working to secure it t...
vulnerabilities.summary: Publicly accessible cloud storage bucket
vulnerabilities.description: Misconfigured storage buckets that allow anonymous read or write access expose sensitive data to the internet. Attackers can enumerate bucket contents, download confidential files, or upload malicious payloads, leading to data leakage or further compromise of downstream services.
vulnerabilities.remediation: Review and tighten bucket policies; enforce least‑privilege access; enable block public access settings; use bucket ACLs and IAM policies to restrict access; enable server‑side encryption; monitor bucket activity with cloud audit logs.
workarounds: Temporarily disable public access on the bucket
Move sensitive data to a more secure storage class with stricter access controls

vulnerabilities.title: Closing the Cloud Security Gap
vulnerabilities.original_title: Closing the Cloud Security Gap
vulnerabilities.content_snippet: Insights From the 2025 Unit 42 Global Incident Response Report The main tenet of cloud security is simple: Apply the same rigorous cybersecurity best practices you use elsewhere. But that’s easier said than done. Since the emergence of cloud technology, organizations have been working to secure it t...
vulnerabilities.summary: Unpatched container image containing known vulnerabilities
vulnerabilities.description: Containers built from base images that are not regularly patched may contain vulnerable libraries or binaries (e.g., CVE‑2024‑XXXX). When such images are deployed, attackers can exploit the embedded flaws to achieve remote code execution, privilege escalation, or data exfiltration within the compromised workload.
vulnerabilities.remediation: Implement automated image scanning in CI/CD pipelines; regularly rebuild images using up‑to‑date base layers; apply vendor patches promptly; enforce signed images and use a trusted registry; adopt a vulnerability management policy for container workloads.
workarounds: Run containers with reduced capabilities and read‑only file systems
Isolate vulnerable containers in separate namespaces or sandbox environments

vulnerabilities.title: Closing the Cloud Security Gap
vulnerabilities.original_title: Closing the Cloud Security Gap
vulnerabilities.content_snippet: Insights From the 2025 Unit 42 Global Incident Response Report The main tenet of cloud security is simple: Apply the same rigorous cybersecurity best practices you use elsewhere. But that’s easier said than done. Since the emergence of cloud technology, organizations have been working to secure it t...
vulnerabilities.summary: Overprivileged IAM credentials and long‑lived access keys
vulnerabilities.description: Credentials with excessive permissions (e.g., Administrator or Owner roles) enable threat actors to enumerate resources, modify configurations, and exfiltrate data. Long‑lived access keys that are not rotated increase the window of opportunity for credential theft and reuse.
vulnerabilities.remediation: Adopt the principle of least privilege; regularly audit IAM policies; enforce short‑lived credentials via STS or workload identity federation; rotate access keys on a defined schedule; enable multi‑factor authentication; monitor IAM activity for anomalous behavior.
workarounds: Restrict API calls from untrusted networks using conditional access policies
Implement just‑in‑time (JIT) access provisioning for privileged actions

vulnerabilities.original_title: ThreatsDay Bulletin: MS Teams Hack, MFA Hijacking, $2B Crypto Heist, Apple Siri Probe & More
vulnerabilities.content_snippet: Cyber threats are evolving faster than ever. Attackers now combine social engineering, AI-driven manipulation, and cloud exploitation to breach targets once considered secure. From communication platforms to connected devices, every system that enhances convenience also expands the attack surface. T...
vulnerabilities.summary: Potential remote code execution or data leakage vulnerability in Microsoft Teams client allowing attackers to hijack sessions or exfiltrate data.
vulnerabilities.description: Attackers combine phishing, AI‑generated social engineering, and cloud API abuse to compromise Microsoft Teams accounts. By exploiting insufficient validation of inbound requests and token handling, they can gain unauthorized access to chat histories, files, and potentially execute code within the client environment.
vulnerabilities.remediation: Apply the latest Microsoft Teams updates, enforce conditional access policies, and require MFA for all logins. Review and rotate compromised tokens.
workarounds: Disable external guest access temporarily
Enforce MFA for all users
Restrict Teams API calls to known IP ranges

vulnerabilities.original_title: ThreatsDay Bulletin: MS Teams Hack, MFA Hijacking, $2B Crypto Heist, Apple Siri Probe & More

From communication platforms to connected devices, every system that enhances convenience also expands the attack surface. T...
vulnerabilities.summary: MFA hijacking technique leveraging push‑notification fatigue and man‑in‑the‑middle attacks to bypass multi‑factor authentication.
vulnerabilities.description: Adversaries send repeated MFA push requests to users, exploiting human fatigue to obtain approval. In some cases, attackers intercept the push flow via compromised mobile devices or malicious apps, allowing them to approve authentication without the user's knowledge.
affected_products: Various MFA providers (Microsoft Authenticator, Duo, Authy)
vulnerabilities.remediation: Implement MFA push‑approval limits, use phishing‑resistant factors (e.g., hardware tokens, biometrics), and monitor for abnormal push‑approval patterns.
workarounds: Require second factor via OTP instead of push
Enable adaptive authentication policies

From communication platforms to connected devices, every system that enhances convenience also expands the attack surface. T...
vulnerabilities.summary: Large‑scale cryptocurrency theft exploiting compromised exchange APIs and insecure hot‑wallet handling.
vulnerabilities.description: Attackers leveraged weak API authentication and lack of transaction signing isolation to move funds from hot wallets, resulting in an estimated $2 billion loss. The breach also involved credential stuffing against exchange admin accounts.
vulnerabilities.remediation: Enforce strict API key scopes, implement multi‑signature wallets, and conduct regular audits of hot‑wallet balances. Apply rate‑limiting and IP‑allowlist controls.
workarounds: Move majority of funds to cold storage
Enable withdrawal whitelists

vulnerabilities.original_title: ThreatsDay Bulletin: MS Teams Hack, MFA Hijacking, $2B Crypto Heist, Apple Siri Probe & More
vulnerabilities.content_snippet: Cyber threats are evolving faster than ever. Attackers now combine social engineering, AI-driven manipulation, and cloud exploitation to breach targets once considered secure. From communication platforms to connected devices, every system that enhances convenience also expands the attack surface. T...
vulnerabilities.summary: Apple Siri voice‑command injection probe that can trigger unauthorized actions on iOS/macOS devices.
vulnerabilities.description: Researchers discovered that specially crafted audio sequences can bypass Siri's command validation, allowing execution of limited system actions (e.g., opening URLs, sending messages). The attack requires proximity to the device's microphone.
vulnerabilities.remediation: Update iOS and macOS to the latest releases where Apple has hardened Siri's command parsing. Disable Siri when device is locked if not needed.
workarounds: Turn off 'Hey Siri' activation
Restrict Siri access on lock screen

vulnerabilities.title: GitHub Copilot Chat Flaw Leaked Data From Private Repositories
vulnerabilities.original_title: GitHub Copilot Chat Flaw Leaked Data From Private Repositories
vulnerabilities.content_snippet: Hidden comments allowed full control over Copilot responses and leaked sensitive information and source code. The post GitHub Copilot Chat Flaw Leaked Data From Private Repositories appeared first on SecurityWeek.
vulnerabilities.summary: Hidden comment injection in GitHub Copilot Chat allows attackers to gain full control over responses and exfiltrate private repository data.
vulnerabilities.description: A flaw in the parsing of hidden comments within GitHub Copilot Chat enables an attacker to embed specially crafted comments that are not stripped before being processed by the underlying language model. These comments can be used to manipulate the model's output, causing it to reveal source code, configuration files, and other sensitive artifacts from private repositories that the user has access to. The vulnerability stems from insufficient sanitization of user‑provided prompt content before it is sent to the AI service, effectively providing a covert channel for data exfiltration.
products_versions: GitHub Copilot Chat (all versions as of 2025-10-09)
vulnerabilities.remediation: GitHub should update the Copilot Chat input sanitization logic to strip or reject hidden comment syntax before processing. Deploy a server‑side validation layer that normalizes prompts and blocks any control sequences. Until a patch is released, administrators should disable Copilot Chat for private repositories and enforce strict access controls on who can invoke the feature.
workarounds: Disable Copilot Chat for private repositories via organization settings.
Restrict usage of hidden comment syntax in prompts.
Monitor and audit Copilot Chat logs for anomalous response patterns.

vulnerabilities.title: Chinese Hackers Breached Law Firm Williams & Connolly via Zero-Day
vulnerabilities.original_title: Chinese Hackers Breached Law Firm Williams & Connolly via Zero-Day
vulnerabilities.content_snippet: The company said there is no evidence that confidential client data was stolen from its systems. The post Chinese Hackers Breached Law Firm Williams & Connolly via Zero-Day appeared first on SecurityWeek.
vulnerabilities.summary: Zero-day exploit used to gain unauthorized access to Williams & Connolly law firm's network
vulnerabilities.description: Chinese state-sponsored threat actors leveraged an undisclosed zero-day vulnerability to bypass security controls and obtain foothold within the internal systems of the law firm Williams & Connolly. The specific vulnerability, affected software, and exploitation technique were not disclosed in the public report. No evidence of client data exfiltration was found, but the breach indicates a high‑impact intrusion capability.
vulnerabilities.remediation: Since the vulnerability is undisclosed, organizations should apply a defense-in-depth approach: ensure all software is up to date, monitor for anomalous activity, segment networks, enforce least‑privilege access, and engage with the vendor for any forthcoming patches or mitigations.
workarounds: Implement network segmentation to isolate critical systems
Deploy application whitelisting and strict execution controls
Increase monitoring of privileged account activity

vulnerabilities.title: Discord denies massive breach, confirms limited exposure of 70K ID photos
vulnerabilities.original_title: Discord denies massive breach, confirms limited exposure of 70K ID photos
vulnerabilities.content_snippet: Discord won’t pay threat actors claiming 5.5M user breach, saying only about 70K ID photos were actually exposed. Discord announced it won’t pay the threat actors claiming to have stolen data on 5.5M users, clarifying that only about 70K ID photos were actually exposed. The attackers claimed they ha...
vulnerabilities.summary: Compromise of third‑party Zendesk support provider leading to unauthorized API queries against Discord internal systems and exfiltration of user data including ID photos.
vulnerabilities.description: Threat actors gained access to Discord's Zendesk instance, likely through compromised credentials or insufficient segmentation of the third‑party vendor. Using Zendesk integrations they issued millions of API queries to Discord's internal support systems, retrieving up to 1.6 TB of data (8.4 M support tickets, 70 K government‑ID photos, emails, usernames, phone numbers, payment details, and MFA information). The breach was limited to data that passed through the support channel; Discord's core platform was not directly compromised. The attackers attempted extortion, demanding several million dollars, and released sample data to pressure the company.
vulnerabilities.remediation: Revoke all third‑party access tokens, rotate API keys and credentials for Zendesk integrations, enforce least‑privilege access for vendors, implement strict API rate‑limiting and anomaly detection, conduct a full security audit of third‑party providers, and require vendors to meet SOC 2 / ISO 27001 controls. Notify affected users and law enforcement.
workarounds: Temporarily disable external Zendesk API integrations until security controls are verified.
Restrict API access to internal IP ranges or VPN.
Apply additional MFA for vendor accounts.

vulnerabilities.title: Hackers Exploit WordPress Sites to Power Next-Gen ClickFix Phishing Attacks
vulnerabilities.original_title: Hackers Exploit WordPress Sites to Power Next-Gen ClickFix Phishing Attacks
vulnerabilities.content_snippet: Cybersecurity researchers are calling attention to a nefarious campaign targeting WordPress sites to make malicious JavaScript injections that are designed to redirect users to sketchy sites. "Site visitors get injected content that was drive-by malware like fake Cloudflare verification," Sucuri res...
vulnerabilities.summary: Malicious JavaScript injection on compromised WordPress sites used to redirect visitors to phishing and drive‑by malware pages.
vulnerabilities.description: Threat actors compromise WordPress installations—often via vulnerable plugins, outdated core, or insecure credentials—and inject malicious JavaScript into site pages. The injected script executes on visitor browsers, performing silent redirects to attacker‑controlled domains that host fake Cloudflare verification pages or other drive‑by malware. The attack is a classic supply‑chain compromise: legitimate traffic is leveraged to deliver phishing or malware without the victim’s knowledge.
affected_products: WordPress plugins/themes vulnerable to arbitrary file upload or XSS
products_versions: All WordPress versions prior to the latest security patches (specific versions depend on the vulnerable plugin/theme).
vulnerabilities.remediation: Update WordPress core, all plugins, and themes to the latest versions; remove or replace vulnerable components. Harden file permissions (disable wp‑admin file editing, set proper ownership). Deploy a Web Application Firewall (WAF) with rules to block suspicious script injections. Scan the site for unknown/modified files and malicious code. Reset all compromised credentials and enforce strong passwords/MFA.
workarounds: Temporarily disable or uninstall the identified vulnerable plugin/theme.
Serve the site behind a reverse‑proxy WAF that sanitizes outbound HTML/JS.
Enable WordPress’s built‑in file integrity checks or use a security plugin (e.g., Sucuri, Wordfence) to monitor file changes.

vulnerabilities.title: Is your computer mouse eavesdropping on you?
vulnerabilities.original_title: Is your computer mouse eavesdropping on you?
vulnerabilities.content_snippet: The short answer is: probably not, but theoretically it’s possible. Researchers at the University of California found a method they called Mic-E-Mouse, which turns your computer mouse into a spy that can listen in on your conversations. The method uses high-performance optical sensors in optical mic...
vulnerabilities.summary: Side-channel attack (Mic-E-Mouse) using high‑DPI optical mouse sensors to reconstruct speech from vibrations.
vulnerabilities.description: Researchers demonstrated that the optical sensor in a standard USB mouse can capture minute vibrations caused by sound waves. By recording raw sensor data, applying AI‑based signal processing, and transmitting the data to a remote server, an attacker can reconstruct intelligible speech (≈61% accuracy) without any visible changes to the host system. The attack requires the victim to run malicious software that reads the mouse sensor data and exfiltrates it. No hardware modification is needed; the attack works on off‑the‑shelf $35 mice.
affected_products: Optical computer mice with high DPI (up to 20,000 DPI)
affected_companies: Various mouse manufacturers (26 notified, names not disclosed in article)
vendors: Various mouse manufacturers (26 notified, names not disclosed in article)
products_versions: High‑DPI optical mice (e.g., 2000‑20000 DPI models) running standard firmware
vulnerabilities.remediation: Update mouse firmware and drivers when patches are released by the manufacturer. Deploy endpoint protection that can detect unauthorized mouse‑sensor access or unusual outbound traffic. Disable or restrict access to raw HID data where possible.
workarounds: Place the mouse on a dampened mouse mat or desk cover to attenuate vibrations.
Operate in a noisy environment (e.g., background music) to mask speech vibrations.
Use a non‑optical (e.g., mechanical) mouse or a trackball that lacks high‑resolution optical sensors.
Restrict execution of unsigned software that can access HID devices.
references: University of California research paper on Mic‑E‑Mouse (link not provided in article)

vulnerabilities.title: “Can you test my game?” Fake itch.io pages spread hidden malware to gamers
vulnerabilities.original_title: “Can you test my game?” Fake itch.io pages spread hidden malware to gamers
vulnerabilities.content_snippet: You get a message from a Discord friend. Or maybe an unknown indie developer reaches out to you. “Can you test my game?” they ask.  The webpage they send over a link to looks legit: screenshots, dev blurb, itch.io-style layout, and the download button is right there, waiting to be clicked. &nbs...
vulnerabilities.summary: Malicious loader delivered via fake itch.io pages uses PowerShell encoded commands, in‑memory execution, and privilege escalation to install a Node.js runtime and download additional payloads.
vulnerabilities.description: A social‑engineering campaign distributes a disguised executable (Setup Game.exe) through compromised Discord accounts and fake itch.io pages hosted on Blogger subdomains or cloud storage. When executed, the file silently launches PowerShell with an -EncodedCommand that decodes and runs a second-stage script entirely in memory. The script hides its console window via a .NET trick, attempts to relaunch with elevated privileges using runas, and compiles a small helper binary on the fly with csc.exe. It then extracts a bundled Node.js runtime and native modules into the user's cache directory (C:\Users\<user>\.cache\pkg\...), terminates browsers to impede investigation, performs sandbox‑evasion checks (network session, registry, BIOS), and finally contacts a C2 server to download the final payload (e.g., backdoor, keylogger, cryptocurrency miner).
affected_products: Web browsers (Chrome, Brave, Firefox, Edge, Opera) – targeted for termination
affected_companies: Various web browsers (Chrome, Brave, Firefox, Edge, Opera)
vendors: Various web browsers (Chrome, Brave, Firefox, Edge, Opera)
vulnerabilities.remediation: Isolate the infected machine, terminate suspicious PowerShell processes, delete the created cache and temporary folders, run a full anti‑malware scan, reset compromised credentials, enable multi‑factor authentication, and consider a clean OS reinstall if deep compromise is suspected.
workarounds: Disable PowerShell script execution for non‑administrative users (Set-ExecutionPolicy Restricted).
Block execution of unsigned binaries from %TEMP% and user cache directories via AppLocker or Windows Defender Application Control.
Restrict usage of csc.exe to authorized developer accounts.

vulnerabilities.title: LLM Black Markets in 2025 – Prompt Injection, Jailbreak Sales & Model Leaks
vulnerabilities.original_title: LLM Black Markets in 2025 – Prompt Injection, Jailbreak Sales & Model Leaks
vulnerabilities.content_snippet: Explore how LLM black markets in 2025 trade prompt jailbreaks, model leaks & exploit tools, insight for red teams, CISOs & threat intel.
vulnerabilities.summary: Prompt injection and jailbreak techniques allow adversaries to manipulate LLM outputs and extract proprietary model weights.
vulnerabilities.description: Adversaries craft specially designed prompts (jailbreaks) that bypass safety filters, causing the LLM to produce disallowed content or reveal internal knowledge. In some cases, repeated queries enable model extraction, leaking weights and training data. These techniques are sold on darknet markets and are readily reproducible with publicly available tooling.
vulnerabilities.remediation: Implement multi‑layered prompt sanitization, enforce strict content policies, employ runtime monitoring, and limit token generation for suspicious patterns. Update model guardrails and apply vendor‑provided safety patches.
workarounds: Deploy a secondary validation LLM to review outputs before release.
Rate‑limit API calls per user and flag anomalous request patterns.
references: Google Gemini Model Guardrails Release Notes (2025)

vulnerabilities.title: A Cascade of Insecure Architectures: Axis Plugin Design Flaw Expose Select Autodesk Revit Users to Supply Chain Risk
vulnerabilities.original_title: A Cascade of Insecure Architectures: Axis Plugin Design Flaw Expose Select Autodesk Revit Users to Supply Chain Risk
vulnerabilities.content_snippet: We discovered Azure Storage Account credentials exposed in Axis Communications’ Autodesk Revit plugin, allowing unauthorized modification of cloud-hosted files. This exposure, combined with vulnerabilities in Autodesk Revit, could enable supply-chain attacks targeting end users.
vulnerabilities.summary: Hardcoded Azure Storage Account credentials in Axis Communications' Autodesk Revit plugin allow unauthorized modification of cloud‑hosted files.
vulnerabilities.description: The plugin ships with hard‑coded Azure Storage Account keys. An attacker who discovers or extracts these credentials can directly access the storage container, read, replace, or delete Revit project files stored in the cloud. When combined with known weaknesses in Autodesk Revit's handling of external file references, an adversary can inject malicious content into Revit models, achieving a supply‑chain compromise of downstream users.
affected_products: Autodesk Revit (any version that loads the plugin)
Azure Storage Account used by the plugin
vulnerabilities.remediation: Remove hard‑coded credentials from the plugin source. Regenerate storage account keys and rotate them. Implement Azure AD authentication or SAS tokens with limited permissions. Release an updated, signed plugin version. Autodesk should advise customers to verify plugin integrity and apply any Revit hardening guidance.
workarounds: Disable or uninstall the Axis Communications plugin until a fixed version is available.
Restrict the Azure Storage Account to specific virtual networks or IP ranges.
Enable Azure Storage logging and set up alerts for anomalous access patterns.

vulnerabilities.title: ShinyHunters Wage Broad Corporate Extortion Spree
vulnerabilities.original_title: ShinyHunters Wage Broad Corporate Extortion Spree
vulnerabilities.content_snippet: A cybercriminal group that used voice phishing attacks to siphon more than a billion records from Salesforce customers earlier this year has launched a website that threatens to publish data stolen from dozens of Fortune 500 firms if they refuse to pay a ransom. The group also claimed responsibility...
vulnerabilities.summary: Unauthenticated remote code execution vulnerability in Oracle E-Business Suite
vulnerabilities.description: A critical zero‑day flaw allows an unauthenticated attacker to execute arbitrary code on the server hosting Oracle E‑Business Suite. The vulnerability was first exploited in August 2025 by the Clop ransomware group to steal data from Oracle E‑Business Suite installations. Exploits were publicly released via scripts on the Scattered Lapsus$ Hunters blog.
products_versions: Oracle E‑Business Suite (all versions vulnerable to CVE‑2025‑61882 until patched)
Salesforce (any edition where third‑party apps can be authorized)
GitLab self‑hosted instance used by Red Hat (specific version not disclosed)
Discord (user‑account data stored by third‑party support provider)
Salesloft AI chatbot integration (specific version not disclosed)
vulnerabilities.remediation: Apply the emergency update released by Oracle immediately. Verify that the patch is installed on all E‑Business Suite instances and restart affected services.
workarounds: Restrict network access to Oracle E‑Business Suite servers to trusted IP ranges.
Disable unnecessary services and enforce strict firewall rules.
Monitor for suspicious outbound connections from the affected servers.
references: Mandiant analysis on Clop exploitation of CVE-2025-61882

vulnerabilities.title: Troops and veterans’ personal information leaked in CPAP Medical data breach
vulnerabilities.original_title: Troops and veterans’ personal information leaked in CPAP Medical data breach
vulnerabilities.content_snippet: In December 2024, CPAP Medical Supplies and Services Inc. (CPAP), a Jacksonville—a Florida-based provider of sleep therapy services and CPAP machines—experienced a cybersecurity incident that compromised the personal data of over 90,000 patients. Since CPAP Medical specializes in tailored sleep apne...
vulnerabilities.summary: Unauthorized actor accessed CPAP Medical's internal network, resulting in exfiltration of personal and health data of over 90,000 patients.
vulnerabilities.description: Between 2024-12-13 and 2024-12-21 an unauthorized actor gained access to CPAP Medical's network. The breach went undetected for approximately six months, allowing the attacker to exfiltrate sensitive personally identifiable information (PII) and protected health information (PHI) including full names, birth dates, Social Security numbers, health insurance details, medical history, and treatment plans. The article does not disclose a specific vulnerability (e.g., CVE) but the prolonged dwell time suggests deficiencies in network segmentation, logging, intrusion detection, and patch management.
affected_products: Potentially underlying operating systems, web applications, or VPN solutions used by CPAP Medical
affected_companies: CPAP Medical Supplies and Services Inc.
vendors: CPAP Medical Supplies and Services Inc.
vulnerabilities.remediation: Conduct a comprehensive forensic investigation to identify the initial entry point, apply all relevant security patches, enforce network segmentation, implement multi-factor authentication for privileged access, and deploy continuous monitoring and anomaly detection solutions.
workarounds: Restrict remote access to trusted IP ranges
Disable unused services and ports
Enforce strong password policies and rotate credentials

vulnerabilities.title: Hackers exploited Zimbra flaw as zero-day using iCalendar files
vulnerabilities.original_title: Hackers exploited Zimbra flaw as zero-day using iCalendar files
vulnerabilities.content_snippet: Researchers monitoring for larger .ICS calendar attachments found that a flaw in Zimbra Collaboration Suite (ZCS) was used in zero-day attacks at the beginning of the year. [...]
vulnerabilities.summary: Remote code execution vulnerability in Zimbra Collaboration Suite (ZCS) triggered by specially crafted iCalendar (.ics) files.
vulnerabilities.description: An attacker can embed malicious JavaScript/HTML payloads within an iCalendar (.ics) attachment. When the attachment is opened in the Zimbra web client or processed by the ZCS mail scanner, the payload is executed on the server, leading to remote code execution with the privileges of the Zimbra service account. The flaw was observed being exploited in the wild as a zero‑day at the start of 2025.
products_versions: Zimbra Collaboration Suite 8.x and 9.x (specific versions not disclosed in the article)
vulnerabilities.remediation: Upgrade Zimbra Collaboration Suite to the version that includes the official security patch released by Zimbra (or Synacor). Apply the provided security update that sanitizes iCalendar parsing and disables unsafe content execution. If a patch is not yet available, apply the temporary mitigation steps listed under workarounds.
workarounds: Block or quarantine .ics attachments at the email gateway.
Disable iCalendar preview functionality in the Zimbra web client.
Configure the mail scanner to strip or sanitize iCalendar files before delivery.
Enforce strict content‑type validation for calendar attachments.

vulnerabilities.title: U.S. CISA adds Smartbedded Meteobridge, Samsung, Juniper ScreenOS, Jenkins, and GNU Bash flaws to its Known Exploited Vulnerabilities catalog
vulnerabilities.original_title: U.S. CISA adds Smartbedded Meteobridge, Samsung, Juniper ScreenOS, Jenkins, and GNU Bash flaws to its Known Exploited Vulnerabilities catalog
vulnerabilities.content_snippet: U.S. Cybersecurity and Infrastructure Security Agency (CISA) adds Smartbedded Meteobridge, Samsung, Juniper ScreenOS, Jenkins, and GNU Bash flaws to its Known Exploited Vulnerabilities catalog. The U.S. Cybersecurity and Infrastructure Security Agency (CISA) added Smartbedded Meteobridge, Samsung, J...
vulnerabilities.summary: GNU Bash OS command injection due to incomplete fix of earlier Bash bugs.
vulnerabilities.description: An attacker can craft specially formed environment variables that trigger arbitrary command execution when Bash parses them. The flaw stems from an incomplete remediation of CVE-2014-6271, CVE-2014-7169, and CVE-2014-6277, allowing remote code execution without authentication.
products_versions: Bash versions prior to the fix for CVE-2014-6278
Juniper ScreenOS versions prior to the security advisory patch
Smartbedded Meteobridge firmware prior to the 2025 security update
Samsung Android devices with libimagecodec.quram.so prior to SMR Sep‑2025 Release 1
vulnerabilities.remediation: Upgrade Bash to a version that includes the fix for CVE-2014-6278 (e.g., Bash 4.4.23 or later) or apply the vendor‑provided patches.
workarounds: Restrict Bash usage to trusted users
Disable Bash for services that accept untrusted input
Deploy a web‑application firewall that blocks malicious environment variable patterns

vulnerabilities.title: U.S. CISA adds Smartbedded Meteobridge, Samsung, Juniper ScreenOS, Jenkins, and GNU Bash flaws to its Known Exploited Vulnerabilities catalog
vulnerabilities.original_title: U.S. CISA adds Smartbedded Meteobridge, Samsung, Juniper ScreenOS, Jenkins, and GNU Bash flaws to its Known Exploited Vulnerabilities catalog
vulnerabilities.content_snippet: U.S. Cybersecurity and Infrastructure Security Agency (CISA) adds Smartbedded Meteobridge, Samsung, Juniper ScreenOS, Jenkins, and GNU Bash flaws to its Known Exploited Vulnerabilities catalog. The U.S. Cybersecurity and Infrastructure Security Agency (CISA) added Smartbedded Meteobridge, Samsung, J...
vulnerabilities.summary: Juniper ScreenOS improper authentication allowing admin access via SSH/TELNET.
vulnerabilities.description: Remote attackers can send an unspecified password during an SSH or TELNET session to bypass authentication and obtain administrative privileges on devices running vulnerable ScreenOS versions.
products_versions: Bash versions prior to the fix for CVE-2014-6278
Juniper ScreenOS versions prior to the security advisory patch
Smartbedded Meteobridge firmware prior to the 2025 security update
Samsung Android devices with libimagecodec.quram.so prior to SMR Sep‑2025 Release 1
vulnerabilities.remediation: Upgrade ScreenOS to the latest release that addresses CVE-2015-7755 or apply the Juniper security advisory patch.
workarounds: Disable TELNET access
Restrict SSH access to trusted IP ranges
Enforce strong, unique passwords and enable two‑factor authentication

vulnerabilities.title: U.S. CISA adds Smartbedded Meteobridge, Samsung, Juniper ScreenOS, Jenkins, and GNU Bash flaws to its Known Exploited Vulnerabilities catalog
vulnerabilities.original_title: U.S. CISA adds Smartbedded Meteobridge, Samsung, Juniper ScreenOS, Jenkins, and GNU Bash flaws to its Known Exploited Vulnerabilities catalog
vulnerabilities.content_snippet: U.S. Cybersecurity and Infrastructure Security Agency (CISA) adds Smartbedded Meteobridge, Samsung, Juniper ScreenOS, Jenkins, and GNU Bash flaws to its Known Exploited Vulnerabilities catalog. The U.S. Cybersecurity and Infrastructure Security Agency (CISA) added Smartbedded Meteobridge, Samsung, J...
vulnerabilities.summary: Jenkins unauthenticated remote code execution via deserialization of a malicious SignedObject.
vulnerabilities.description: An attacker can send a serialized Java SignedObject to the Jenkins remoting CLI. The object is deserialized using a new ObjectInputStream that bypasses the blacklist, leading to arbitrary code execution on the Jenkins master.
affected_products: Jenkins (core and plugins using the remoting CLI)
products_versions: Bash versions prior to the fix for CVE-2014-6278
Juniper ScreenOS versions prior to the security advisory patch
Smartbedded Meteobridge firmware prior to the 2025 security update
Samsung Android devices with libimagecodec.quram.so prior to SMR Sep‑2025 Release 1
vulnerabilities.remediation: Upgrade Jenkins to a version that includes the fix (Jenkins 2.176.3 or later) and ensure the remoting CLI is disabled if not required.
workarounds: Disable the remote CLI feature
Restrict access to the Jenkins server to trusted networks
Apply a custom blacklist that includes SignedObject

vulnerabilities.original_title: U.S. CISA adds Smartbedded Meteobridge, Samsung, Juniper ScreenOS, Jenkins, and GNU Bash flaws to its Known Exploited Vulnerabilities catalog

The U.S. Cybersecurity and Infrastructure Security Agency (CISA) added Smartbedded Meteobridge, Samsung, J...
vulnerabilities.summary: Smartbedded Meteobridge web interface command injection allowing unauthenticated root command execution.
vulnerabilities.description: The web interface fails to properly sanitize user‑supplied input, enabling an attacker to inject OS commands that are executed with root privileges on the device.
products_versions: Bash versions prior to the fix for CVE-2014-6278
Juniper ScreenOS versions prior to the security advisory patch
Smartbedded Meteobridge firmware prior to the 2025 security update
Samsung Android devices with libimagecodec.quram.so prior to SMR Sep‑2025 Release 1
vulnerabilities.remediation: Apply the firmware update released by Smartbedded that sanitizes command inputs, or upgrade to the latest Meteobridge version.
workarounds: Block external access to the Meteobridge web UI via firewall rules
Restrict management access to trusted internal networks only

vulnerabilities.title: U.S. CISA adds Smartbedded Meteobridge, Samsung, Juniper ScreenOS, Jenkins, and GNU Bash flaws to its Known Exploited Vulnerabilities catalog

vulnerabilities.content_snippet: U.S. Cybersecurity and Infrastructure Security Agency (CISA) adds Smartbedded Meteobridge, Samsung, Juniper ScreenOS, Jenkins, and GNU Bash flaws to its Known Exploited Vulnerabilities catalog. The U.S. Cybersecurity and Infrastructure Security Agency (CISA) added Smartbedded Meteobridge, Samsung, J...
vulnerabilities.summary: Samsung mobile devices out‑of‑bounds write in libimagecodec.quram.so leading to arbitrary code execution.
vulnerabilities.description: A flaw in the image codec library permits an out‑of‑bounds write, which can be triggered by a crafted media file. Successful exploitation results in remote code execution on the device.
affected_products: Samsung mobile devices (Android) using libimagecodec.quram.so prior to SMR Sep‑2025 Release 1
products_versions: Bash versions prior to the fix for CVE-2014-6278
Juniper ScreenOS versions prior to the security advisory patch
Smartbedded Meteobridge firmware prior to the 2025 security update
Samsung Android devices with libimagecodec.quram.so prior to SMR Sep‑2025 Release 1
vulnerabilities.remediation: Update the device to the SMR Sep‑2025 Release 1 or later, which contains the patched libimagecodec.quram.so.
workarounds: Avoid opening untrusted media files on affected devices
Deploy mobile device management (MDM) policies to enforce the latest security patch level

vulnerabilities.title: ShinyHunters Launches Data Leak Site: Trinity of Chaos Announces New Ransomware Victims
vulnerabilities.original_title: ShinyHunters Launches Data Leak Site: Trinity of Chaos Announces New Ransomware Victims
vulnerabilities.content_snippet: Trinity of Chaos, tied to Lapsus$, Scattered Spider & ShinyHunters, hit 39 firms via Salesforce flaws, launching a TOR data leak site. The Trinity of Chaos, a ransomware collective presumably associated with Lapsus$, Scattered Spider, and ShinyHunters groups, launched a Data Leak Site (DLS) on t...
vulnerabilities.summary: Improper protection of OAuth tokens and insufficient verification in Salesforce integrations allowing attackers to hijack accounts via stolen tokens and vishing attacks.
vulnerabilities.description: Threat actors targeted vulnerable Salesforce instances by obtaining OAuth access tokens through social engineering (vishing) and credential theft. The stolen tokens were then used to access Salesloft’s Drift AI chat integration, allowing extraction of large volumes of PII from compromised tenant data. The lack of token revocation, insufficient MFA enforcement, and overly permissive API scopes facilitated lateral movement and data exfiltration, culminating in ransomware extortion and public data leak on a TOR site.
vulnerabilities.remediation: Rotate all OAuth tokens, enforce MFA for all privileged accounts, restrict API scopes to least privilege, implement token revocation policies, apply latest Salesforce security patches, and review third‑party integration configurations.
workarounds: Temporarily disable non‑essential third‑party integrations until token hygiene is verified
Enforce IP allow‑lists for API access

vulnerabilities.title: CommetJacking attack tricks Comet browser into stealing emails
vulnerabilities.original_title: CommetJacking attack tricks Comet browser into stealing emails
vulnerabilities.content_snippet: A new attack called 'CometJacking' exploits URL parameters to pass to Perplexity's Comet AI browser hidden instructions that allow access to sensitive data from connected services, like email and calendar. [...]
vulnerabilities.summary: CometJacking vulnerability in Perplexity's Comet AI browser allows crafted URL parameters to inject hidden instructions, enabling theft of email and calendar data from connected services.
vulnerabilities.description: The CometJacking attack abuses the way the Comet AI browser parses URL query parameters. An attacker can craft a URL that includes hidden instruction payloads (e.g., JavaScript or AI prompt injection) which the browser forwards to the Perplexity backend. The backend then executes these instructions with the user's authenticated context, allowing the attacker to retrieve data from linked services such as email and calendar. The vulnerability stems from insufficient validation and sanitization of URL‑derived input before it is used to generate backend API calls.
vulnerabilities.remediation: Perplexity should implement strict validation and sanitization of all URL parameters, enforce a whitelist of allowed commands, and require explicit user consent before executing any instruction that accesses external services. Deploy a security patch that isolates AI instruction handling from user‑controlled input. Users should update to the patched version as soon as it is released.
workarounds: Avoid clicking on untrusted links that open the Comet browser.
Disable automatic opening of URLs in the Comet browser and use a sandboxed environment for AI interactions.
Revoke and re‑authenticate third‑party service tokens in the Comet settings until a fix is deployed.

vulnerabilities.title: Oracle tells Clop-targeted EBS users to apply July patch, problem solved
vulnerabilities.original_title: Oracle tells Clop-targeted EBS users to apply July patch, problem solved
vulnerabilities.content_snippet: Researchers suggest internet-facing portals are exposing 'thousands' of orgs Oracle has finally broken its silence on those Clop-linked extortion emails, but only to tell customers what they already should have known: patch your damn systems.…
vulnerabilities.summary: Remote code execution vulnerability in Oracle E-Business Suite (EBS) internet-facing portals exploited by Clop ransomware/extortion group
vulnerabilities.description: Internet-facing Oracle EBS portals were found to expose vulnerable services that allow unauthenticated attackers to execute arbitrary code on the underlying application server. The vulnerability is leveraged by the Clop ransomware group to gain initial foothold, encrypt data, and demand ransom. The flaw is likely due to insufficient input validation and insecure default configurations in the web tier of EBS deployments that are exposed to the public internet.
products_versions: Oracle E-Business Suite 12.2.x and 12.1.x (any version with internet-facing web tier)
vulnerabilities.remediation: Apply the Oracle July 2025 security patch for E-Business Suite, which addresses the remote code execution issue. Verify that the patch is successfully installed and that the system is rebooted if required.
workarounds: Restrict public access to Oracle EBS portals using firewall rules or VPN.
Deploy a Web Application Firewall (WAF) with rules to block malicious payloads.
Disable unnecessary services and modules on the application server.

vulnerabilities.title: Unauthenticated RCE Flaw Patched in DrayTek Routers
vulnerabilities.original_title: Unauthenticated RCE Flaw Patched in DrayTek Routers
vulnerabilities.content_snippet: The security defect can be exploited remotely via crafted HTTP/S requests to a vulnerable device’s web user interface. The post Unauthenticated RCE Flaw Patched in DrayTek Routers appeared first on SecurityWeek.
vulnerabilities.summary: Unauthenticated remote code execution vulnerability in DrayTek router web UI allowing attackers to execute arbitrary commands via crafted HTTP/S requests.
vulnerabilities.description: The vulnerability resides in the web management interface of DrayTek routers. An attacker can send specially crafted HTTP or HTTPS requests to the device's web UI without authentication. The malformed request triggers unsafe handling of input, leading to execution of arbitrary system commands with root privileges. This enables full compromise of the router, allowing the attacker to modify configurations, intercept traffic, or use the device as a pivot point within the network.
affected_products: DrayTek routers (all models with vulnerable web UI)
vulnerabilities.remediation: Upgrade the router firmware to the latest version released by DrayTek that contains the fix. Verify the firmware version after upgrade.
workarounds: Disable remote management (WAN access to the web UI).
Restrict access to the web UI to trusted internal IP ranges using firewall rules.
Block inbound HTTP/HTTPS traffic to the router's management ports from untrusted networks.

vulnerabilities.title: Organizations Warned of Exploited Meteobridge Vulnerability
vulnerabilities.original_title: Organizations Warned of Exploited Meteobridge Vulnerability
vulnerabilities.content_snippet: Patched in mid-May, the security defect allows remote unauthenticated attackers to execute arbitrary commands with root privileges. The post Organizations Warned of Exploited Meteobridge Vulnerability appeared first on SecurityWeek.
vulnerabilities.summary: Remote unauthenticated command execution vulnerability in Meteobridge allowing attackers to execute arbitrary commands with root privileges.
vulnerabilities.description: The vulnerability resides in the Meteobridge software/firmware and permits remote attackers without authentication to inject and execute arbitrary system commands. Successful exploitation results in full root privileges on the compromised device, enabling data theft, device takeover, and lateral movement within the network. The flaw was patched in mid‑May 2025, but active exploitation has been observed in the wild.
products_versions: All Meteobridge versions prior to the mid‑May 2025 patch
vulnerabilities.remediation: Apply the Meteobridge security patch released in mid‑May 2025. Verify the patch version and update all affected devices to the patched release.
workarounds: Block inbound traffic to the Meteobridge management interface at the network perimeter.
Restrict access to trusted IP ranges using firewall rules.
Disable any unnecessary remote management services on the device.

vulnerabilities.title: Oracle Says Known Vulnerabilities Possibly Exploited in Recent Extortion Attacks
vulnerabilities.original_title: Oracle Says Known Vulnerabilities Possibly Exploited in Recent Extortion Attacks
vulnerabilities.content_snippet: The software giant’s investigation showed that vulnerabilities patched in July 2025 may be involved. The post Oracle Says Known Vulnerabilities Possibly Exploited in Recent Extortion Attacks appeared first on SecurityWeek.
vulnerabilities.summary: Potentially exploited Oracle vulnerabilities patched in July 2025, used in recent extortion attacks.
vulnerabilities.description: Oracle disclosed that vulnerabilities fixed in its July 2025 security patch may have been leveraged by threat actors to conduct extortion campaigns. The exact CVE identifiers, technical details, and affected components have not been publicly disclosed. The vulnerabilities appear to allow remote exploitation leading to data theft or system compromise, which is then used to demand ransom.
products_versions: Oracle products patched in July 2025 (specific versions not disclosed)
vulnerabilities.remediation: Apply the July 2025 Oracle security patches to all affected Oracle installations. Verify patch deployment through Oracle's patch management tools.
workarounds: Isolate vulnerable Oracle systems from untrusted networks until patches are applied.
Implement strict network segmentation and firewall rules to limit inbound traffic to Oracle services.

vulnerabilities.title: Chrome 141 and Firefox 143 Patches Fix High-Severity Vulnerabilities
vulnerabilities.original_title: Chrome 141 and Firefox 143 Patches Fix High-Severity Vulnerabilities
vulnerabilities.content_snippet: High-severity flaws were patched in Chrome’s WebGPU and Video components, and in Firefox’s Graphics and JavaScript Engine components. The post Chrome 141 and Firefox 143 Patches Fix High-Severity Vulnerabilities appeared first on SecurityWeek.
vulnerabilities.summary: Memory corruption vulnerability in Chrome's WebGPU component leading to remote code execution
vulnerabilities.description: A flaw in the WebGPU implementation of Chrome 141 allows an attacker to craft malicious GPU commands that trigger out‑of‑bounds memory access. Successful exploitation results in arbitrary code execution in the context of the browser process, potentially compromising the host system.
vulnerabilities.remediation: Update Chrome to version 141 or later where the issue is patched.
workarounds: Disable WebGPU via chrome://flags
Use enterprise policy to block WebGPU usage

vulnerabilities.title: Chrome 141 and Firefox 143 Patches Fix High-Severity Vulnerabilities
vulnerabilities.original_title: Chrome 141 and Firefox 143 Patches Fix High-Severity Vulnerabilities
vulnerabilities.content_snippet: High-severity flaws were patched in Chrome’s WebGPU and Video components, and in Firefox’s Graphics and JavaScript Engine components. The post Chrome 141 and Firefox 143 Patches Fix High-Severity Vulnerabilities appeared first on SecurityWeek.
vulnerabilities.summary: Use‑after‑free vulnerability in Chrome's Video component that can lead to remote code execution
vulnerabilities.description: Improper handling of video frame buffers in Chrome 141's media pipeline may allow an attacker to trigger a use‑after‑free condition. Crafted video streams can cause memory corruption and enable arbitrary code execution.
vulnerabilities.remediation: Upgrade to Chrome 141 or newer where the fix is applied.
workarounds: Disable hardware‑accelerated video decoding via chrome://settings
Block untrusted video content using content security policies

vulnerabilities.title: Chrome 141 and Firefox 143 Patches Fix High-Severity Vulnerabilities
vulnerabilities.original_title: Chrome 141 and Firefox 143 Patches Fix High-Severity Vulnerabilities
vulnerabilities.content_snippet: High-severity flaws were patched in Chrome’s WebGPU and Video components, and in Firefox’s Graphics and JavaScript Engine components. The post Chrome 141 and Firefox 143 Patches Fix High-Severity Vulnerabilities appeared first on SecurityWeek.
vulnerabilities.summary: Memory safety issue in Firefox's Graphics component (GPU process) that may allow remote code execution
vulnerabilities.description: A flaw in the GPU process handling of graphics commands in Firefox 143 can be triggered by malicious web content, leading to out‑of‑bounds writes. This enables an attacker to execute arbitrary code within the browser sandbox.
vulnerabilities.remediation: Apply the Firefox 143 update which contains the fix.
workarounds: Disable GPU acceleration via about:config (gfx.webrender.enabled = false)
Use the hardened security settings in about:config

vulnerabilities.title: Chrome 141 and Firefox 143 Patches Fix High-Severity Vulnerabilities
vulnerabilities.original_title: Chrome 141 and Firefox 143 Patches Fix High-Severity Vulnerabilities
vulnerabilities.content_snippet: High-severity flaws were patched in Chrome’s WebGPU and Video components, and in Firefox’s Graphics and JavaScript Engine components. The post Chrome 141 and Firefox 143 Patches Fix High-Severity Vulnerabilities appeared first on SecurityWeek.
vulnerabilities.summary: JIT compiler bug in Firefox's JavaScript Engine (SpiderMonkey) leading to remote code execution
vulnerabilities.description: Improper validation of JIT‑generated code in SpiderMonkey can be abused by specially crafted JavaScript, resulting in memory corruption and arbitrary code execution. The vulnerability is exploitable via malicious web pages.
vulnerabilities.remediation: Upgrade to Firefox 143 or later where the issue is patched.
workarounds: Disable JIT compilation via about:config (javascript.options.asmjs = false, javascript.options.wasm = false)
Enable Enhanced Tracking Protection to block untrusted scripts

vulnerabilities.title: Google warns of Cl0p extortion campaign against Oracle E-Business users
vulnerabilities.original_title: Google warns of Cl0p extortion campaign against Oracle E-Business users
vulnerabilities.content_snippet: Google observed Cl0p ransomware group sending extortion emails to executives, claiming theft of Oracle E-Business Suite data. Google Mandiant and Google Threat Intelligence Group (GTIG) researchers are tracking a suspected Cl0p ransomware group’s activity, where threat actors attempt to extort...
vulnerabilities.summary: Exploitation of Oracle E-Business Suite default password reset mechanism to obtain valid credentials and exfiltrate data.
vulnerabilities.description: Threat actors leveraged the default password reset functionality in Oracle E-Business Suite to reset user passwords without proper verification, allowing them to obtain valid credentials. The stolen credentials were then used to access sensitive ERP data, which was exfiltrated and later used for extortion. The attack was facilitated by a high‑volume phishing campaign that delivered malicious links and credential‑harvesting forms to executives. No specific CVE was disclosed; the vulnerability appears to be a mis‑configuration or logic flaw in the password reset workflow.
products_versions: Oracle E-Business Suite (all supported versions at time of incident)
vulnerabilities.remediation: Apply the latest Oracle security patches that address password reset workflow issues, disable or restrict the default password reset feature, enforce multi‑factor authentication for all privileged accounts, rotate all potentially compromised passwords, and implement strict password policies.
workarounds: Disable the default password reset functionality until it can be securely re‑implemented.
Require additional verification steps (e.g., security questions, out‑of‑band confirmation) for password resets.
Implement account lockout thresholds and monitoring for abnormal reset activity.

vulnerabilities.title: OpenSSL patches 3 vulnerabilities, urging immediate updates
vulnerabilities.original_title: OpenSSL patches 3 vulnerabilities, urging immediate updates
vulnerabilities.content_snippet: OpenSSL updates addressed 3 flaws enabling key recovery, code execution, and DoS attacks. Users are urged to update asap. The OpenSSL Project has released security updates to address three vulnerabilities, tracked as CVE-2025-9230, CVE-2025-9231, and CVE-2025-9232, in its open-source SSL/TLS toolkit...
vulnerabilities.summary: Out-of-bounds read/write in OpenSSL CMS decryption with password-based encryption (PWRI) leading to possible DoS or remote code execution.
vulnerabilities.description: When processing CMS encrypted data that uses password‑based encryption, OpenSSL fails to correctly validate buffer boundaries. An attacker can supply crafted data that triggers an out‑of‑bounds read, causing a crash (Denial of Service), or an out‑of‑bounds write, leading to memory corruption that may be leveraged for arbitrary code execution. The flaw is rare in practice because PWRI usage is uncommon, but it is exploitable in any application that accepts CMS data via OpenSSL.
vulnerabilities.remediation: Upgrade OpenSSL to one of the patched releases: 3.5.4, 3.4.3, 3.3.5, 3.2.6, 3.0.18, 1.0.2zm, or 1.1.1zd. If PWRI is not required, disable or avoid using CMS decryption with password‑based encryption.
workarounds: Disable CMS decryption with PWRI in application code.
Validate input size before invoking OpenSSL CMS APIs.

vulnerabilities.title: OpenSSL patches 3 vulnerabilities, urging immediate updates
vulnerabilities.original_title: OpenSSL patches 3 vulnerabilities, urging immediate updates
vulnerabilities.content_snippet: OpenSSL updates addressed 3 flaws enabling key recovery, code execution, and DoS attacks. Users are urged to update asap. The OpenSSL Project has released security updates to address three vulnerabilities, tracked as CVE-2025-9230, CVE-2025-9231, and CVE-2025-9232, in its open-source SSL/TLS toolkit...
vulnerabilities.summary: Timing side‑channel in OpenSSL SM2 signature computation on 64‑bit ARM platforms that may allow private‑key recovery.
vulnerabilities.description: OpenSSL's implementation of SM2 signature generation on 64‑bit ARM CPUs leaks timing information dependent on the private key. An attacker who can trigger repeated SM2 signatures and measure the execution time with high precision can apply statistical analysis to recover the private key. While OpenSSL does not natively support SM2 in TLS, custom cryptographic providers may enable it, making the issue relevant for specialized applications.
affected_products: OpenSSL (all versions prior to the patched releases listed above) on 64‑bit ARM platforms supporting SM2 via custom providers
vulnerabilities.remediation: Upgrade to the patched OpenSSL releases. If SM2 is not required, disable SM2 support or avoid using custom providers that enable it on affected platforms.
workarounds: Disable SM2 algorithms in OpenSSL configuration.
Introduce constant‑time implementations or add artificial timing noise.

vulnerabilities.title: OpenSSL patches 3 vulnerabilities, urging immediate updates
vulnerabilities.original_title: OpenSSL patches 3 vulnerabilities, urging immediate updates
vulnerabilities.content_snippet: OpenSSL updates addressed 3 flaws enabling key recovery, code execution, and DoS attacks. Users are urged to update asap. The OpenSSL Project has released security updates to address three vulnerabilities, tracked as CVE-2025-9230, CVE-2025-9231, and CVE-2025-9232, in its open-source SSL/TLS toolkit...
vulnerabilities.summary: Low‑severity flaw in OpenSSL that can cause crashes leading to Denial‑of‑Service.
vulnerabilities.description: A coding error in OpenSSL can be triggered by crafted input, causing the library to crash. The impact is limited to service interruption; no code execution or data leakage is known.
affected_products: OpenSSL (all versions prior to the patched releases listed above)
vulnerabilities.remediation: Update OpenSSL to the patched versions released by the project.
workarounds: Apply input validation to reject malformed data before it reaches OpenSSL.

vulnerabilities.title: OpenSSL Vulnerabilities Allow Private Key Recovery, Code Execution, DoS Attacks
vulnerabilities.original_title: OpenSSL Vulnerabilities Allow Private Key Recovery, Code Execution, DoS Attacks
vulnerabilities.content_snippet: Three vulnerabilities have been patched with the release of OpenSSL updates. The post OpenSSL Vulnerabilities Allow Private Key Recovery, Code Execution, DoS Attacks appeared first on SecurityWeek.
vulnerabilities.summary: OpenSSL vulnerability that enables private key recovery
vulnerabilities.description: A flaw in OpenSSL's handling of certain cryptographic operations allows an attacker to recover private keys from public information, potentially leading to full compromise of TLS sessions.
products_versions: OpenSSL versions prior to the 2025-10-01 patch
vulnerabilities.remediation: Update OpenSSL to the latest patched version released on 2025-10-01.
workarounds: Disable affected cipher suites
Use alternative TLS libraries until the patch is applied

vulnerabilities.title: OpenSSL Vulnerabilities Allow Private Key Recovery, Code Execution, DoS Attacks
vulnerabilities.original_title: OpenSSL Vulnerabilities Allow Private Key Recovery, Code Execution, DoS Attacks
vulnerabilities.content_snippet: Three vulnerabilities have been patched with the release of OpenSSL updates. The post OpenSSL Vulnerabilities Allow Private Key Recovery, Code Execution, DoS Attacks appeared first on SecurityWeek.
vulnerabilities.summary: OpenSSL remote code execution vulnerability
vulnerabilities.description: A memory corruption issue in OpenSSL can be triggered by specially crafted packets, allowing remote attackers to execute arbitrary code on the vulnerable host.
products_versions: OpenSSL versions prior to the 2025-10-01 patch
vulnerabilities.remediation: Apply the OpenSSL update released on 2025-10-01.
workarounds: Restrict network access to services using vulnerable OpenSSL versions
Enable address space layout randomization (ASLR)

vulnerabilities.title: OpenSSL Vulnerabilities Allow Private Key Recovery, Code Execution, DoS Attacks
vulnerabilities.original_title: OpenSSL Vulnerabilities Allow Private Key Recovery, Code Execution, DoS Attacks
vulnerabilities.content_snippet: Three vulnerabilities have been patched with the release of OpenSSL updates. The post OpenSSL Vulnerabilities Allow Private Key Recovery, Code Execution, DoS Attacks appeared first on SecurityWeek.
vulnerabilities.summary: OpenSSL denial-of-service vulnerability
vulnerabilities.description: A crafted input can cause OpenSSL to enter an infinite loop or crash, leading to denial of service for TLS connections.
products_versions: OpenSSL versions prior to the 2025-10-01 patch
vulnerabilities.remediation: Update to the patched OpenSSL version released on 2025-10-01.
workarounds: Rate-limit connections
Deploy IDS signatures for known malicious payloads

vulnerabilities.title: Gemini AI flaws could have exposed your data
vulnerabilities.original_title: Gemini AI flaws could have exposed your data
vulnerabilities.content_snippet: Security researchers discovered three vulnerabilities in Google’s Gemini artificial intelligence (AI) assistant. Although now patched, this “Trifecta”, as the researchers called it, raises important questions about how safe AI tools really are, especially as they become a part of s...
vulnerabilities.summary: Prompt injection in Gemini Cloud Assist allowing hidden prompts in web requests to execute malicious instructions on cloud resources.
vulnerabilities.description: An attacker can embed hidden prompt commands within normal web requests sent to Gemini Cloud Assist. The AI interprets these hidden prompts as legitimate instructions, potentially granting the attacker control over cloud services such as log aggregation, configuration changes, or data exfiltration.
products_versions: Google Gemini AI (Cloud Assist, Search Personalization Model, Browsing Tool) – versions prior to October 2025 patch
vulnerabilities.remediation: Google patched the issue by blocking Gemini from rendering dangerous links and improving input sanitization for prompt handling.
workarounds: Disable Gemini Cloud Assist integration with critical cloud services until the patch is confirmed.
Validate and sanitize incoming web request data before it reaches the AI component.

vulnerabilities.title: Gemini AI flaws could have exposed your data
vulnerabilities.original_title: Gemini AI flaws could have exposed your data
vulnerabilities.content_snippet: Security researchers discovered three vulnerabilities in Google’s Gemini artificial intelligence (AI) assistant. Although now patched, this “Trifecta”, as the researchers called it, raises important questions about how safe AI tools really are, especially as they become a part of s...
vulnerabilities.summary: Prompt injection in Gemini Search Personalization Model enabling malicious commands to be injected via a crafted website and later executed when a user interacts with personalized search.
vulnerabilities.description: By visiting a specially crafted website, an attacker can inject malicious prompts into the user's Chrome browsing history. When the user later uses Gemini's personalized search, the injected prompts cause the AI to leak personal data such as saved information and location.
products_versions: Google Gemini AI (Cloud Assist, Search Personalization Model, Browsing Tool) – versions prior to October 2025 patch
vulnerabilities.remediation: Google updated the personalization model to block rendering of dangerous links and added stricter validation of history‑derived prompts.
workarounds: Avoid visiting untrusted websites while logged into Chrome.
Clear browsing history and personalization data regularly.

vulnerabilities.title: Gemini AI flaws could have exposed your data
vulnerabilities.original_title: Gemini AI flaws could have exposed your data
vulnerabilities.content_snippet: Security researchers discovered three vulnerabilities in Google’s Gemini artificial intelligence (AI) assistant. Although now patched, this “Trifecta”, as the researchers called it, raises important questions about how safe AI tools really are, especially as they become a part of s...
vulnerabilities.summary: Prompt injection in Gemini Browsing Tool allowing exfiltration of stored user information and location via malicious web page summarization.
vulnerabilities.description: The browsing tool can be tricked into sending a user's stored data and precise location to an attacker‑controlled server when summarizing a malicious web page. The attacker embeds hidden prompts that cause the AI to include sensitive information in the summary payload.
products_versions: Google Gemini AI (Cloud Assist, Search Personalization Model, Browsing Tool) – versions prior to October 2025 patch
vulnerabilities.remediation: Google patched the component to filter out dangerous links and added checks to prevent unauthorized data leakage during summarization.
workarounds: Disable the Gemini Browsing Tool feature in Chrome settings.
Use network monitoring to detect unexpected outbound connections from the browser.

vulnerabilities.title: Red Hat OpenShift AI Flaw Exposes Hybrid Cloud Infrastructure to Full Takeover
vulnerabilities.original_title: Red Hat OpenShift AI Flaw Exposes Hybrid Cloud Infrastructure to Full Takeover
vulnerabilities.content_snippet: A severe security flaw has been disclosed in the Red Hat OpenShift AI service that could allow attackers to escalate privileges and take control of the complete infrastructure under certain conditions. OpenShift AI is a platform for managing the lifecycle of predictive and generative artificial inte...
vulnerabilities.summary: Privilege escalation vulnerability in Red Hat OpenShift AI that can allow attackers to gain full control of the hybrid cloud infrastructure under certain conditions.
vulnerabilities.description: A severe flaw in the OpenShift AI service enables an attacker who can interact with the platform to exploit insufficient isolation and privilege checks. By chaining misconfigurations with a vulnerable component, the attacker can elevate privileges from a low‑privileged service account to cluster‑admin level, resulting in full takeover of the underlying hybrid‑cloud infrastructure. The vulnerability is triggered under specific deployment configurations where external access to the AI service is permitted without adequate network segmentation or RBAC restrictions.
products_versions: Red Hat OpenShift AI (specific versions not disclosed in the article)
vulnerabilities.remediation: Apply the security patches released by Red Hat for OpenShift AI as soon as they become available.
