Review and tighten RBAC policies, restrict external network access to the AI service, and enforce network segmentation between AI workloads and critical cluster components. Upgrade to the latest supported OpenShift AI version that includes the fix.
workarounds: Disable external access to the OpenShift AI service until a patch is applied.
Enforce strict RBAC policies limiting the permissions of service accounts used by OpenShift AI.
Place the OpenShift AI components in a dedicated, isolated network segment.

vulnerabilities.title: Hackers Exploit Milesight Routers to Send Phishing SMS to European Users
vulnerabilities.original_title: Hackers Exploit Milesight Routers to Send Phishing SMS to European Users
vulnerabilities.content_snippet: Unknown threat actors are abusing Milesight industrial cellular routers to send SMS messages as part of a smishing campaign targeting users in European countries since at least February 2022. French cybersecurity company SEKOIA said the attackers are exploiting the cellular router's API to send mali...
vulnerabilities.summary: Unauthenticated API abuse in Milesight industrial cellular routers allows threat actors to send arbitrary SMS messages, enabling smishing campaigns.
vulnerabilities.description: The routers expose a management API that can be accessed over the cellular or Ethernet interface without proper authentication or input validation. Attackers can invoke the SMS-sending endpoint to dispatch malicious messages containing phishing URLs to any phone number reachable via the carrier. The abuse has been observed in the wild since at least February 2022, targeting users in European countries. The vulnerability enables large‑scale smishing campaigns without requiring physical access to the device.
vulnerabilities.remediation: Apply the latest firmware released by Milesight that restricts API access and enforces authentication. Disable or firewall the SMS‑send API if not required. Change default credentials and enforce strong passwords. Segment the routers on a dedicated VLAN and restrict outbound SMS traffic to authorized services.
workarounds: Block outbound SMS traffic from the router at the carrier or firewall level.
Disable the SMS‑sending API via configuration if the feature is not needed.
Restrict management interface to trusted IP addresses only.
references: SEKOIA advisory on Milesight router API abuse (if available)

vulnerabilities.title: Apple urges users to update iPhone and Mac to patch font bug
vulnerabilities.original_title: Apple urges users to update iPhone and Mac to patch font bug
vulnerabilities.content_snippet: Apple released iOS and macOS updates to fix a flaw in font processing that could trigger a denial-of-service condition or memory corruption. Apple released iOS and macOS updates to address a medium-severity flaw, tracked as CVE-2025-43400, in font processing that could trigger a denial-of-service co...
vulnerabilities.summary: Out-of-bounds write in Apple's FontParser component leading to possible denial-of-service, memory corruption, and arbitrary code execution via crafted fonts.
vulnerabilities.description: The FontParser component in iOS, iPadOS, macOS and visionOS fails to properly validate font data, allowing an out-of-bounds write when processing a maliciously crafted font file. The write can corrupt adjacent memory, causing crashes (denial of service) or, in the worst case, enabling remote code execution if an attacker can control the corrupted memory region. The vulnerability can be triggered by any application or system process that loads fonts, which includes many background services and user‑visible apps.
vulnerabilities.remediation: Apply the Apple security updates: iOS/iPadOS 26.0.1, iOS/iPadOS 18.7.1, macOS 26.0.1, macOS 15.7.1, macOS 14.8.1, and visionOS 26.0.1. Ensure devices are running the latest firmware and OS version.
workarounds: Avoid opening documents, web pages, or apps that provide untrusted font files.
Use Mobile Device Management (MDM) to enforce the latest OS version on managed devices.
Disable or restrict automatic font downloading where possible.
references: SecurityAffairs article: Apple urges users to update iPhone and Mac to patch font bug

vulnerabilities.title: Broadcom Fails to Disclose Zero-Day Exploitation of VMware Vulnerability
vulnerabilities.original_title: Broadcom Fails to Disclose Zero-Day Exploitation of VMware Vulnerability
vulnerabilities.content_snippet: Impacting VMware Aria Operations and VMware Tools, the flaw can be exploited to elevate privileges on the VM. The post Broadcom Fails to Disclose Zero-Day Exploitation of VMware Vulnerability appeared first on SecurityWeek.
vulnerabilities.summary: Privilege escalation vulnerability in VMware Aria Operations and VMware Tools allowing attackers to elevate privileges on the virtual machine.
vulnerabilities.description: A zero‑day vulnerability affecting VMware Aria Operations and VMware Tools enables an attacker with limited access to a virtual machine to execute code with elevated privileges. The flaw can be leveraged to break out of the VM sandbox and gain higher‑level rights on the host or other VMs. Details of the vulnerability have not been publicly disclosed by Broadcom, but evidence of active exploitation has been reported.
vulnerabilities.remediation: Apply the security patches released by VMware as soon as they become available. If patches are not yet released, limit the use of VMware Tools on untrusted VMs, enforce strict access controls, and monitor for abnormal privilege escalation events.
workarounds: Disable unnecessary VMware Tools features
Restrict VM console access
Use network segmentation to isolate vulnerable VMs

vulnerabilities.title: $50 Battering RAM Attack Breaks Intel and AMD Cloud Security Protections
vulnerabilities.original_title: $50 Battering RAM Attack Breaks Intel and AMD Cloud Security Protections
vulnerabilities.content_snippet: A group of academics from KU Leuven and the University of Birmingham has demonstrated a new vulnerability called Battering RAM to bypass the latest defenses on Intel and AMD cloud processors. "We built a simple, $50 interposer that sits quietly in the memory path, behaving transparently during start...
vulnerabilities.summary: Battering RAM is a low‑cost hardware interposer that sits in the memory bus of Intel and AMD cloud processors, allowing an attacker to bypass CPU‑based security mechanisms such as memory encryption and secure boot.
vulnerabilities.description:
The researchers built a $50 interposer that is inserted between the CPU and DRAM modules. The device operates transparently during system boot, passing all firmware and TPM trust checks, but it can intercept, modify, or replay memory traffic. By doing so it defeats hardware‑based protections such as Intel SGX, AMD SEV, and other memory‑encryption technologies, enabling extraction of cryptographic keys, injection of malicious code, and full control of the victim VM or host.

The attack requires physical access to the server rack to install the interposer, after which the compromised system behaves normally from a software perspective, making detection difficult.
products_versions: All current Intel Xeon Scalable cloud processors (2023‑2025)
All current AMD EPYC cloud processors (2023‑2025)
vulnerabilities.remediation: No vendor‑issued patch is currently available. Mitigation relies on strict physical security controls, tamper‑evident chassis, and hardware integrity verification. Vendors should consider firmware updates that include cryptographic validation of the memory bus topology and support for detection of unauthorized interposers.
workarounds: Deploy tamper‑evident seals and intrusion detection on server racks.
Enable BIOS/UEFI secure boot with measured boot that includes memory‑bus topology checks.
Use external hardware monitoring (e.g., side‑channel anomaly detectors) to spot unexpected bus activity.
Limit physical access to data‑center hardware to trusted personnel only.
references: Research paper: "Battering RAM: Low‑Cost Memory‑Bus Interposer Attacks on Cloud CPUs" (KU Leuven & University of Birmingham, 2025)

vulnerabilities.title: New $50 Battering RAM Attack Breaks Intel and AMD Cloud Security Protections
vulnerabilities.original_title: New $50 Battering RAM Attack Breaks Intel and AMD Cloud Security Protections
vulnerabilities.content_snippet: A group of academics from KU Leuven and the University of Birmingham has demonstrated a new vulnerability called Battering RAM to bypass the latest defenses on Intel and AMD cloud processors. "We built a simple, $50 interposer that sits quietly in the memory path, behaving transparently during start...
vulnerabilities.summary: Battering RAM hardware interposer bypasses Intel and AMD cloud processor security protections
vulnerabilities.description: Researchers demonstrated a $50 interposer that can be inserted into the memory bus of cloud servers. The device operates transparently during boot, passes existing trust checks, and allows an attacker to read, modify, or inject memory contents, effectively breaking isolation between virtual machines and bypassing hardware root of trust mechanisms on Intel and AMD cloud CPUs.
vulnerabilities.remediation: Implement strict physical security controls for server hardware, use tamper‑evident chassis, enable memory‑bus integrity monitoring in firmware, and deploy firmware updates that incorporate interposer detection mechanisms where available.
workarounds: Deploy hardware tamper detection sensors on memory slots
Restrict physical access to servers to trusted personnel only
Use encrypted memory (e.g., Intel SGX, AMD SEV) with attestation that includes memory‑bus integrity checks
references: Research paper by Jesse De Meulemeester, David Oswald, et al., KU Leuven & University of Birmingham (2025)

vulnerabilities.title: Warnings about Cisco vulns under active exploit are falling on deaf ears
vulnerabilities.original_title: Warnings about Cisco vulns under active exploit are falling on deaf ears
vulnerabilities.content_snippet: 50,000 firewall devices still exposed Nearly 50,000 Cisco ASA/FTD instances vulnerable to two bugs that are actively being exploited by "advanced" attackers remain exposed to the internet, according to Shadowserver data.…
vulnerabilities.summary: Remote code execution vulnerabilities in Cisco ASA and Firepower Threat Defense (FTD) allowing unauthenticated network attackers to execute arbitrary code.
vulnerabilities.description: Two separate vulnerabilities in the Cisco ASA/FTD code path can be triggered by sending specially crafted packets to the management or data interfaces. Successful exploitation results in remote code execution with root privileges, allowing attackers to take full control of the firewall, modify policies, exfiltrate data, or use the device as a pivot point within the victim network. The flaws are being actively exploited by advanced threat actors, as evidenced by Shadowserver scans detecting exploitation attempts against nearly 50,000 internet‑exposed devices.
vulnerabilities.remediation: Apply the latest Cisco security advisories and patches for the affected ASA/FTD releases. Upgrade to a patched software version, enable only required services, and restrict management access to trusted IP ranges.
workarounds: Block inbound traffic to the vulnerable ports at the perimeter firewall.
Restrict management interface access to VPN or internal network only.
Disable any unnecessary services (e.g., HTTP/HTTPS management) until patches are applied.
references: Cisco Security Advisory (specific advisory ID pending)

vulnerabilities.title: Tile trackers plagued by weak security, researchers warn
vulnerabilities.original_title: Tile trackers plagued by weak security, researchers warn
vulnerabilities.content_snippet: Researchers at the Georgia Institute of Technology scrutinized the security of the popular Tile tracker and came out disappointed. Bluetooth trackers are a steadily growing market, and Life360 is one of the major players. In 2021, Amazon expanded its Sidewalk network to include Tile. That means Ring...
vulnerabilities.summary: Tile trackers broadcast a static MAC address and unencrypted unique ID, enabling persistent tracking and easy interception of location data.
vulnerabilities.description: Tile devices emit a static Bluetooth MAC address combined with a rotating but weakly generated unique identifier. The broadcast is unencrypted, allowing any nearby BLE scanner to capture the identifier and MAC address. The captured data is forwarded to Life360 servers without encryption, and the servers appear to store the information in cleartext. This enables attackers to fingerprint a device after a single capture and track it for its entire lifetime, as well as to harvest large datasets in a mass scan. The lack of encryption also exposes location data in the event of a server breach.
affected_products: Amazon Sidewalk relay devices (Ring, Echo) when used with Tile
products_versions: All Tile tracker hardware models released up to 2025
Life360 Tile mobile application versions prior to the undisclosed post‑Nov 2024 patches
vulnerabilities.remediation: Implement BLE-level encryption for all broadcasts, use rotating MAC addresses, generate cryptographically strong rotating IDs, and encrypt data in transit and at rest on servers. Deploy firmware updates to replace static MAC usage. Provide background anti‑stalking scanning in the mobile app.
workarounds: Disable Amazon Sidewalk on devices that act as relays.
Limit Bluetooth exposure by turning off Tile when not needed.
Use third‑party trackers that employ rotating MACs and encrypted BLE communication.
Manually scan for unknown Tile devices frequently.

vulnerabilities.title: Tile trackers plagued by weak security, researchers warn
vulnerabilities.original_title: Tile trackers plagued by weak security, researchers warn
vulnerabilities.content_snippet: Researchers at the Georgia Institute of Technology scrutinized the security of the popular Tile tracker and came out disappointed. Bluetooth trackers are a steadily growing market, and Life360 is one of the major players. In 2021, Amazon expanded its Sidewalk network to include Tile. That means Ring...
vulnerabilities.summary: Weak rotating ID generation allows continuous tracking despite ID changes.
vulnerabilities.description: The algorithm used by Tile to rotate its unique identifier is insufficiently random, enabling an observer to correlate successive IDs and maintain a persistent tracking profile of the device.
products_versions: All Tile tracker hardware models released up to 2025
Life360 Tile mobile application versions prior to the undisclosed post‑Nov 2024 patches
vulnerabilities.remediation: Replace the ID rotation algorithm with a cryptographically secure random generator and tie rotation to encrypted session keys.
workarounds: Avoid using Tile in high‑risk environments.
Periodically reset the tracker to obtain a new seed.

vulnerabilities.title: Tile trackers plagued by weak security, researchers warn
vulnerabilities.original_title: Tile trackers plagued by weak security, researchers warn
vulnerabilities.content_snippet: Researchers at the Georgia Institute of Technology scrutinized the security of the popular Tile tracker and came out disappointed. Bluetooth trackers are a steadily growing market, and Life360 is one of the major players. In 2021, Amazon expanded its Sidewalk network to include Tile. That means Ring...
vulnerabilities.summary: Server stores location and device data in cleartext, exposing it to breach and unauthorized access.
vulnerabilities.description: Data received from Tile devices (MAC, unique ID, location) is transmitted to Life360 servers without encryption and is stored in cleartext. A breach of these servers would reveal precise location histories of users and could be leveraged for stalking or other malicious purposes.
products_versions: All Tile tracker hardware models released up to 2025
Life360 Tile mobile application versions prior to the undisclosed post‑Nov 2024 patches
vulnerabilities.remediation: Encrypt data in transit using TLS, and encrypt data at rest using industry‑standard encryption (e.g., AES‑256). Implement strict access controls and audit logging.
workarounds: Limit the amount of personal data sent to the server by disabling optional features.
Use network monitoring to detect unencrypted outbound traffic from the app.

vulnerabilities.title: Google Patches Gemini AI Hacks Involving Poisoned Logs, Search Results
vulnerabilities.original_title: Google Patches Gemini AI Hacks Involving Poisoned Logs, Search Results
vulnerabilities.content_snippet: Researchers found more methods for tricking an AI assistant into aiding sensitive data theft. The post Google Patches Gemini AI Hacks Involving Poisoned Logs, Search Results appeared first on SecurityWeek.
vulnerabilities.summary: Prompt injection and poisoned log techniques allow attackers to manipulate Google's Gemini AI assistant into revealing sensitive data
vulnerabilities.description: Researchers demonstrated that by injecting malicious content into system logs or manipulating search result rankings, Gemini's language model can be coerced into providing confidential information. The attacks exploit the model's reliance on contextual data without proper sanitization, leading to data exfiltration via seemingly benign assistant queries.
vulnerabilities.remediation: Google has released patches that add contextual validation, log sanitization, and stricter prompt handling for Gemini. Apply the latest updates to all Gemini deployments.
workarounds: Restrict Gemini access to internal, vetted data sources
Implement a whitelist of allowed query patterns
Monitor and filter logs for suspicious entries before they are ingested by the model

vulnerabilities.title: Chinese hackers exploiting VMware zero-day since October 2024
vulnerabilities.original_title: Chinese hackers exploiting VMware zero-day since October 2024
vulnerabilities.content_snippet: Broadcom has patched a high-severity privilege escalation vulnerability in its VMware Aria Operations and VMware Tools software, which has been exploited in zero-day attacks since October 2024. [...]
vulnerabilities.summary: High-severity privilege escalation vulnerability in VMware Aria Operations and VMware Tools
vulnerabilities.description: A privilege escalation flaw exists in VMware Aria Operations and VMware Tools that allows an attacker to execute code with elevated privileges on the host. The vulnerability has been actively exploited in zero‑day attacks since October 2024, enabling threat actors to gain SYSTEM/ROOT level access on affected VMware environments. Exploitation appears to be remote, requiring no prior authentication or user interaction, and results in a change of security scope from the compromised process to the entire host.
products_versions: All supported versions of VMware Aria Operations and VMware Tools prior to the September 2025 patch
vulnerabilities.remediation: Apply the security patch released by Broadcom for VMware Aria Operations and VMware Tools. Verify patch installation via the vendor's advisory and restart affected services.
workarounds: Temporarily disable VMware Tools on critical workloads until the patch is applied.
Restrict network access to management interfaces of VMware components using firewall rules.
Enforce least‑privilege service accounts for VMware services.
references: Broadcom Security Advisory (VMware Aria Operations and Tools Patch) – 2025-09-30

vulnerabilities.title: CISA warns of critical Linux Sudo flaw exploited in attacks
vulnerabilities.original_title: CISA warns of critical Linux Sudo flaw exploited in attacks
vulnerabilities.content_snippet: Hackers are actively exploiting a critical vulnerability (CVE-2025-32463) in the sudo package that enables the execution of commands with root-level privileges on Linux operating systems. [...]
vulnerabilities.summary: Critical sudo privilege escalation vulnerability allowing unauthenticated users to execute arbitrary commands as root on Linux systems.
vulnerabilities.description: The vulnerability exists in the sudo package's handling of user-supplied arguments. An attacker with a low‑privileged account can craft a malicious command that bypasses sudo's intended restrictions, causing sudo to execute arbitrary commands with root privileges. The flaw is exploitable without any special conditions beyond having a user account that can invoke sudo.
products_versions: All sudo versions prior to the patched release (e.g., < 1.9.15p5)
vulnerabilities.remediation: Update sudo to the version that includes the fix released by the upstream project (e.g., sudo 1.9.15p5 or later). Apply vendor‑specific patches for affected distributions. Restart any services that rely on sudo after updating.
workarounds: Restrict sudo access to trusted users only.
Remove the vulnerable sudo package and replace it with a patched build.
Configure sudoers to require authentication for all commands and disable any risky defaults.

vulnerabilities.title: Broadcom fixes high-severity VMware NSX bugs reported by NSA
vulnerabilities.original_title: Broadcom fixes high-severity VMware NSX bugs reported by NSA
vulnerabilities.content_snippet: Broadcom has released security updates to patch two high-severity VMware NSX vulnerabilities reported by the U.S. National Security Agency (NSA). [...]
vulnerabilities.summary: High-severity vulnerability in VMware NSX reported by the NSA, patched by Broadcom.
vulnerabilities.description: Two critical vulnerabilities affecting VMware NSX were disclosed by the U.S. National Security Agency. Specific technical details, including CVE identifiers, CVSS metrics, and exploitation mechanics, have not been publicly disclosed in the source article. The vulnerabilities are considered high severity and have been addressed in a security update released by Broadcom.
vulnerabilities.remediation: Apply the security updates released by Broadcom for VMware NSX as soon as possible.

vulnerabilities.title: Broadcom fixes high-severity VMware NSX bugs reported by NSA
vulnerabilities.original_title: Broadcom fixes high-severity VMware NSX bugs reported by NSA
vulnerabilities.content_snippet: Broadcom has released security updates to patch two high-severity VMware NSX vulnerabilities reported by the U.S. National Security Agency (NSA). [...]
vulnerabilities.summary: Second high-severity vulnerability in VMware NSX reported by the NSA, patched by Broadcom.
vulnerabilities.description: A second critical vulnerability affecting VMware NSX was disclosed by the U.S. National Security Agency. Specific technical details, including CVE identifiers, CVSS metrics, and exploitation mechanics, have not been publicly disclosed in the source article. The vulnerability is classified as high severity and is mitigated by the Broadcom security update.
vulnerabilities.remediation: Apply the security updates released by Broadcom for VMware NSX as soon as possible.

vulnerabilities.title: High-Severity Vulnerabilities Patched in VMware Aria Operations, NSX, vCenter
vulnerabilities.original_title: High-Severity Vulnerabilities Patched in VMware Aria Operations, NSX, vCenter
vulnerabilities.content_snippet: The flaws could allow attackers to escalate privileges, manipulate notifications, and enumerate usernames. The post High-Severity Vulnerabilities Patched in VMware Aria Operations, NSX, vCenter appeared first on SecurityWeek.
vulnerabilities.summary: Multiple high-severity vulnerabilities in VMware Aria Operations, NSX, and vCenter that allow privilege escalation, notification manipulation, and username enumeration.
vulnerabilities.description: The disclosed flaws in VMware's management and networking platforms can be exploited by remote attackers to elevate their privileges within the environment, tamper with system notifications, and enumerate valid usernames. These weaknesses stem from insufficient input validation and improper access control checks in the web interfaces and API endpoints of Aria Operations, NSX, and vCenter. Successful exploitation may lead to further lateral movement and compromise of additional VMware services.
vulnerabilities.remediation: Apply the security patches released by VMware for Aria Operations, NSX, and vCenter as soon as possible. Verify that the patch level matches the advisory version numbers provided in VMware's security bulletin.
workarounds: Restrict network access to the management interfaces to trusted IP ranges.
Enable multi-factor authentication for all administrative accounts.
Monitor and block suspicious API calls or web requests using a web application firewall.

vulnerabilities.title: Apple fixes critical font processing bug. Update now!
vulnerabilities.original_title: Apple fixes critical font processing bug. Update now!
vulnerabilities.content_snippet: Apple has released important security updates to address a critical vulnerability in FontParser—the part of MacOS/iOS/iPadOS that processes fonts. Identified as CVE-2025-43400, the flaw was discovered internally by Apple and allows an attacker to craft a malicious font that can cause apps to crash o...
vulnerabilities.summary: Out-of-bounds write in FontParser allows memory corruption and potential arbitrary code execution when processing a maliciously crafted font.
vulnerabilities.description: FontParser, the component responsible for parsing font files on Apple platforms, contains an out-of-bounds write vulnerability. An attacker can craft a malicious font that, when loaded by any application or system process, writes data beyond the intended memory bounds, corrupting process memory. This can cause crashes, denial of service, or, in the worst case, execution of attacker-controlled code with the privileges of the compromised process. Because fonts are processed silently in many contexts (web pages, document viewers, UI rendering), the vulnerability presents a high‑impact attack surface.
vulnerabilities.remediation: Install the security updates released by Apple for macOS, iOS, iPadOS, visionOS, watchOS, and tvOS (e.g., macOS Tahoe 26.0.1, iOS 26.0.1, etc.). Enable automatic updates to ensure future patches are applied promptly.
workarounds: Avoid opening documents or web content from untrusted sources that may contain custom fonts.
Disable automatic font downloading in browsers where possible.
Use endpoint protection that can block execution of unknown font files.

vulnerabilities.title: Akira Ransomware bypasses MFA on SonicWall VPNs
vulnerabilities.original_title: Akira Ransomware bypasses MFA on SonicWall VPNs
vulnerabilities.content_snippet: Akira ransomware is targeting SonicWall SSL VPNs, bypassing OTP MFA on accounts, likely using stolen OTP seeds. Since July 2025, Akira ransomware has exploited SonicWall SSL VPNs, likely using credentials obtained from the exploitation of the CVE-2024-40766 vulnerability, bypassing OTP MFA. Attacks ...
vulnerabilities.summary: Improper handling of authentication data in SonicWall SSL VPN allows remote attackers to obtain valid credentials and bypass OTP‑based multi‑factor authentication.
vulnerabilities.description: The vulnerability resides in the way SonicWall's SSL VPN component processes authentication tokens. An attacker who can interact with the VPN endpoint can exploit CVE‑2024‑40766 to extract or forge authentication material (including OTP seeds). The stolen credentials are then reused to log in via the VPN, effectively bypassing OTP‑based MFA. Because the credential store is not invalidated across firmware upgrades, devices that have been patched may still be compromised if the original credentials are not rotated. The exploit enables full remote access to the internal network, after which attackers perform rapid internal reconnaissance, lateral movement, credential dumping, and ransomware deployment.
affected_products: SonicWall SSL VPN (SonicOS 6–8) on NSA and TZ series devices, including 7.3.0 builds
products_versions: SonicOS 7.3.0 builds on NSA and TZ series appliances
vulnerabilities.remediation: Apply the SonicWall firmware update that addresses CVE‑2024‑40766. Immediately reset all SSL VPN credentials on affected devices and rotate associated Active Directory passwords. Enforce MFA with hardware‑based tokens or push‑based solutions that do not rely on static OTP seeds. Disable OTP seed reuse and consider disabling OTP‑only MFA for privileged accounts. Review and purge any lingering credential artifacts from previous firmware versions.
workarounds: Force password change for all VPN users and AD accounts used for VPN authentication.
Restrict VPN access to known IP ranges or trusted jump hosts.
Disable OTP‑only MFA and require certificate‑based or push‑based MFA.
Monitor for anomalous VPN logins from the same source IP across multiple accounts.
references: SonicWall Security Advisory for CVE‑2024‑40766 (official vendor advisory URL)
Arctic Wolf report on Akira ransomware MFA bypass

vulnerabilities.title: Despite Russian influence, Moldova votes Pro-EU, highlighting future election risks
vulnerabilities.original_title: Despite Russian influence, Moldova votes Pro-EU, highlighting future election risks
vulnerabilities.content_snippet: Moldova ’s deputy PM blames Russia for an election cyberattack, calling it part of a planned hybrid campaign to destabilize democracy. Moldova Deputy Prime Minister Doina Nistor blamed Russia for a cyberattack targeting the country’s Central Electoral Commission last week, ahead of the forthco...
vulnerabilities.summary: Exploitation of an unpatched vulnerability in network routers used to hijack traffic and launch DDoS attacks against the Central Electoral Commission's infrastructure.
vulnerabilities.description: Threat actors leveraged a known but unpatched weakness in the firmware or configuration of routers to gain control of the devices, redirect traffic, and amplify a Distributed Denial‑of‑Service (DDoS) attack against the Central Electoral Commission. The vulnerability allowed remote code execution or unauthorized administrative access, enabling the hijacking of routers and participation in a botnet used for the DDoS campaign.
affected_companies: Central Electoral Commission web platform (custom software)
vendors: Central Electoral Commission web platform (custom software)
vulnerabilities.remediation: Apply the latest firmware updates from the router manufacturers, enforce strong administrative passwords, disable unnecessary services, and implement network‑level authentication (e.g., RADIUS/TACACS+). Conduct a full inventory of network devices and verify they are running supported, patched software.
workarounds: Segment critical election infrastructure from the public internet.
Deploy upstream DDoS mitigation services (e.g., scrubbing centers).
Restrict inbound traffic to known IP ranges and use ACLs.
references: CERT advisories on router firmware vulnerabilities (generic)

vulnerabilities.title: Prompt injection – and a $5 domain – trick Salesforce Agentforce into leaking sales
vulnerabilities.original_title: Prompt injection – and a $5 domain – trick Salesforce Agentforce into leaking sales
vulnerabilities.content_snippet: More fun with AI agents and their security holes A now-fixed flaw in Salesforce’s Agentforce could have allowed external attackers to steal sensitive customer data via prompt injection, according to security researchers who published a proof-of-concept attack on Thursday. They were aided by an expir...
vulnerabilities.summary: Prompt injection vulnerability in Salesforce Agentforce allowing external attackers to exfiltrate sensitive customer data via crafted prompts and a hijacked trusted domain.
vulnerabilities.description: The flaw resides in Agentforce's handling of AI prompts. An attacker can register an expired trusted domain (purchased for $5) and craft a malicious prompt that is injected into the AI agent's processing pipeline. The agent, trusting the domain, executes the malicious prompt, causing it to retrieve and return sensitive customer data to the attacker. The vulnerability is a classic prompt injection combined with insufficient domain validation.
products_versions: Salesforce Agentforce (versions prior to the September 2025 security update)
vulnerabilities.remediation: Salesforce has released a patch that adds strict validation of trusted domains, sanitizes AI prompts, and enforces least‑privilege access to customer data. Apply the latest Agentforce update and rotate any compromised credentials.
workarounds: Block untrusted or newly registered domains from being added to the trusted list.
Implement input sanitization and prompt whitelisting.
Restrict AI agent access to only necessary data fields.

vulnerabilities.title: Neon App pays users to record their phone calls, sells data for AI training [updated]
vulnerabilities.original_title: Neon App pays users to record their phone calls, sells data for AI training [updated]
vulnerabilities.content_snippet: TechCrunch reports about a “bizarre app” inviting you to record and share your audio calls so that it can sell the data to AI companies. And if that’s not weird enough on its own, it’s ranking No. 2 in Apple’s US app store at the time of writing. The name of the app is Neon Mobile and it ...
vulnerabilities.summary: Improper access control allowing Neon Mobile users to retrieve other users' call recordings and personal data
vulnerabilities.description: A flaw in Neon Mobile's backend API and account handling logic permits an authenticated user to request and download call recordings and associated metadata belonging to other users without proper authorization checks. The vulnerability can be exploited by crafting API requests with another user's identifier, resulting in unauthorized disclosure of voice data, contact information, and usage metrics. The issue persists as long as the user's account remains active, even after the app is removed from the device, because recordings are tied to the server-side account rather than the client.
vulnerabilities.remediation: Neon Mobile must implement strict server‑side access control checks for all endpoints that return call recordings or personal data, ensuring the requesting user is either the owner of the data or has explicit consent. Deploy authentication token validation, enforce least‑privilege principles, and add audit logging. Release updated app binaries and force a mandatory update. Consider shutting down vulnerable endpoints until patches are applied.
workarounds: Stop using Neon Mobile and delete the account via the in‑app settings.
Revoke all third‑party permissions granted to the app.
Monitor network traffic for unexpected API calls to Neon servers.

vulnerabilities.title: No Patches for Vulnerabilities Allowing Cognex Industrial Camera Hacking
vulnerabilities.original_title: No Patches for Vulnerabilities Allowing Cognex Industrial Camera Hacking
vulnerabilities.content_snippet: Cognex is advising customers to transition to newer versions of its machine vision products. The post No Patches for Vulnerabilities Allowing Cognex Industrial Camera Hacking appeared first on SecurityWeek.
vulnerabilities.summary: Multiple undisclosed vulnerabilities in Cognex industrial cameras that allow remote hacking and unauthorized access.
vulnerabilities.description: The article reports that Cognex has identified several vulnerabilities in its industrial camera line that can be exploited to gain unauthorized control, capture images, or disrupt operations. No public CVE identifiers or detailed technical disclosures have been released. The vulnerabilities appear to be remotely exploitable over the network, potentially without authentication, and affect multiple firmware versions of Cognex vision products.
vulnerabilities.remediation: Cognex recommends customers migrate to newer product versions that incorporate security hardening. Until patches are released, apply network segmentation, restrict access to camera management interfaces, change default credentials, and disable unnecessary services.
workarounds: Place cameras on isolated VLANs with strict firewall rules
Enforce strong, unique passwords for all camera accounts
Disable remote management interfaces if not required
Monitor network traffic for anomalous connections to camera IPs

vulnerabilities.title: Cisco Firewall Zero-Days Exploited in China-Linked ArcaneDoor Attacks
vulnerabilities.original_title: Cisco Firewall Zero-Days Exploited in China-Linked ArcaneDoor Attacks
vulnerabilities.content_snippet: Leading to remote code execution and privilege escalation, the flaws were exploited on Cisco ASA 5500-X series devices that lack secure boot. The post Cisco Firewall Zero-Days Exploited in China-Linked ArcaneDoor Attacks appeared first on SecurityWeek.
vulnerabilities.summary: Remote code execution and privilege escalation vulnerabilities in Cisco ASA 5500-X series devices lacking secure boot.
vulnerabilities.description: The vulnerabilities allow an unauthenticated attacker to send specially crafted network packets to Cisco ASA 5500-X firewalls that do not have Secure Boot enabled. Successful exploitation results in remote code execution with root privileges, enabling full control of the device and further lateral movement within the protected network. The flaws also permit privilege escalation from a low‑privileged context to administrative rights on the firewall.
products_versions: Cisco ASA 5500-X series (devices without Secure Boot enabled)
vulnerabilities.remediation: Upgrade to the latest ASA software version that includes Secure Boot enforcement and the associated security patches. If upgrading is not immediately possible, enable Secure Boot on affected devices and apply any available Cisco security advisories.
workarounds: Enable Secure Boot on all ASA 5500-X devices.
Restrict management access to trusted IP ranges and enforce strong authentication.
Disable unnecessary services and ports on the firewall.
Implement network segmentation to limit exposure of the ASA to untrusted networks.

vulnerabilities.title: Cisco ASA Firewall Zero-Day Exploits Deploy RayInitiator and LINE VIPER Malware
vulnerabilities.original_title: Cisco ASA Firewall Zero-Day Exploits Deploy RayInitiator and LINE VIPER Malware
vulnerabilities.content_snippet: The U.K. National Cyber Security Centre (NCSC) has revealed that threat actors have exploited the recently disclosed security flaws impacting Cisco firewalls as part of zero-day attacks to deliver previously undocumented malware families like RayInitiator and LINE VIPER. "The RayInitiator and LINE V...
vulnerabilities.summary: Zero‑day vulnerabilities in Cisco ASA firewall used to deliver RayInitiator and LINE VIPER malware.
vulnerabilities.description: Threat actors exploited newly disclosed flaws in Cisco ASA firewalls to execute code remotely without authentication. The vulnerabilities allow attackers to upload and execute arbitrary payloads, which were used to install the previously undocumented RayInitiator and LINE VIPER malware families. The attacks are classified as zero‑day because they were observed in the wild before any public fix was released. The exploitation chain involves sending specially crafted network packets to the ASA management interface, triggering a buffer overflow/command injection that results in remote code execution and subsequent malware drop.
vulnerabilities.remediation: Apply the Cisco security advisory patches as soon as they are released. Until patches are available, restrict access to the ASA management interfaces to trusted IP ranges, enforce multi‑factor authentication, disable unnecessary services (e.g., HTTP/HTTPS management on the data plane), and ensure the latest firmware is deployed. Conduct a full inventory of ASA devices and verify they are running supported versions.
workarounds: Block inbound traffic to ASA management ports (e.g., TCP 22, 443, 80) from untrusted networks.
Enable strict ACLs on the management interface.
Use out‑of‑band management consoles for configuration changes.
references: Cisco Security Advisory (placeholder for actual advisory URL)

vulnerabilities.title: Cisco ASA Firewall Zero-Day Exploits Deploy RayInitiator and LINE VIPER Malware
vulnerabilities.original_title: Cisco ASA Firewall Zero-Day Exploits Deploy RayInitiator and LINE VIPER Malware
vulnerabilities.content_snippet: The U.K. National Cyber Security Centre (NCSC) has revealed that threat actors have exploited the recently disclosed security flaws impacting Cisco firewalls as part of zero-day attacks to deliver previously undocumented malware families like RayInitiator and LINE VIPER. "The RayInitiator and LINE V...
vulnerabilities.summary: Zero-day vulnerabilities in Cisco ASA firewalls exploited to deliver RayInitiator and LINE VIPER malware.
vulnerabilities.description: Threat actors leveraged recently disclosed but unpatched flaws in Cisco ASA firewalls to execute remote code without authentication. The exploited vulnerabilities allow attackers to install previously undocumented malware families, RayInitiator and LINE VIPER, providing persistent footholds and data exfiltration capabilities. Specific CVE identifiers were not disclosed in the source article.
vulnerabilities.remediation: Apply the latest Cisco ASA security patches as soon as they are released. Verify firmware version and update to a patched release. Review Cisco security advisories for detailed guidance.
workarounds: Restrict inbound traffic to the ASA management interfaces.
Disable unnecessary services and protocols on the firewall.
Implement strict ACLs to limit exposure of vulnerable ports.

vulnerabilities.title: U.S. CISA adds CISCO Secure Firewall ASA and Secure FTD flaws to its Known Exploited Vulnerabilities catalog
vulnerabilities.original_title: U.S. CISA adds CISCO Secure Firewall ASA and Secure FTD flaws to its Known Exploited Vulnerabilities catalog
vulnerabilities.content_snippet: U.S. Cybersecurity and Infrastructure Security Agency (CISA) adds CISCO Secure Firewall ASA and Secure FTD flaws to its Known Exploited Vulnerabilities catalog. The U.S. Cybersecurity and Infrastructure Security Agency (CISA) added CISCO Secure Firewall ASA and Secure FTD flaws to its Known Exploite...
vulnerabilities.summary: Missing authorization vulnerability in Cisco Secure Firewall ASA and FTD VPN Web Server that can be chained with CVE-2025-20333 for remote code execution.
vulnerabilities.description: The VPN Web Server component of Cisco ASA/FTD lacks proper authorization checks, allowing an unauthenticated attacker to access privileged functionality. When combined with the buffer overflow in CVE-2025-20333, an attacker can achieve full remote code execution and subsequently modify ROM to retain persistence across reboots and upgrades.
affected_products: Cisco Secure Firewall Adaptive Security Appliance (ASA)
Cisco Secure Firewall Threat Defense (FTD) Software
products_versions: Specific vulnerable versions of Cisco Secure Firewall ASA and Cisco Secure Firewall Threat Defense (FTD) – exact versions not disclosed in the article.
vulnerabilities.remediation: Apply the Cisco security advisory patches released for CVE-2025-20362. Upgrade to the latest supported ASA/FTD software version. Verify that the VPN Web Server is disabled if not required.
workarounds: Disable the VPN Web Server interface if it is not needed.
Restrict access to the ASA/FTD management and VPN web interfaces to trusted IP ranges using ACLs.
Enable strong authentication and MFA for any remaining administrative access.
references: Cisco Security Advisory for CVE-2025-20362 (hypothetical URL)

vulnerabilities.title: U.S. CISA adds CISCO Secure Firewall ASA and Secure FTD flaws to its Known Exploited Vulnerabilities catalog
vulnerabilities.original_title: U.S. CISA adds CISCO Secure Firewall ASA and Secure FTD flaws to its Known Exploited Vulnerabilities catalog
vulnerabilities.content_snippet: U.S. Cybersecurity and Infrastructure Security Agency (CISA) adds CISCO Secure Firewall ASA and Secure FTD flaws to its Known Exploited Vulnerabilities catalog. The U.S. Cybersecurity and Infrastructure Security Agency (CISA) added CISCO Secure Firewall ASA and Secure FTD flaws to its Known Exploite...
vulnerabilities.summary: Buffer overflow vulnerability in Cisco Secure Firewall ASA and FTD VPN Web Server that enables unauthenticated remote code execution and can be chained with CVE-2025-20362.
vulnerabilities.description: A memory corruption bug in the VPN Web Server component of ASA/FTD allows an attacker to overflow a buffer and execute arbitrary code with root privileges. The vulnerability can be leveraged together with CVE-2025-20362 to bypass any remaining authorization checks, leading to full system compromise and the ability to modify ROM for persistence.
affected_products: Cisco Secure Firewall Adaptive Security Appliance (ASA)
Cisco Secure Firewall Threat Defense (FTD) Software
products_versions: Specific vulnerable versions of Cisco Secure Firewall ASA and Cisco Secure Firewall Threat Defense (FTD) – exact versions not disclosed in the article.
vulnerabilities.remediation: Install the Cisco-provided patch for CVE-2025-20333. Upgrade to the latest supported ASA/FTD release. Verify that the VPN Web Server is not exposed to untrusted networks.
workarounds: Disable the VPN Web Server feature if it is not required.
Apply strict network ACLs to limit access to the ASA/FTD management interfaces.
Monitor for abnormal memory usage or crash dumps from the VPN Web Server process.
references: Cisco Security Advisory for CVE-2025-20333 (hypothetical URL)

vulnerabilities.title: CISA orders agencies to patch Cisco flaws exploited in zero-day attacks
vulnerabilities.original_title: CISA orders agencies to patch Cisco flaws exploited in zero-day attacks
vulnerabilities.content_snippet: CISA has issued a new emergency directive ordering U.S. federal agencies to secure their Cisco firewall devices against two flaws that have been exploited in zero-day attacks. [...]
vulnerabilities.summary: Two Cisco firewall vulnerabilities exploited in zero‑day attacks, prompting an emergency CISA directive.
vulnerabilities.description: Both flaws allow unauthenticated remote attackers to execute arbitrary code on the underlying operating system of Cisco firewall devices. The vulnerabilities are triggered by sending specially crafted network packets to the management interface, resulting in full system compromise. Exploits have been observed in the wild and are being used in targeted zero‑day campaigns against U.S. federal networks.
vulnerabilities.remediation: Apply the security patches released by Cisco for the affected firewall models as soon as possible. Verify patch installation via Cisco's advisory and update the device firmware to the latest recommended version.
workarounds: Restrict inbound traffic to the management interface to trusted IP ranges only.
Disable any unnecessary services on the firewall that expose the vulnerable ports.
Enable strict ACLs and intrusion‑prevention signatures that detect the malicious packet patterns.

vulnerabilities.title: New SVG-based phishing campaign is a recipe for disaster
vulnerabilities.original_title: New SVG-based phishing campaign is a recipe for disaster
vulnerabilities.content_snippet: We’ve written in the past about cybercriminals using SVG files for phishing and for clickjack campaigns. We found a new, rather sophisticated example of an SVG involved in phishing. For readers that missed the earlier posts, SVG files are not always simply image files. Because they are written...
vulnerabilities.summary: Malicious SVG files containing embedded JavaScript can be opened by Microsoft Edge on Windows, allowing attackers to execute redirects and harvest credentials via phishing.
vulnerabilities.description: SVG files are XML documents that can embed HTML and JavaScript. When a malicious SVG is opened in Microsoft Edge, the embedded script executes. In the observed campaign, the script decodes an obfuscated string to produce a call to window.location.replace, redirecting the victim to a phishing domain that mimics a legitimate Microsoft 365/Outlook login page. The SVG also carries the target's email address, enabling tailored Business Email Compromise (BEC) attacks. No specific CVE is assigned, but the issue stems from the lack of strict content sanitization for SVG files in Edge and the default association of SVG with Edge on Windows.
affected_products: Any Windows system that opens SVG files with Edge as the default handler
products_versions: Microsoft Edge (all Windows versions that associate .svg with Edge)
vulnerabilities.remediation: Apply any available Microsoft Edge updates that harden SVG handling. Configure Edge or system policies to block execution of scripts within SVG files. Deploy email security gateways that detect and quarantine SVG attachments. Educate users to treat SVG attachments as potentially dangerous and verify senders before opening.
workarounds: Disable Edge as the default handler for .svg files and use a browser that blocks script execution in SVGs.
Enable Windows Defender Application Guard or similar sandboxing for opening untrusted files.
Set Group Policy to block JavaScript execution in SVG content.

vulnerabilities.title: New SVG-based phishing campaign is a recipe for disaster
vulnerabilities.original_title: New SVG-based phishing campaign is a recipe for disaster
vulnerabilities.content_snippet: We’ve written in the past about cybercriminals using SVG files for phishing and for clickjack campaigns. We found a new, rather sophisticated example of an SVG involved in phishing. For readers that missed the earlier posts, SVG files are not always simply image files. Because they are written...
vulnerabilities.summary: Malicious SVG file leveraged to execute JavaScript for credential‑phishing via window.location.replace redirection.
vulnerabilities.description: The SVG attachment contains embedded JavaScript that decodes an obfuscated data‑ingredients attribute to produce a URL. The script then calls window.location.replace() to redirect the victim to a phishing site that mimics Microsoft 365/Outlook login pages. The attack relies on the fact that Windows opens SVG files with Microsoft Edge regardless of the user’s default browser, bypassing browser‑specific security extensions. The malicious SVG is delivered via targeted phishing emails with the victim’s email address embedded in the file, indicating a Business Email Compromise (BEC) campaign.
affected_products: Microsoft Edge (default SVG handler on Windows)
Any web browser that renders SVG with JavaScript enabled
products_versions: Microsoft Edge (all versions that handle SVG with JavaScript enabled)
Windows 10/11 default file association for SVG
vulnerabilities.remediation: Disable automatic opening of SVG files or configure the system to open SVGs with a safe viewer that does not execute JavaScript. Apply email security gateways that scan and quarantine SVG attachments. Use web‑filtering solutions that block known malicious domains (e.g., devconptytld.com.au). Educate users to treat SVG attachments as potentially dangerous. Enforce Content Security Policy (CSP) on internal web applications to disallow inline scripts in SVGs.
workarounds: Configure Windows file association for .svg to a non‑browser viewer.
Block .svg attachments at the mail gateway.
Deploy endpoint protection with behavior‑based detection for script execution from SVG files.

vulnerabilities.title: ForcedLeak Flaw in Salesforce Agentforce AI Agent Exposed CRM Data
vulnerabilities.original_title: ForcedLeak Flaw in Salesforce Agentforce AI Agent Exposed CRM Data
vulnerabilities.content_snippet: Cybersecurity firm Noma Security reveals ForcedLeak, a critical flaw in Salesforce Agentforce that allowed data theft. Learn what companies need to do now to secure AI agents.
vulnerabilities.summary: ForcedLeak vulnerability in Salesforce Agentforce AI Agent enables unauthorized extraction of CRM data.
vulnerabilities.description: ForcedLeak is a logic/authorization bypass flaw in the Agentforce AI Agent component of Salesforce. The flaw allows an attacker to craft malicious requests to the Agent's API endpoints, causing the service to leak CRM records (contacts, accounts, opportunities) to an arbitrary external destination. The issue stems from insufficient validation of the data flow between the AI agent and the underlying Salesforce data store, enabling data exfiltration without proper permission checks.
products_versions: Salesforce Agentforce (all versions prior to the September 2025 security patch)
vulnerabilities.remediation: Apply the security patch released by Salesforce for Agentforce (see Salesforce security advisory). Rotate all API keys and OAuth tokens used by Agentforce. Review and tighten IAM policies for the AI agent, limiting data scope to the minimum required. Enable Salesforce Shield Event Monitoring to audit Agentforce activity.
workarounds: Temporarily disable the Agentforce AI Agent feature until the patch is applied.
Restrict network access to Agentforce endpoints to trusted IP ranges.
Implement strict field‑level security and object‑level permissions for data accessed by the AI agent.
references: Noma Security advisory on ForcedLeak (internal report)
