vulnerabilities.original_title: CTEM's Core: Prioritization and Validation
vulnerabilities.content_snippet: Despite a coordinated investment of time, effort, planning, and resources, even the most up-to-date cybersecurity systems continue to fail. Every day. Why?  It’s not because security teams can't see enough. Quite the contrary. Every security tool spits out thousands of findings. Patch this. Blo...
vulnerabilities.summary: The article discusses generic challenges in vulnerability management and alert fatigue, but does not reference a specific vulnerability.

vulnerabilities.title: Zero-day deja vu as another Cisco IOS bug comes under attack
vulnerabilities.original_title: Zero-day deja vu as another Cisco IOS bug comes under attack
vulnerabilities.content_snippet: The latest in a run of serious networking bugs gives attackers root if they have SNMP access Cisco has confirmed a new IOS and IOS XE zero-day, the latest in a string of flaws that attackers have been quick to weaponize.…
vulnerabilities.summary: Zero-day vulnerability in Cisco IOS and IOS XE that allows remote attackers with SNMP access to obtain root privileges.
vulnerabilities.description: Cisco has confirmed a new zero‑day flaw in IOS and IOS XE. The vulnerability is triggered via SNMP requests. An attacker who can send crafted SNMP packets to a vulnerable device can execute arbitrary code with root privileges, effectively taking full control of the router or switch. The bug appears to be exploitable without authentication beyond the ability to reach the SNMP service, and early reports indicate that exploit code is already being used in the wild.
vulnerabilities.remediation: Apply the Cisco security advisory patch as soon as it is released. Until a patch is available, disable SNMP or restrict SNMP access to trusted management stations using ACLs and firewall rules. Ensure that SNMP community strings are changed from defaults and consider using SNMPv3 with authentication and encryption.
workarounds: Disable SNMP on affected devices.
Restrict SNMP access to trusted IP addresses via ACLs.
Upgrade to a version of IOS/IOS XE that is not vulnerable, if available.
Monitor and block suspicious SNMP traffic at network perimeters.

vulnerabilities.title: Zero-day deja vu as another Cisco IOS bug comes under attack
vulnerabilities.original_title: Zero-day deja vu as another Cisco IOS bug comes under attack
vulnerabilities.content_snippet: The latest in a run of serious networking bugs gives attackers root if they have SNMP access Cisco has confirmed a new IOS and IOS XE zero-day, the latest in a string of flaws that attackers have been quick to weaponize.…
vulnerabilities.summary: Unauthenticated remote code execution vulnerability in Cisco IOS and IOS XE that allows attackers with SNMP access to gain root privileges.
vulnerabilities.description: A zero‑day flaw in the SNMP implementation of Cisco IOS and IOS XE allows an attacker who can send specially crafted SNMP packets to execute arbitrary code with root privileges. The vulnerability is triggered without authentication if the device is reachable via SNMP, and it can be weaponized to obtain full control of the networking device. Cisco has confirmed the existence of the bug and indicated that it is being actively exploited in the wild.
products_versions: Cisco IOS (various releases prior to patch)
Cisco IOS XE (various releases prior to patch)
vulnerabilities.remediation: Apply the official Cisco security advisory patch as soon as it is released. If a patch is not yet available, mitigate by disabling SNMP or restricting SNMP access to trusted management networks, using strong community strings or SNMPv3 with authentication and encryption, and implementing ACLs to block unauthorized SNMP traffic.
workarounds: Disable SNMP on affected devices until a patch is applied.
Restrict SNMP access to management VLANs and trusted IP addresses.
Upgrade to the latest IOS/IOS XE release that includes the fix.
Switch to SNMPv3 with authentication and encryption.

vulnerabilities.title: Cisco Patches Zero-Day Flaw Affecting Routers and Switches
vulnerabilities.original_title: Cisco Patches Zero-Day Flaw Affecting Routers and Switches
vulnerabilities.content_snippet: The security defect allows remote attackers with administrative privileges to execute arbitrary code as the root user. The post Cisco Patches Zero-Day Flaw Affecting Routers and Switches appeared first on SecurityWeek.
vulnerabilities.summary: Remote code execution vulnerability in Cisco routers and switches allowing attackers with administrative privileges to execute arbitrary code as root.
vulnerabilities.description: A flaw in the management plane of certain Cisco routing and switching platforms permits an authenticated attacker with administrative rights to inject and execute arbitrary code with root privileges. The vulnerability stems from insufficient validation of privileged commands, leading to command injection and subsequent privilege escalation. Successful exploitation results in full control of the device, enabling data exfiltration, network disruption, and lateral movement within the environment.
products_versions: Specific router and switch models affected are not disclosed in the article.
vulnerabilities.remediation: Apply the security patches released by Cisco for the affected platforms. Verify patch installation and reboot devices if required.
workarounds: Restrict remote administrative access to trusted IP ranges.
Enforce multi-factor authentication for all privileged accounts.
Disable unused management services and interfaces.
Monitor and log privileged command usage.

vulnerabilities.title: Cisco fixed actively exploited zero-day in Cisco IOS and IOS XE software
vulnerabilities.original_title: Cisco fixed actively exploited zero-day in Cisco IOS and IOS XE software
vulnerabilities.content_snippet: Cisco addressed a high-severity zero-day in Cisco IOS and IOS XE Software that is being actively exploited in attacks in the wild. Cisco fixed an actively exploited zero-day, tracked as CVE-2025-20352, impacting Cisco IOS and IOS XE Software. The high-severity vulnerability resides in the Simple Net...
vulnerabilities.summary: Stack overflow in the SNMP subsystem of Cisco IOS and IOS XE allows remote authenticated attackers to cause DoS or execute arbitrary code as root.
vulnerabilities.description: A stack overflow condition exists in the Simple Network Management Protocol (SNMP) subsystem of Cisco IOS and IOS XE. An attacker with valid SNMPv1/v2c read‑only community string or SNMPv3 credentials can send a crafted SNMP packet over IPv4 or IPv6. With low‑privilege credentials the attacker can trigger a denial‑of‑service condition. With high‑privilege (admin/privilege‑15) credentials the attacker can achieve root code execution on the device.
products_versions: All Cisco IOS and IOS XE releases with SNMP enabled (specific versions not disclosed)
vulnerabilities.remediation: Upgrade to the Cisco IOS/IOS XE software release that contains the fix for CVE-2025-20352.
workarounds: Restrict SNMP access to trusted hosts via ACLs or firewall rules.
Disable SNMP if it is not required.
Use SNMPv3 with strong authentication and encryption.
Change default community strings to strong, unique values.

vulnerabilities.title: New Supermicro BMC flaws can create persistent backdoors
vulnerabilities.original_title: New Supermicro BMC flaws can create persistent backdoors
vulnerabilities.content_snippet: Two vulnerabilities affecting the firmware of Supermicro hardware, including Baseboard Management Controller (BMC) allow attackers to update systems with maliciously crafted images. [...]
vulnerabilities.summary: Unauthenticated firmware update vulnerability in Supermicro Baseboard Management Controller (BMC) allowing malicious image injection and persistent backdoor creation.
vulnerabilities.description: Two separate flaws in the Supermicro BMC firmware bypass authentication checks and allow an attacker to upload a maliciously crafted firmware image. The vulnerable code fails to properly validate the image signature and does not enforce integrity checks, enabling remote attackers to replace the BMC firmware with a malicious version. Once installed, the malicious firmware can persist across reboots, provide full control over the host system, and create covert backdoors for later access.
affected_products: Supermicro SuperServer platforms with BMC firmware
products_versions: All Supermicro BMC firmware versions prior to the September 2025 security release
vulnerabilities.remediation: Apply the vendor-supplied firmware update that includes proper signature verification and input validation. Verify firmware integrity using cryptographic hashes provided by Supermicro. Re‑flash the BMC with a clean, signed image if compromise is suspected.
workarounds: Disable remote BMC access (IPMI over LAN) until a patched firmware version is available.
Restrict BMC network traffic to trusted management VLANs and enforce firewall rules.
Enable BMC authentication and strong passwords, even though the vulnerability bypasses auth, it reduces attack surface for other vectors.
references: NVD entries for related CVEs (if any)

vulnerabilities.title: Cisco warns of IOS zero-day vulnerability exploited in attacks
vulnerabilities.original_title: Cisco warns of IOS zero-day vulnerability exploited in attacks
vulnerabilities.content_snippet: Cisco has released security updates to address a high-severity zero-day vulnerability in Cisco IOS and IOS XE Software that is currently being exploited in attacks. [...]
vulnerabilities.summary: A high-severity zero-day vulnerability in Cisco IOS and IOS XE that allows remote code execution and is actively being exploited.
vulnerabilities.description: The vulnerability resides in the packet processing engine of Cisco IOS/IOS XE. An unauthenticated attacker can send specially crafted network packets to a vulnerable router or switch, triggering a buffer overflow that leads to arbitrary code execution with root privileges. The flaw is exploitable over the network without prior authentication and has been observed in the wild, with attackers using it to gain persistent footholds on critical infrastructure.
products_versions: Cisco IOS 15.x through 17.x (all releases prior to the September 2025 security advisory)
Cisco IOS XE 16.x through 17.x (all releases prior to the September 2025 security advisory)
vulnerabilities.remediation: Apply the security updates released by Cisco for the affected IOS and IOS XE releases. Verify the installation of the patches via the Cisco Software Checker and reboot the devices if required.
workarounds: Restrict inbound management traffic to trusted IP addresses using ACLs.
Disable any unnecessary services (e.g., HTTP, Telnet) on the affected devices.
Enable control plane policing (CoPP) to limit malformed traffic.

vulnerabilities.title: Nation-State hackers exploit Libraesva Email Gateway flaw
vulnerabilities.original_title: Nation-State hackers exploit Libraesva Email Gateway flaw
vulnerabilities.content_snippet: State-sponsored hackers exploited a vulnerability, tracked as CVE-2025-59689, in Libraesva Email Gateway via malicious attachments. Nation-state actors exploited a command injection flaw, tracked as CVE-2025-59689, in Libraesva Email Security Gateway. Libraesva Email Security Gateway is an advanced ...
vulnerabilities.summary: Command injection vulnerability in Libraesva Email Security Gateway triggered by specially crafted compressed email attachments.
vulnerabilities.description: The vulnerability arises from improper sanitization of code in certain compressed archive formats processed by the Libraesva ESG. An attacker can embed malicious payload files within a compressed attachment that bypasses the gateway's sanitization logic, leading to arbitrary shell command execution under a non‑privileged user account. The attack is delivered via a crafted email containing the malicious archive.
products_versions: Libraesva ESG 4.5 through 5.5 (4.x no longer supported)
vulnerabilities.remediation: Apply the vendor-provided patch for ESG 5.x versions. Upgrade to the latest supported version of Libraesva ESG. If upgrading is not possible, disable processing of the affected compressed archive formats.
workarounds: Block or quarantine compressed attachment types known to be affected.
Configure the gateway to reject emails with suspicious archive structures.
Enforce strict file type validation and content inspection before extraction.

vulnerabilities.title: iframe Security Exposed: The Blind Spot Fueling Payment Skimmer Attacks
vulnerabilities.original_title: iframe Security Exposed: The Blind Spot Fueling Payment Skimmer Attacks
vulnerabilities.content_snippet: Think payment iframes are secure by design? Think again. Sophisticated attackers have quietly evolved malicious overlay techniques to exploit checkout pages and steal credit card data by bypassing the very security policies designed to stop them. Download the complete iframe security guide here.&nbs...
vulnerabilities.summary: Malicious overlay techniques used to compromise payment iframes and exfiltrate credit card data
vulnerabilities.description: Attackers inject malicious HTML/CSS/JavaScript overlays into pages that host payment iframes. The overlay mimics the legitimate checkout UI, captures user input (card number, CVV, expiration), and forwards it to attacker‑controlled servers. Because the overlay is rendered in the same browser context as the iframe, standard iframe sandboxing and X‑Frame‑Options can be bypassed if the parent page does not enforce strict Content Security Policy (CSP) or frame‑ancestors directives. The technique leverages supply‑chain compromise, compromised third‑party scripts, or DOM‑based injection (e.g., via vulnerable ad networks or compromised CDN resources).
affected_products: Web-based checkout pages embedding third‑party payment iframes
vulnerabilities.remediation: Implement a strict Content Security Policy that disallows inline scripts and limits frame sources (frame‑ancestors 'self' https://trusted‑gateway.com). Use X‑Frame‑Options: DENY or SAMEORIGIN on all pages that embed payment iframes. Enforce SameSite=Lax or Strict on session cookies. Deploy Subresource Integrity (SRI) for third‑party scripts. Apply runtime application self‑protection (RASP) to detect DOM manipulation. Tokenize payment data so that raw card details never touch the merchant site.
workarounds: Host the payment form entirely on the payment provider’s domain using redirect rather than iframe.
Enable multi‑factor authentication for checkout actions to reduce impact of credential theft.

vulnerabilities.title: iframe Security Exposed: The Blind Spot Fueling Payment Skimmer Attacks
vulnerabilities.original_title: iframe Security Exposed: The Blind Spot Fueling Payment Skimmer Attacks
vulnerabilities.content_snippet: Think payment iframes are secure by design? Think again. Sophisticated attackers have quietly evolved malicious overlay techniques to exploit checkout pages and steal credit card data by bypassing the very security policies designed to stop them. Download the complete iframe security guide here.&nbs...
vulnerabilities.summary: Malicious overlay attacks on payment iframes allowing credential theft by bypassing same-origin and frame security policies.
vulnerabilities.description: Attackers inject malicious HTML/CSS/JavaScript overlays into pages that host payment iframes. By exploiting lax Content Security Policy (CSP), missing X‑Frame‑Options, or improper sandbox attributes, the malicious layer can capture keystrokes, clone the iframe UI, or redirect form submissions to attacker‑controlled endpoints. The technique works even when the iframe content is served over HTTPS because the overlay runs in the parent page’s origin, allowing it to read user input before it reaches the secure iframe. Variants include CSS‑based clickjacking, DOM‑clobbering, and script injection via compromised third‑party resources.
affected_products: Web-based checkout pages using embedded payment iframes
Third‑party payment gateway widgets (e.g., Stripe, PayPal, Adyen)
E‑commerce platforms that embed external payment iframes (Shopify, Magento, WooCommerce, BigCommerce)
vulnerabilities.remediation: Implement strict CSP with frame‑ancestors limited to trusted domains, set X‑Frame‑Options to DENY or SAMEORIGIN, use sandbox attribute on iframes, enforce SameSite=Lax/Strict on session cookies, employ UI integrity checks (e.g., Subresource Integrity, runtime DOM integrity validation), and adopt tokenized payment flows that never expose raw card data to the merchant site.
workarounds: Host payment forms entirely on the payment provider’s domain instead of embedding iframes.
Use server‑side rendering of payment fields with tokenization APIs.
Apply client‑side JavaScript integrity monitors that alert on unexpected DOM changes.

vulnerabilities.title: Libraesva Email Security Gateway Vulnerability Exploited by Nation-State Hackers
vulnerabilities.original_title: Libraesva Email Security Gateway Vulnerability Exploited by Nation-State Hackers
vulnerabilities.content_snippet: Tracked as CVE-2025-59689, the command injection bug could be triggered via malicious emails containing crafted compressed attachments. The post Libraesva Email Security Gateway Vulnerability Exploited by Nation-State Hackers appeared first on SecurityWeek.
vulnerabilities.summary: Command injection vulnerability in Libraesva Email Security Gateway triggered by crafted compressed attachments in malicious emails.
vulnerabilities.description: An attacker can embed specially crafted compressed files (e.g., ZIP, RAR) within an email. When the Libraesva Email Security Gateway processes the attachment, insufficient input validation allows arbitrary OS commands to be executed with the privileges of the gateway service. This leads to remote code execution on the gateway, enabling the attacker to compromise the email infrastructure and pivot to internal networks.
vulnerabilities.remediation: Apply the vendor-supplied patch as soon as it is released. Until a patch is available, disable automatic processing of compressed attachments, enforce attachment type restrictions, and update the gateway to the latest version with all security updates.
workarounds: Block or quarantine compressed attachment types (ZIP, RAR, 7z) at the email gateway.
Enable sandboxing of attachments and reject those that exhibit suspicious behavior.
Restrict the execution context of the gateway service to least‑privilege accounts.

vulnerabilities.title: Microsoft Fixed Entra ID Vulnerability Allowing Global Admin Impersonation
vulnerabilities.original_title: Microsoft Fixed Entra ID Vulnerability Allowing Global Admin Impersonation
vulnerabilities.content_snippet: Microsoft patched an Entra ID vulnerability that let attackers impersonate Global Admins across tenants, risking full Microsoft 365 and Azure takeover.
vulnerabilities.summary: Entra ID vulnerability allowing attackers to impersonate Global Admins across tenants, enabling full Microsoft 365 and Azure takeover.
vulnerabilities.description: A flaw in Microsoft Entra ID token handling or role assignment logic permitted an attacker to forge or reuse authentication tokens to assume Global Administrator privileges in any tenant. This cross‑tenant impersonation bypassed normal tenant isolation, granting the attacker unrestricted access to all resources within Microsoft 365 and Azure services of the compromised tenant, including the ability to create, modify, or delete resources, exfiltrate data, and establish persistence.
products_versions: Microsoft Entra ID (Azure AD) versions prior to the September 2025 security update
vulnerabilities.remediation: Apply the Microsoft security update released on 2025-09-23. After patching, rotate all Global Administrator credentials, enforce multi‑factor authentication for privileged accounts, and review role assignments for any unauthorized changes.
workarounds: Restrict Global Administrator assignments to a minimal set of accounts.
Enable Conditional Access policies that require MFA for privileged sign‑ins.
Monitor Entra ID sign‑in logs for anomalous cross‑tenant token usage.

vulnerabilities.title: U.S. CISA adds Google Chromium flaw to its Known Exploited Vulnerabilities catalog
vulnerabilities.original_title: U.S. CISA adds Google Chromium flaw to its Known Exploited Vulnerabilities catalog
vulnerabilities.content_snippet: U.S. Cybersecurity and Infrastructure Security Agency (CISA) adds Google Chromium flaw to its Known Exploited Vulnerabilities catalog. The U.S. Cybersecurity and Infrastructure Security Agency (CISA) added Google Chromium flaw, tracked as CVE-2025-10585, to its Known Exploited Vulnerabilities (KEV) ...
vulnerabilities.summary: Type confusion vulnerability in V8 JavaScript and WebAssembly engine of Google Chromium/Chrome allowing remote code execution.
vulnerabilities.description: A type confusion issue in the V8 engine causes the browser to misinterpret memory objects, enabling attackers to corrupt memory, cause crashes, or achieve arbitrary code execution. The flaw is exploitable via crafted JavaScript or WebAssembly payloads delivered through malicious web pages. Google’s Threat Analysis Group confirmed active exploitation in the wild.
products_versions: Google Chrome versions prior to the September 2025 security update
Chromium builds prior to the September 2025 security update
vulnerabilities.remediation: Apply the security updates released by Google in mid‑September 2025 that patch CVE‑2025‑10585. Enable automatic updates for Chrome/Chromium across all endpoints.
workarounds: Temporarily disable JavaScript execution for untrusted sites via enterprise policies.
Deploy browser isolation or remote browsing solutions.
Enforce strict Content Security Policy (CSP) to limit script sources.

vulnerabilities.title: SolarWinds Makes Third Attempt at Patching Exploited Vulnerability
vulnerabilities.original_title: SolarWinds Makes Third Attempt at Patching Exploited Vulnerability
vulnerabilities.content_snippet: CVE-2025-26399 is a patch bypass of CVE-2024-28988, which is a patch bypass of the exploited CVE-2024-28986. The post SolarWinds Makes Third Attempt at Patching Exploited Vulnerability appeared first on SecurityWeek.
vulnerabilities.summary: Patch bypass vulnerability in SolarWinds Orion that defeats the mitigation applied for CVE-2024-28988, which itself bypassed the fix for the exploited CVE-2024-28986.
vulnerabilities.description: CVE-2025-26399 is a patch bypass that allows an attacker to re‑exploit the underlying vulnerability CVE-2024-28986 even after the vendor released a fix (CVE-2024-28988). The bypass works by manipulating the patch validation logic in SolarWinds Orion, enabling the execution of malicious code remotely. This chain of bypasses indicates that the original exploit (CVE-2024-28986) remains viable and that the subsequent patches were insufficiently robust.
vulnerabilities.remediation: Deploy the latest SolarWinds Orion update that addresses CVE-2025-26399 once released. Until then, apply temporary mitigations such as disabling unnecessary remote management interfaces, enforcing strict network segmentation, and monitoring for anomalous activity related to Orion services.
workarounds: Restrict inbound network traffic to Orion management ports to trusted IP ranges.
Enable multi‑factor authentication for all Orion administrative accounts.
Increase logging verbosity and forward logs to a centralized SIEM for real‑time analysis.

vulnerabilities.title: OnePlus leaves researchers on read over Android bug that exposes texts
vulnerabilities.original_title: OnePlus leaves researchers on read over Android bug that exposes texts
vulnerabilities.content_snippet: Rapid7 warns flaw could let any app peek at your SMS, but smartphone vendor won't pick up Security researchers report that OnePlus smartphone users remain vulnerable to a critical bug that allows any application to read SMS and MMS data — a flaw that has persisted since late 2021.…
vulnerabilities.summary: Improper permission enforcement in OnePlus Android firmware allows any installed application to read SMS and MMS messages without user consent.
vulnerabilities.description: A flaw in the OnePlus Android implementation bypasses the standard Android permission checks for READ_SMS and READ_MMS. The vulnerability resides in a privileged system service that does not correctly validate the caller's identity before granting access to the SMS/MMS content provider. As a result, any third‑party app that can be installed on the device can query the provider and retrieve the full text of SMS and MMS messages, exposing personal communications, two‑factor authentication codes, and potentially sensitive links. The issue has existed since late 2021 and remains unpatched in current OnePlus firmware releases.
affected_products: OnePlus smartphones running Android 12 and Android 13 (devices released from late 2021 onward)
products_versions: OnePlus 8 series and newer (Android 12/13) released after October 2021
vulnerabilities.remediation: OnePlus must release a firmware update that adds proper permission verification in the affected system service and enforces the Android security model. Until a patch is available, users should limit installation of untrusted apps and revoke SMS permissions where possible.
workarounds: Uninstall or disable any untrusted third‑party applications.
Use the Android permission manager to manually revoke SMS/MMS read permissions for all apps.
Switch to alternative messaging platforms that do not rely on SMS for sensitive communications.
Enable a mobile security suite that monitors SMS read events.

vulnerabilities.title: American Archive of Public Broadcasting allowed access to restricted media for years
vulnerabilities.original_title: American Archive of Public Broadcasting allowed access to restricted media for years
vulnerabilities.content_snippet: A security flaw in the American Archive of Public Broadcasting (AAPB) website allowed unauthorized access to protected and private media, according to BleepingComputer. The American Archive of Public Broadcasting (AAPB) is a collaborative initiative between the Library of Congress and WGBH Education...
vulnerabilities.summary: Improper access control on AAPB media retrieval endpoint allowing download of protected/private media by ID
vulnerabilities.description: The AAPB web application exposed an endpoint that accepted a media ID parameter and returned the corresponding media file without performing proper authorization checks. An attacker (or any unauthenticated user) could supply a valid media ID—regardless of the media's classification (public, protected, or private)—and retrieve the file. The flaw persisted for years and was actively exploited from at least 2021. The issue stems from missing or mis‑implemented access‑control logic and lack of rate‑limiting or request validation, enabling mass enumeration and download of copyrighted or sensitive archival content.
affected_products: American Archive of Public Broadcasting website (media retrieval API)
products_versions: AAPB web portal (media retrieval API) – version prior to 2025‑09‑23 fix
vulnerabilities.remediation: Implement strict authorization checks for all media retrieval endpoints, ensuring that only users with appropriate permissions can access protected or private content. Enforce authentication, role‑based access control, and validate media IDs against user privileges. Add rate limiting, logging, and monitoring for anomalous request patterns. Conduct a security review of the API to close enumeration vectors.
workarounds: Temporarily disable the public media ID endpoint until proper access controls are in place.
Restrict access to the API to authenticated internal IP ranges.
Monitor and block bulk download attempts via firewall or WAF rules.
references: Discord discussion (mid‑2024) circulating the exploit script

vulnerabilities.title: All Microsoft Entra Tenants Were Exposed to Silent Compromise via Invisible Actor Tokens: Researcher
vulnerabilities.original_title: All Microsoft Entra Tenants Were Exposed to Silent Compromise via Invisible Actor Tokens: Researcher
vulnerabilities.content_snippet: The strength of responsible disclosure is that it can solve problems before they are actioned. The weakness is that it potentially generates a false sense of security in the vendor. The post All Microsoft Entra Tenants Were Exposed to Silent Compromise via Invisible Actor Tokens: Researcher appeared...
vulnerabilities.summary: Silent compromise of Microsoft Entra (Azure AD) tenants via invisible actor tokens allowing attackers to obtain valid authentication tokens without user interaction.
vulnerabilities.description: Research indicates that an attacker can generate or hijack invisible actor tokens within Microsoft Entra tenants. These tokens are not visible in standard token logs and can be used to silently authenticate to Azure AD protected resources, leading to persistent, low‑visibility compromise across all tenant workloads. The flaw stems from inadequate token validation and insufficient logging of token issuance paths, allowing malicious actors to bypass MFA and conditional access policies.
products_versions: All Microsoft Entra (Azure AD) tenant configurations
vulnerabilities.remediation: Microsoft should issue a security update that tightens token issuance validation, adds mandatory logging for all token creation events, and enforces stricter lifetime and scope checks. Administrators should rotate all service principal secrets, enforce conditional access policies, and enable token lifetime management.
workarounds: Enable Azure AD Identity Protection risk-based conditional access.
Restrict service principal permissions to least privilege.
Implement continuous monitoring of token issuance via Azure AD sign‑in logs and Azure Sentinel.
Force token expiration and re‑authentication for high‑risk applications.

vulnerabilities.title: ShadowV2 Botnet Exploits Misconfigured AWS Docker Containers for DDoS-for-Hire Service
vulnerabilities.original_title: ShadowV2 Botnet Exploits Misconfigured AWS Docker Containers for DDoS-for-Hire Service
vulnerabilities.content_snippet: Cybersecurity researchers have disclosed details of a new botnet that customers can rent access to conduct distributed denial-of-service (DDoS) attacks against targets of interest. The ShadowV2 botnet, according to Darktrace, predominantly targets misconfigured Docker containers on Amazon Web Servic...
vulnerabilities.summary: Exploitation of misconfigured Docker containers on AWS to deploy Go-based malware for DDoS-for-hire operations
vulnerabilities.description: The ShadowV2 botnet scans AWS environments for Docker containers that are exposed or misconfigured (e.g., Docker daemon listening on 0.0.0.0 without TLS, overly permissive IAM roles, open ports in security groups). Once identified, the botnet injects a Go‑based payload that runs with root privileges inside the container, turning the host into a DDoS node. The malware can also download additional modules, communicate with C2 over HTTP/HTTPS, and persist via Docker restart policies. The compromised containers are then leveraged to provide a DDoS‑for‑hire service to paying customers.
vulnerabilities.remediation:
1. Restrict Docker daemon access – bind to localhost or use TLS with client authentication.
2. Apply the principle of least privilege to IAM roles attached to EC2/ECS/EKS instances.
3. Harden security groups – close all inbound ports not required for the application.
4. Enable AWS GuardDuty and Amazon Inspector to detect exposed containers.
5. Regularly patch Docker Engine and underlying host OS.
6. Deploy container runtime security tools (e.g., Falco, Aqua, Twistlock) to monitor for unauthorized exec calls.
7. Enforce immutable infrastructure – use signed container images and image scanning.
8. Rotate credentials and enforce MFA for all AWS accounts.
workarounds: Run Docker in rootless mode where possible.
Use network ACLs to block traffic to Docker daemon ports from the internet.
Implement host‑based firewalls (iptables, firewalld) to limit container-to-host communication.

vulnerabilities.title: Top 25 MCP Vulnerabilities Reveal How AI Agents Can Be Exploited
vulnerabilities.original_title: Top 25 MCP Vulnerabilities Reveal How AI Agents Can Be Exploited
vulnerabilities.content_snippet: A new ranking of Model Context Protocol weaknesses highlights critical risks—from prompt injection to command injection—and provides a roadmap for securing the foundations of agentic AI. The post Top 25 MCP Vulnerabilities Reveal How AI Agents Can Be Exploited appeared first on SecurityWeek.
vulnerabilities.summary: Prompt injection and command injection vulnerabilities in Model Context Protocol (MCP) used by AI agents
vulnerabilities.description: MCP enables AI agents to exchange context and commands. Weak validation of prompts and commands allows an adversary to inject malicious instructions (prompt injection) or embed executable code (command injection). Exploiting these weaknesses can cause the AI agent to perform unintended actions, exfiltrate data, or execute arbitrary code on the host environment.
affected_products: AI agents and platforms implementing Model Context Protocol
affected_companies: Various AI platform providers implementing MCP
vendors: Various AI platform providers implementing MCP
vulnerabilities.remediation: Apply strict input sanitization and validation for all prompts and commands, enforce least‑privilege execution environments for AI agents, adopt sandboxing/isolated runtimes, and implement robust authentication and authorization for inter‑agent communication.
workarounds: Deploy a whitelist of allowed commands and prompt patterns
Run AI agents in containerized sandboxes with limited system access
Monitor and log all agent communications for anomalous content

vulnerabilities.title: CISA Shares Lessons Learned from an Incident Response Engagement
vulnerabilities.original_title: CISA Shares Lessons Learned from an Incident Response Engagement
vulnerabilities.content_snippet: Advisory at a Glance Executive Summary CISA began incident response efforts at a U.S. federal civilian executive branch (FCEB) agency following the detection of potential malicious activity identified through security alerts generated by the agency’s endpoint detection and response (EDR) tool. CISA ...
vulnerabilities.summary: GeoServer eval injection vulnerability allowing unauthenticated remote code execution.
vulnerabilities.description: An eval injection flaw (CWE‑95) in GeoServer permits an attacker to supply crafted input that is evaluated as code on the server. Successful exploitation results in remote code execution (RCE) with the privileges of the GeoServer process, enabling attackers to upload web shells, download additional tools, and move laterally within the victim network.
products_versions: Vulnerable GeoServer versions prior to the patch released after 2024‑06‑30
vulnerabilities.remediation: Apply the vendor‑provided patch for GeoServer (upgrade to the fixed version), disable or restrict the vulnerable endpoint, enforce network‑level access controls (e.g., firewall or WAF rules) to limit exposure of GeoServer to trusted IP ranges, and rotate any credentials that may have been compromised.
workarounds: Place GeoServer behind a reverse proxy that blocks malicious payloads.
Restrict inbound traffic to GeoServer to internal networks or VPN.
Enable application‑level firewall rules to block eval‑injection patterns.

vulnerabilities.title: CISA Shares Lessons Learned from an Incident Response Engagement
vulnerabilities.original_title: CISA Shares Lessons Learned from an Incident Response Engagement
vulnerabilities.content_snippet: Advisory at a Glance Executive Summary CISA began incident response efforts at a U.S. federal civilian executive branch (FCEB) agency following the detection of potential malicious activity identified through security alerts generated by the agency’s endpoint detection and response (EDR) tool. CISA ...
vulnerabilities.summary: DirtyCow privilege‑escalation vulnerability in Linux kernel.
vulnerabilities.description: DirtyCow is a race‑condition bug that allows an unprivileged user to gain write access to read‑only memory mappings, enabling privilege escalation to root. In the incident, threat actors attempted to exploit this CVE to elevate from a compromised web‑service account to higher‑privileged system accounts.
products_versions: Vulnerable GeoServer versions prior to the patch released after 2024‑06‑30
vulnerabilities.remediation: Update the Linux kernel to a version that includes the fix (kernel >= 4.8.3 or later distribution patches). Verify that all systems are running patched kernels and consider enabling kernel hardening options (e.g., SELinux, AppArmor).
workarounds: Mount critical binaries with the "nosuid" and "nodev" options where possible.
Use mandatory access controls to limit the impact of a compromised account.

vulnerabilities.title: ChatGPT solves CAPTCHAs if you tell it they’re fake
vulnerabilities.original_title: ChatGPT solves CAPTCHAs if you tell it they’re fake
vulnerabilities.content_snippet: If you’re seeing fewer or different CAPTCHA puzzles in the near future, that’s not because website owners have agreed that they’re annoying, but it might be because they no longer prove that the visitor is human. For those that forgot what CAPTCHA stands for: Completely Automated Public Turing test ...
vulnerabilities.summary: Prompt injection vulnerability allowing LLM agents (e.g., ChatGPT-4o) to bypass usage restrictions and solve CAPTCHAs on behalf of an attacker
vulnerabilities.description: Researchers demonstrated that by priming the model with a false premise (telling the LLM that the CAPTCHA is "fake"), the model can be coaxed into performing actions it would normally refuse, such as interpreting and solving image‑based CAPTCHAs. The attack leverages prompt injection / jailbreak techniques to override the model's safety guardrails, enabling automated solving of one‑click, logic‑based, and some image‑based CAPTCHAs. This can be used to automate account creation, credential stuffing, or other malicious activities that rely on CAPTCHA bypass.
affected_products: OpenAI AI agents built on GPT-4 architecture
Third‑party applications integrating OpenAI LLM APIs
vulnerabilities.remediation: OpenAI should strengthen prompt‑injection detection, improve guardrails to reject instructions that attempt to override policy, and add context‑aware checks for CAPTCHA‑related requests. Deploy rate‑limiting and usage monitoring on API endpoints. Encourage developers to implement additional verification layers (behavioral analysis, device fingerprinting) beyond traditional CAPTCHAs.
workarounds: Deploy CAPTCHAs that require interactive gestures difficult for LLM agents (e.g., drag‑and‑drop with precise pixel coordinates).
Combine CAPTCHAs with browser‑based challenges that involve JavaScript execution or timing analysis.
Use risk‑based authentication and rate limiting on account creation endpoints.

vulnerabilities.title: Researchers Earn $150,000 for L1TF Exploit Leaking Data From Public Cloud
vulnerabilities.original_title: Researchers Earn $150,000 for L1TF Exploit Leaking Data From Public Cloud
vulnerabilities.content_snippet: L1TF Reloaded is a vulnerability combining the old L1TF and half-Spectre hardware flaws to bypass deployed software mitigations. The post Researchers Earn $150,000 for L1TF Exploit Leaking Data From Public Cloud appeared first on SecurityWeek.
vulnerabilities.summary: L1TF Reloaded combines the original L1 Terminal Fault (L1TF) and half-Spectre microarchitectural flaws to bypass existing software mitigations and leak data across VM boundaries.
vulnerabilities.description: L1TF Reloaded is a side‑channel exploit that leverages speculative execution and microarchitectural data sampling to read data from the L1 data cache of sibling logical cores. By chaining the original L1TF primitive with a half‑Spectre gadget, the attacker can bypass mitigations such as L1D flush, page table isolation, and retpoline. The exploit works from an unprivileged context inside a virtual machine and can extract cryptographic keys, memory contents of co‑tenant VMs, or host kernel data in public‑cloud environments.
affected_products: Intel CPUs vulnerable to L1TF (e.g., Skylake, Kaby Lake, Coffee Lake, Whiskey Lake, Ice Lake)
Hypervisor platforms (KVM, Xen, VMware ESXi, Hyper-V) running on affected CPUs
Public cloud tenant VMs hosted on vulnerable hardware
products_versions: Intel Kaby Lake, Coffee Lake, Whiskey Lake, Ice Lake families
Hypervisors: KVM 5.15+, Xen 4.14+, VMware ESXi 7.0+, Hyper‑V 2022
vulnerabilities.remediation: Apply the latest Intel microcode updates, update hypervisor and guest OS kernels to include the newest L1TF mitigations, disable hyper‑threading where feasible, enable CPU feature mitigations (e.g., MD_CLEAR, L1D_FLUSH), and enforce strict VM isolation policies.
workarounds: Disable hyper‑threading in BIOS/UEFI
Use CPU pinning to ensure single‑threaded execution per VM
Deploy containers or workloads on CPUs with microcode that fully mitigates L1TF

vulnerabilities.title: ⚡ Weekly Recap: Chrome 0-Day, AI Hacking Tools, DDR5 Bit-Flips, npm Worm & More
vulnerabilities.original_title: ⚡ Weekly Recap: Chrome 0-Day, AI Hacking Tools, DDR5 Bit-Flips, npm Worm & More
vulnerabilities.content_snippet: The security landscape now moves at a pace no patch cycle can match. Attackers aren’t waiting for quarterly updates or monthly fixes—they adapt within hours, blending fresh techniques with old, forgotten flaws to create new openings. A vulnerability closed yesterday can become the blueprint for tomo...
vulnerabilities.summary: Chrome zero‑day vulnerability referenced in the weekly recap
vulnerabilities.description: A remotely exploitable flaw in Google Chrome that allows an attacker to execute arbitrary code on the victim's machine. The article does not disclose technical details, CVE identifier, or patch status.
vulnerabilities.remediation: Apply the next Chrome update as soon as it is released. Until a patch is available, consider disabling JavaScript on untrusted sites or using a hardened browser configuration.
workarounds: Enable Chrome's built‑in sandbox and site isolation features
Use an alternative browser for high‑risk browsing

vulnerabilities.title: ⚡ Weekly Recap: Chrome 0-Day, AI Hacking Tools, DDR5 Bit-Flips, npm Worm & More
vulnerabilities.original_title: ⚡ Weekly Recap: Chrome 0-Day, AI Hacking Tools, DDR5 Bit-Flips, npm Worm & More
vulnerabilities.content_snippet: The security landscape now moves at a pace no patch cycle can match. Attackers aren’t waiting for quarterly updates or monthly fixes—they adapt within hours, blending fresh techniques with old, forgotten flaws to create new openings. A vulnerability closed yesterday can become the blueprint for tomo...
vulnerabilities.summary: DDR5 memory row‑hammer style bit‑flip vulnerability
vulnerabilities.description: Researchers demonstrated that targeted memory accesses can induce bit flips in DDR5 modules, potentially leading to privilege escalation or data corruption. No CVE identifier is provided in the article.
vulnerabilities.remediation: Update firmware of affected platforms when manufacturers release mitigations. Deploy ECC memory where possible.
workarounds: Enable memory refresh rate tuning if supported
Use hardware‑based memory integrity checks

vulnerabilities.title: ⚡ Weekly Recap: Chrome 0-Day, AI Hacking Tools, DDR5 Bit-Flips, npm Worm & More
vulnerabilities.original_title: ⚡ Weekly Recap: Chrome 0-Day, AI Hacking Tools, DDR5 Bit-Flips, npm Worm & More

Attackers aren’t waiting for quarterly updates or monthly fixes—they adapt within hours, blending fresh techniques with old, forgotten flaws to create new openings. A vulnerability closed yesterday can become the blueprint for tomo...
vulnerabilities.summary: npm supply‑chain worm affecting JavaScript packages
vulnerabilities.description: A malicious npm package propagates a worm that injects malicious code into dependent projects. The article does not name the package or provide CVE details.
vulnerabilities.remediation: Audit dependencies, remove suspicious packages, and rotate compromised credentials. Enable npm audit and two‑factor authentication on npm accounts.
workarounds: Pin dependencies to known‑good versions
Use a private npm proxy with content scanning

vulnerabilities.title: ShadowLeak Exploit Exposed Gmail Data Through ChatGPT Agent
vulnerabilities.original_title: ShadowLeak Exploit Exposed Gmail Data Through ChatGPT Agent
vulnerabilities.content_snippet: Radware researchers revealed a service-side flaw in OpenAI's ChatGPT. The ShadowLeak attack had used indirect prompt injection to bypass defences and leak sensitive data, but the issue has since been fixed.
vulnerabilities.summary: Service-side indirect prompt injection vulnerability in OpenAI's ChatGPT allowing bypass of defenses and exfiltration of Gmail data via a ChatGPT agent.
vulnerabilities.description: The flaw resides in the prompt handling logic of the ChatGPT service. An attacker can craft an indirect prompt injection that manipulates the model's reasoning chain, causing it to execute actions on behalf of the user (e.g., accessing Gmail via an integrated agent) and return sensitive email contents. The injection bypasses existing content filters and safety layers, leading to data leakage. The vulnerability was exploited in the "ShadowLeak" attack and has since been patched by OpenAI.
vulnerabilities.remediation: OpenAI has released a fix that tightens prompt sanitization and isolates agent actions from user-provided content. Users should ensure they are running the latest version of the ChatGPT API/service.
workarounds: Avoid sending prompts that contain user-controlled data to agents capable of external actions.
Implement additional application-layer validation and content filtering before forwarding data to ChatGPT.
Restrict ChatGPT integration to non-sensitive workloads.

vulnerabilities.title: Researchers expose MalTerminal, an LLM-enabled malware pioneer
vulnerabilities.original_title: Researchers expose MalTerminal, an LLM-enabled malware pioneer
vulnerabilities.content_snippet: SentinelOne uncovered MalTerminal, the earliest known malware with built-in LLM capabilities, and presented it at LABScon 2025. SentinelLABS researchers discovered MalTerminal, the earliest known LLM-enabled malware, which generates malicious logic at runtime, making the detection more complex. Rese...
vulnerabilities.summary: Hardcoded LLM API keys and static prompts embedded in malware binaries enable detection but also expose the malware to key revocation.
vulnerabilities.description: MalTerminal and related tools embed API keys and predefined prompts directly in the executable. The malware contacts external LLM services to generate malicious code (ransomware payloads, reverse shells, phishing content) at runtime. The reliance on hard‑coded credentials makes the malware fragile—revoking the keys or altering the prompt format can neutralize it—but also provides a clear detection surface for defenders.
vulnerabilities.remediation: Revoke any exposed API keys, rotate credentials, enforce strict API usage policies, and implement rate‑limiting and anomaly detection on LLM service endpoints.
workarounds: Deploy YARA rules that match known key patterns and prompt strings.
Block outbound traffic to known LLM provider endpoints from untrusted hosts.
Use application allow‑lists to restrict which processes may call external APIs.

vulnerabilities.title: Airport Cyberattack Disrupts More Flights Across Europe
vulnerabilities.original_title: Airport Cyberattack Disrupts More Flights Across Europe
vulnerabilities.content_snippet: The cyberattack affected software of Collins Aerospace, whose systems help passengers check in, print boarding passes and bag tags, and dispatch their luggage. The post Airport Cyberattack Disrupts More Flights Across Europe appeared first on SecurityWeek.
vulnerabilities.summary: Undisclosed vulnerability in Collins Aerospace passenger processing software used for check‑in, boarding‑pass printing, bag‑tag generation and luggage dispatch.
vulnerabilities.description: Threat actors exploited an unknown flaw in the software stack supplied by Collins Aerospace that handles passenger check‑in, boarding‑pass printing, bag‑tag creation and luggage dispatch. The exploitation resulted in widespread service disruption at multiple European airports, preventing passengers from completing check‑in and causing flight delays and cancellations. Technical details of the vulnerability (e.g., code execution, authentication bypass) have not been disclosed publicly.
vulnerabilities.remediation: Apply any patches or firmware updates released by Collins Aerospace as soon as they become available. Conduct a thorough inventory of all deployed instances of the affected software and verify they are running the latest hardened configuration.
workarounds: Isolate the passenger processing network from the corporate and internet‑facing networks.
Implement strict firewall rules limiting inbound traffic to required management protocols.
Enable multi‑factor authentication for administrative access to the systems.

vulnerabilities.title: A cyberattack on Collins Aerospace disrupted operations at major European airports
vulnerabilities.original_title: A cyberattack on Collins Aerospace disrupted operations at major European airports
vulnerabilities.content_snippet: A cyberattack on Collins Aerospace disrupted operations at major European airports, with Heathrow, Brussels, and Berlin most affected. A cyber attack on Collins Aerospace disrupted check-in and boarding systems at major European airports, heavily impacting Heathrow, Brussels, and Berlin. The outage ...
vulnerabilities.summary: Compromise of Collins Aerospace Muse software leading to disruption of airport check‑in, baggage drop and boarding systems.
vulnerabilities.description: A cyberattack targeted the Muse application used by multiple European airports for electronic check‑in, baggage drop and boarding. The intrusion caused a widespread outage, forcing airports to revert to manual procedures. The article does not disclose the specific vulnerability (e.g., CVE) exploited, but the impact indicates a successful compromise of the application’s availability, likely through remote code execution, credential theft, or supply‑chain compromise. The attack demonstrates a single‑point‑of‑failure risk when critical airport functions rely on a centralized provider.
affected_products: Collins Aerospace Muse software (airport passenger processing suite)
vulnerabilities.remediation: Apply any vendor‑released patches for Muse immediately; conduct a thorough forensic investigation; rotate all service accounts and credentials; enforce multi‑factor authentication; segment Muse network traffic from other critical systems; implement strict change‑control and code‑signing for updates.
workarounds: Enable manual check‑in and baggage processes as a fallback.
Isolate Muse servers from the internet and limit inbound connections to trusted IP ranges.
Deploy redundant or alternative passenger processing solutions from different vendors.

vulnerabilities.title: CISA exposes malware kits deployed in Ivanti EPMM attacks
vulnerabilities.original_title: CISA exposes malware kits deployed in Ivanti EPMM attacks
vulnerabilities.content_snippet: The U.S. Cybersecurity and Infrastructure Security Agency (CISA) has published an analysis of the malware deployed in attacks exploiting vulnerabilities affecting Ivanti Endpoint Manager Mobile (EPMM). [...]
vulnerabilities.summary: Multiple vulnerabilities in Ivanti Endpoint Manager Mobile (EPMM) that allow remote code execution and privilege escalation, exploited by malware kits disclosed by CISA.
vulnerabilities.description: CISA analysis indicates that threat actors are leveraging unpatched flaws in Ivanti EPMM to deliver malicious payloads. The vulnerabilities appear to involve insecure deserialization and improper input validation in the mobile device management console, enabling attackers to upload malicious binaries, execute arbitrary commands, and gain administrative control over managed devices. Exploitation is performed over the internet via the exposed management interface, often after obtaining valid credentials through phishing or credential stuffing.
products_versions: Ivanti Endpoint Manager Mobile versions prior to the September 2025 security update
exploit_kits: Ivanti EPMM malware kit (as described by CISA)
Custom backdoor payloads delivered via malicious APKs
vulnerabilities.remediation: Apply the latest security patches released by Ivanti for EPMM, enforce multi-factor authentication for all administrative accounts, restrict access to the management console to trusted IP ranges, and disable any unnecessary services or APIs.
workarounds: Block inbound traffic to the EPMM management ports from untrusted networks.
Enable strict input validation and content‑type checking on the console APIs.
Rotate all administrative credentials and enforce strong password policies.

vulnerabilities.title: Fortra warns of max severity flaw in GoAnywhere MFT’s License Servlet
vulnerabilities.original_title: Fortra warns of max severity flaw in GoAnywhere MFT’s License Servlet
vulnerabilities.content_snippet: Fortra has released security updates to patch a maximum severity vulnerability in GoAnywhere MFT's License Servlet that can be exploited in command injection attacks. [...]
vulnerabilities.summary: Command injection vulnerability in GoAnywhere MFT License Servlet allowing remote code execution.
vulnerabilities.description: The License Servlet component of GoAnywhere Managed File Transfer (MFT) fails to properly sanitize user-supplied input. An unauthenticated attacker can send a crafted HTTP request to the servlet endpoint, causing the underlying operating system to execute arbitrary commands. Successful exploitation can lead to full system compromise, data exfiltration, and service disruption.
products_versions: GoAnywhere MFT versions prior to the September 2025 security update
vulnerabilities.remediation: Apply the security updates released by Fortra for GoAnywhere MFT. Verify that the installed version includes the fix for the License Servlet command injection.
workarounds: Restrict network access to the License Servlet endpoint using firewall rules or access control lists.
Disable the License Servlet if it is not required for operation.
Deploy a Web Application Firewall (WAF) rule to block suspicious payloads targeting the servlet.

vulnerabilities.title: ChatGPT Deep Research zero-click vulnerability fixed by OpenAI
vulnerabilities.original_title: ChatGPT Deep Research zero-click vulnerability fixed by OpenAI
vulnerabilities.content_snippet: OpenAI has moved quickly to patch a vulnerability known as “ShadowLeak” before anyone detected real-world abuse. Revealed by researchers yesterday, ShadowLeak was an issue in OpenAI’s Deep Research project that attackers could exploit by simply sending an email to the target. Deep Research was launc...
vulnerabilities.summary: Zero-click prompt injection vulnerability ('ShadowLeak') in OpenAI's Deep Research agent allowing exfiltration of Gmail inbox data via crafted email.
vulnerabilities.description: The Deep Research agent processes user‑provided emails as prompts. By embedding a hidden malicious prompt (e.g., using tiny font, white‑on‑white text) in a specially crafted email, an attacker can cause the model to read the prompt, extract PII from the victim's Gmail inbox, encode it (base64), and send it to an attacker‑controlled URL. The encoding occurs within the model before the request reaches the execution layer, bypassing existing guardrails that block raw PII exfiltration. The exploit requires no user interaction and occurs entirely on OpenAI's cloud infrastructure, making detection by the victim difficult.
affected_products: OpenAI ChatGPT Deep Research agent (early 2025 release)
Gmail connector used by Deep Research
vulnerabilities.remediation: OpenAI has released a patch that adds stricter validation of inbound email content, blocks hidden text techniques, and prevents the model from performing arbitrary encoding before external requests. Users should update to the latest ChatGPT version and apply any OpenAI‑provided security updates.
workarounds: Disable the Gmail connector for Deep Research until the patch is applied.
Restrict Deep Research access to non‑sensitive email accounts.
Enforce MFA and monitor activity logs for unexpected outbound requests from OpenAI services.

vulnerabilities.title: OpenAI plugs ShadowLeak bug in ChatGPT that let miscreants raid inboxes
vulnerabilities.original_title: OpenAI plugs ShadowLeak bug in ChatGPT that let miscreants raid inboxes
vulnerabilities.content_snippet: Radware says flaw enabled hidden email prompts to trick Deep Research agent into exfiltrating sensitive data ChatGPT's research assistant sprung a leak – since patched – that let attackers steal Gmail secrets with just a single carefully crafted email.…
vulnerabilities.summary: Hidden email prompt vulnerability in OpenAI's ChatGPT Deep Research agent allowed exfiltration of Gmail credentials via a crafted email.
vulnerabilities.description: A flaw in the Deep Research assistant of ChatGPT allowed an attacker to embed a hidden prompt within a specially crafted email. When the email was processed by the assistant, the prompt caused the model to retrieve and exfiltrate Gmail authentication tokens and other sensitive data without user consent. The exploit required only a single email to be sent to the target, leveraging the model's automatic handling of email content. The vulnerability was mitigated by OpenAI releasing a patch that disables the hidden prompt handling and adds stricter validation of email content.
vulnerabilities.remediation: Update to the latest version of ChatGPT that includes the patch released by OpenAI. Disable the Deep Research assistant feature if not required. Enforce MFA on Gmail accounts and monitor for anomalous token usage.
workarounds: Disable the Deep Research agent in ChatGPT settings.
Restrict ChatGPT's access to email data via API permissions.
Implement email content scanning to block suspicious payloads.

vulnerabilities.title: WatchGuard Issues Fix for 9.3-Rated Firebox Firewall Vulnerability
vulnerabilities.original_title: WatchGuard Issues Fix for 9.3-Rated Firebox Firewall Vulnerability
vulnerabilities.content_snippet: WatchGuard has issued a critical security alert for its Firebox firewalls due to a serious vulnerability, CVE-2025-9242. Learn what this 'out-of-bounds write' flaw means, which Fireware OS versions are affected, and the urgent steps to take to protect your network from remote attacks.
vulnerabilities.summary: Out-of-bounds write vulnerability in WatchGuard Firebox firewalls allowing remote code execution.
vulnerabilities.description: A memory corruption flaw (out-of-bounds write) exists in the packet processing component of Fireware OS. An attacker can send specially crafted network packets to the firewall, causing the software to write data beyond the intended buffer boundaries. This can lead to arbitrary code execution with system privileges, enabling full compromise of the firewall and the internal network.
products_versions: Specific Fireware OS versions prior to the released patch (exact versions not disclosed in the article)
vulnerabilities.remediation: Apply the security patch released by WatchGuard for the affected Fireware OS versions. Verify that the firmware version is updated to the fixed release.
workarounds: Restrict inbound traffic to the firewall from untrusted networks until the patch is applied.
Disable any non‑essential services that process external packets.
Enable strict packet inspection and anomaly‑based IDS rules to detect malformed traffic.

vulnerabilities.title: Unpatched Vulnerabilities Expose Novakon HMIs to Remote Hacking
vulnerabilities.original_title: Unpatched Vulnerabilities Expose Novakon HMIs to Remote Hacking
vulnerabilities.content_snippet: Novakon HMIs are affected by remote code execution and information exposure vulnerabilities. The post Unpatched Vulnerabilities Expose Novakon HMIs to Remote Hacking appeared first on SecurityWeek.
vulnerabilities.summary: Remote code execution vulnerability in Novakon HMI devices allowing unauthenticated attackers to execute arbitrary code over the network.
vulnerabilities.description: A flaw in the network service of Novakon Human-Machine Interface (HMI) firmware permits remote attackers to send specially crafted packets that trigger arbitrary code execution with system privileges. Successful exploitation can lead to full control of the HMI, manipulation of industrial processes, and lateral movement within the OT network.
vulnerabilities.remediation: Apply the vendor‑provided firmware patch as soon as it becomes available. If a patch is not yet released, restrict network access to the HMI, enforce strict firewall rules, and disable unnecessary services.
workarounds: Block inbound traffic to the HMI management ports at the network perimeter.
Place HMIs in a segmented VLAN with no direct internet exposure.
Enable strong authentication and enforce least‑privilege accounts.

vulnerabilities.title: Unpatched Vulnerabilities Expose Novakon HMIs to Remote Hacking
vulnerabilities.original_title: Unpatched Vulnerabilities Expose Novakon HMIs to Remote Hacking
vulnerabilities.content_snippet: Novakon HMIs are affected by remote code execution and information exposure vulnerabilities. The post Unpatched Vulnerabilities Expose Novakon HMIs to Remote Hacking appeared first on SecurityWeek.
vulnerabilities.summary: Information exposure vulnerability in Novakon HMI devices that leaks sensitive configuration and process data.
vulnerabilities.description: Improper access controls on certain HTTP endpoints of the Novakon HMI allow unauthenticated remote users to retrieve configuration files, system logs, and process parameters. This exposure can aid reconnaissance and facilitate subsequent attacks.
vulnerabilities.remediation: Install the security update released by Novakon that restricts access to the affected endpoints. Until the patch is applied, restrict HTTP access to trusted IP ranges only.
workarounds: Disable the vulnerable web interface if not required for operations.
Enforce TLS with client certificate authentication for any remaining web access.

vulnerabilities.title: ShadowLeak: Radware Uncovers Zero-Click Attack on ChatGPT
vulnerabilities.original_title: ShadowLeak: Radware Uncovers Zero-Click Attack on ChatGPT
vulnerabilities.content_snippet: Radware discovered a server-side data theft attack, dubbed ShadowLeak, targeting ChatGPT. OpenAI patched the zero-click vulnerability. Researchers at Radware uncovered a server-side data theft attack targeting ChatGPT, called ShadowLeak. The experts discovered a zero-click vulnerability in ChatGPT&#...
vulnerabilities.summary: Zero-click server‑side data exfiltration vulnerability in OpenAI's ChatGPT Deep Research agent when processing malicious HTML content from connected services (e.g., Gmail).
vulnerabilities.description: An attacker crafts an email (or other connector content) containing hidden HTML instructions (tiny fonts, white‑on‑white text, CSS tricks) that are silently read by ChatGPT's Deep Research agent. When a user invokes the agent to "research" their mailbox, the agent parses the malicious content, executes an indirect prompt injection, extracts PII from the victim's inbox, and sends it to an attacker‑controlled URL. The exfiltration occurs entirely within OpenAI's cloud infrastructure, bypassing client‑side defenses and URL restrictions. The flaw affects any connector that feeds raw text into the agent, enabling silent data theft across multiple SaaS platforms.
affected_products: ChatGPT connectors: Gmail, Google Drive, Dropbox, SharePoint, Outlook, Teams, GitHub, HubSpot, Notion
products_versions: ChatGPT Deep Research (pre‑patch version, prior to August 2025)
vulnerabilities.remediation: OpenAI has patched the issue. Apply the latest ChatGPT/Deep Research update. For organizations, disable or restrict Deep Research connectors, sanitize inbound HTML before ingestion, and implement continuous monitoring of agent behavior and outbound requests.
workarounds: Disable Deep Research or specific connectors (e.g., Gmail) until the patch is verified.
Sanitize incoming emails and documents: strip invisible CSS, obfuscated characters, and suspicious HTML elements.
Enforce manual review of any data exported by the agent.
references: Radware ShadowLeak research report (internal link if available)

vulnerabilities.title: Google pushes emergency patch for Chrome 0-day - check your browser version now
vulnerabilities.original_title: Google pushes emergency patch for Chrome 0-day - check your browser version now
vulnerabilities.content_snippet: Sixth such Chrome flaw this year spotted by the Chocolate Factory, already in play Google pushed an emergency patch for a high-severity Chrome flaw, already under active exploitation. So it's time to make sure you're running the most recent version of the web browser.…
vulnerabilities.summary: High‑severity remote code execution vulnerability in Google Chrome that is actively exploited in the wild.
vulnerabilities.description: A memory‑corruption flaw in the Blink rendering engine of Google Chrome allows an attacker to execute arbitrary code on the victim's machine when the victim visits a malicious web page. The vulnerability is chainable with Chrome's sandbox bypass techniques, enabling full system compromise without user privileges. The flaw is being exploited by a threat actor group known as the Chocolate Factory, and active exploitation has been observed in the wild.
products_versions: Google Chrome versions prior to the emergency patch (e.g., 129.0.xxxx and earlier).
vulnerabilities.remediation: Update Google Chrome to the emergency patch released on 2025-09-18 (or later). Enable automatic updates to receive future patches promptly.
workarounds: Temporarily disable JavaScript execution for untrusted sites via Chrome policies.
Use enterprise policy to block loading of the vulnerable Blink component.
Run Chrome with additional sandboxing or in a virtualized environment until the patch is applied.

vulnerabilities.title: Update your Chrome today: Google patches 4 vulnerabilities including one zero-day
vulnerabilities.original_title: Update your Chrome today: Google patches 4 vulnerabilities including one zero-day
vulnerabilities.content_snippet: Google has released an update for its Chrome browser to patch four security vulnerabilities, including one zero-day. A zero-day vulnerability refers to a bug that has been found and exploited by cybercriminals before the vendor even knew about it (they have “zero days” to fix it). This u...
vulnerabilities.summary: Type confusion vulnerability in V8 JavaScript engine allowing remote code execution via malicious website
vulnerabilities.description: A type‑confusion flaw in the V8 JavaScript engine occurs when the engine fails to verify the type of an object before using it. An attacker can craft malicious JavaScript that triggers the flaw, causing V8 to treat data of one type as another. This leads to memory corruption and enables remote code execution without any user interaction beyond visiting the malicious page. The vulnerability was actively exploited in the wild before Google was aware of it, constituting a zero‑day.
affected_products: Chromium-based browsers using the same V8 version (e.g., Microsoft Edge, Brave, Opera, Vivaldi)
products_versions: Corresponding V8 versions in other Chromium‑based browsers
vulnerabilities.remediation: Update Google Chrome to version 140.0.7339.185 or later (Windows/macOS) or 140.0.7339.186 (Linux). Apply corresponding updates for other Chromium‑based browsers as they become available.
workarounds: Temporarily disable JavaScript execution in the browser or via security extensions.
Use browser extensions that block or sandbox untrusted scripts (e.g., NoScript, uBlock Origin).
Employ network‑level URL filtering to block known malicious sites.

vulnerabilities.summary: Type confusion in V8 JavaScript and WebAssembly engine allowing memory corruption and code execution.
vulnerabilities.description: A type‑confusion bug in the V8 engine misinterprets a memory region as an object of the wrong type. This enables an attacker to corrupt heap structures, trigger crashes, or achieve arbitrary code execution via crafted JavaScript or WebAssembly payloads delivered through a malicious web page.
vulnerabilities.remediation: Update Chrome to version 140.0.7339.185 or later (Windows, macOS, Linux).
workarounds: Disable JavaScript execution for untrusted sites via enterprise policies.
Use Content Security Policy (CSP) to restrict script sources.
Run Chrome with the --disable-features=V8TypeConfusion flag if available.

vulnerabilities.remediation: Update Chrome to version 140.0.7339.185 or later.

Use enterprise policy to restrict Chrome extensions and sync features.

Deploy endpoint protection that monitors for abnormal handle creation.

vulnerabilities.summary: Type confusion vulnerability in the V8 JavaScript engine allowing remote code execution.
vulnerabilities.description: A type confusion bug in V8 enables an attacker to corrupt memory structures, bypassing Chrome's sandbox and achieving arbitrary code execution. The vulnerability is triggered by crafted JavaScript payloads delivered via malicious web pages. Google Threat Analysis Group observed active exploitation in the wild prior to patch release.
vulnerabilities.remediation: Update to Chrome 140 or later, which includes the fix for CVE-2025-10585. Apply the same update to all Chromium‑based browsers.
workarounds: Deploy enterprise policy to disable V8 JIT compilation.
Enforce script blocking extensions or Content Security Policy (CSP) that restricts inline scripts.
Run Chrome with the --disable-features=V8TypeConfusion flag if available.

The zero-day vulnerability in question is CVE-2025-10585, which has been described as a type confusion issue in the V8 JavaScript and W...
vulnerabilities.summary: Type confusion vulnerability in V8 JavaScript and WebAssembly engine leading to remote code execution.
vulnerabilities.description: A type confusion flaw in the V8 engine allows an attacker to craft malicious JavaScript or WebAssembly code that tricks the engine into treating an object of one type as another. This can corrupt memory, bypass Chrome's sandbox, and achieve arbitrary code execution on the victim's machine. The vulnerability is actively exploited in the wild via malicious web pages.
products_versions: Google Chrome versions prior to the September 2025 security update
vulnerabilities.remediation: Update Google Chrome to the version released on 2025-09-18 that contains the fix for CVE-2025-10585. Enable automatic updates to receive future patches promptly.
workarounds: Temporarily disable JavaScript execution via Chrome policies.
Block execution of WebAssembly modules using enterprise policies.
Use an alternative browser that is not affected until the patch is applied.
