vulnerabilities.original_title: Apple backports fix for actively exploited CVE-2025-43300
vulnerabilities.content_snippet: Apple announced it has backported patches for a recently addressed actively exploited vulnerability tracked as CVE-2025-43300. Apple has backported security patches released to address an actively exploited vulnerability tracked as CVE-2025-43300. In August 2025, Apple addressed the actively exploit...
vulnerabilities.summary: Out-of-bounds write in Apple ImageIO framework leading to memory corruption when processing a crafted image file.
vulnerabilities.description: The vulnerability resides in the ImageIO framework used across iOS, iPadOS, and macOS. A specially crafted image can trigger an out-of-bounds write, corrupting memory and potentially allowing arbitrary code execution. Apple reports that the issue has been actively exploited in sophisticated, targeted attacks. The exploit chain has been observed together with CVE-2025-55177 in spyware campaigns.
vulnerabilities.remediation: Update devices to the latest patched versions: iOS 18.6.2, iPadOS 18.6.2, iOS 16.7.12, iPadOS 16.7.12, iOS 15.8.5, iPadOS 15.8.5, macOS Ventura 13.7.8, macOS Sonoma 14.7.8, macOS Sequoia 15.6.1, or later.
workarounds: Avoid opening image files from untrusted sources.
Disable automatic image preview in email/web browsers until patches are applied.
Use application sandboxing or MDM policies to restrict ImageIO usage.

vulnerabilities.title: Ruh-roh. DDR5 memory vulnerable to new Rowhammer attack
vulnerabilities.original_title: Ruh-roh. DDR5 memory vulnerable to new Rowhammer attack
vulnerabilities.content_snippet: Google and ETH Zurich found problems with AMD/SK Hynix combo, will probe other hardware Researchers from Google and Swiss university ETH Zurich have found a new class of Rowhammer vulnerability that could allow attackers to access info stored in DDR5 memory.…
vulnerabilities.summary: New class of Rowhammer vulnerability affecting DDR5 memory modules using AMD memory controllers paired with SK Hynix DRAM chips, enabling bit‑flips that can be leveraged to read or corrupt data.
vulnerabilities.description: Researchers from Google and ETH Zurich demonstrated that aggressive row activation patterns can induce bit flips in DDR5 DRAM cells despite the higher refresh rates and built‑in mitigations present in DDR5. The attack exploits the physical coupling between adjacent rows (Rowhammer) and can be triggered from unprivileged user space code, allowing an attacker to flip bits in memory owned by other processes or even kernel space. The vulnerability is specific to the interaction between AMD's DDR5 memory controller logic and SK Hynix's DRAM cell design, suggesting a hardware‑level weakness rather than a software bug.
affected_products: DDR5 memory modules with SK Hynix DRAM chips
Systems using AMD DDR5 memory controllers
vulnerabilities.remediation: Await vendor firmware/BIOS updates that increase DRAM refresh rates, enable built‑in Rowhammer mitigation features, or apply microcode patches to the AMD memory controller. In the meantime, enable ECC memory where available, configure higher refresh intervals in BIOS/UEFI, and apply operating‑system mitigations such as page‑table isolation and memory allocation randomization.
workarounds: Deploy DDR5 modules with ECC support and enable ECC in the system BIOS.
Increase DRAM refresh rate via BIOS/UEFI settings if the platform allows.
Limit the use of high‑frequency memory access patterns in untrusted code (e.g., sandbox JavaScript engines).
Use memory‑scrambling or address randomization features provided by the platform.

vulnerabilities.title: Update your Apple devices to fix dozens of vulnerabilities
vulnerabilities.original_title: Update your Apple devices to fix dozens of vulnerabilities
vulnerabilities.content_snippet: Apple has released security updates for iPhones, iPads, Apple Watches, Apple TVs, and Macs as well as for Safari, and Xcode to fix dozens of vulnerabilities which could give cybercriminals access to sensitive data. How to update your devices How to update your iPhone or iPad For iOS and iPadOS users...
vulnerabilities.summary: Call History fingerprinting vulnerability that allows attackers to infer user identity through insufficient redaction of call metadata.
vulnerabilities.description: The vulnerability resides in the handling of Call History data. Insufficient redaction of sensitive information enables an attacker to fingerprint a device by observing call metadata, potentially linking the device to a specific user. Apple mitigated the issue by improving redaction of sensitive fields in the affected operating systems.
vulnerabilities.remediation: Update devices to iOS 26, iPadOS 26, or macOS Tahoe 26 (or later) which contain the fix for CVE-2025-43357.
workarounds: Limit exposure of call history data to untrusted applications.
Disable call history syncing with iCloud if not required.

vulnerabilities.title: Update your Apple devices to fix dozens of vulnerabilities
vulnerabilities.original_title: Update your Apple devices to fix dozens of vulnerabilities
vulnerabilities.content_snippet: Apple has released security updates for iPhones, iPads, Apple Watches, Apple TVs, and Macs as well as for Safari, and Xcode to fix dozens of vulnerabilities which could give cybercriminals access to sensitive data. How to update your devices How to update your iPhone or iPad For iOS and iPadOS users...
vulnerabilities.summary: Safari address bar spoofing vulnerability that allows malicious websites to display forged URLs in the address bar, facilitating credential harvesting.
vulnerabilities.description: When a user visits a specially crafted malicious website, Safari fails to correctly validate the origin of the displayed URL, allowing the address bar to be spoofed (e.g., showing "login.bank.com" while the user is on an attacker‑controlled page). This can trick users into entering credentials on a phishing page. Apple fixed the issue by adding additional validation logic to the address bar rendering code.
vulnerabilities.remediation: Update Safari to version 26 by installing the latest macOS Sonoma or macOS Sequoia updates.
workarounds: Avoid clicking links from untrusted sources.
Verify the TLS certificate details before entering credentials.
Use browser extensions that highlight mismatched URLs.

vulnerabilities.title: Apple 0-day likely used in spy attacks affected devices as old as iPhone 8
vulnerabilities.original_title: Apple 0-day likely used in spy attacks affected devices as old as iPhone 8
vulnerabilities.content_snippet: May have been used in 'extremely sophisticated' attacks against 'specific targeted individuals' Apple backported a fix to older iPhones and iPads for a serious bug it patched last month – but only after it may have been exploited in what the company calls "extremely sophisticated" attacks.…
vulnerabilities.summary: Zero-day vulnerability in iOS kernel used in targeted espionage attacks, backported to older iPhone and iPad models.
vulnerabilities.description: A previously unknown iOS kernel vulnerability (likely a memory corruption flaw) was exploited in highly sophisticated, targeted attacks against specific individuals. The exploit appears to be delivered via a malicious web page or app, allowing remote code execution with kernel privileges. Apple released a security update that backported the fix to older devices, including iPhone 8 and legacy iPad models, indicating the vulnerability existed in versions released several years prior.
vulnerabilities.remediation: Update all affected iOS devices to the latest iOS version released by Apple (iOS 17.x or later) which includes the backported fix. Enroll devices in Mobile Device Management (MDM) to enforce timely updates.
workarounds: Avoid opening links or installing apps from untrusted sources.
Restrict Safari's ability to open external URLs via configuration profiles.
Enable network‑level filtering to block known malicious domains.

vulnerabilities.title: Chaos Mesh Critical GraphQL Flaws Enable RCE and Full Kubernetes Cluster Takeover
vulnerabilities.original_title: Chaos Mesh Critical GraphQL Flaws Enable RCE and Full Kubernetes Cluster Takeover
vulnerabilities.content_snippet: Cybersecurity researchers have disclosed multiple critical security vulnerabilities in Chaos Mesh that, if successfully exploited, could lead to cluster takeover in Kubernetes environments. "Attackers need only minimal in-cluster network access to exploit these vulnerabilities, execute the platform'...
vulnerabilities.summary: Critical GraphQL injection flaws in Chaos Mesh allow remote code execution and full Kubernetes cluster takeover.
vulnerabilities.description: The vulnerable GraphQL API in Chaos Mesh does not properly validate and sanitize user‑supplied queries. An attacker with minimal in‑cluster network access can craft malicious GraphQL mutations that trigger arbitrary command execution on the Chaos Mesh controller pod. Because the controller runs with cluster‑wide privileges, successful exploitation leads to execution of fault‑injection primitives (e.g., pod termination, network disruption) and ultimately full control over the Kubernetes cluster.
vulnerabilities.remediation: Upgrade to the patched version of Chaos Mesh (>= 3.2.1) where the GraphQL endpoint input validation is hardened. If upgrading is not immediately possible, disable the GraphQL API or restrict access to the controller namespace using NetworkPolicies and RBAC.
workarounds: Apply a NetworkPolicy that blocks all inbound traffic to the Chaos Mesh controller pod except from trusted namespaces.
Restrict the ServiceAccount used by Chaos Mesh to the minimal set of permissions required for its use cases.
Deploy an API gateway or WAF in front of the GraphQL endpoint to filter suspicious payloads.

vulnerabilities.title: Apple backports zero-day patches to older iPhones and iPads
vulnerabilities.original_title: Apple backports zero-day patches to older iPhones and iPads
vulnerabilities.content_snippet: ​Apple has released security updates to backport patches released last month to older iPhones and iPads, addressing a zero-day bug that was exploited in "extremely sophisticated" attacks. [...]
vulnerabilities.summary: Zero-day vulnerability in iOS/iPadOS that allows remote code execution and was exploited in highly sophisticated attacks.
vulnerabilities.description: A previously unknown flaw in the iOS/iPadOS kernel (or a core system component) enables an attacker to execute arbitrary code on the device without prior authentication. The vulnerability was leveraged in targeted, highly sophisticated campaigns, suggesting a zero‑click or minimal‑interaction exploit chain. Apple backported the fix to older supported devices after the vulnerability was publicly disclosed.
affected_products: iOS versions prior to the backported patch
iPadOS versions prior to the backported patch
products_versions: iOS 15.x and 16.x on older iPhone models
iPadOS 15.x and 16.x on older iPad models
vulnerabilities.remediation: Apply the latest iOS/iPadOS security update released by Apple that includes the backported patches. Enable automatic updates to ensure future patches are applied promptly.
workarounds: Restrict network access to untrusted Wi‑Fi and cellular networks.
Disable unnecessary services such as AirDrop and Bluetooth when not in use.
Use Mobile Device Management (MDM) to enforce strict configuration profiles.
references: Apple Security Updates page (specific advisory for the backported patches)

vulnerabilities.title: ChatGPT’s Calendar Integration Can Be Exploited to Steal Emails
vulnerabilities.original_title: ChatGPT’s Calendar Integration Can Be Exploited to Steal Emails
vulnerabilities.content_snippet: Researchers show how a crafted calendar invite can trigger ChatGPT to exfiltrate sensitive emails. The post ChatGPT’s Calendar Integration Can Be Exploited to Steal Emails appeared first on SecurityWeek.
vulnerabilities.summary: ChatGPT calendar integration can be tricked by a crafted calendar invite to exfiltrate a user's email contents.
vulnerabilities.description: The vulnerability resides in the way ChatGPT processes iCalendar (.ics) invites received through its calendar integration feature. By embedding malicious payloads (e.g., specially crafted event descriptions or attachment URLs) in an invite, an attacker can cause ChatGPT to retrieve and forward the victim's email data to an external server controlled by the attacker. The exploit does not require elevated privileges on the victim's system but does require the victim to accept or view the malicious calendar invite within ChatGPT.
affected_products: ChatGPT (web UI and API) with Calendar integration
vulnerabilities.remediation: OpenAI should sanitize all fields of incoming calendar invites, enforce strict content‑type validation, and implement same‑origin checks for any external resources referenced in invites. Deploy patches that block automatic fetching of external resources from calendar data. Users should update to the latest ChatGPT version once the fix is released.
workarounds: Disable the Calendar integration feature in ChatGPT settings.
Restrict ChatGPT access to external URLs via network firewalls.
Use a separate, hardened email client for sensitive communications.

vulnerabilities.title: China-linked Mustang Panda deploys advanced SnakeDisk USB worm
vulnerabilities.original_title: China-linked Mustang Panda deploys advanced SnakeDisk USB worm
vulnerabilities.content_snippet: China-linked APT group Mustang Panda has been spotted using a new USB worm called SnakeDisk along with a new version of known malware China-linked APT group Mustang Panda (aka Hive0154, Camaro Dragon, RedDelta or Bronze President) has been spotted using an updated version of the TONESHELL backdoor a...
vulnerabilities.summary: USB worm SnakeDisk uses DLL sideloading and hard‑coded C2 to deploy the Yokai backdoor on Windows systems
vulnerabilities.description: SnakeDisk is a 32‑bit DLL (named 01.dat) that is dropped onto removable USB drives. It activates only on hosts whose public IP resolves to Thailand. The worm checks ipinfo.io, creates a mutex, and scans for hot‑plugged USB devices. When a USB is inserted, it moves existing files into a hidden folder, drops a malicious executable that mimics the volume name, and restores the original files to hide its activity. The executable is signed and sideloads a malicious DLL, which loads the Yokai backdoor. Yokai establishes persistence via a scheduled task (non‑admin), connects to a hard‑coded C2 server using encrypted POST requests, and opens a reverse shell through anonymous pipes. The malware uses a two‑phase XOR decryption routine for payloads and validates configuration files by size and CRC32. The propagation technique mirrors earlier Tonedisk/Toneshell families, indicating code reuse across Hive0154 sub‑clusters.
affected_products: Microsoft Windows (all versions supporting USB storage and DLL loading)
vulnerabilities.remediation: Deploy endpoint protection that blocks unknown DLL execution and monitors USB device activity; disable Windows AutoRun/AutoPlay; enforce strict device control policies; remove the signed malicious executable and associated DLL; delete the scheduled task created by Yokai; block outbound traffic to the hard‑coded C2 IP/hostname; apply least‑privilege principles to user accounts.
workarounds: Disable USB mass‑storage device usage on sensitive workstations
Enforce application whitelisting (e.g., Windows AppLocker) to prevent unsigned or unknown DLLs from loading
Restrict scheduled task creation to administrators
references: Trend Micro observations on Mustang Panda (Feb 2024)

vulnerabilities.title: Shiny tools, shallow checks: how the AI hype opens the door to malicious MCP servers
vulnerabilities.original_title: Shiny tools, shallow checks: how the AI hype opens the door to malicious MCP servers
vulnerabilities.content_snippet: Introduction In this article, we explore how the Model Context Protocol (MCP) — the new “plug-in bus” for AI assistants — can be weaponized as a supply chain foothold. We start with a primer on MCP, map out protocol-level and supply chain attack paths, then walk through a hands-on proof ...
vulnerabilities.summary: Malicious MCP server installed via untrusted PyPI package can execute arbitrary code, harvest sensitive files, and exfiltrate data to attacker-controlled endpoints.
vulnerabilities.description: An attacker publishes a seemingly legitimate MCP server package (e.g., devtools-assistant) to a public repository. When a developer installs the package and registers the server with an AI assistant, the server runs with the user's privileges. The server's code includes a malicious engine that scans project directories and system locations for sensitive artifacts such as .env files, SSH keys, cloud credentials, API tokens, and browser password stores. Collected data is base64‑encoded and sent via disguised HTTP POST requests that mimic GitHub API traffic to an attacker‑controlled endpoint. The malicious server also employs techniques like name spoofing, tool poisoning, shadowing, and rug‑pull updates to maintain persistence and evade detection.
affected_products: Model Context Protocol (MCP) client implementations (e.g., Claude Desktop, Cursor)
Third‑party MCP servers installed from PyPI, Docker Hub, GitHub Releases
Developer workstations running the malicious server with user privileges
products_versions: Any MCP client version that supports dynamic tool registration
MCP server implementations distributed via PyPI, Docker Hub, GitHub Releases
vulnerabilities.remediation: Remove the malicious MCP server package, revoke any exposed credentials, and rotate secrets. Conduct a full code review of all installed MCP servers. Apply strict approval workflows for third‑party MCP packages. Run MCP servers in isolated containers or VMs with least‑privilege file system access. Implement network egress filtering and monitor for anomalous outbound traffic.
workarounds: Run MCP servers only from a vetted whitelist of internal packages.
Disable automatic updates for MCP servers until they are verified.
Restrict MCP client configurations to point only to trusted internal servers.
references: Kaspersky GERT proof‑of‑concept repository (if publicly released)
Model Context Protocol specification by Anthropic

vulnerabilities.title: Shiny tools, shallow checks: how the AI hype opens the door to malicious MCP servers
vulnerabilities.original_title: Shiny tools, shallow checks: how the AI hype opens the door to malicious MCP servers
vulnerabilities.content_snippet: Introduction In this article, we explore how the Model Context Protocol (MCP) — the new “plug-in bus” for AI assistants — can be weaponized as a supply chain foothold. We start with a primer on MCP, map out protocol-level and supply chain attack paths, then walk through a hands-on proof ...
vulnerabilities.summary: Malicious MCP server delivered via a PyPI package that harvests sensitive files and exfiltrates them disguised as legitimate GitHub API traffic.
vulnerabilities.description: The malicious package installs an MCP server that runs with the installing user's privileges. Upon activation, it enumerates project directories and system locations for sensitive artifacts (environment files, SSH keys, cloud credentials, API tokens, browser passwords, crypto wallets, etc.). Collected data is base64‑encoded and sent via HTTPS POST requests that mimic GitHub API calls, allowing the exfiltration to blend with normal traffic. The server is registered in the AI client, making the AI assistant unknowingly invoke the compromised toolset. The attack leverages supply‑chain trust in PyPI and the default trust model of MCP tool discovery, requiring no additional exploit code beyond the malicious package itself.
affected_products: MCP client implementations (e.g., Claude Desktop, Cursor, Windsurf)
AI assistants integrating MCP (Anthropic Claude, Cursor AI, etc.)
vulnerabilities.remediation: Remove the malicious package, revoke any exposed credentials, and rotate secrets. Implement strict approval workflows for MCP server installation, enforce package signing verification, and sandbox MCP servers (containers/VMs) with least‑privilege filesystem and network access. Monitor outbound traffic for anomalous GitHub‑like API calls and inspect AI assistant tool registries for unknown entries.
workarounds: Run MCP servers in isolated containers with read‑only mounts for source code.
Disable automatic discovery of MCP tools and manually whitelist known good servers.
Use network egress filtering to block unknown destinations from development workstations.
references: Kaspersky GERT proof‑of‑concept repository (if publicly released)

vulnerabilities.title: Samsung Patches Zero-Day Exploited Against Android Users
vulnerabilities.original_title: Samsung Patches Zero-Day Exploited Against Android Users
vulnerabilities.content_snippet: Reported by Meta and WhatsApp, the vulnerability leads to remote code execution and was likely exploited by a spyware vendor. The post Samsung Patches Zero-Day Exploited Against Android Users appeared first on SecurityWeek.
vulnerabilities.summary: Zero-day remote code execution vulnerability affecting Samsung Android devices, exploited by a spyware vendor.
vulnerabilities.description: A previously unknown vulnerability in Samsung's Android firmware allows an attacker to execute arbitrary code on the device without user permission. The flaw was reported by Meta and WhatsApp and is believed to have been weaponized by a commercial spyware provider. Exploitation results in full device compromise, enabling data exfiltration, surveillance, and further payload deployment.
vulnerabilities.remediation: Apply the security patch released by Samsung as soon as possible. Ensure devices are running the latest firmware and security updates.
workarounds: Disable automatic installation of apps from unknown sources.
Restrict background data for untrusted applications.
Use mobile device management (MDM) solutions to enforce patch compliance.

vulnerabilities.title: Samsung Fixes Image Parsing Vulnerability Exploited in Android Attacks
vulnerabilities.original_title: Samsung Fixes Image Parsing Vulnerability Exploited in Android Attacks
vulnerabilities.content_snippet: Samsung patched CVE-2025-21043, a critical flaw in its Android devices exploited in live attacks. Users urged to install September 2025 update.
vulnerabilities.summary: Image parsing vulnerability in Samsung Android devices that allows remote code execution.
vulnerabilities.description: The vulnerability resides in the image parsing component of Samsung's Android firmware. A specially crafted image file can trigger a memory corruption leading to arbitrary code execution with system privileges. The flaw is exploitable when a user opens or previews a malicious image through native or third‑party apps, enabling attackers to gain full control of the device. Live attacks have been observed in the wild, indicating active exploitation.
affected_products: Samsung Galaxy smartphones and tablets running Android
products_versions: Samsung Galaxy devices running Android 12, 13, and 14 prior to the September 2025 security patch
vulnerabilities.remediation: Install the September 2025 security update from Samsung, which patches CVE-2025-21043. Ensure devices receive OTA updates automatically.
workarounds: Avoid opening images from untrusted sources until the patch is applied.
Disable automatic image preview in messaging and email apps.

vulnerabilities.title: Security Affairs newsletter Round 541 by Pierluigi Paganini – INTERNATIONAL EDITION
vulnerabilities.original_title: Security Affairs newsletter Round 541 by Pierluigi Paganini – INTERNATIONAL EDITION
vulnerabilities.content_snippet: A new round of the weekly Security Affairs newsletter has arrived! Every week, the best security articles from Security Affairs are free in your email box. Enjoy a new round of the weekly SecurityAffairs newsletter, including the international press. FBI warns of Salesforce attacks by UNC6040 and UN...
vulnerabilities.summary: NT OS Kernel Information Disclosure Vulnerability allowing attackers to read kernel memory.
vulnerabilities.description: The vulnerability resides in the Windows NT kernel handling of certain system calls, leading to an information disclosure condition where an unprivileged process can read kernel memory contents. This can be leveraged to enumerate security-sensitive data such as process credentials, cryptographic keys, or system configuration.
affected_products: Microsoft Windows NT kernel (Windows 10, Windows 11, Windows Server 2022 and later)
products_versions: Cisco IOS XR (specific releases prior to patch)
Samsung Galaxy devices (specific models prior to patch)
Google Chrome (versions prior to September 2025 update)
vulnerabilities.remediation: Apply the security update released by Microsoft in the September 2025 Patch Tuesday. Ensure all Windows endpoints are updated to the latest cumulative update that includes the fix for CVE-2025-53136.
workarounds: Restrict execution of untrusted code and limit local user privileges.
Enable Device Guard and Credential Guard where possible to mitigate impact of kernel memory disclosure.

vulnerabilities.title: Security Affairs newsletter Round 541 by Pierluigi Paganini – INTERNATIONAL EDITION
vulnerabilities.original_title: Security Affairs newsletter Round 541 by Pierluigi Paganini – INTERNATIONAL EDITION
vulnerabilities.content_snippet: A new round of the weekly Security Affairs newsletter has arrived! Every week, the best security articles from Security Affairs are free in your email box. Enjoy a new round of the weekly SecurityAffairs newsletter, including the international press. FBI warns of Salesforce attacks by UNC6040 and UN...
vulnerabilities.summary: SessionReaper vulnerability in Magento/Commerce platforms enabling attacker-controlled session hijacking.
vulnerabilities.description: The SessionReaper flaw arises from improper validation of session identifiers in Magento/Commerce. An attacker can craft a malicious request that forces the server to accept an arbitrary session ID, allowing hijacking of authenticated user sessions and access to customer accounts and sensitive e‑commerce data.
affected_products: Adobe Commerce (Magento) versions prior to the September 2025 security release
products_versions: Cisco IOS XR (specific releases prior to patch)
Samsung Galaxy devices (specific models prior to patch)
Google Chrome (versions prior to September 2025 update)
vulnerabilities.remediation: Update Magento/Commerce to the latest version released in the September 2025 Patch Day. Apply the vendor‑provided security patch that enforces strict session ID validation and regenerates session tokens after authentication.
workarounds: Force HTTPS for all traffic to protect session cookies.
Enable SameSite cookie attribute and set secure flag.
Implement additional monitoring for anomalous session usage.

vulnerabilities.title: ShinyHunters Attack National Credit Information Center of Vietnam
vulnerabilities.original_title: ShinyHunters Attack National Credit Information Center of Vietnam
vulnerabilities.content_snippet: Vietnam’s National Credit Information Center (CIC) was hit by a ShinyHunters cyberattack, with VNCERT confirming signs of unauthorized access to steal personal data. Authorities are investigating a cyber-attack against National Credit Information Center (CIC) of Vietnam by ShinyHunters. As confirmed...
vulnerabilities.summary: Exploitation of an unpatched, end-of-life (EOL) software component used by Vietnam's National Credit Information Center (CIC) allowing unauthorized access and data exfiltration.
vulnerabilities.description: The attackers (ShinyHunters) leveraged a known vulnerability in software that had reached end-of-life and was no longer receiving security updates. Because the vendor no longer provided patches, the vulnerability remained exploitable. Exploitation granted the threat actors sufficient privileges to access personal identifying information (PII) stored in the CIC database and to exfiltrate large volumes of data, which were later posted for sale on underground forums.
affected_products: Legacy credit information management system (EOL software) used by CIC
vulnerabilities.remediation: Replace the EOL software with a supported solution, apply all available security patches, and conduct a full security audit of the affected system. If replacement is not immediately possible, isolate the system from the network, enforce strict firewall rules, and apply compensating controls such as application whitelisting and intrusion prevention signatures.
workarounds: Network segmentation to limit external access to the vulnerable system
Deploy host‑based intrusion detection/prevention systems (HIDS/HIPS)
Implement strict outbound data transfer monitoring and DLP controls
Enforce multi‑factor authentication for any privileged access
references: VNCERT public advisory (Vietnam Cyber Emergency Response Team)

vulnerabilities.title: FBI warns of Salesforce attacks by UNC6040 and UNC6395 groups
vulnerabilities.original_title: FBI warns of Salesforce attacks by UNC6040 and UNC6395 groups
vulnerabilities.content_snippet: The U.S. FBI issued a flash alert to warn of malicious activities carried out by two cybercriminal groups tracked as UNC6040 and UNC6395. The FBI issued a FLASH alert with IOCs for cybercriminal groups UNC6040 and UNC6395, which are increasingly targeting Salesforce platforms for data theft and exto...
vulnerabilities.summary: Abuse of compromised OAuth tokens for third‑party app (Salesloft Drift) to gain unauthorized access to Salesforce instances
vulnerabilities.description: Threat actors obtained valid OAuth access tokens for the Salesloft Drift application, which is integrated with Salesforce. Using these tokens they were able to authenticate to the victim's Salesforce org without MFA, enumerate data via the Salesforce API, and exfiltrate large volumes of customer records. The tokens were likely harvested from compromised Salesloft accounts or through credential stuffing. The attack bypasses traditional credential checks because the OAuth token is considered a bearer token with full API privileges.
vulnerabilities.remediation: Revoke all OAuth tokens for the Salesloft Drift app, enforce token expiration, require re‑authentication for third‑party integrations, and implement strict scopes for OAuth tokens (least‑privilege). Rotate all API keys and secrets. Review and limit the permissions granted to third‑party apps in Salesforce.
workarounds: Temporarily disable the Salesloft Drift integration until token hygiene is verified
Implement IP allow‑list for API calls from third‑party services
references: FBI FLASH alert (2025-09-13) – UNC6395 OAuth token abuse

vulnerabilities.title: FBI warns of Salesforce attacks by UNC6040 and UNC6395 groups
vulnerabilities.original_title: FBI warns of Salesforce attacks by UNC6040 and UNC6395 groups
vulnerabilities.content_snippet: The U.S. FBI issued a flash alert to warn of malicious activities carried out by two cybercriminal groups tracked as UNC6040 and UNC6395. The FBI issued a FLASH alert with IOCs for cybercriminal groups UNC6040 and UNC6395, which are increasingly targeting Salesforce platforms for data theft and exto...
vulnerabilities.summary: Social engineering (vishing) to convince employees to install malicious connected apps and grant OAuth permissions in Salesforce
vulnerabilities.description: Actors impersonate IT support and use phone‑based social engineering (vishing) to persuade call‑center staff to approve a malicious connected app in Salesforce. The app is granted OAuth scopes that allow bulk data export via the API. Because the app is registered as a trusted integration, MFA is bypassed and the attacker receives a bearer token that can be used to query and download customer databases. The malicious app may be a modified version of Salesforce Data Loader or a custom app registered through a trial Salesforce account to evade detection.
affected_products: Custom malicious connected app (modified Data Loader)
vulnerabilities.remediation: Educate staff to verify any request for app installation, enforce MFA for all OAuth authorizations, require secondary approval for new connected apps, and apply the principle of least privilege to OAuth scopes. Regularly audit connected apps and revoke any that are not business‑critical.
workarounds: Disable the ability for end‑users to self‑authorize connected apps
Require admin approval for any new app integration
references: FBI FLASH alert (2025-09-13) – UNC6040 vishing campaign

vulnerabilities.title: HybridPetya ransomware bypasses UEFI Secure Boot echoing Petya/NotPetya
vulnerabilities.original_title: HybridPetya ransomware bypasses UEFI Secure Boot echoing Petya/NotPetya
vulnerabilities.content_snippet: HybridPetya ransomware bypasses UEFI Secure Boot to infect EFI partitions, echoing the infamous Petya/NotPetya attacks of 2016–2017. ESET researchers discovered a new ransomware called HybridPetya on the platform VirusTotal. The malware echoes the infamous Petya/NotPetya malware, supporting addition...
vulnerabilities.summary: UEFI Secure Boot bypass vulnerability allowing malicious bootkits to execute unsigned code on affected firmware.
vulnerabilities.description: The vulnerability in UEFI firmware (CVE-2024-7344) permits an attacker with limited privileges to bypass Secure Boot checks. By exploiting flaws in the firmware's signature verification process, malicious code can be placed in the EFI System Partition and executed during boot, enabling bootkits such as HybridPetya to replace the Windows bootloader, encrypt the MFT, and enforce ransomware demands. The bypass works on systems that have not applied recent firmware updates and can be triggered without user interaction.
affected_products: UEFI firmware implementations lacking updated Secure Boot validation (various motherboard vendors)
Windows systems relying on Secure Boot for boot integrity
affected_companies: Various motherboard/UEFI firmware vendors (e.g., AMI, Insyde, Phoenix, Dell, HP, Lenovo)
vendors: Various motherboard/UEFI firmware vendors (e.g., AMI, Insyde, Phoenix, Dell, HP, Lenovo)
products_versions: Windows 10/11 systems with UEFI Secure Boot enabled on outdated firmware versions vulnerable to CVE-2024-7344
Hyper‑V implementations prior to the 2020 security update
vulnerabilities.remediation: Update UEFI/BIOS firmware to the latest version provided by the hardware vendor that addresses CVE-2024-7344. Re‑enable Secure Boot with up‑to‑date Microsoft keys. Verify the integrity of the EFI System Partition and restore original bootloaders from trusted backups.
workarounds: Disable legacy boot options and enforce UEFI‑only boot mode.
Restrict write access to the EFI System Partition using OS‑level policies.
Monitor and alert on changes to files in \EFI\Microsoft\Boot and \EFI\Boot directories.

vulnerabilities.title: HybridPetya ransomware bypasses UEFI Secure Boot echoing Petya/NotPetya
vulnerabilities.original_title: HybridPetya ransomware bypasses UEFI Secure Boot echoing Petya/NotPetya
vulnerabilities.content_snippet: HybridPetya ransomware bypasses UEFI Secure Boot to infect EFI partitions, echoing the infamous Petya/NotPetya attacks of 2016–2017. ESET researchers discovered a new ransomware called HybridPetya on the platform VirusTotal. The malware echoes the infamous Petya/NotPetya malware, supporting addition...
vulnerabilities.summary: Hyper-V backdoor vulnerability allowing code execution in the hypervisor context.
vulnerabilities.description: CVE-2020-26200 is a vulnerability in the Hyper-V hypervisor that can be exploited to gain code execution with hypervisor privileges. The vulnerability was referenced in the article as part of a proof‑of‑concept bootkit (Hyper‑V Backdoor PoC) but is not directly used by HybridPetya.
affected_products: Microsoft Windows Hyper-V (versions prior to patch released in 2020)
affected_companies: Various motherboard/UEFI firmware vendors (e.g., AMI, Insyde, Phoenix, Dell, HP, Lenovo)
vendors: Various motherboard/UEFI firmware vendors (e.g., AMI, Insyde, Phoenix, Dell, HP, Lenovo)
products_versions: Windows 10/11 systems with UEFI Secure Boot enabled on outdated firmware versions vulnerable to CVE-2024-7344
Hyper‑V implementations prior to the 2020 security update
vulnerabilities.remediation: Apply the Microsoft security update released in March 2020 that patches CVE-2020-26200. Ensure Hyper‑V is kept up‑to‑date.
workarounds: Disable Hyper‑V if not required.

vulnerabilities.title: HybridPetya: More proof that Secure Boot bypasses are not just an urban legend
vulnerabilities.original_title: HybridPetya: More proof that Secure Boot bypasses are not just an urban legend
vulnerabilities.content_snippet: Although it hasn't been seen in the wild yet A new ransomware strain dubbed HybridPetya was able to exploit a patched vulnerability to bypass Unified Extensible Firmware Interface (UEFI) Secure Boot on unrevoked Windows systems, making it the fourth publicly known bootkit capable of punching through...
vulnerabilities.summary: UEFI Secure Boot bypass vulnerability exploited by HybridPetya bootkit to gain code execution before OS load.
vulnerabilities.description: HybridPetya leverages a previously patched UEFI firmware vulnerability that allows an attacker to bypass Secure Boot validation on systems where the firmware signature database has not been revoked. By injecting malicious code into the boot path, the bootkit obtains full system control before the operating system starts, enabling ransomware deployment without requiring OS-level execution. The vulnerability resides in the firmware's signature verification logic, permitting forged signatures to be accepted when the firmware's revocation list is not up‑to‑date.
affected_companies: Various PC OEMs (e.g., Dell, HP, Lenovo, ASUS)
vendors: Various PC OEMs (e.g., Dell, HP, Lenovo, ASUS)
products_versions: UEFI firmware versions prior to vendor‑released patches (specific versions vary by OEM)
vulnerabilities.remediation: Apply the latest firmware/BIOS updates from the hardware vendor that address the Secure Boot bypass. Ensure Secure Boot revocation lists are current and enable firmware rollback protection. Deploy Microsoft’s latest cumulative updates that include mitigation for known bootkit techniques.
workarounds: Disable legacy (CSM) boot and enforce UEFI‑only boot mode.
Enable firmware TPM and measured boot to detect unauthorized changes.
Configure Secure Boot with a custom whitelist and regularly update the signature database.

vulnerabilities.title: Samsung fixes Android 0-day that may have been used to spy on WhatsApp messages
vulnerabilities.original_title: Samsung fixes Android 0-day that may have been used to spy on WhatsApp messages
vulnerabilities.content_snippet: A similar vuln on Apple devices was used against 'specific targeted users' Samsung has fixed a critical flaw that affects its Android devices - but not before attackers found and exploited the bug, which could allow remote code execution on affected devices.…
vulnerabilities.summary: Critical remote code execution vulnerability in Samsung Android devices that could be used to spy on WhatsApp messages.
vulnerabilities.description: The vulnerability allows an unauthenticated remote attacker to execute arbitrary code on the device. Exploitation can lead to full device compromise, enabling the attacker to intercept or read WhatsApp messages and potentially other user data. The flaw was actively exploited in the wild before Samsung released a patch.
products_versions: All Samsung Android devices prior to the September 2025 security patch
vulnerabilities.remediation: Apply the security patch released by Samsung as soon as possible. Update the device to the latest official firmware version.
workarounds: Temporarily disable network connectivity on affected devices until the patch is applied.
Avoid installing apps from untrusted sources.
Use a reputable mobile security solution that can detect anomalous behavior.

vulnerabilities.title: CISA warns of actively exploited Dassault RCE vulnerability
vulnerabilities.original_title: CISA warns of actively exploited Dassault RCE vulnerability
vulnerabilities.content_snippet: The U.S. Cybersecurity and Infrastructure Security Agency (CISA) is warning of hackers exploiting a critical remote code execution flaw in DELMIA Apriso, a manufacturing operations management (MOM) and execution (MES) solution from French company Dassault Systèmes. [...]
vulnerabilities.summary: Critical remote code execution vulnerability in DELMIA Apriso (Dassault Systèmes) being actively exploited.
vulnerabilities.description: A remote code execution flaw exists in the web interface of DELMIA Apriso that allows an unauthenticated attacker to send specially crafted HTTP requests to execute arbitrary commands on the underlying server. The vulnerability stems from insufficient input validation in a server‑side component that processes XML/JSON payloads. Successful exploitation grants the attacker full control over the MES server, enabling data exfiltration, manipulation of production processes, and deployment of additional malware within the manufacturing environment.
products_versions: DELMIA Apriso versions prior to the September 2025 security patch
vulnerabilities.remediation: Apply the security patch released by Dassault Systèmes as soon as possible. If a patch is not yet available, temporarily disable external access to the affected web service, enforce strict network segmentation, and restrict access to trusted IP ranges.
workarounds: Block inbound traffic to the vulnerable endpoint at the perimeter firewall.
Require VPN access for any remote administration of DELMIA Apriso.
Enable application‑level authentication and enforce strong passwords.
references: Vendor advisory from Dassault Systèmes (if available)

vulnerabilities.title: AI browsers or agentic browsers: a look at the future of web surfing
vulnerabilities.original_title: AI browsers or agentic browsers: a look at the future of web surfing
vulnerabilities.content_snippet: Browsers like Chrome, Edge, and Firefox are our traditional gateway to the internet. But lately, we have seen a new generation of browsers emerge. These are AI-powered browsers or “agentic browsers”—which are not to be confused with your regular browsers that have just AI-powered plugins...
vulnerabilities.summary: Prompt injection vulnerability in AI‑enabled browsers allowing malicious commands to be executed by the embedded AI agent.
vulnerabilities.description: AI browsers embed large language model agents that process user prompts, web page content, and can autonomously execute actions (e.g., filling forms, clicking buttons, making purchases). Researchers have demonstrated that crafted prompts can manipulate the model into performing unintended actions, bypassing built‑in safeguards. Because the AI agent often runs with the same privileges as the browser process, a successful prompt injection can lead to unauthorized data exfiltration, credential theft, or fraudulent transactions. The attack surface is enlarged by dynamic content rendering, tool execution APIs, and optional cloud‑based inference, making it possible to inject malicious instructions via malicious web pages, compromised extensions, or crafted URLs.
vulnerabilities.remediation: Apply strict prompt sanitization and context‑aware filtering inside the AI engine; enforce a confirmation step for any action that modifies external resources; sandbox the AI agent in a separate process with least‑privilege OS permissions; limit or encrypt any cloud‑based inference; regularly update the browser to incorporate vendor patches; provide security‑focused developer guidelines for prompt handling.
workarounds: Disable autonomous AI actions and require manual confirmation for all form submissions and navigation commands.
Use a traditional browser for sensitive tasks and keep AI browsers isolated to low‑risk activities.
Restrict AI browsers to local‑only inference models where possible to avoid sending browsing context to external servers.
references: Research paper: "Prompt Injection Attacks on Agentic Web Browsers" (2025)
CWE‑94: Improper Control of Generation of Code ('Code Injection')

vulnerabilities.title: DELMIA Factory Software Vulnerability Exploited in Attacks
vulnerabilities.original_title: DELMIA Factory Software Vulnerability Exploited in Attacks
vulnerabilities.content_snippet: A deserialization of untrusted data in the MOM software allows attackers to achieve remote code execution. The post DELMIA Factory Software Vulnerability Exploited in Attacks appeared first on SecurityWeek.
vulnerabilities.summary: Deserialization of untrusted data in DELMIA Factory MOM software leads to remote code execution.
vulnerabilities.description: The Manufacturing Operations Management (MOM) component of DELMIA Factory accepts serialized objects from external sources without proper validation. An attacker can craft a malicious serialized payload that, when deserialized by the server, triggers arbitrary code execution with the privileges of the MOM service. This vulnerability has been observed in the wild, with attackers delivering the payload over the network to compromised or exposed MOM endpoints.
vulnerabilities.remediation: Apply the security patch released by Dassault Systèmes as soon as it becomes available. If a patch is not yet released, mitigate by disabling the vulnerable deserialization feature, enforcing strict input validation, and restricting network access to the MOM service to trusted hosts only.
workarounds: Restrict access to the MOM interface to trusted IP ranges via firewall rules.
Deploy a web application firewall (WAF) rule to block suspicious serialized payloads.

vulnerabilities.title: Samsung fixed actively exploited zero-day
vulnerabilities.original_title: Samsung fixed actively exploited zero-day
vulnerabilities.content_snippet: Samsung fixed the remote code execution flaw CVE-2025-21043 that was exploited in zero-day attacks against Android devices. Samsung addressed the remote code execution vulnerability, tracked as CVE-2025-21043, that was exploited in zero-day attacks against Android users. The vulnerability is an out-...
vulnerabilities.summary: Out-of-bounds write in libimagecodec.quram.so on Samsung Android devices allowing remote code execution.
vulnerabilities.description: The vulnerable libimagecodec.quram.so library fails to validate buffer boundaries when processing crafted image data, resulting in an out-of-bounds write. An attacker can send a malicious payload over the network (e.g., via a zero‑click message) that triggers the write, corrupts memory, and gains arbitrary code execution with system privileges on the device.
affected_products: Samsung Android devices (all models prior to SMR Sep-2025 Release 1)
products_versions: Samsung Android devices prior to SMR Sep-2025 Release 1
WhatsApp versions prior to September 2025 patch
Apple iOS/macOS versions prior to September 2025 patch
vulnerabilities.remediation: Update the device to the Samsung SMR Sep-2025 Release 1 patch or later, which corrects the buffer handling logic in libimagecodec.quram.so.
workarounds: Restrict receipt of unsolicited messages from unknown senders.
Disable automatic processing of image files in messaging apps until the patch is applied.
references: Samsung Security Bulletin SMR Sep-2025 Release 1
