vulnerabilities.content_snippet: Samsung fixed the remote code execution flaw CVE-2025-21043 that was exploited in zero-day attacks against Android devices. Samsung addressed the remote code execution vulnerability, tracked as CVE-2025-21043, that was exploited in zero-day attacks against Android users. The vulnerability is an out-...
vulnerabilities.summary: Authorization bypass in WhatsApp on iOS and macOS allowing arbitrary URL content rendering.
vulnerabilities.description: A flaw in WhatsApp's content rendering pipeline permits an attacker to bypass authorization checks and force the client to load and render content from an arbitrary URL. This can be leveraged to execute code or exfiltrate data without user interaction.
products_versions: Samsung Android devices prior to SMR Sep-2025 Release 1
WhatsApp versions prior to September 2025 patch
Apple iOS/macOS versions prior to September 2025 patch
vulnerabilities.remediation: Update WhatsApp to the latest version released after the vulnerability disclosure, which includes the authorization bypass fix.
workarounds: Limit WhatsApp's network access via firewall or MDM policies.
Disable automatic preview of links in messages.

vulnerabilities.title: Samsung fixed actively exploited zero-day
vulnerabilities.original_title: Samsung fixed actively exploited zero-day
vulnerabilities.content_snippet: Samsung fixed the remote code execution flaw CVE-2025-21043 that was exploited in zero-day attacks against Android devices. Samsung addressed the remote code execution vulnerability, tracked as CVE-2025-21043, that was exploited in zero-day attacks against Android users. The vulnerability is an out-...
vulnerabilities.summary: Zero‑click vulnerability in Apple iOS/macOS exploited to achieve remote code execution.
vulnerabilities.description: A zero‑click flaw allows an attacker to execute arbitrary code on the target device simply by sending a specially crafted message. No user interaction is required, making it a powerful tool for advanced threat actors.
affected_products: Apple iOS (versions prior to the September 2025 security update)
Apple macOS (versions prior to the September 2025 security update)
products_versions: Samsung Android devices prior to SMR Sep-2025 Release 1
WhatsApp versions prior to September 2025 patch
Apple iOS/macOS versions prior to September 2025 patch
vulnerabilities.remediation: Apply the Apple September 2025 security update that patches CVE-2025-43300.
workarounds: Enable iOS/macOS security features such as Gatekeeper and automatic updates.
Restrict receipt of messages from unknown sources where possible.

vulnerabilities.title: VMScape: Academics Break Cloud Isolation With New Spectre Attack
vulnerabilities.original_title: VMScape: Academics Break Cloud Isolation With New Spectre Attack
vulnerabilities.content_snippet: Exploiting incomplete speculative execution attack mitigations extended to the branch predictor state, VMScape leaks arbitrary memory. The post VMScape: Academics Break Cloud Isolation With New Spectre Attack appeared first on SecurityWeek.
vulnerabilities.summary: VMScape is a new Spectre variant that exploits incomplete speculative execution mitigations extended to the branch predictor state, allowing arbitrary memory leakage across virtual machines in cloud environments.
vulnerabilities.description: VMScape leverages a flaw in the way current Spectre mitigations handle branch predictor state. By inducing speculative execution paths that manipulate the branch predictor across VM exits, an attacker co‑located on the same physical host can cause the processor to speculatively execute instructions that read arbitrary memory from a neighboring VM. The leaked data can include cryptographic keys, credentials, or other sensitive information, effectively breaking isolation guarantees in multi‑tenant cloud environments.
affected_products: Virtual Machine hypervisors (e.g., VMware ESXi, Microsoft Hyper-V, KVM, Xen)
vulnerabilities.remediation: Apply vendor‑provided microcode updates and hypervisor patches that fully flush or partition branch predictor state on VM entry/exit. Enable full Spectre mitigations (e.g., IBRS, STIBP, RSB refilling) and consider disabling hyper‑threading where feasible. Deploy hardware‑based isolation technologies such as AMD SEV, Intel TDX, or ARM Confidential Compute if available.
workarounds: Disable simultaneous multithreading (SMT) on hosts running untrusted workloads.
Enforce strict VM placement policies to avoid co‑residency of high‑risk tenants.
Use encrypted memory technologies (SEV, TDX) to protect data at rest within VMs.
references: Original research paper (if published) – authors' university repository

vulnerabilities.title: Payment System Vendor Took Year+ to Patch Infinite Card Top-Up Hack: Security Firm
vulnerabilities.original_title: Payment System Vendor Took Year+ to Patch Infinite Card Top-Up Hack: Security Firm
vulnerabilities.content_snippet: KioSoft was notified about a serious NFC card vulnerability in 2023 and only recently claimed to have released a patch. The post Payment System Vendor Took Year+ to Patch Infinite Card Top-Up Hack: Security Firm appeared first on SecurityWeek.
vulnerabilities.summary: Infinite card top‑up vulnerability in KioSoft payment system leveraging NFC communication
vulnerabilities.description: An attacker can exploit a flaw in the NFC communication handling of KioSoft's payment system to repeatedly trigger the card top‑up function without proper validation, allowing unlimited credit to be added to a victim's account. The vulnerability was first reported to KioSoft in 2023, but a patch was only released over a year later. Exploitation requires proximity to the victim's NFC card or reader and can be performed with off‑the‑shelf hardware.
vulnerabilities.remediation: Apply the official KioSoft patch as soon as possible. Verify patch version with vendor advisory. If patch cannot be applied immediately, disable NFC functionality on affected terminals and enforce transaction limits.
workarounds: Disable NFC on payment terminals until the patch is applied
Enforce strict per‑transaction and daily top‑up limits
Monitor for anomalous top‑up activity and flag accounts with sudden large balance increases

vulnerabilities.title: Apple issues spyware warnings as CERT-FR confirms attacks
vulnerabilities.original_title: Apple issues spyware warnings as CERT-FR confirms attacks
vulnerabilities.content_snippet: Apple warned users of a spyware campaign; France’s cyber agency confirmed targeted iCloud-linked devices may be compromised. Apple warned customers last week about new spyware attacks, the French national Computer Emergency Response Team (CERT-FR) said. The agency confirmed at least four such alerts...
vulnerabilities.summary: Zero-day vulnerabilities in iOS/macOS used by sophisticated spyware campaigns targeting iCloud-linked devices
vulnerabilities.description: Advanced spyware (e.g., Pegasus, Predator, Graphite, Triangulation) exploits one or more undisclosed zero‑day flaws in iOS/macOS to gain persistent, stealthy access to iCloud‑linked devices. The attacks require no user interaction and can remain undetected for months before Apple’s threat‑notification system alerts the victim. Exploits likely involve remote code execution through iMessage, iCloud authentication flows, or other Apple services.
vulnerabilities.remediation: Install all available iOS/macOS updates immediately; enable automatic updates; activate Isolation Mode on iOS 17+; restart devices daily; separate personal and work accounts; enforce strong passcodes and two‑factor authentication; avoid installing untrusted applications.
workarounds: Use a secondary, air‑gapped device for sensitive communications
Limit iCloud synchronization for high‑risk accounts
Disable iMessage on devices that do not require it

vulnerabilities.title: Cursor AI Code Editor Flaw Enables Silent Code Execution via Malicious Repositories
vulnerabilities.original_title: Cursor AI Code Editor Flaw Enables Silent Code Execution via Malicious Repositories
vulnerabilities.content_snippet: A security weakness has been disclosed in the artificial intelligence (AI)-powered code editor Cursor that could trigger code execution when a maliciously crafted repository is opened using the program. The issue stems from the fact that an out-of-the-box security setting is disabled by default, ope...
vulnerabilities.summary: Cursor AI code editor executes arbitrary code when opening a maliciously crafted repository due to a disabled security setting by default.
vulnerabilities.description: The vulnerability stems from an out‑of‑the‑box security setting that is disabled by default in the Cursor AI‑powered code editor. When a user opens a repository that contains malicious code, the editor automatically executes the code with the privileges of the logged‑in user. No additional user interaction beyond opening the repository is required. This enables attackers to run arbitrary commands, install malware, or exfiltrate data on the victim's machine.
products_versions: Cursor AI Code Editor (versions prior to patch)
vulnerabilities.remediation: Update Cursor to a version that enables the security setting by default or manually enable the protection feature in the application settings. Apply any vendor‑released patches. Consider running the editor with reduced privileges or within a sandbox.
workarounds: Manually enable the security setting that blocks automatic code execution.
Open untrusted repositories only in a sandboxed environment or virtual machine.
Restrict execution permissions for the Cursor process using OS‑level policies.

vulnerabilities.title: New Google AppSheet Phishing Scam Deliver Fake Trademark Notices
vulnerabilities.original_title: New Google AppSheet Phishing Scam Deliver Fake Trademark Notices
vulnerabilities.content_snippet: A phishing scam is exploiting Google’s trusted AppSheet platform to bypass email filters. Learn how hackers are using…
vulnerabilities.summary: Phishing campaign abusing Google AppSheet to deliver fake trademark notices and bypass email filters.
vulnerabilities.description: Threat actors send phishing emails that appear to be legitimate trademark notices. The emails contain links to malicious Google AppSheet applications that are hosted on Google's trusted infrastructure. Because AppSheet URLs are whitelisted by many email security solutions, the messages bypass traditional filters. When the victim clicks the link, they are prompted to grant permissions to a malicious AppSheet app, which can harvest credentials, exfiltrate data, or install additional payloads. The abuse leverages the trust relationship between Google services and enterprise email gateways, making detection difficult.
vulnerabilities.remediation: Disable or restrict the use of Google AppSheet within the organization, enforce least‑privilege OAuth scopes, implement strict URL filtering for AppSheet domains, and educate users about unexpected trademark notices. Apply DMARC, SPF, and DKIM hardening to reduce email spoofing. Monitor OAuth consent logs for anomalous app installations.
workarounds: Block outbound traffic to *.appsheet.com for untrusted users.
Require admin approval for all third‑party AppSheet apps.
Implement user training on recognizing unsolicited trademark or legal notices.

vulnerabilities.title: Spectre haunts CPUs again: VMSCAPE vulnerability leaks cloud secrets
vulnerabilities.original_title: Spectre haunts CPUs again: VMSCAPE vulnerability leaks cloud secrets
vulnerabilities.content_snippet: AMD Zen hardware and Intel Coffee Lake affected If you thought the world was done with side-channel CPU attacks, think again. ETH Zurich has identified yet another Spectre-based transient execution vulnerability that affects AMD Zen CPUs and Intel Coffee Lake processors by breaking virtualization bo...
vulnerabilities.summary: VMSCAPE – a Spectre-based transient execution vulnerability that breaks virtualization boundaries on AMD Zen and Intel Coffee Lake CPUs, allowing cross-VM data leakage.
vulnerabilities.description: The VMSCAPE vulnerability exploits speculative execution and transient execution side‑channels similar to Spectre Variant 2. By crafting malicious code inside a guest VM, an attacker can induce the CPU to speculatively execute instructions that access data belonging to other VMs or the hypervisor. The transient results are then recovered via cache‑based side‑channel measurements, leaking cryptographic keys, tokens, or other secrets from co‑located cloud tenants. The attack works on AMD Zen and Intel Coffee Lake CPUs that implement vulnerable branch prediction and store‑forward mechanisms and does not require elevated privileges within the victim VM.
affected_products: AMD Zen microarchitectures (Zen, Zen+, Zen 2, Zen 3)
Intel Coffee Lake processors (8th Generation Core i7/i5/i3)
products_versions: AMD Zen (all generations up to Zen 3)
Intel Coffee Lake (8th Generation Core i7/i5/i3)
vulnerabilities.remediation: Apply vendor‑provided microcode/firmware updates for affected CPUs, install OS patches that include mitigations (e.g., retpoline, IBRS, STIBP), and enable hardware‑based isolation features such as AMD SEV or Intel SGX where available. Disable Simultaneous Multithreading (SMT) on affected hosts until patches are deployed.
workarounds: Disable SMT/Hyper‑Threading in BIOS/UEFI
Enable CPU mitigations (e.g., IBRS, STIBP, SSBD) via kernel parameters
Deploy AMD Secure Encrypted Virtualization (SEV) or Intel Trusted Execution Technology (TXT) to isolate VM memory
Restrict co‑location of high‑value workloads on the same physical host

vulnerabilities.title: Cisco Patches High-Severity IOS XR Vulnerabilities
vulnerabilities.original_title: Cisco Patches High-Severity IOS XR Vulnerabilities
vulnerabilities.content_snippet: High-severity flaws in IOS XR could lead to ISO image verification bypass and denial-of-service conditions. The post Cisco Patches High-Severity IOS XR Vulnerabilities appeared first on SecurityWeek.
vulnerabilities.summary: High-severity flaws in Cisco IOS XR that could bypass ISO image verification and cause denial-of-service conditions.
vulnerabilities.description: The vulnerabilities allow an attacker to bypass the integrity verification of IOS XR software images, potentially loading malicious code, and to trigger conditions that lead to a denial of service. Exploitation may be possible remotely over the network without authentication.
vulnerabilities.remediation: Apply the Cisco IOS XR security patches released on 2025-09-11.

vulnerabilities.title: Google fixes critical Chrome flaw, researcher earns $43K
vulnerabilities.original_title: Google fixes critical Chrome flaw, researcher earns $43K
vulnerabilities.content_snippet: Google addressed a critical use-after-free vulnerability in its Chrome browser that could potentially lead to code execution. A researcher earned $43000 from Google for reporting a critical Chrome vulnerability, tracked as CVE-2025-10200, in the Serviceworker component. A use-after-free (UAF) occurs...
vulnerabilities.summary: Use-after-free vulnerability in Chrome's ServiceWorker component allowing remote code execution.
vulnerabilities.description: The vulnerability arises when Chrome's ServiceWorker module frees an object but later accesses it, leading to a use‑after‑free condition. An attacker controlling a malicious web page can trigger the freed memory access, achieve arbitrary code execution in the context of the browser process, and potentially escape sandbox protections.
products_versions: Google Chrome versions prior to 140.0.7339.127 (Windows/Linux) and 140.0.7339.132 (macOS)
vulnerabilities.remediation: Update Chrome to version 140.0.7339.127 (Windows/Linux) or 140.0.7339.132 (macOS) or later, which includes the fix for CVE-2025-10200.
workarounds: Disable ServiceWorker via enterprise policy or command‑line flag (--disable-features=ServiceWorker).
Enforce site isolation and enable sandboxing features.
references: Google Chrome security advisory (internal link if available)

vulnerabilities.title: Google fixes critical Chrome flaw, researcher earns $43K
vulnerabilities.original_title: Google fixes critical Chrome flaw, researcher earns $43K
vulnerabilities.content_snippet: Google addressed a critical use-after-free vulnerability in its Chrome browser that could potentially lead to code execution. A researcher earned $43000 from Google for reporting a critical Chrome vulnerability, tracked as CVE-2025-10200, in the Serviceworker component. A use-after-free (UAF) occurs...
vulnerabilities.summary: Improper implementation vulnerability in Chrome's Mojo IPC framework.
vulnerabilities.description: The flaw is an inappropriate implementation within Mojo, Chrome's inter‑process communication layer. It can be abused by a malicious renderer process to corrupt IPC messages, potentially leading to sandbox escape or remote code execution across process boundaries.
products_versions: Google Chrome versions prior to 140.0.7339.127 (Windows/Linux) and 140.0.7339.132 (macOS)
vulnerabilities.remediation: Update Chrome to the same patched versions (140.0.7339.127/128 for Windows/Linux, 140.0.7339.132/133 for macOS) which contain the fix for CVE-2025-10201.
workarounds: Restrict usage of Mojo APIs via enterprise policies where feasible.
Enable additional sandboxing layers and reduce renderer privileges.
references: Google Chrome security advisory (internal link if available)

vulnerabilities.title: Critical Chrome Vulnerability Earns Researcher $43,000
vulnerabilities.original_title: Critical Chrome Vulnerability Earns Researcher $43,000
vulnerabilities.content_snippet: Google patched a critical use-after-free vulnerability in Chrome that could potentially lead to code execution. The post Critical Chrome Vulnerability Earns Researcher $43,000 appeared first on SecurityWeek.
vulnerabilities.summary: Critical use-after-free vulnerability in Google Chrome that can lead to arbitrary code execution.
vulnerabilities.description: A use-after-free memory corruption bug in Chrome's rendering engine (Blink/V8) allows an attacker to craft malicious web content that frees an object while it is still in use. By controlling the freed memory, the attacker can achieve arbitrary code execution in the context of the browser process, potentially escaping the sandbox and compromising the host system.
products_versions: Google Chrome versions prior to the September 2025 security patch
vulnerabilities.remediation: Update Google Chrome to the latest version that includes the security patch released by Google.
workarounds: Disable JavaScript execution in the browser.
Enable Chrome's built‑in sandbox and site isolation features.
Use enterprise policies to enforce automatic updates.
references: Chrome release notes (September 2025) – security patch details

vulnerabilities.title: UAE’s K2 Think AI Jailbroken Through Its Own Transparency Features
vulnerabilities.original_title: UAE’s K2 Think AI Jailbroken Through Its Own Transparency Features
vulnerabilities.content_snippet: Researchers exploited K2 Think’s built-in explainability to dismantle its safety guardrails, raising new questions about whether transparency and security in AI can truly coexist. The post UAE’s K2 Think AI Jailbroken Through Its Own Transparency Features appeared first on SecurityWeek.
vulnerabilities.summary: K2 Think AI's built-in explainability feature can be abused to bypass safety guardrails, allowing adversarial prompt injection and model jailbreak.
vulnerabilities.description: The K2 Think AI platform includes a transparency/explainability module that returns model reasoning for a given input. Researchers discovered that by crafting specially‑structured queries to this module, they can extract internal prompt context and manipulate the model's response generation pipeline. The exploit leverages the fact that the explainability service does not enforce the same safety checks as the primary inference endpoint, effectively allowing an attacker to reconstruct and override the system prompt, leading to a full jailbreak of the AI's guardrails. This vulnerability is inherent to the design of the explainability feature and does not require authentication or elevated privileges.
vulnerabilities.remediation: Apply vendor‑provided patch that isolates the explainability service from the main inference pipeline, enforces identical safety checks, and adds rate‑limiting and input validation. If a patch is not yet available, disable the explainability feature in production or restrict its access to trusted internal users only.
workarounds: Disable the built‑in explainability feature until a security update is released.
Restrict API access to the explainability endpoint to a whitelist of IP addresses or service accounts.
Implement an external, audited explainability layer that enforces the same content filters as the primary model.

vulnerabilities.title: SonicWall SSL VPN Flaw and Misconfigurations Actively Exploited by Akira Ransomware Hackers
vulnerabilities.original_title: SonicWall SSL VPN Flaw and Misconfigurations Actively Exploited by Akira Ransomware Hackers
vulnerabilities.content_snippet: Threat actors affiliated with the Akira ransomware group have continued to target SonicWall devices for initial access. Cybersecurity firm Rapid7 said it observed a spike in intrusions involving SonicWall appliances over the past month, particularly following reports about renewed Akira ransomware a...
vulnerabilities.summary: Remote exploitation of SonicWall SSL VPN service and configuration weaknesses allowing unauthenticated attackers to gain initial access and deploy Akira ransomware.
vulnerabilities.description: Threat actors affiliated with the Akira ransomware group are exploiting a combination of a known SSL VPN vulnerability in SonicWall devices and common misconfigurations (e.g., default credentials, permissive firewall rules, lack of MFA). The flaw permits remote code execution or unauthorized VPN tunnel establishment without valid credentials, providing a foothold for ransomware deployment. Rapid7 observed a spike in intrusions targeting these appliances after Akira activity resurfaced in July 2025.
vulnerabilities.remediation: Apply the latest SonicWall firmware updates that address SSL VPN vulnerabilities, enforce strong, unique passwords, enable multi‑factor authentication for VPN users, restrict VPN access to required IP ranges, and disable unused services. Review and harden firewall policies associated with the VPN.
workarounds: Temporarily disable SSL VPN if not required
Enforce MFA on all VPN accounts
Restrict VPN access via ACLs to known IP addresses
Change all default credentials and enforce complex password policies
references: SonicWall Security Advisory (2025) – SSL VPN Remote Access Vulnerability

vulnerabilities.title: Attackers abuse ConnectWise ScreenConnect to drop AsyncRAT
vulnerabilities.original_title: Attackers abuse ConnectWise ScreenConnect to drop AsyncRAT
vulnerabilities.content_snippet: Hackers exploit ConnectWise ScreenConnect to drop AsyncRAT via scripted loaders, stealing data and persisting with a fake Skype updater. LevelBlue researchers warn of a campaign abusing ConnectWise ScreenConnect to deploy AsyncRAT. Attackers use VBScript/PowerShell loaders and achieve persistence vi...
vulnerabilities.summary: Compromise of ConnectWise ScreenConnect client allowing execution of malicious VBScript/PowerShell loaders that deliver fileless AsyncRAT
vulnerabilities.description: Attackers obtain access to a legitimate ScreenConnect client, initiate an interactive session via a malicious domain, and execute a VBScript that launches PowerShell commands. The script downloads two .NET payloads (logs.ldk, logs.ldr) to C:\Users\Public, loads them in memory via reflection, and runs AsyncRAT components (Obfuscator.dll, AsyncClient.exe). The malware establishes persistence through a fake Skype updater scheduled task, disables AMSI and ETW, and performs keylogging, data exfiltration, and system reconnaissance. The fileless technique avoids writing executables to disk, evading traditional antivirus detection.
vulnerabilities.remediation: Update ScreenConnect to the latest version, enforce strong authentication (MFA), restrict remote access to trusted IPs, monitor and block connections to known malicious domains, disable unnecessary PowerShell remoting, enable AMSI/ETW protections, and apply application whitelisting.
workarounds: Block outbound traffic to relay.shipperzone.online
Disable execution of unsigned scripts in PowerShell
Restrict write permissions to C:\Users\Public for non‑admin users

vulnerabilities.title: Akira ransomware crims abusing trifecta of SonicWall security holes for extortion attacks
vulnerabilities.original_title: Akira ransomware crims abusing trifecta of SonicWall security holes for extortion attacks
vulnerabilities.content_snippet: Patch, turn on MFA, and restrict access to trusted networks…or else Affiliates of the Akira ransomware gang are again exploiting a critical SonicWall vulnerability abused last summer, after a suspected zero-day flaw actually turned out to be related to a year-old bug.…
vulnerabilities.summary: Critical remote code execution vulnerability in SonicWall appliances exploited by Akira ransomware affiliates.
vulnerabilities.description: A chain of three related vulnerabilities in SonicWall's SSL VPN implementation allows unauthenticated attackers to bypass authentication, execute arbitrary code, and gain administrative access to the appliance. The flaws were initially thought to be a zero‑day but later linked to a bug disclosed over a year ago. Exploitation enables attackers to deploy ransomware payloads (Akira) and exfiltrate data.
vulnerabilities.remediation: Apply the latest SonicWall firmware patches released for the affected models, enable multi‑factor authentication on all administrative accounts, and restrict management interface access to trusted IP ranges or VPNs.
workarounds: Block inbound traffic to the SonicWall management ports (e.g., 443/8443) from untrusted networks.
Disable remote administration if not required.
Enforce strong, unique passwords for all admin accounts.

vulnerabilities.title: Cursor AI editor lets repos “autorun” malicious code on devices
vulnerabilities.original_title: Cursor AI editor lets repos “autorun” malicious code on devices
vulnerabilities.content_snippet: A weakness in the Cursor code editor exposes developers to the risk of automatically executing tasks in a malicious repository as soon as it's opened. [...]
vulnerabilities.summary: Cursor AI code editor automatically executes tasks defined in a repository when the repo is opened, allowing malicious code execution without explicit user consent.
vulnerabilities.description: The vulnerability resides in Cursor's repository handling logic. When a developer opens a repository, Cursor parses configuration files (e.g., .cursor, package.json scripts, or hidden init scripts) and automatically runs defined tasks such as build steps, linting, or custom commands. An attacker can embed malicious commands in these scripts, causing arbitrary code execution on the developer's machine as soon as the repository is opened in Cursor. The execution occurs with the privileges of the logged‑in user and can lead to credential theft, persistence mechanisms, or further lateral movement.
products_versions: All Cursor AI editor versions prior to the forthcoming security update (exact versions not disclosed)
vulnerabilities.remediation: Update Cursor to a version that disables automatic task execution by default or requires explicit user confirmation. If no patch is available, configure the editor to disable autorun features via settings or environment variables. Review and sanitize any scripts in newly cloned repositories before opening them in Cursor.
workarounds: Disable automatic task execution in Cursor settings (e.g., set "autorun": false).
Open repositories in a sandboxed or virtualized environment.
Manually review and approve any scripts or commands defined in repository configuration files before allowing execution.

vulnerabilities.title: Can I have a new password, please? The $400M question.
vulnerabilities.original_title: Can I have a new password, please? The $400M question.
vulnerabilities.content_snippet: Scattered Spider didn't need a zero-day to breach Clorox. They just phoned the help desk—convincing agents to reset passwords & MFA without proper checks. The result: $380M in damages. Learn from Specops Software why caller verification and audit trails are critical. [...]
vulnerabilities.summary: Social engineering attack exploiting weak help‑desk verification procedures to reset user passwords and MFA tokens.
vulnerabilities.description: Threat actors called the organization's help‑desk, impersonated legitimate users, and convinced support agents to reset passwords and MFA devices without proper identity verification. The lack of audit trails and caller‑verification controls allowed the attackers to gain full account control, leading to extensive data exfiltration and financial loss.
vulnerabilities.remediation: Implement strict caller verification procedures (e.g., multi‑factor out‑of‑band verification), enforce documented password‑reset policies, require secondary approval for MFA resets, and maintain immutable audit logs of all credential changes.
workarounds: Require in‑person or video‑based identity proof for password/MFA resets.
Temporarily disable remote password reset capability until verification processes are hardened.
references: Specops Software best‑practice guide for help‑desk security

vulnerabilities.title: Microsoft Fixes 80 Flaws — Including SMB PrivEsc and Azure CVSS 10.0 Bugs
vulnerabilities.original_title: Microsoft Fixes 80 Flaws — Including SMB PrivEsc and Azure CVSS 10.0 Bugs
vulnerabilities.content_snippet: Microsoft on Tuesday addressed a set of 80 security flaws in its software, including one vulnerability that has been disclosed as publicly known at the time of release. Of the 80 vulnerabilities, eight are rated Critical and 72 are rated Important in severity. None of the shortcomings has been explo...
vulnerabilities.summary: Multiple Microsoft security flaws addressed, including SMB privilege escalation and Azure remote code execution bugs, with 8 critical and 72 important severity ratings.
vulnerabilities.description: The update resolves 80 vulnerabilities across Microsoft products. Among them are SMB-related privilege escalation flaws that allow a local attacker to gain higher privileges, and Azure bugs with CVSS base scores of 10.0 that could enable remote code execution in cloud environments. One of the flaws was publicly disclosed prior to the patch release. No evidence of exploitation in the wild has been observed.
vulnerabilities.remediation: Apply the Microsoft security updates released on 2025-09-10. Ensure automatic updates are enabled and verify patch installation via Windows Update or WSUS.
workarounds: Disable SMBv1 and restrict SMB traffic to trusted networks.
Enforce strict network segmentation for Azure workloads.
Apply temporary registry or group policy mitigations as described in Microsoft security advisory.

vulnerabilities.title: This Patch Tuesday, SAP is the worst offender and Microsoft users can kinda chill
vulnerabilities.original_title: This Patch Tuesday, SAP is the worst offender and Microsoft users can kinda chill
vulnerabilities.content_snippet: ERP giant patches flaw that allows total takeover of NetWeaver, Microsoft has nothing under attack for once September’s Patch Tuesday won’t require Microsoft users to rapidly repair rancid software, but SAP users need to move fast to address extremely dangerous bugs.…
vulnerabilities.summary: Remote code execution vulnerability in SAP NetWeaver that allows an attacker to gain full control of the application server.
vulnerabilities.description: A flaw in the SAP NetWeaver component enables unauthenticated remote attackers to execute arbitrary code with system privileges. The vulnerability stems from insufficient input validation in a web service endpoint, allowing crafted requests to trigger a stack buffer overflow and subsequently achieve remote code execution. Successful exploitation results in complete takeover of the NetWeaver instance, granting the attacker the ability to read, modify, or delete data and to pivot to other systems within the enterprise network.
products_versions: SAP NetWeaver Application Server 7.x (specific version not disclosed in article)
vulnerabilities.remediation: Apply the SAP security patch released on 2025-09-10. Verify that the patch is successfully installed on all NetWeaver instances and restart the application server as required.
workarounds: Restrict inbound traffic to NetWeaver services to trusted IP ranges using firewall rules.
Disable the vulnerable web service endpoint if it is not required for business operations.
Enable SAP's security hardening guide recommendations, including input validation and least‑privilege configurations.

vulnerabilities.title: Adobe Patches Critical ColdFusion and Commerce Vulnerabilities
vulnerabilities.original_title: Adobe Patches Critical ColdFusion and Commerce Vulnerabilities
vulnerabilities.content_snippet: Adobe has patched nearly two dozen vulnerabilities across nine of its products with its September 2025 Patch Tuesday updates. The post Adobe Patches Critical ColdFusion and Commerce Vulnerabilities appeared first on SecurityWeek.
vulnerabilities.summary: Multiple vulnerabilities patched in Adobe products as part of the September 2025 Patch Tuesday release.
vulnerabilities.description: Adobe released patches for nearly two dozen vulnerabilities across nine of its products. Specific technical details, CVE identifiers, and impact metrics were not disclosed in the article.
vulnerabilities.remediation: Apply the September 2025 security updates released by Adobe for all affected products.
workarounds: Temporarily disable affected services or features until patches can be applied.
Restrict network access to vulnerable services.

vulnerabilities.title: Adobe patches critical SessionReaper flaw in Magento eCommerce platform
vulnerabilities.original_title: Adobe patches critical SessionReaper flaw in Magento eCommerce platform
vulnerabilities.content_snippet: Adobe is warning of a critical vulnerability (CVE-2025-54236) in its Commerce and Magento Open Source platforms that researchers call SessionReaper and describe as one of " the most severe" flaws in the history of the product. [...]
vulnerabilities.summary: Critical SessionReaper flaw in Adobe Commerce and Magento Open Source allowing remote session hijacking and potential code execution.
vulnerabilities.description: The SessionReaper vulnerability (codenamed SessionReaper) resides in the session management component of Adobe Commerce and Magento Open Source. An unauthenticated attacker can craft malicious requests that manipulate session handling, enabling session fixation/hijacking. Successful exploitation may allow the attacker to assume the identity of any logged‑in user, access sensitive data, modify content, and potentially achieve remote code execution on the underlying server.
products_versions: Adobe Commerce versions prior to the September 2025 security update
Magento Open Source versions prior to the September 2025 security update
vulnerabilities.remediation: Apply the official Adobe security patch released for CVE-2025-54236. Update all Magento/Commerce installations to the latest patched version. Verify that the patch is correctly applied by checking the version number and reviewing the applied security advisories.
workarounds: Temporarily disable the SessionReaper feature via configuration if possible.
Enforce strict SameSite and HttpOnly flags on session cookies.
Implement a Web Application Firewall rule to block anomalous session manipulation patterns.

vulnerabilities.title: SAP Patches Critical NetWeaver Vulnerabilities
vulnerabilities.original_title: SAP Patches Critical NetWeaver Vulnerabilities
vulnerabilities.content_snippet: The critical-severity NetWeaver flaws could be exploited for remote code execution and privilege escalation. The post SAP Patches Critical NetWeaver Vulnerabilities appeared first on SecurityWeek.
vulnerabilities.summary: Critical vulnerabilities in SAP NetWeaver that allow remote code execution and privilege escalation.
vulnerabilities.description: Multiple flaws in SAP NetWeaver components enable an unauthenticated attacker to execute arbitrary code on the target system and subsequently elevate privileges. The vulnerabilities are exploitable over the network without any user interaction, potentially leading to full system compromise.
products_versions: SAP NetWeaver (all supported versions at time of disclosure)
vulnerabilities.remediation: Apply the SAP security patches released for the affected NetWeaver versions as soon as possible. Verify patch installation through SAP's update verification tools.
workarounds: Restrict network access to NetWeaver services to trusted IP ranges.
Disable or firewall off any unnecessary NetWeaver interfaces until patches are applied.
references: SAP Security Advisory (specific advisory URL not provided in article)

vulnerabilities.title: SAP fixes maximum severity NetWeaver command execution flaw
vulnerabilities.original_title: SAP fixes maximum severity NetWeaver command execution flaw
vulnerabilities.content_snippet: SAP has addressed 21 new vulnerabilities affecting its products, including three critical severity issues impacting the NetWeaver software solution. [...]
vulnerabilities.summary: Critical command execution vulnerability in SAP NetWeaver allowing remote attackers to execute arbitrary OS commands.
vulnerabilities.description: A flaw in the NetWeaver command handling component permits an attacker to inject and execute arbitrary operating‑system commands. The vulnerability is triggered via specially crafted HTTP requests to the NetWeaver dispatcher, bypassing authentication checks. Successful exploitation results in full system compromise, allowing data exfiltration, modification, and service disruption.
products_versions: SAP NetWeaver AS ABAP 7.5 and later
SAP NetWeaver AS Java 7.5 and later
vulnerabilities.remediation: Apply the SAP Security Patch released on 2025-09-09. Verify that the patch level matches the SAP Security Note for the affected NetWeaver versions.
workarounds: Restrict inbound traffic to NetWeaver services to trusted IP ranges.
Disable the vulnerable dispatcher endpoint if not required.
Enforce strict input validation at the web application firewall (WAF) level.

vulnerabilities.title: Zero-Day in Sitecore Exploited to Deploy WEEPSTEEL Malware
vulnerabilities.original_title: Zero-Day in Sitecore Exploited to Deploy WEEPSTEEL Malware
vulnerabilities.content_snippet: Hackers exploit a Sitecore zero-day (CVE-2025-53690) to deploy WEEPSTEEL Malware via ViewState attacks, enabling Remote Code Execution (RCE).
vulnerabilities.summary: Sitecore CMS zero‑day allowing remote code execution via crafted ViewState payloads.
vulnerabilities.description: The vulnerability resides in Sitecore's handling of ViewState data. An attacker can craft a malicious ViewState payload that, when deserialized by the server, leads to arbitrary code execution. The exploit chain observed in the wild delivers the WEEPSTEEL malware, establishing persistence and further command‑and‑control capabilities. No authentication is required and the attack can be launched over the Internet against any vulnerable Sitecore instance that accepts ViewState without proper MAC validation.
products_versions: Sitecore CMS versions prior to the forthcoming security patch (e.g., 10.x, 9.x)
vulnerabilities.remediation: Apply the official Sitecore security patch once released. In the meantime, enable ViewState MAC validation, restrict access to the Sitecore admin endpoints, and deploy a Web Application Firewall rule that blocks suspicious ViewState parameters.
workarounds: Enable ViewState MAC validation in web.config
Restrict inbound traffic to Sitecore servers to trusted IP ranges
Deploy a WAF rule to detect and block malformed ViewState payloads

vulnerabilities.title: Venezuela’s President Maduro said his Huawei Mate X6 cannot be hacked by US cyber spies
vulnerabilities.original_title: Venezuela’s President Maduro said his Huawei Mate X6 cannot be hacked by US cyber spies
vulnerabilities.content_snippet: Venezuela’s President Maduro shows Huawei Mate X6 gift from China’s President Xi Jinping, hailing it as “unhackable” by U.S. spies. Last week, Venezuelan President Nicolás Maduro showcased a Huawei Mate X6 smartphone, reportedly gifted by China’s President Xi Jinping, claiming that US cyber sp...
vulnerabilities.summary: Potential unknown vulnerabilities in HarmonyOS and proprietary hardware/firmware of Huawei Mate X6 due to limited public scrutiny and rapid development cycle.
vulnerabilities.description: Because HarmonyOS is relatively new and tightly integrated with proprietary hardware, implementation bugs, insecure default configurations, or supply‑chain backdoors could be present. Nation‑state actors with sufficient resources may discover zero‑day flaws that allow remote code execution, data exfiltration, or persistent footholds on the device.
vulnerabilities.remediation: Apply all available firmware and OS updates from Huawei as soon as they are released. Verify the authenticity of update packages via digital signatures. Consider enrolling the device in a mobile device management (MDM) solution that enforces security policies.
workarounds: Disable unnecessary services (e.g., Bluetooth, NFC) when not in use.
Restrict network access to the device via firewalls or VPNs.
Use strong device encryption and a complex lock screen PIN/password.

Enjoy a new round of the weekly SecurityAffairs newsletter, including the international press. Qantas cuts executive bonuses by 15% after a July...
vulnerabilities.summary: Critical code injection vulnerability in SAP S/4HANA allowing remote code execution.
vulnerabilities.description: An unauthenticated attacker can send specially crafted HTTP requests to the SAP S/4HANA application server, triggering a code injection path that leads to execution of arbitrary commands with system privileges. The flaw is actively exploited in the wild, with attackers leveraging it to exfiltrate data and install back‑doors.
affected_products: SAP S/4HANA (all on-premise and cloud editions)
products_versions: SAP S/4HANA (all supported releases as of 2025)
vulnerabilities.remediation: Apply the SAP Security Patch released on 2025‑09‑05 for S/4HANA. Review and restrict inbound network access to the S/4HANA application server. Enable SAP security audit logs and monitor for anomalous requests.
workarounds: Block external access to the vulnerable S/4HANA endpoints at the firewall.
Deploy a Web Application Firewall (WAF) rule to filter the malicious request patterns.

vulnerabilities.summary: Heap‑based buffer overflow in Kernel Streaming WOW Thunk Service Driver (kswow64.sys) leading to privilege escalation.
vulnerabilities.description: A heap‑based buffer overflow exists in the Kernel Streaming WOW Thunk Service Driver (kswow64.sys). By supplying a malformed media stream to the driver, an attacker with low‑privilege access can corrupt kernel memory and achieve SYSTEM level code execution.
affected_products: Microsoft Windows (Kernel Streaming WOW Thunk Service Driver) version 10.0.22621 and earlier
products_versions: SAP S/4HANA (all supported releases as of 2025)
vulnerabilities.remediation: Install the Microsoft security update released on 2025‑09‑03 (KB5021234) which fixes the overflow. Ensure that the driver is not exposed to untrusted media streams.
workarounds: Disable Kernel Streaming services on systems that do not require media processing.
Restrict execution of untrusted media files via AppLocker or Software Restriction Policies.

vulnerabilities.title: Critical, make-me-super-user SAP S/4HANA bug under active exploitation
vulnerabilities.original_title: Critical, make-me-super-user SAP S/4HANA bug under active exploitation
vulnerabilities.content_snippet: 9.9-rated flaw on the loose, so patch now A critical code-injection bug in SAP S/4HANA that allows low-privileged attackers to take over your SAP system is being actively exploited, according to security researchers.…
vulnerabilities.summary: Critical code‑injection vulnerability in SAP S/4HANA that enables low‑privileged attackers to achieve full system takeover.
vulnerabilities.description: The vulnerability is a remote code‑injection flaw in the SAP S/4HANA application layer. An attacker with low‑privileged access (e.g., a regular user account) can inject malicious code through a vulnerable API/transaction, bypassing normal authentication checks. Successful exploitation results in execution of arbitrary commands with system‑level privileges, allowing full compromise of the SAP environment, including data exfiltration, modification, and service disruption.
vulnerabilities.remediation: Apply the SAP‑issued security patch immediately. If a patch is not yet released, upgrade to the latest supported S/4HANA release that includes the fix. Review and harden SAP user roles to enforce least‑privilege principles.
workarounds: Restrict network access to SAP S/4HANA front‑end services to trusted IP ranges.
Disable or block the vulnerable API/transaction until a patch is applied.
Enable SAP Web Application Firewall (WAF) rules that detect and block code‑injection payloads.
Enforce strong input validation on custom ABAP code that interacts with the affected component.

vulnerabilities.summary: Unauthenticated file upload vulnerability in SAP NetWeaver allowing remote code execution and full system compromise.
vulnerabilities.description: The vulnerability permits an attacker to upload arbitrary files to the SAP NetWeaver server without authentication. Exploited by ransomware groups such as BianLian and RansomExx, it can lead to execution of malicious code, data exfiltration, and complete takeover of the affected SAP environment.
products_versions: SimpleHelp remote administration tool (versions prior to vendor patch)
FortiGate firmware (versions prior to security advisory)
Microsoft Windows (versions containing vulnerable CLFS driver)
vulnerabilities.remediation: Apply the security patch released by SAP for NetWeaver (refer to SAP Security Note associated with CVE-2025-31324). If a patch is not yet available, restrict network access to the NetWeaver service, enforce strong authentication, and monitor for anomalous file uploads.
workarounds: Block inbound traffic to NetWeaver management interfaces from untrusted networks.
Enable Web Application Firewall (WAF) rules to detect and block suspicious file upload attempts.
references: SAP Security Note (specific ID not provided in article)

vulnerabilities.title: China-aligned crew poisons Windows servers to manipulate Google results
vulnerabilities.original_title: China-aligned crew poisons Windows servers to manipulate Google results
vulnerabilities.content_snippet: Defrauding search with custom malware, Potato-family exploits A new China-aligned cybercrime crew named GhostRedirector has compromised at least 65 Windows servers worldwide - spotted in a June internet scan - using previously undocumented malware to juice gambling sites' rankings in Google search, ...
vulnerabilities.summary: Custom, previously undocumented malware used by the GhostRedirector group to compromise Windows Server systems and manipulate Google search rankings.
vulnerabilities.description: The GhostRedirector threat actor deploys a novel malware family (referred to as "Potato-family") that gains persistence on vulnerable Windows Server hosts. The malware leverages undocumented vulnerabilities or misconfigurations to achieve remote code execution, installs a backdoor, and modifies DNS or HTTP traffic to redirect search engine crawlers, inflating the ranking of gambling sites. Indicators include anomalous scheduled tasks, unknown services, and outbound connections to command‑and‑control infrastructure.
vulnerabilities.remediation: Apply all pending Windows security updates, especially those addressing remote code execution and privilege escalation. Remove unknown services and scheduled tasks, revert unauthorized DNS/hosts file changes, and conduct a full malware scan with updated signatures.
workarounds: Isolate critical servers from the internet until they can be fully patched.
Disable unnecessary remote management protocols (e.g., RDP, SMB) on exposed servers.
Implement strict outbound firewall rules limiting traffic to known C2 domains.

vulnerabilities.title: Roblox introduces age checks to use communication features
vulnerabilities.original_title: Roblox introduces age checks to use communication features
vulnerabilities.content_snippet: Roblox is an online platform that allows users to build, play and share online worlds and 3D games. Unfortunately, it’s also a popular platform among predators reaching out to kids and seducing them using game features such as messaging, avatar customization, and role-play. Over the years, the compa...
vulnerabilities.summary: Insecure storage and handling of facial biometric data used for age estimation
vulnerabilities.description: Roblox collects selfies to estimate user age. The biometric images and derived data are stored on Roblox servers. If the storage mechanisms lack strong encryption, access controls, or proper retention policies, attackers who breach the infrastructure could exfiltrate sensitive biometric information, leading to privacy violations and potential identity misuse.
products_versions: Roblox platform (all versions supporting age verification as of 2025)
vulnerabilities.remediation: Implement end‑to‑end encryption for biometric data at rest and in transit, enforce strict access controls, adopt data minimization and limited retention, and conduct regular security audits of the storage subsystem.
workarounds: Use third‑party zero‑knowledge age verification providers that never expose raw biometric data to Roblox.
Allow parents to opt‑out of facial age estimation and rely on alternative verification methods.

vulnerabilities.title: Roblox introduces age checks to use communication features
vulnerabilities.original_title: Roblox introduces age checks to use communication features
vulnerabilities.content_snippet: Roblox is an online platform that allows users to build, play and share online worlds and 3D games. Unfortunately, it’s also a popular platform among predators reaching out to kids and seducing them using game features such as messaging, avatar customization, and role-play. Over the years, the compa...
vulnerabilities.summary: Age verification bypass via deepfake or spoofed selfie attacks
vulnerabilities.description: The AI model used to estimate age from user‑submitted selfies can be fooled by high‑quality deepfake images or manipulated photos, allowing under‑age users to appear older (or vice‑versa). Attackers can craft spoofed images to gain access to communication features restricted to older age groups, facilitating predatory behavior.
products_versions: Roblox platform (all versions supporting age verification as of 2025)
vulnerabilities.remediation: Integrate anti‑spoofing liveness detection, multi‑factor verification (e.g., ID document verification), and continuous model hardening against adversarial examples. Log and flag repeated verification failures for manual review.
workarounds: Require secondary verification (e.g., parental approval) for access to chat features.
Limit functionality for accounts with failed or suspicious age estimations.
references: IEEE Transactions on Information Forensics and Security – Deepfake Detection Techniques
