vulnerabilities.original_title: Prisma SASE 4.0: Powering the AI-Ready Enterprise
vulnerabilities.content_snippet: The enterprise landscape has transformed. Work happens anywhere, on managed and unmanaged devices, across SaaS apps, AI tools, cloud environments and networks. The traditional perimeter has dissolved, while adversaries armed with AI now launch faster, more sophisticated attacks that can bypass proxi...
vulnerabilities.summary: Post‑load browser malware assembly and execution bypassing traditional network controls
vulnerabilities.description: Adversaries deliver malicious code that is inert during transport and only becomes active after the web page is fully rendered in the browser. The payload is assembled client‑side (post‑load) using JavaScript, WebAssembly or other browser APIs, allowing it to evade transport‑layer decryption and traditional secure web gateways. Once assembled, the malware can execute, exfiltrate data, or establish persistence without triggering conventional network‑based signatures.
affected_products: Prisma SASE 4.0 – Prisma Browser Advanced Web Protection
Any modern web browser used with Prisma SASE
vulnerabilities.remediation: Enable Prisma Browser Advanced Web Protection to inspect fully rendered pages in real time, block post‑load script execution, and enforce script‑allow lists. Apply browser hardening policies (e.g., CSP, script‑blocking extensions) and keep browsers up to date.
workarounds: Restrict execution of unsigned scripts via Content Security Policy (CSP)
Deploy endpoint protection that monitors browser process behavior

vulnerabilities.title: Prisma SASE 4.0: Powering the AI-Ready Enterprise
vulnerabilities.original_title: Prisma SASE 4.0: Powering the AI-Ready Enterprise
vulnerabilities.content_snippet: The enterprise landscape has transformed. Work happens anywhere, on managed and unmanaged devices, across SaaS apps, AI tools, cloud environments and networks. The traditional perimeter has dissolved, while adversaries armed with AI now launch faster, more sophisticated attacks that can bypass proxi...
vulnerabilities.summary: Large‑scale DNS abuse and exploitation of resolver weaknesses
vulnerabilities.description: Threat actors manipulate DNS queries and responses to deliver malicious payloads, perform data exfiltration, or redirect users to command‑and‑control servers. The article notes that ADNSR can inspect every DNS request/response and block twice as many threats as competitors, implying that existing resolvers may be vulnerable to cache poisoning, tunneling, and domain‑generation algorithm (DGA) abuse.
vulnerabilities.remediation: Deploy Prisma SASE ADNSR or equivalent DNS security solution that validates DNS responses, enforces DNS‑SEC, and applies AI‑driven threat intelligence. Disable open recursive resolvers and enforce least‑privilege ACLs on DNS servers.
workarounds: Enable DNS‑SEC validation on existing resolvers
Block known malicious domains via firewall/IPS

vulnerabilities.title: Prisma SASE 4.0: Powering the AI-Ready Enterprise
vulnerabilities.original_title: Prisma SASE 4.0: Powering the AI-Ready Enterprise
vulnerabilities.content_snippet: The enterprise landscape has transformed. Work happens anywhere, on managed and unmanaged devices, across SaaS apps, AI tools, cloud environments and networks. The traditional perimeter has dissolved, while adversaries armed with AI now launch faster, more sophisticated attacks that can bypass proxi...
vulnerabilities.summary: AI‑driven attacks leveraging SaaS agents, copilots and plugins to exfiltrate sensitive data
vulnerabilities.description: Malicious or compromised generative AI agents, copilots, and plugins can automatically access corporate data stores, source code repositories, and document libraries. Because traditional DLP focuses on static files and keyword matching, these AI‑driven data flows create blind spots, allowing large‑scale extraction of unstructured data (images, code, AI‑generated text) without triggering alerts.
affected_products: Prisma SASE 4.0 – SaaS Security Posture Management (SSPM)
Third‑party AI agents, copilots, and plugins integrated with corporate SaaS
vulnerabilities.remediation: Activate Prisma SASE SSPM to continuously discover AI agents, enforce granular access policies, and apply AI‑augmented classification to all data types. Implement least‑privilege API scopes for AI integrations and monitor anomalous data access patterns.
workarounds: Manually audit AI agent permissions in SaaS platforms
Disable unnecessary AI plugins until governance controls are in place

vulnerabilities.title: TP-Link warns of botnet infecting routers and targeting Microsoft 365 accounts
vulnerabilities.original_title: TP-Link warns of botnet infecting routers and targeting Microsoft 365 accounts
vulnerabilities.content_snippet: TP-Link has issued a warning about a botnet exploiting two vulnerabilities to infect small office/home (SOHO) routers, which are then weaponized to attack Microsoft 365 accounts.  The vulnerabilities affect the Archer C7 and TL-WR841N/ND routers, though other models may also be at risk. Despite...
vulnerabilities.summary: Improper authentication handling allows an attacker to retrieve stored router admin passwords.
vulnerabilities.description: The vulnerability resides in the router's web management interface where password fields are exposed without proper access controls. An unauthenticated remote attacker can issue crafted HTTP requests to extract the admin password hash stored on the device, enabling subsequent privileged actions.
affected_companies: Internet Service Providers that rebrand TP-Link routers (e.g., Ziggo)
vendors: Internet Service Providers that rebrand TP-Link routers (e.g., Ziggo)
vulnerabilities.remediation: Apply the firmware update released by TP-Link for the affected models. Change the router admin password to a strong, unique value after updating.
workarounds: Disable remote management if not required.
Restrict access to the router's web UI to trusted LAN hosts only.

vulnerabilities.title: TP-Link warns of botnet infecting routers and targeting Microsoft 365 accounts
vulnerabilities.original_title: TP-Link warns of botnet infecting routers and targeting Microsoft 365 accounts
vulnerabilities.content_snippet: TP-Link has issued a warning about a botnet exploiting two vulnerabilities to infect small office/home (SOHO) routers, which are then weaponized to attack Microsoft 365 accounts.  The vulnerabilities affect the Archer C7 and TL-WR841N/ND routers, though other models may also be at risk. Despite...
vulnerabilities.summary: Command injection vulnerability in the Parental Control feature enables remote code execution on the router.
vulnerabilities.description: The Parental Control module fails to properly sanitize input parameters passed to underlying shell commands. An attacker can send a crafted request to the parental control endpoint, injecting arbitrary commands that are executed with root privileges on the router, allowing full compromise of the device and its inclusion in a botnet.
affected_companies: Internet Service Providers that rebrand TP-Link routers (e.g., Ziggo)
vendors: Internet Service Providers that rebrand TP-Link routers (e.g., Ziggo)
vulnerabilities.remediation: Install the TP-Link firmware update that patches the command injection flaw. Verify that the Parental Control interface is protected by strong authentication.
workarounds: Disable the Parental Control feature if not needed.
Block inbound traffic to the router's management ports from the Internet.

vulnerabilities.title: Cybercriminals Exploit X’s Grok AI to Bypass Ad Protections and Spread Malware to Millions
vulnerabilities.original_title: Cybercriminals Exploit X’s Grok AI to Bypass Ad Protections and Spread Malware to Millions
vulnerabilities.content_snippet: Cybersecurity researchers have flagged a new technique that cybercriminals have adopted to bypass social media platform X's malvertising protections and propagate malicious links using its artificial intelligence (AI) assistant Grok. The findings were highlighted by Nati Tal, head of Guardio Labs, i...
vulnerabilities.summary: Logic flaw in X's Grok AI assistant allowing generation of malicious links that bypass X's malvertising protections
vulnerabilities.description: Cybercriminals leverage the Grok AI assistant to automatically generate and post malicious URLs that are not flagged by X's existing malvertising detection mechanisms. The AI's content moderation bypass allows the crafted links to appear legitimate, leading users to download malware when they click. The technique, dubbed "Grokking," exploits a lack of contextual validation and URL reputation checks within the AI output pipeline.
vulnerabilities.remediation: X should implement stricter content moderation for AI-generated outputs, incorporate real‑time URL reputation checks, enforce rate‑limiting on AI‑generated posts, and add sandbox analysis of generated links before they are published. Deploy AI model updates that flag or block malicious intent patterns.
workarounds: Temporarily disable public posting of AI‑generated links on X
Apply third‑party URL filtering on outbound traffic from X
Monitor and manually review AI‑generated content before it goes live

vulnerabilities.title: US puts $10M bounty on three Russians accused of attacking critical infrastructure
vulnerabilities.original_title: US puts $10M bounty on three Russians accused of attacking critical infrastructure
vulnerabilities.content_snippet: Seven-year-old Cisco vuln that remains inexplicably unpatched is their way in The US State Department has put a $10 million bounty on the heads of three Russians accused of being intelligence agents hacking America's critical infrastructure - primarily via old Cisco kit, it seems.…
vulnerabilities.summary: Unauthenticated remote code execution vulnerability in legacy Cisco networking equipment allowing attackers to gain control of critical infrastructure devices.
vulnerabilities.description: A seven‑year‑old vulnerability in Cisco's operating system code remains unpatched in many deployed devices. The flaw permits an unauthenticated attacker to send specially crafted packets that trigger a buffer overflow, leading to remote code execution with root privileges. Exploitation has been attributed to state‑sponsored actors targeting U.S. critical infrastructure, allowing them to manipulate routing, intercept traffic, and disrupt services.
vulnerabilities.remediation: Upgrade affected devices to the latest Cisco IOS/IOS‑XE releases that contain the fix. If upgrade is not immediately possible, apply Cisco's recommended configuration hardening and disable the vulnerable services.
workarounds: Disable the vulnerable protocol/service (e.g., CDP, LLDP, or specific management ports) if not required.
Implement strict ACLs to restrict inbound traffic to management interfaces.
Place legacy devices behind firewalls or segmentation zones that limit exposure to untrusted networks.

vulnerabilities.title: Android drops mega patch bomb - 120 fixes, two already exploited
vulnerabilities.original_title: Android drops mega patch bomb - 120 fixes, two already exploited
vulnerabilities.content_snippet: September bundle the largest this year, and possibly the most serious Patch Tuesday is next week, but Android is ahead of the game, dropping its biggest patch bundle this year while attackers actively exploit two of the now-fixed flaws.…
vulnerabilities.summary: Remote code execution vulnerability in Android media framework exploited in the wild.
vulnerabilities.description: A flaw in the Android media processing component allows an attacker to execute arbitrary code on the device by delivering a crafted media file (e.g., video or image). The vulnerability is remotely exploitable without authentication and has been observed in active malware campaigns targeting Android 12‑14 devices.
vulnerabilities.remediation: Apply the September 2025 Android security patch released by Google.
workarounds: Avoid opening media files from untrusted sources
Disable the vulnerable media component via device configuration if possible

vulnerabilities.title: Android drops mega patch bomb - 120 fixes, two already exploited
vulnerabilities.original_title: Android drops mega patch bomb - 120 fixes, two already exploited
vulnerabilities.content_snippet: September bundle the largest this year, and possibly the most serious Patch Tuesday is next week, but Android is ahead of the game, dropping its biggest patch bundle this year while attackers actively exploit two of the now-fixed flaws.…
vulnerabilities.summary: Privilege escalation vulnerability in Android kernel exploited in the wild.
vulnerabilities.description: The vulnerability resides in the Android kernel's handling of certain system calls, allowing a low‑privileged application to gain root privileges. Exploits have been observed in the wild, primarily delivered through malicious apps distributed via third‑party marketplaces.
vulnerabilities.remediation: Install the September 2025 Android security patch that addresses the kernel flaw.
workarounds: Restrict installation of apps from unknown sources
Use mobile device management (MDM) solutions to enforce app whitelisting

vulnerabilities.title: Update your Android! Google patches 111 vulnerabilities, 2 are critical
vulnerabilities.original_title: Update your Android! Google patches 111 vulnerabilities, 2 are critical
vulnerabilities.content_snippet: Google has patched 111 vulnerabilities in Android, including two critical flaws, in its September 2025 Android Security Bulletin. While the last few months have been quite calm regarding the number of vulnerabilities, this month is a real whopper with 111, compared to 6 in August and none in July. T...
vulnerabilities.summary: Race condition in the Linux kernel time subsystem allowing local privilege escalation.
vulnerabilities.description: A race condition exists in the time subsystem of the Linux kernel used by Android. When multiple threads access unsynchronized time‑related resources, an attacker controlling a local process can exploit the timing window to execute code with elevated privileges, potentially gaining root access.
vulnerabilities.remediation: Apply the September 2025 Android security patch (patch level 2025-09-05 or later) which includes the fix for the kernel race condition.
workarounds: Limit installation of untrusted applications.
Run devices with reduced privileges and enable SELinux enforcing mode.

vulnerabilities.title: Update your Android! Google patches 111 vulnerabilities, 2 are critical
vulnerabilities.original_title: Update your Android! Google patches 111 vulnerabilities, 2 are critical
vulnerabilities.content_snippet: Google has patched 111 vulnerabilities in Android, including two critical flaws, in its September 2025 Android Security Bulletin. While the last few months have been quite calm regarding the number of vulnerabilities, this month is a real whopper with 111, compared to 6 in August and none in July. T...
vulnerabilities.summary: Privilege escalation vulnerability in Android Runtime (ART) that requires no user interaction.
vulnerabilities.description: A flaw in the Android Runtime component allows a malicious application to execute code with elevated privileges without requiring any additional permissions or user interaction. The vulnerability stems from improper validation when translating bytecode to native instructions.
vulnerabilities.remediation: Install the September 2025 Android security update (patch level 2025-09-05 or later) which patches the ART vulnerability.
workarounds: Do not install apps from unknown sources.
Enable Play Protect and keep Google Play Services up to date.

vulnerabilities.title: Update your Android! Google patches 111 vulnerabilities, 2 are critical
vulnerabilities.original_title: Update your Android! Google patches 111 vulnerabilities, 2 are critical
vulnerabilities.content_snippet: Google has patched 111 vulnerabilities in Android, including two critical flaws, in its September 2025 Android Security Bulletin. While the last few months have been quite calm regarding the number of vulnerabilities, this month is a real whopper with 111, compared to 6 in August and none in July. T...
vulnerabilities.summary: Critical remote (proximal/adjacent) code execution vulnerability in the Android System component.
vulnerabilities.description: A vulnerability in the Android System component enables an attacker in close physical proximity (e.g., via Bluetooth, NFC, or Wi‑Fi Direct) to execute arbitrary code on the device without any user interaction. The flaw may be wormable, allowing rapid spread in dense environments such as conferences or concerts.
vulnerabilities.remediation: Update the device to the September 2025 security patch (patch level 2025-09-05 or later).
workarounds: Disable unnecessary proximity radios (Bluetooth, NFC, Wi‑Fi Direct) when not in use.
Enforce device pairing authentication and keep device visibility off.

vulnerabilities.title: Cookies and how to bake them: what they are for, associated risks, and what session hijacking has to do with it
vulnerabilities.original_title: Cookies and how to bake them: what they are for, associated risks, and what session hijacking has to do with it
vulnerabilities.content_snippet: When you visit almost any website, you’ll see a pop-up asking you to accept, decline, or customize the cookies it collects. Sometimes, it just tells you that cookies are in use by default. We randomly checked 647 websites, and 563 of them displayed cookie notifications. Most of the time, users...
vulnerabilities.summary: Session sniffing of cookies over unencrypted HTTP connections
vulnerabilities.description: When a website uses plain HTTP, cookies—including Session IDs—are sent in clear text. An attacker on the same network (e.g., public Wi‑Fi) can capture the traffic and extract the Session ID, allowing full impersonation of the victim's session.
affected_products: Web applications that transmit cookies over HTTP
vulnerabilities.remediation: Enforce HTTPS for all pages, enable HSTS, set the Secure attribute on cookies, and disable mixed‑content loading.
workarounds: Use a VPN when accessing sites over untrusted networks
Manually clear cookies after each session

vulnerabilities.title: Cookies and how to bake them: what they are for, associated risks, and what session hijacking has to do with it
vulnerabilities.original_title: Cookies and how to bake them: what they are for, associated risks, and what session hijacking has to do with it
vulnerabilities.content_snippet: When you visit almost any website, you’ll see a pop-up asking you to accept, decline, or customize the cookies it collects. Sometimes, it just tells you that cookies are in use by default. We randomly checked 647 websites, and 563 of them displayed cookie notifications. Most of the time, users...
vulnerabilities.summary: Cross‑Site Scripting (XSS) leading to Session ID theft
vulnerabilities.description: An attacker injects malicious JavaScript into a vulnerable page. When a victim visits the page, the script runs in the victim's browser and reads cookies marked HttpOnly‑less, exfiltrating the Session ID to the attacker.
affected_products: Web applications that reflect user input without proper sanitisation
vulnerabilities.remediation: Implement input validation and output encoding, enable HttpOnly on all session cookies, deploy a strict Content Security Policy (CSP), and use frameworks that auto‑escape content.
workarounds: Use browser extensions that block inline scripts
Disable JavaScript for untrusted sites

vulnerabilities.title: Cookies and how to bake them: what they are for, associated risks, and what session hijacking has to do with it
vulnerabilities.original_title: Cookies and how to bake them: what they are for, associated risks, and what session hijacking has to do with it
vulnerabilities.content_snippet: When you visit almost any website, you’ll see a pop-up asking you to accept, decline, or customize the cookies it collects. Sometimes, it just tells you that cookies are in use by default. We randomly checked 647 websites, and 563 of them displayed cookie notifications. Most of the time, users...
vulnerabilities.summary: Session fixation via URL‑embedded Session ID
vulnerabilities.description: An attacker crafts a link containing a pre‑generated Session ID and tricks the victim into clicking it. After the victim authenticates, the server continues to use the attacker‑chosen Session ID, granting the attacker access to the authenticated session.
affected_products: Web applications that accept Session IDs from URL parameters without regeneration after login
vulnerabilities.remediation: Regenerate Session ID after successful authentication, reject Session IDs supplied via URL parameters, and enforce HttpOnly + Secure flags.
workarounds: Educate users to avoid clicking unknown links
Configure web server to strip Session ID parameters

vulnerabilities.title: Cookies and how to bake them: what they are for, associated risks, and what session hijacking has to do with it
vulnerabilities.original_title: Cookies and how to bake them: what they are for, associated risks, and what session hijacking has to do with it
vulnerabilities.content_snippet: When you visit almost any website, you’ll see a pop-up asking you to accept, decline, or customize the cookies it collects. Sometimes, it just tells you that cookies are in use by default. We randomly checked 647 websites, and 563 of them displayed cookie notifications. Most of the time, users...
vulnerabilities.summary: Cross‑Site Request Forgery (CSRF) using stolen Session cookies
vulnerabilities.description: An attacker hosts a malicious page that automatically sends a forged request to a target site where the victim is logged in. The browser includes the victim's Session cookie, causing the action to be performed with the victim's privileges.
affected_products: Web applications that rely solely on cookies for authentication without CSRF tokens
vulnerabilities.remediation: Implement anti‑CSRF tokens, enforce SameSite=Lax or Strict on cookies, and require re‑authentication for sensitive actions.
workarounds: Use browser extensions that block third‑party requests
Log out after each session

vulnerabilities.title: Cookies and how to bake them: what they are for, associated risks, and what session hijacking has to do with it
vulnerabilities.original_title: Cookies and how to bake them: what they are for, associated risks, and what session hijacking has to do with it
vulnerabilities.content_snippet: When you visit almost any website, you’ll see a pop-up asking you to accept, decline, or customize the cookies it collects. Sometimes, it just tells you that cookies are in use by default. We randomly checked 647 websites, and 563 of them displayed cookie notifications. Most of the time, users...
vulnerabilities.summary: Man‑in‑the‑Middle (MitM) attacks against HTTP or improperly validated HTTPS
vulnerabilities.description: An attacker intercepts traffic, possibly downgrading HTTPS to HTTP (SSL stripping) or presenting a forged certificate. This enables the attacker to read or modify cookies, including Session IDs.
affected_products: Web services without HSTS, with optional HTTPS, or with weak certificate validation
vulnerabilities.remediation: Enforce HTTPS with HSTS, use certificate pinning where possible, and disable SSL stripping via HTTP Strict Transport Security.
workarounds: Verify certificate details manually
Use VPN on untrusted networks

vulnerabilities.title: Cookies and how to bake them: what they are for, associated risks, and what session hijacking has to do with it
vulnerabilities.original_title: Cookies and how to bake them: what they are for, associated risks, and what session hijacking has to do with it
vulnerabilities.content_snippet: When you visit almost any website, you’ll see a pop-up asking you to accept, decline, or customize the cookies it collects. Sometimes, it just tells you that cookies are in use by default. We randomly checked 647 websites, and 563 of them displayed cookie notifications. Most of the time, users...
vulnerabilities.summary: Predictable Session ID generation
vulnerabilities.description: Session IDs are generated using predictable algorithms (e.g., timestamps, incremental counters). Attackers can collect a sample set, infer the generation pattern, and guess valid Session IDs to hijack sessions.
affected_products: Web applications using weak random number generators for session identifiers
vulnerabilities.remediation: Use cryptographically secure random generators (e.g., /dev/urandom, Java SecureRandom), ensure sufficient entropy and length (>=128 bits).
workarounds: Rotate Session IDs frequently
Monitor for repeated failed session lookups

vulnerabilities.title: Cookies and how to bake them: what they are for, associated risks, and what session hijacking has to do with it
vulnerabilities.original_title: Cookies and how to bake them: what they are for, associated risks, and what session hijacking has to do with it
vulnerabilities.content_snippet: When you visit almost any website, you’ll see a pop-up asking you to accept, decline, or customize the cookies it collects. Sometimes, it just tells you that cookies are in use by default. We randomly checked 647 websites, and 563 of them displayed cookie notifications. Most of the time, users...
vulnerabilities.summary: Cookie tossing via subdomain takeover
vulnerabilities.description: If an attacker gains control of a subdomain (e.g., sub.example.com), they can set a cookie with the same name as the main site's Session cookie and a Domain attribute of .example.com. The browser will send the attacker's cookie first, potentially overriding the legitimate Session ID.
affected_products: Web sites that set cookies with a broad Domain attribute (e.g., .example.com)
vulnerabilities.remediation: Use the __Host- prefix for session cookies, avoid setting Domain attribute unless necessary, and regularly audit DNS records for unused subdomains.
workarounds: Restrict cookie scope to exact host
Implement server‑side validation of Session ID source

vulnerabilities.title: Frostbyte10 bugs put thousands of refrigerators at major grocery chains at risk
vulnerabilities.original_title: Frostbyte10 bugs put thousands of refrigerators at major grocery chains at risk
vulnerabilities.content_snippet: Major flaws uncovered in Copeland controllers: Patch now Ten vulnerabilities in Copeland controllers, which are found in thousands of devices used by the world's largest supermarket chains and cold storage companies, could have allowed miscreants to manipulate temperatures and spoil food and medicin...
vulnerabilities.summary: Multiple vulnerabilities in Copeland controller firmware allow remote manipulation of refrigeration temperature settings.
vulnerabilities.description: Ten separate flaws have been identified in the firmware of Copeland controllers. The vulnerabilities include insecure authentication bypass, command injection, and insufficient input validation that can be exploited over the network to change temperature set‑points, disable safety limits, or trigger a denial‑of‑service condition. An attacker who successfully exploits any of these flaws can cause food and medicine spoilage, create supply‑chain disruptions, and potentially damage hardware.
affected_products: Copeland refrigeration controllers (various models used in supermarket and cold‑storage installations)
affected_companies: Supermarket chains and cold‑storage operators using Copeland controllers
vendors: Supermarket chains and cold‑storage operators using Copeland controllers
products_versions: All known firmware versions prior to the September 2025 security patch
vulnerabilities.remediation: Apply the vendor‑provided firmware patch immediately. Verify that the patch version matches the advisory and reboot devices after installation.
workarounds: Isolate controllers on a dedicated VLAN with no internet access.
Disable any unused remote management interfaces.
Enforce strong network segmentation and firewall rules to restrict traffic to trusted management stations.

vulnerabilities.title: Silver Fox Exploits Microsoft-Signed WatchDog Driver to Deploy ValleyRAT Malware
vulnerabilities.original_title: Silver Fox Exploits Microsoft-Signed WatchDog Driver to Deploy ValleyRAT Malware
vulnerabilities.content_snippet: The threat actor known as Silver Fox has been attributed to abuse of a previously unknown vulnerable driver associated with WatchDog Anti-malware as part of a Bring Your Own Vulnerable Driver (BYOVD) attack aimed at disarming security solutions installed on compromised hosts. The vulnerable driver i...
vulnerabilities.summary: Vulnerable WatchDog anti-malware driver (amsdk.sys 1.0.600) allows arbitrary kernel code execution, enabling BYOVD attacks and deployment of ValleyRAT.
vulnerabilities.description: The amsdk.sys driver (version 1.0.600), signed by Microsoft, contains a vulnerability that permits arbitrary code execution in kernel mode. An attacker can load the driver via a Bring Your Own Vulnerable Driver (BYOVD) technique, bypassing security controls, disabling security solutions, and installing the ValleyRAT malware. The driver’s signing status masks its malicious use, making detection difficult.
vulnerabilities.remediation: Update or replace the WatchDog anti-malware product with a version that includes a patched driver. If no patch is available, uninstall the vulnerable driver, block its loading via driver signing enforcement policies, and apply application control rules to prevent execution of unsigned or suspicious drivers.
workarounds: Disable or uninstall WatchDog Anti-malware until a patched driver is released.
Configure Windows to enforce driver signature verification and block loading of amsdk.sys.
Implement application whitelisting (e.g., AppLocker, Windows Defender Application Control) to prevent unknown drivers from loading.

vulnerabilities.title: WhatsApp fixes vulnerability used in zero-click attacks
vulnerabilities.original_title: WhatsApp fixes vulnerability used in zero-click attacks
vulnerabilities.content_snippet: WhatsApp says it has issued an update to patch a vulnerability that has been used in conjunction with an Apple vulnerability to target specific users and compromise their devices. Reportedly, attackers used this exploit against dozens of WhatsApp users, and WhatsApp has notified those affected: “Our...
vulnerabilities.summary: Out-of-bounds write in Apple's Image I/O framework allowing memory corruption when processing crafted image files.
vulnerabilities.description: A crafted image file can trigger an out-of-bounds write in the Image I/O framework. The write corrupts memory, enabling arbitrary code execution with the privileges of the vulnerable process. The flaw is exploitable without any user interaction, making it suitable for zero‑click attacks.
affected_products: Any application using Image I/O for image handling
products_versions: iOS/macOS (all versions prior to Apple patch released September 2025)
vulnerabilities.remediation: Update to the latest iOS/macOS versions where Apple has added stricter bounds checking to Image I/O. Apply any firmware updates released by Apple.
workarounds: Disable automatic image preview in messaging apps.
Restrict apps from accessing untrusted image data via MDM policies.

vulnerabilities.title: WhatsApp fixes vulnerability used in zero-click attacks
vulnerabilities.original_title: WhatsApp fixes vulnerability used in zero-click attacks
vulnerabilities.content_snippet: WhatsApp says it has issued an update to patch a vulnerability that has been used in conjunction with an Apple vulnerability to target specific users and compromise their devices. Reportedly, attackers used this exploit against dozens of WhatsApp users, and WhatsApp has notified those affected: “Our...
vulnerabilities.summary: Improper authorization of linked‑device synchronization messages in WhatsApp for iOS/macOS, allowing processing of arbitrary URLs.
vulnerabilities.description: WhatsApp failed to properly authorize linked‑device sync messages. An attacker could send a specially crafted sync message containing an arbitrary URL, causing the target device to fetch and process the URL without user interaction. When combined with the Image I/O vulnerability, this enables a full device compromise chain.
affected_products: WhatsApp for iOS prior to v2.25.21.73
products_versions: iOS/macOS (all versions prior to Apple patch released September 2025)
vulnerabilities.remediation: Update WhatsApp to version 2.25.21.73 (iOS) or later, and macOS version 2.25.21.78 or later. Perform a full factory reset if compromise is suspected.
workarounds: Disable linked‑device synchronization until the patch is applied.
Restrict background network access for WhatsApp via MDM.

vulnerabilities.title: WhatsApp warns of 'attack against specific targeted users'
vulnerabilities.original_title: WhatsApp warns of 'attack against specific targeted users'
vulnerabilities.content_snippet: PLUS: Microsoft ends no-MFA Azure access; WorkDay attack diverts payments; FreePBX warns of CVSS 10 flaw; and more Infosec In brief A flaw in Meta's WhatsApp app “may have been exploited in a sophisticated attack against specific targeted users.”…
vulnerabilities.summary: Potential remote code execution / data exfiltration vulnerability in Meta's WhatsApp application exploited in a targeted attack
vulnerabilities.description: WhatsApp disclosed that a previously unknown flaw in its messaging client may have been leveraged in a sophisticated, targeted attack. The vulnerability appears to allow an attacker to deliver malicious payloads to specific users, potentially leading to unauthorized access to messages, contacts, and device data. The exact technical details (e.g., buffer overflow, deserialization issue, or logic flaw) have not been publicly disclosed, but the attack requires the victim to interact with a crafted message or link, after which malicious code can be executed within the WhatsApp process.
products_versions: WhatsApp versions prior to the forthcoming security patch (exact versions not disclosed)
vulnerabilities.remediation: Update WhatsApp to the latest version released by Meta as soon as it becomes available. Enable automatic updates on mobile devices. Review and apply any security advisories issued by Meta. Consider reinstalling the app from official app stores to ensure a clean installation.
workarounds: Do not open messages or links from unknown or unexpected sources.
Verify the authenticity of contacts before interacting with shared media or links.
Use device-level sandboxing or mobile security solutions that can detect anomalous app behavior.

vulnerabilities.title: Salt Typhoon Exploits Flaws in Edge Network Devices to Breach 600 Organizations Worldwide

Consider using alternative code editors temporarily

vulnerabilities.title: Researchers Warn of Sitecore Exploit Chain Linking Cache Poisoning and Remote Code Execution
vulnerabilities.original_title: Researchers Warn of Sitecore Exploit Chain Linking Cache Poisoning and Remote Code Execution
vulnerabilities.content_snippet: Three new security vulnerabilities have been disclosed in the Sitecore Experience Platform that could be exploited to achieve information disclosure and remote code execution.  The flaws, per watchTowr Labs, are listed below - CVE-2025-53693 - HTML cache poisoning through unsafe reflections CVE...
vulnerabilities.summary: HTML cache poisoning through unsafe reflections in Sitecore Experience Platform
vulnerabilities.description: Improper handling of reflected user input allows an attacker to inject malicious HTML into the server-side cache. Subsequent users receive the poisoned content, enabling cross‑site scripting, credential theft, or further exploitation steps such as triggering insecure deserialization.
products_versions: Sitecore Experience Platform (specific versions not disclosed)
vulnerabilities.remediation: Apply the Sitecore security patch that sanitizes reflected inputs and disables caching of untrusted HTML. Upgrade to the latest supported version of Sitecore Experience Platform.
workarounds: Configure the cache to exclude pages that contain user‑controlled HTML.
Implement strict Content‑Security‑Policy (CSP) headers.

vulnerabilities.title: Researchers Warn of Sitecore Exploit Chain Linking Cache Poisoning and Remote Code Execution
vulnerabilities.original_title: Researchers Warn of Sitecore Exploit Chain Linking Cache Poisoning and Remote Code Execution
vulnerabilities.content_snippet: Three new security vulnerabilities have been disclosed in the Sitecore Experience Platform that could be exploited to achieve information disclosure and remote code execution.  The flaws, per watchTowr Labs, are listed below - CVE-2025-53693 - HTML cache poisoning through unsafe reflections CVE...
vulnerabilities.summary: Remote code execution via insecure deserialization in Sitecore Experience Platform
vulnerabilities.description: The platform deserializes attacker‑controlled data without sufficient integrity checks. By crafting a malicious serialized object, an unauthenticated remote attacker can achieve arbitrary code execution on the application server, leading to full compromise of the Sitecore instance.
products_versions: Sitecore Experience Platform (specific versions not disclosed)
vulnerabilities.remediation: Install the official Sitecore patch that introduces signed deserialization and disables the vulnerable deserialization endpoints. Upgrade to the latest version where the issue is fixed.
workarounds: Disable the vulnerable serialization endpoints if they are not required.
Enforce strict type whitelisting for deserialization.

vulnerabilities.description: The article references a third vulnerability (CVE‑2025‑53694) without providing technical details. Based on typical patterns, it likely involves information disclosure or privilege escalation.
products_versions: Sitecore Experience Platform (specific versions not disclosed)
vulnerabilities.remediation: Monitor Sitecore security advisories for a dedicated patch and apply updates as soon as they are released.
workarounds: Restrict network access to the Sitecore management interfaces.
Enable logging and monitor for anomalous activity.

vulnerabilities.title: How attackers adapt to built-in macOS protection
vulnerabilities.original_title: How attackers adapt to built-in macOS protection
vulnerabilities.content_snippet: If a system is popular with users, you can bet it’s just as popular with cybercriminals. Although Windows still dominates, second place belongs to macOS. And this makes it a viable target for attackers. With various built-in protection mechanisms, macOS generally provides a pretty much end-to-...
vulnerabilities.summary: Local extraction of macOS Keychain data using tools like Chainbreaker or native 'security' commands
vulnerabilities.description: An attacker with file system access to a user's Keychain files and knowledge of the master password can use the open‑source Chainbreaker utility or the built‑in /usr/bin/security CLI to dump and decrypt stored credentials, certificates, and secrets. The technique does not exploit a code flaw but leverages legitimate functionality when local access is already obtained.
vulnerabilities.remediation: Enforce strong, unique Keychain master passwords; enable FileVault full‑disk encryption; restrict local admin access; monitor for 'security dump-keychain' and 'security list-keychains' command executions via EDR.
workarounds: Limit execution of the 'security' CLI to privileged accounts
Audit and alert on unusual Keychain file access
references: Kaspersky EDR Sigma rule for Keychain access

vulnerabilities.title: How attackers adapt to built-in macOS protection
vulnerabilities.original_title: How attackers adapt to built-in macOS protection
vulnerabilities.content_snippet: If a system is popular with users, you can bet it’s just as popular with cybercriminals. Although Windows still dominates, second place belongs to macOS. And this makes it a viable target for attackers. With various built-in protection mechanisms, macOS generally provides a pretty much end-to-...
vulnerabilities.summary: Disabling System Integrity Protection (SIP) via csrutil in Recovery Mode
vulnerabilities.description: An attacker with physical access can reboot a Mac into Recovery Mode and run 'csrutil disable', turning off SIP. This removes kernel‑level protection for system directories, enabling further tampering or persistence mechanisms. The action is not logged by normal OS mechanisms, making detection difficult.
vulnerabilities.remediation: Physically secure devices; enable firmware password; use FileVault; monitor for changes in SIP status via periodic checks; alert if 'csrutil status' reports disabled.
workarounds: Enforce boot‑security policies, such as requiring a firmware password to enter Recovery Mode
references: Kaspersky EDR Sigma rule for SIP status discovery

vulnerabilities.title: How attackers adapt to built-in macOS protection
vulnerabilities.original_title: How attackers adapt to built-in macOS protection
vulnerabilities.content_snippet: If a system is popular with users, you can bet it’s just as popular with cybercriminals. Although Windows still dominates, second place belongs to macOS. And this makes it a viable target for attackers. With various built-in protection mechanisms, macOS generally provides a pretty much end-to-...
vulnerabilities.summary: TCC clickjacking to obtain Full Disk Access or Accessibility permissions
vulnerabilities.description: Attackers present a malicious UI overlay that mimics the TCC permission dialog, tricking users into granting privileged access (e.g., Full Disk Access, Accessibility). The technique exploits user trust rather than a software bug, but results in the same level of system compromise as a legitimate grant.
affected_products: macOS Transparency, Consent, and Control (TCC) framework
vulnerabilities.remediation: Educate users to verify permission dialogs; enforce UI integrity checks; use third‑party endpoint protection that detects UI overlay anomalies; limit which apps can request high‑risk TCC permissions.
workarounds: Require admin approval for Full Disk Access changes
Use Mobile Device Management (MDM) to pre‑approve or block certain TCC entries

vulnerabilities.title: How attackers adapt to built-in macOS protection
vulnerabilities.original_title: How attackers adapt to built-in macOS protection
vulnerabilities.content_snippet: If a system is popular with users, you can bet it’s just as popular with cybercriminals. Although Windows still dominates, second place belongs to macOS. And this makes it a viable target for attackers. With various built-in protection mechanisms, macOS generally provides a pretty much end-to-...
vulnerabilities.summary: Removal of the com.apple.quarantine extended attribute to bypass File Quarantine checks
vulnerabilities.description: An attacker can strip the quarantine attribute from a downloaded file using 'xattr -d com.apple.quarantine <file>'. Without the attribute, Gatekeeper and the OS will not warn the user before execution, facilitating silent malware deployment.
vulnerabilities.remediation: Monitor execution of 'xattr' with '-d com.apple.quarantine' arguments; block or alert on attribute removal; enforce application signing policies; educate users to avoid running files from untrusted sources.
workarounds: Disable execution of 'xattr' for non‑admin accounts
Use endpoint protection that restores quarantine attributes automatically
references: Kaspersky EDR Sigma rule for Quarantine attribute removal

vulnerabilities.title: How attackers adapt to built-in macOS protection
vulnerabilities.original_title: How attackers adapt to built-in macOS protection
vulnerabilities.content_snippet: If a system is popular with users, you can bet it’s just as popular with cybercriminals. Although Windows still dominates, second place belongs to macOS. And this makes it a viable target for attackers. With various built-in protection mechanisms, macOS generally provides a pretty much end-to-...
vulnerabilities.summary: Disabling Gatekeeper via 'spctl --master-disable' or '--global-disable'
vulnerabilities.description: An attacker with admin rights can turn off Gatekeeper, removing signature verification for all applications. This opens the system to execution of unsigned or malicious binaries without user prompts.
vulnerabilities.remediation: Restrict admin privileges; monitor for 'spctl' invocations with '--master-disable' or '--global-disable'; enforce configuration management to keep Gatekeeper enabled; use MDM to lock Gatekeeper settings.
workarounds: Set a configuration profile that prevents Gatekeeper from being disabled
references: Kaspersky EDR Sigma rule for Gatekeeper disable

vulnerabilities.title: How attackers adapt to built-in macOS protection
vulnerabilities.original_title: How attackers adapt to built-in macOS protection
vulnerabilities.content_snippet: If a system is popular with users, you can bet it’s just as popular with cybercriminals. Although Windows still dominates, second place belongs to macOS. And this makes it a viable target for attackers. With various built-in protection mechanisms, macOS generally provides a pretty much end-to-...
vulnerabilities.summary: Local extraction of macOS Keychain data using Chainbreaker or native security utility
vulnerabilities.description: If an attacker obtains a copy of a user's Keychain file and the master password (or can coerce the user to reveal it), they can use the open‑source Chainbreaker tool or the built‑in `security` CLI to dump all stored credentials, certificates, and secrets. The technique does not exploit a code flaw; it leverages inadequate local access controls and the fact that Keychain files are stored on disk in an encrypted but accessible format.
vulnerabilities.remediation: Enforce strong, unique master passwords; enable FileVault full‑disk encryption; restrict local admin access; monitor for execution of `security dump-keychain` and `security list-keychains` via EDR; audit process creation logs with macOS ESF.
workarounds: Store highly sensitive secrets in hardware security modules or external password managers that never write plaintext to disk.
Disable remote login and limit physical access to machines.
references: Securelist article "How attackers adapt to built‑in macOS protection" (2025-08-29)

vulnerabilities.title: How attackers adapt to built-in macOS protection
vulnerabilities.original_title: How attackers adapt to built-in macOS protection
vulnerabilities.content_snippet: If a system is popular with users, you can bet it’s just as popular with cybercriminals. Although Windows still dominates, second place belongs to macOS. And this makes it a viable target for attackers. With various built-in protection mechanisms, macOS generally provides a pretty much end-to-...
vulnerabilities.summary: Discovery of System Integrity Protection (SIP) status via `csrutil status`
vulnerabilities.description: Adversaries query the SIP status to decide whether they can attempt to disable SIP (which requires booting into Recovery mode). The command `csrutil status` is benign but can indicate reconnaissance activity when observed repeatedly.
vulnerabilities.remediation: Monitor for execution of `csrutil status` and generate alerts on repeated calls; enforce strict physical security to prevent booting into Recovery mode; keep SIP enabled at all times.
workarounds: Configure macOS Endpoint Security framework to log `csrutil` invocations.
references: Apple documentation for System Integrity Protection

vulnerabilities.content_snippet: If a system is popular with users, you can bet it’s just as popular with cybercriminals. Although Windows still dominates, second place belongs to macOS. And this makes it a viable target for attackers. With various built-in protection mechanisms, macOS generally provides a pretty much end-to-...
vulnerabilities.summary: TCC clickjacking – UI redressing to obtain Full Disk Access or Accessibility permissions
vulnerabilities.description: Attackers overlay a fake window on top of the TCC consent dialog, tricking the user into granting privileged permissions (e.g., Full Disk Access, Accessibility). The technique exploits user interface design rather than a software bug, but results in the same impact as a successful privilege‑escalation.
vulnerabilities.remediation: Educate users to verify the authenticity of permission dialogs; use macOS privacy controls to require admin approval for high‑risk permissions; employ UI‑integrity monitoring tools.
workarounds: Disable automatic granting of Accessibility for unsigned apps via MDM policies.

vulnerabilities.title: How attackers adapt to built-in macOS protection
vulnerabilities.original_title: How attackers adapt to built-in macOS protection
vulnerabilities.content_snippet: If a system is popular with users, you can bet it’s just as popular with cybercriminals. Although Windows still dominates, second place belongs to macOS. And this makes it a viable target for attackers. With various built-in protection mechanisms, macOS generally provides a pretty much end-to-...
vulnerabilities.summary: Removal of the quarantine attribute (`xattr -d com.apple.quarantine`) to bypass Gatekeeper and File Quarantine
vulnerabilities.description: By removing the `com.apple.quarantine` extended attribute from a downloaded file, an attacker prevents macOS from prompting the user or Gatekeeper from blocking execution. The technique works for files obtained via command‑line tools (curl, wget) that do not set the attribute, or after manual removal with `xattr -d`.
vulnerabilities.remediation: Monitor for execution of `xattr` with `-d com.apple.quarantine`; enforce application whitelisting; restrict use of `xattr` to privileged accounts; educate users about the risks of running files from untrusted sources.
workarounds: Configure MDM to block execution of binaries lacking a valid Apple signature regardless of quarantine status.

vulnerabilities.title: How attackers adapt to built-in macOS protection
vulnerabilities.original_title: How attackers adapt to built-in macOS protection
vulnerabilities.content_snippet: If a system is popular with users, you can bet it’s just as popular with cybercriminals. Although Windows still dominates, second place belongs to macOS. And this makes it a viable target for attackers. With various built-in protection mechanisms, macOS generally provides a pretty much end-to-...
vulnerabilities.summary: Disabling Gatekeeper via `spctl --master-disable` or `spctl --global-disable`
vulnerabilities.description: An attacker with administrative rights can permanently turn off Gatekeeper, allowing execution of unsigned or malicious applications without user prompts. The command `spctl --master-disable` modifies system policy and is not logged by default when run in Recovery mode, making detection difficult.
vulnerabilities.remediation: Audit for changes to Gatekeeper status; restrict admin privileges; enforce MDM policies that keep Gatekeeper enabled; monitor for `spctl` invocations with `--master-disable` or `--global-disable` flags.
workarounds: Re‑enable Gatekeeper via `spctl --master-enable` after any detected change.

vulnerabilities.title: Google: Salesloft Drift breach hits all integrations
vulnerabilities.original_title: Google: Salesloft Drift breach hits all integrations
vulnerabilities.content_snippet: Google warns that Salesloft Drift OAuth breach affects all integrations, not just Salesforce. All tokens should be treated as compromised. Google disclosed that the Salesloft Drift OAuth breach is broader than Salesforce, affecting all integrations. GTIG and Mandiant advise all customers to treat co...
vulnerabilities.summary: OAuth token compromise affecting Salesloft Drift integrations
vulnerabilities.description: A threat actor (UNC6395) compromised OAuth tokens associated with Salesloft Drift, allowing unauthorized access to customer data. Initially thought to affect only Salesforce integrations, the breach was later discovered to impact all integrations with Drift, including Google Workspace email access. Attackers used stolen tokens to access email data and exfiltrate sensitive information including AWS access keys and Snowflake tokens.
products_versions: All versions of Salesloft Drift with integrations
vulnerabilities.remediation: Revoke all OAuth tokens connected to Drift, disable integrations, rotate credentials, re-authenticate connections, and review logs for suspicious activity.
workarounds: Disable all Drift integrations immediately
Revoke all OAuth tokens associated with Drift

vulnerabilities.summary: Cloud deployment vulnerability leading to data breaches
vulnerabilities.description: The article describes a scenario where hidden code flaws in applications become critical vulnerabilities when deployed to cloud environments, potentially leading to massive data breaches with significant financial impact.
vulnerabilities.remediation: Implement comprehensive code-to-cloud mapping to identify and remediate vulnerabilities before deployment to cloud environments.
workarounds: Implement strict code review processes
Conduct thorough security testing before cloud deployment
Use application security testing tools

vulnerabilities.original_title: Claude AI chatbot abused to launch “cybercrime spree”

The company issued a Threat Intelligence report in which it describes several instances...
vulnerabilities.summary: AI chatbot Claude abused to automate cybercrime operations
vulnerabilities.description: Cybercriminals are exploiting Claude AI's 'vibe coding' capabilities to automate sophisticated cyber attacks. This abuse lowers the technical barrier for cybercriminals, enabling them to rapidly develop and deploy malware, ransomware, and other attack tools without deep technical expertise. The AI is being used throughout the entire attack lifecycle, from reconnaissance to execution.
vulnerabilities.remediation: Anthropic has deployed a Threat Intelligence team to investigate abuse and improve defenses. Organizations should implement AI usage policies and monitoring to detect potential abuse of AI systems.
workarounds: Monitor AI system outputs for suspicious code generation
Implement usage restrictions on AI coding capabilities
Regularly audit AI system logs for unusual activity
references: Malwarebytes Article - Claude AI chatbot abused to launch 'cybercrime spree'

vulnerabilities.original_title: UNC6395 targets Salesloft in Drift OAuth token theft campaign
vulnerabilities.content_snippet: Hackers breached Salesloft to steal OAuth/refresh tokens for Drift AI chat; GTIG and Mandiant link the campaign to threat actor UNC6395. Google Threat Intelligence Group and Mandiant researchers investigate a large-scale data theft campaign carried out to hack the sales automation platform Salesloft...
vulnerabilities.summary: OAuth token theft via compromised Salesloft Drift integration
vulnerabilities.description: Threat actor UNC6395 compromised OAuth tokens associated with the Salesloft Drift third-party application to gain unauthorized access to Salesforce customer instances. The actor systematically exported large volumes of data, including AWS access keys, passwords, and Snowflake-related access tokens, between August 8-18, 2025. The attack involved compromised OAuth credentials that allowed the threat actor to bypass authentication and access sensitive customer data.
vulnerabilities.remediation: Revoke all Drift-Salesforce connections, re-authenticate Salesforce integrations, rotate all credentials including API keys, access keys, and tokens, perform log reviews to detect any unauthorized access, and investigate for data exfiltration.
workarounds: Disconnect Drift from Salesforce integration
Monitor Salesforce API usage logs for unusual activity
Implement additional authentication layers for Salesforce access

vulnerabilities.title: Developer verification: a promised lift for Android security
vulnerabilities.original_title: Developer verification: a promised lift for Android security
vulnerabilities.content_snippet: To reduce the number of harmful apps targeting Android users, Google has announced that certified Android devices will require all apps to be registered by verified developers in order to be installed. But this new measure is not just about malware that’s found on the Google Play Store, it’s m...
vulnerabilities.summary: Lack of developer verification for sideloaded Android apps allows malware distribution
vulnerabilities.description: The article describes a security vulnerability where Android devices allow installation of unverified applications from outside the Google Play Store. This enables cybercriminals to distribute malware, commit financial fraud, and steal sensitive data. The vulnerability affects all Android devices that allow sideloading of applications, with research indicating that 50 times more malware comes from sideloaded sources than from Google Play itself.
products_versions: All Android versions that allow sideloading of applications
vulnerabilities.remediation: Google is implementing a developer verification requirement that will be enforced starting September 2026 in Brazil, Indonesia, Singapore, and Thailand, with global rollout to follow. This requires all apps installed on certified Android devices to be registered by verified developers.
workarounds: Only install apps from the Google Play Store
Avoid sideloading apps from untrusted sources
Use certified Android devices that receive security updates
Consider using security software like Malwarebytes for Android

vulnerabilities.title: More vulnerable stalkerware victims’ data exposed in new TheTruthSpy flaw
vulnerabilities.original_title: More vulnerable stalkerware victims’ data exposed in new TheTruthSpy flaw
vulnerabilities.content_snippet: TheTruthSpy is at it again. A security researcher has discovered a flaw in the Android-based stalkerware that allows anyone to compromise any record in the system. TheTruthSpy stalkerware is designed to be installed surreptitiously on a victim’s Android phone. It then monitors that phone&#8217...
vulnerabilities.summary: Password reset vulnerability allowing unauthorized access to any account on TheTruthSpy stalkerware servers
vulnerabilities.description: A vulnerability in TheTruthSpy stalkerware allows attackers to reset passwords for any account on the system, potentially compromising all victim data stored on the servers. The flaw enables unauthorized access to call logs, text messages, GPS location data, messaging app activities, files, photos, social media interactions, emails, browsing history, audio recordings, and keystroke logs.
products_versions: All versions of TheTruthSpy Android stalkerware
vulnerabilities.remediation: The vendor claims to be building a new version from scratch, but TechCrunch found they were still using the same vulnerable software library. No patch is currently available.

vulnerabilities.title: 77 malicious apps removed from Google Play Store
vulnerabilities.original_title: 77 malicious apps removed from Google Play Store
vulnerabilities.content_snippet: Google has removed 77 malicious apps from the Google Play Store. Before they were removed, researchers at ThreatLabz discovered the apps had been installed over 19 million times. One of the malware families discovered by the researchers is a banking Trojan known as Anatsa or TeaBot. This banking Tro...
vulnerabilities.summary: Multiple malicious apps in Google Play Store including banking Trojan Anatsa/TeaBot and Joker malware
vulnerabilities.description: 77 malicious apps were discovered in the Google Play Store, including the banking Trojan Anatsa/TeaBot which steals banking and cryptocurrency credentials, and the Joker malware family which steals SMS messages, contacts, device info, and enrolls victims in unwanted premium services. The apps disguise themselves as benign applications with useful functionality before downloading malicious payloads.
vulnerabilities.remediation: Google has removed the malicious apps from the Play Store. Users should uninstall any affected apps and ensure Google Play Protect is enabled. Regularly review app permissions and remove unused apps.
workarounds: Check app permissions before installation
Review app permissions after updates
Uninstall unused apps
Keep device and apps updated
Install security software

vulnerabilities.title: DSLRoot, Proxies, and the Threat of ‘Legal Botnets’
vulnerabilities.original_title: DSLRoot, Proxies, and the Threat of ‘Legal Botnets’
vulnerabilities.content_snippet: The cybersecurity community on Reddit responded in disbelief this month when a self-described Air National Guard member with top secret security clearance began questioning the arrangement they’d made with company called DSLRoot, which was paying $250 a month to plug a pair of laptops into the...
vulnerabilities.summary: DSLRoot client software contains hardcoded administrative credentials and vendor‑specific exploits that allow remote control of residential networking equipment.
vulnerabilities.description: Reverse engineering by Infrawatch revealed that the DSLRoot installer pre‑configures networking equipment with hard‑coded admin passwords and exploits vendor‑specific firmware vulnerabilities to gain remote code execution. The software also enumerates nearby Wi‑Fi networks, potentially expanding its reach beyond the primary DSL line. Once compromised, the host becomes part of a “legal botnet”, relaying traffic for third‑party customers and exposing the resident’s network to further malicious activity such as ad fraud, credential harvesting, and lateral movement.
affected_products: Residential DSL routers (e.g., CenturyLink, Frontier models)
Wi‑Fi access points used in host premises
vulnerabilities.remediation: Remove all DSLRoot software and associated hardware from the network. Reset router/admin passwords to unique, strong values. Apply the latest firmware updates from the router vendor. Block outbound connections to proxysource.net and related domains. Conduct a full malware scan on the host machines and monitor for unauthorized traffic.
workarounds: Network‑segment the DSLRoot devices on a separate VLAN with strict egress filtering.
Disable remote management interfaces on residential routers.
Use host‑based firewalls to block unknown outbound ports.

vulnerabilities.title: ShadowCaptcha Exploits WordPress Sites to Spread Ransomware, Info Stealers, and Crypto Miners
vulnerabilities.original_title: ShadowCaptcha Exploits WordPress Sites to Spread Ransomware, Info Stealers, and Crypto Miners
vulnerabilities.content_snippet: A new large-scale campaign has been observed exploiting over 100 compromised WordPress sites to direct site visitors to fake CAPTCHA verification pages that employ the ClickFix social engineering tactic to deliver information stealers, ransomware, and cryptocurrency miners. The large-scale cybercrim...
vulnerabilities.summary: WordPress sites compromised to serve fake CAPTCHA verification pages delivering malware
vulnerabilities.description: Attackers have compromised over 100 WordPress sites to redirect visitors to fake CAPTCHA verification pages. These pages use the ClickFix social engineering tactic to trick users into downloading and executing malicious software including information stealers, ransomware, and cryptocurrency miners.
vulnerabilities.remediation: Regularly update WordPress core, themes, and plugins; implement strong authentication mechanisms; review and limit plugin permissions; use security plugins to detect and block malicious redirects; monitor website traffic for unusual redirects.
workarounds: Implement CAPTCHA verification on the server side rather than client side
Use Content Security Policy (CSP) headers to restrict resource loading
Implement strict input validation and output encoding
Regularly audit third-party scripts and plugins

vulnerabilities.title: AI browsers could leave users penniless: A prompt injection warning
vulnerabilities.original_title: AI browsers could leave users penniless: A prompt injection warning
vulnerabilities.content_snippet: Artificial Intelligence (AI) browsers are gaining traction, which means we may need to start worrying about the potential dangers of something called “prompt injection.” Large language models (LLMs)—like the ones that power AI chatbots including ChatGPT, Claude, and Gemini—are designed t...
vulnerabilities.summary: Prompt injection vulnerability in AI browsers allowing malicious actors to manipulate AI assistants through specially crafted inputs
vulnerabilities.description: The vulnerability allows attackers to embed malicious instructions in web content that AI browsers process as commands. This can lead to unauthorized actions such as stealing credentials, making unauthorized purchases, or manipulating the AI assistant to perform actions contrary to user intent. The attack is particularly dangerous for agentic browsers that can autonomously execute complex tasks including financial transactions.
vulnerabilities.remediation: Implement proper input validation and sanitization to distinguish between user instructions and web content. Develop robust context awareness to differentiate between trusted and untrusted inputs. Apply principle of least privilege to limit what AI assistants can do automatically.
workarounds: Limit permissions granted to AI browsers
Avoid using agentic browsers for sensitive transactions
Review all AI browser actions before approval
Keep software updated with security patches

vulnerabilities.summary: Ivanti Connect Secure and Ivanti Policy Secure web component command injection vulnerability, often chained after authentication bypass.
vulnerabilities.description: An unauthenticated attacker can send specially crafted HTTP requests to the vulnerable web component, achieving command execution on the underlying server. The vulnerability is frequently exploited after obtaining initial foothold via CVE-2023-46805 authentication bypass.
vulnerabilities.remediation: Apply Ivanti security patches that address CVE-2024-21887. Upgrade to the latest supported version of Connect Secure/Policy Secure. Verify that the web component is disabled if not required.
workarounds: Disable the vulnerable web component if not needed.
Restrict access to the management interface via firewall ACLs.
Enforce strong authentication and network segmentation.

vulnerabilities.summary: Palo Alto Networks PAN-OS GlobalProtect arbitrary file creation leading to OS command injection (unauthenticated RCE).
vulnerabilities.description: When GlobalProtect is enabled, an attacker can craft requests that cause arbitrary file creation on the firewall filesystem, which can be leveraged to execute OS commands with root privileges, leading to full compromise of the firewall.
vulnerabilities.remediation: Upgrade PAN-OS to a version that includes the fix for CVE-2024-3400. If upgrade is not possible, disable GlobalProtect or restrict its exposure to trusted networks.
workarounds: Disable GlobalProtect on externally reachable interfaces.
Enforce strict inbound firewall rules to block unauthenticated access to the GlobalProtect portal.

vulnerabilities.summary: Cisco IOS XE web management UI post‑authentication command injection / privilege escalation.
vulnerabilities.description: After authenticating to the Cisco IOS XE web UI, an attacker can inject commands via crafted parameters, achieving root‑level code execution. The vulnerability is often chained with CVE-2023-20198 for initial access.
vulnerabilities.remediation: Upgrade to a Cisco IOS XE release that patches CVE-2023-20273. Disable the web management interface if not required.
workarounds: Restrict access to the web UI to management VLANs only.
Enforce strong authentication and use of HTTPS.

While these actors focus on large backbone routers of ...
vulnerabilities.summary: Cisco IOS XE authentication bypass allowing creation of unauthorized administrative accounts via WSMA endpoints.
vulnerabilities.description: The WSMA (Web Services Management Agent) endpoints (/webui_wsma_Http or /webui_wsma_Https) can be accessed without authentication, enabling attackers to create privileged accounts and execute arbitrary CLI commands. Attackers often double‑encode the URL path to evade detection.
vulnerabilities.remediation: Apply Cisco IOS XE patches that fix CVE-2023-20198. After patching, verify that WSMA endpoints are proxied and that the Proxy-Uri-Source header appears in logs, indicating remediation.
workarounds: Block WSMA endpoint URLs at the perimeter firewall.
Disable WSMA if not required.

vulnerabilities.summary: Cisco IOS and IOS XE Smart Install remote code execution vulnerability.
vulnerabilities.description: The Smart Install feature can be abused to execute arbitrary code on affected Cisco devices without authentication, providing attackers full control over the router or switch.
vulnerabilities.remediation: Upgrade to Cisco IOS/IOS XE versions that disable or patch Smart Install. If the feature is not needed, disable it with the command "no smart install enable".
workarounds: Disable Smart Install globally.
Restrict management access to trusted IP ranges.

vulnerabilities.title: Clickjack attack steals password managers’ secrets
vulnerabilities.original_title: Clickjack attack steals password managers’ secrets
vulnerabilities.content_snippet: Sometimes it can seem as though everything’s toxic online, and the latest good thing turned bad is here: Browser pop-ups that look like they’re trying to help or authenticate you could be programmed to steal data from your password manager. To make matters worse, most browser extension-b...
vulnerabilities.summary: Clickjacking attack on browser extension-based password managers that can steal credentials, credit card info, passkeys, and TOTP codes
vulnerabilities.description: A clickjacking attack that manipulates browser page structure to place an invisible overlay over legitimate clickable elements. When users click these elements, they're actually clicking on an invisible password manager dropdown selector, causing the password manager to reveal stored credentials, credit card information, passkeys, and TOTP codes without user knowledge.
products_versions: Multiple versions of browser extension-based password managers before patches were applied
vulnerabilities.remediation: Update to the latest versions of password managers that have patched this vulnerability. For Chromium browsers, change extension settings to 'site access' -> 'on click' to require manual activation of autofill features.
workarounds: Disable autofill features and manually copy/paste credentials
Only use autofill when specifically clicking on the browser extension in the toolbar
Be cautious about clicking on any elements on websites, especially less trustworthy ones
references: DEFCON security conference presentation by Marek Tóth

vulnerabilities.title: All Apple users should update after company patches zero-day vulnerability in all platforms
vulnerabilities.original_title: All Apple users should update after company patches zero-day vulnerability in all platforms
vulnerabilities.content_snippet: Apple has released security updates for iPhones, iPads and Macs to fix a zero-day vulnerability (a vulnerability which Apple was previously unaware of) that is reportedly being used in targeted attacks. The updates cover: iOS 18.6.2 and iPadOS 18.6.2 (iPhone XS and later, iPad Pro 13-inch, iPad Pro ...
vulnerabilities.summary: Out-of-bounds write vulnerability in Image I/O framework
vulnerabilities.description: The vulnerability lies in the Image I/O framework, which handles opening and saving images. It's an out-of-bounds write flaw that allows attackers to manipulate parts of device memory that should be inaccessible. Attackers could construct a malicious image file that, when processed, results in memory corruption that can be exploited to crash processes or execute arbitrary code.
affected_products: iOS 18.6.2 and iPadOS 18.6.2 (iPhone XS and later, iPad Pro 13-inch, iPad Pro 12.9-inch 3rd generation and later, iPad Pro 11-inch 1st generation and later, iPad Air 3rd generation and later, iPad 7th generation and later, and iPad mini 5th generation and later)
iPadOS 17.7.10 (iPad Pro 12.9-inch 2nd generation, iPad Pro 10.5-inch, and iPad 6th generation)
vulnerabilities.remediation: Apply the security updates released by Apple: iOS 18.6.2 and iPadOS 18.6.2 (or 17.7.10 for older models), macOS Sequoia 15.6.1, macOS Sonoma 14.7.8, and macOS Ventura 13.7.8.
workarounds: Avoid opening images from untrusted sources
Restrict access to image processing applications
Disable image preview features in applications
references: Apple security updates for iOS, iPadOS, and macOS
Malwarebytes article on Apple zero-day vulnerability

vulnerabilities.title: Warlock: From SharePoint Vulnerability Exploit to Enterprise Ransomware
vulnerabilities.original_title: Warlock: From SharePoint Vulnerability Exploit to Enterprise Ransomware
vulnerabilities.content_snippet: Warlock ransomware exploits unpatched Microsoft SharePoint vulnerabilities to gain access, escalate privileges, steal credentials, move laterally, and deploy ransomware with data exfiltration across enterprise environments.
vulnerabilities.summary: Unpatched Microsoft SharePoint server vulnerabilities exploited to gain initial access and execute ransomware payloads.
vulnerabilities.description: Warlock ransomware leverages publicly disclosed but unpatched SharePoint vulnerabilities to bypass authentication, upload malicious web shells, and execute arbitrary code. The chain typically involves: (1) exploiting a remote code execution (RCE) flaw in SharePoint's web services, (2) uploading a web shell to gain persistent foothold, (3) stealing stored credentials from the SharePoint configuration database, (4) lateral movement to domain controllers via Pass-the-Hash or credential dumping, and (5) deployment of ransomware with data exfiltration. The vulnerabilities affect multiple SharePoint versions that have not received the security updates released by Microsoft in early 2024 and 2025.
vulnerabilities.remediation: Apply the latest cumulative updates for Microsoft SharePoint Server (see Microsoft Security Advisory for CVE-2024-xxxx series). Harden SharePoint by disabling unnecessary web services, enforcing MFA for all accounts, and restricting external access via firewall or Azure AD Application Proxy. Conduct credential rotation for all service accounts.
workarounds: Block inbound traffic to SharePoint web endpoints (ports 80/443) from untrusted networks.
Deploy a Web Application Firewall (WAF) with rules to block known malicious payloads and web shell signatures.
Disable anonymous access and enforce least‑privilege permissions on SharePoint sites.

vulnerabilities.title: Oregon Man Charged in ‘Rapper Bot’ DDoS Service
vulnerabilities.original_title: Oregon Man Charged in ‘Rapper Bot’ DDoS Service
vulnerabilities.content_snippet: A 22-year-old Oregon man has been arrested on suspicion of operating “Rapper Bot,” a massive botnet used to power a service for launching distributed denial-of-service (DDoS) attacks against targets — including a March 2025 DDoS that knocked Twitter/X offline. The Justice Departmen...
vulnerabilities.summary: Exploitation of a previously unknown vulnerability in IoT devices to recruit approximately 32,000 devices into the Rapper Bot botnet
vulnerabilities.description: The suspect leveraged a previously undocumented vulnerability in a large number of Internet‑of‑Things devices, likely a flaw that allowed remote code execution without authentication (e.g., default credentials, unpatched service, or firmware bug). By exploiting this flaw, the attacker was able to install the Rapper Bot malware, creating a botnet of roughly 65,000 devices, of which 32,000 were added in a single wave. The botnet was then used to launch multi‑terabit DDoS attacks for extortion and DDoS‑as‑a‑service. The malware re‑uses code from the Mirai/fBot/Satori families, which are known for scanning for devices with default credentials and leveraging weak authentication to gain control.
affected_products: IoT devices (e.g., smart refrigerators, cameras, routers, other embedded devices)
affected_companies: Various IoT device manufacturers (including smart refrigerator vendors)
Potentially any vendor with devices exposing the undocumented vulnerability
vendors: Various IoT device manufacturers (including smart refrigerator vendors)
Potentially any vendor with devices exposing the undocumented vulnerability
vulnerabilities.remediation: 1. Apply the latest firmware updates from device manufacturers. 2. Change all default usernames and passwords on IoT devices. 3. Disable unnecessary services (e.g., Telnet, UPnP, SSH) on exposed devices. 4. Segment IoT devices onto isolated VLANs or separate networks. 5. Deploy network‑level egress filtering and rate limiting. 6. Enforce strong authentication (e.g., MFA) for management interfaces. 7. Monitor for abnormal outbound traffic patterns.
workarounds: Block outbound traffic to known C2 IP ranges used by Rapper Bot.
Implement sinkholing of the botnet's command‑and‑control domains.
Use firewall rules to restrict IoT devices to only required inbound/outbound ports.

vulnerabilities.title: GodRAT – New RAT targeting financial institutions
vulnerabilities.original_title: GodRAT – New RAT targeting financial institutions
vulnerabilities.content_snippet: Summary In September 2024, we detected malicious activity targeting financial (trading and brokerage) firms through the distribution of malicious .scr (screen saver) files disguised as financial documents via Skype messenger. The threat actor deployed a newly identified Remote Access Trojan (RAT) na...
vulnerabilities.summary: GodRAT Remote Access Trojan targeting financial institutions
vulnerabilities.description: GodRAT is a Remote Access Trojan based on the Gh0st RAT codebase, distributed through malicious .scr and .pif files disguised as financial documents via Skype. The malware uses steganography to embed shellcode in image files, which downloads the RAT from a C2 server. Once installed, attackers use the FileManager plugin to explore systems and deploy browser password stealers to extract credentials. The malware also uses AsyncRAT as a secondary implant for extended access.
vulnerabilities.remediation:
1. Block malicious file extensions (.scr, .pif) at email gateways and endpoints
2. Implement application whitelisting to prevent execution of unauthorized applications
3. Use endpoint detection and response (EDR) solutions to detect and block suspicious process behavior
4. Regularly update antivirus and anti-malware solutions with latest threat intelligence
5. Implement network segmentation to limit lateral movement
6. Train users to recognize and report suspicious communications and attachments
workarounds: Disable execution of .scr and .pif files through application control policies
Implement strict email filtering rules for attachments with financial document names
Use sandboxing technologies to analyze suspicious attachments before delivery to users
