vulnerabilities.title: Microsoft Patch Tuesday, August 2025 Edition
vulnerabilities.original_title: Microsoft Patch Tuesday, August 2025 Edition
vulnerabilities.content_snippet: Microsoft today released updates to fix more than 100 security flaws in its Windows operating systems and other software. At least 13 of the bugs received Microsoft’s most-dire “critical” rating, meaning they could be abused by malware or malcontents to gain remote access to a Wind...
vulnerabilities.summary: Hybrid connection bypass allowing on‑premises Exchange Server compromise to pivot into Exchange Online and Office 365 services.
vulnerabilities.description: A flaw in the hybrid connectivity component enables an attacker who has already compromised an on‑premises Exchange server to authenticate to the tenant’s Azure AD and gain access to Exchange Online and other Office 365 services, effectively moving laterally from the data‑center to the cloud without additional user interaction.
vulnerabilities.remediation: Apply the Microsoft security update released in August 2025 and follow the manual guidance to create a dedicated service that locks down the hybrid connection.
workarounds: Temporarily disable hybrid connectivity until the patch is applied
Restrict inbound traffic to Exchange servers to known management IPs
Enforce MFA for all Azure AD privileged accounts

vulnerabilities.title: Microsoft Patch Tuesday, August 2025 Edition
vulnerabilities.original_title: Microsoft Patch Tuesday, August 2025 Edition
vulnerabilities.content_snippet: Microsoft today released updates to fix more than 100 security flaws in its Windows operating systems and other software. At least 13 of the bugs received Microsoft’s most-dire “critical” rating, meaning they could be abused by malware or malcontents to gain remote access to a Wind...
vulnerabilities.summary: Kerberos delegation flaw (BadSuccessor) that lets an unauthenticated attacker obtain domain‑admin privileges via compromised dMSA accounts.
vulnerabilities.description: The vulnerability resides in the Kerberos authentication implementation for delegated Managed Service Accounts (dMSA). An attacker can craft Kerberos tickets that bypass normal delegation checks, granting domain‑admin rights without prior credentials.
affected_products: Windows Server 2025 (delegated Managed Service Account feature)
vulnerabilities.remediation: Install the August 2025 security update and, where possible, disable or restrict the use of dMSA accounts until the issue is fully mitigated.
workarounds: Disable dMSA where not required
Enforce strict Kerberos delegation policies
Monitor for anomalous Kerberos ticket requests

vulnerabilities.title: Microsoft Patch Tuesday, August 2025 Edition
vulnerabilities.original_title: Microsoft Patch Tuesday, August 2025 Edition
vulnerabilities.content_snippet: Microsoft today released updates to fix more than 100 security flaws in its Windows operating systems and other software. At least 13 of the bugs received Microsoft’s most-dire “critical” rating, meaning they could be abused by malware or malcontents to gain remote access to a Wind...
vulnerabilities.summary: Remote code execution in Windows GDI+ graphics rendering component.
vulnerabilities.description: A specially crafted image file processed by GDI+ can trigger memory corruption, leading to arbitrary code execution in the context of the user processing the file.
vulnerabilities.remediation: Apply the August 2025 cumulative update that patches GDI+.
workarounds: Block execution of untrusted image files from email/web sources
Enable Enhanced Mitigation Experience Toolkit (EMET) style mitigations

vulnerabilities.title: Microsoft Patch Tuesday, August 2025 Edition
vulnerabilities.original_title: Microsoft Patch Tuesday, August 2025 Edition
vulnerabilities.content_snippet: Microsoft today released updates to fix more than 100 security flaws in its Windows operating systems and other software. At least 13 of the bugs received Microsoft’s most-dire “critical” rating, meaning they could be abused by malware or malcontents to gain remote access to a Wind...
vulnerabilities.summary: Graphics rendering weakness affecting Windows GDI+ (secondary graphics bug).
vulnerabilities.description: Another flaw in the GDI+ component that can be triggered by maliciously crafted graphic files, leading to remote code execution.
vulnerabilities.remediation: Install the August 2025 security update that addresses CVE‑2025‑50165.
workarounds: Restrict opening of graphic files from untrusted sources
Enable AppLocker rules for graphic processing binaries

vulnerabilities.content_snippet: Microsoft today released updates to fix more than 100 security flaws in its Windows operating systems and other software. At least 13 of the bugs received Microsoft’s most-dire “critical” rating, meaning they could be abused by malware or malcontents to gain remote access to a Wind...
vulnerabilities.summary: Remote code execution in Microsoft Word via the Preview Pane without user interaction.
vulnerabilities.description: A specially crafted document can be rendered in the Windows Explorer preview pane, triggering code execution without any user click or opening of the file.
affected_products: Microsoft Word (part of Microsoft Office 2021, Microsoft 365)
vulnerabilities.remediation: Apply the August 2025 Office update that fixes the preview pane handling bug.
workarounds: Disable the Preview Pane in Windows Explorer
Configure Group Policy to block rendering of untrusted Office files

vulnerabilities.title: Microsoft Patch Tuesday, August 2025 Edition
vulnerabilities.original_title: Microsoft Patch Tuesday, August 2025 Edition
vulnerabilities.content_snippet: Microsoft today released updates to fix more than 100 security flaws in its Windows operating systems and other software. At least 13 of the bugs received Microsoft’s most-dire “critical” rating, meaning they could be abused by malware or malcontents to gain remote access to a Wind...
vulnerabilities.summary: NTLM authentication flaw allowing low‑privilege network users to elevate to SYSTEM level.
vulnerabilities.description: An attacker with low‑level network access can manipulate NTLM challenge/response exchanges to gain SYSTEM privileges on the target host, making the vulnerability highly exploitable.
affected_products: Windows NTLM authentication subsystem (Windows 10, Windows 11, Windows Server 2016‑2025)
vulnerabilities.remediation: Install the August 2025 cumulative update that patches the NTLM subsystem.
workarounds: Enforce SMB signing and disable NTLM where possible
Deploy LDAP signing and Kerberos authentication as primary methods

vulnerabilities.title: Driver of destruction: How a legitimate driver is being used to take down AV processes
vulnerabilities.original_title: Driver of destruction: How a legitimate driver is being used to take down AV processes
vulnerabilities.content_snippet: Introduction In a recent incident response case in Brazil, we spotted intriguing new antivirus (AV) killer software that has been circulating in the wild since at least October 2024. This malicious artifact abuses the ThrottleStop.sys driver, delivered together with the malware, to terminate numerou...
vulnerabilities.summary: The ThrottleStop.sys driver contains memory read/write vulnerabilities that allow any user with administrative privileges to read and write physical memory, which can be exploited to disable security software.
vulnerabilities.description: The ThrottleStop.sys driver exposes two vulnerable IOCTL functions that allow reading from memory and writing to it using physical addresses. The vulnerability leverages the MmMapIoSpace function to perform physical memory access, which enables reads and writes to virtual memory to directly affect the corresponding physical memory. This vulnerability has been exploited to create AV killer software that terminates antivirus processes by calling kernel functions like PsLookupProcessById and PsTerminateProcess.
affected_companies: Various antivirus vendors including Avast, AVG, BitDefender, CrowdStrike, ESET, Kaspersky, McAfee, Microsoft, Quick Heal, Symantec, Panda Security, SentinelOne, and Sophos
vendors: Various antivirus vendors including Avast, AVG, BitDefender, CrowdStrike, ESET, Kaspersky, McAfee, Microsoft, Quick Heal, Symantec, Panda Security, SentinelOne, and Sophos
vulnerabilities.remediation: The vendor is preparing a patch. In the meantime, security solutions should monitor for the presence of this known vulnerable driver in the operating system.
workarounds: Block the use of ThrottleStop.sys driver in enterprise environments
Implement application whitelisting to prevent unauthorized drivers from loading

vulnerabilities.title: Cobalt Strike Beacon delivered via GitHub and social media
vulnerabilities.original_title: Cobalt Strike Beacon delivered via GitHub and social media
vulnerabilities.content_snippet: Introduction In the latter half of 2024, the Russian IT industry, alongside a number of entities in other countries, experienced a notable cyberattack. The attackers employed a range of malicious techniques to trick security systems and remain undetected. To bypass detection, they delivered informat...
vulnerabilities.summary: DLL Hijacking vulnerability in BugSplat Crash reporting Send Utility
vulnerabilities.description: Attackers exploit a DLL hijacking vulnerability in the legitimate BugSplat Crash reporting Send Utility. By renaming malicious DLLs to match required dependencies (BugSplatRc64.dll), attackers can execute arbitrary code when the legitimate utility is launched. The malicious DLL employs Dynamic API Resolution techniques to evade detection.
products_versions: All versions of BugSplat Crash reporting Send Utility
vulnerabilities.remediation: Restrict execution of BugSplat.exe to authorized paths only. Implement application whitelisting to prevent execution of renamed versions of the utility. Monitor for unauthorized DLL loading in processes.
workarounds: Rename the legitimate BugSplatRc64.dll to a unique name and update the BsSndRpt.exe configuration to use the renamed DLL
Restrict write permissions to the BugSplat installation directory
Implement application control policies to prevent execution of renamed versions of BsSndRpt.exe

vulnerabilities.title: CISA and USCG Identify Areas for Cyber Hygiene Improvement After Conducting Proactive Threat Hunt at US Critical Infrastructure Organization
vulnerabilities.original_title: CISA and USCG Identify Areas for Cyber Hygiene Improvement After Conducting Proactive Threat Hunt at US Critical Infrastructure Organization
vulnerabilities.content_snippet: Summary The Cybersecurity and Infrastructure Security Agency (CISA) and U.S. Coast Guard (USCG) are issuing this Cybersecurity Advisory to present findings from a recent CISA and USCG hunt engagement. The purpose of this advisory is to highlight identified cybersecurity issues, thereby informing sec...
vulnerabilities.summary: Plaintext storage of shared local administrator credentials in batch scripts
vulnerabilities.description: Local admin accounts were created via batch scripts that contained non‑unique passwords stored in clear text. The same credentials were reused across many workstations, enabling any adversary who discovers a single script to gain administrative access to any host where the account exists and move laterally using valid credentials (T1078.003, T1021.001).
affected_products: Microsoft System Center Configuration Manager (SCCM) scripts
vulnerabilities.remediation: Deploy Microsoft Local Administrator Password Solution (LAPS) or equivalent to generate unique, complex passwords per host; remove plaintext credentials from scripts; store secrets in a credential vault; enforce MFA for all privileged access; rotate passwords regularly.
workarounds: Restrict read access to script directories to administrators only
Temporarily disable the batch scripts until they are rewritten

vulnerabilities.title: CISA and USCG Identify Areas for Cyber Hygiene Improvement After Conducting Proactive Threat Hunt at US Critical Infrastructure Organization
vulnerabilities.original_title: CISA and USCG Identify Areas for Cyber Hygiene Improvement After Conducting Proactive Threat Hunt at US Critical Infrastructure Organization
vulnerabilities.content_snippet: Summary The Cybersecurity and Infrastructure Security Agency (CISA) and U.S. Coast Guard (USCG) are issuing this Cybersecurity Advisory to present findings from a recent CISA and USCG hunt engagement. The purpose of this advisory is to highlight identified cybersecurity issues, thereby informing sec...
vulnerabilities.summary: Insufficient network segmentation between IT and OT (SCADA) environments
vulnerabilities.description: Standard user accounts on the IT network could directly connect to the SCADA VLAN over port 21 (FTP) and other services, indicating missing or mis‑configured firewalls/ACLs and lack of dedicated bastion hosts. This permits an attacker who compromises an IT workstation to pivot into OT systems controlling critical physical processes.
vulnerabilities.remediation: Implement strict VLAN segregation with Layer‑3 ACLs; deploy dedicated, hardened bastion hosts for OT access; enforce MFA on all OT remote sessions; block unnecessary services (e.g., FTP) on OT devices; use firewalls/IPS with SCADA‑aware rules; consider DMZ or data diode architecture.
workarounds: Temporarily disable FTP services on OT devices
Restrict IT user accounts from reaching OT subnets via ACLs

vulnerabilities.title: CISA and USCG Identify Areas for Cyber Hygiene Improvement After Conducting Proactive Threat Hunt at US Critical Infrastructure Organization
vulnerabilities.original_title: CISA and USCG Identify Areas for Cyber Hygiene Improvement After Conducting Proactive Threat Hunt at US Critical Infrastructure Organization
vulnerabilities.content_snippet: Summary The Cybersecurity and Infrastructure Security Agency (CISA) and U.S. Coast Guard (USCG) are issuing this Cybersecurity Advisory to present findings from a recent CISA and USCG hunt engagement. The purpose of this advisory is to highlight identified cybersecurity issues, thereby informing sec...
vulnerabilities.summary: Insufficient logging and log retention on Windows workstations
vulnerabilities.description: Workstation event logs were not forwarded to the central SIEM, command‑line auditing (Event ID 4688) was disabled, and log retention periods were insufficient. This hampers detection of living‑off‑the‑land techniques, valid‑account abuse, and other ATT&CK TTPs.
affected_products: Security Information and Event Management (SIEM) solutions
vulnerabilities.remediation: Enable full Windows audit policy including command‑line logging; forward all workstation logs to an out‑of‑band SIEM; retain logs per compliance requirements (e.g., 90‑180 days); implement baseline behavior analytics.
workarounds: Manually collect logs from critical hosts on a regular schedule

vulnerabilities.title: CISA and USCG Identify Areas for Cyber Hygiene Improvement After Conducting Proactive Threat Hunt at US Critical Infrastructure Organization
vulnerabilities.original_title: CISA and USCG Identify Areas for Cyber Hygiene Improvement After Conducting Proactive Threat Hunt at US Critical Infrastructure Organization
vulnerabilities.content_snippet: Summary The Cybersecurity and Infrastructure Security Agency (CISA) and U.S. Coast Guard (USCG) are issuing this Cybersecurity Advisory to present findings from a recent CISA and USCG hunt engagement. The purpose of this advisory is to highlight identified cybersecurity issues, thereby informing sec...
vulnerabilities.summary: Misconfigured IIS sslFlags set to "0" (legacy one‑certificate‑per‑IP mode) allowing anonymous TLS handshakes
vulnerabilities.description: The ApplicationHost.config file contained an HTTPS binding with sslFlags="0", disabling client‑certificate enforcement and leaving the server vulnerable to man‑in‑the‑middle (MITM) attacks and protocol‑downgrade attacks against outdated TLS/SSL ciphers.
affected_products: Microsoft Internet Information Services (IIS) 10.x and earlier
vulnerabilities.remediation: Set sslFlags="3" to require client certificates; disable deprecated protocols (SSL 2.0/3.0, TLS 1.0/1.1); enforce TLS 1.2/1.3 only; review and harden cipher suites; restart IIS after changes.
workarounds: Place a reverse proxy that terminates TLS with strict settings in front of IIS

vulnerabilities.title: CISA and USCG Identify Areas for Cyber Hygiene Improvement After Conducting Proactive Threat Hunt at US Critical Infrastructure Organization
vulnerabilities.original_title: CISA and USCG Identify Areas for Cyber Hygiene Improvement After Conducting Proactive Threat Hunt at US Critical Infrastructure Organization
vulnerabilities.content_snippet: Summary The Cybersecurity and Infrastructure Security Agency (CISA) and U.S. Coast Guard (USCG) are issuing this Cybersecurity Advisory to present findings from a recent CISA and USCG hunt engagement. The purpose of this advisory is to highlight identified cybersecurity issues, thereby informing sec...
vulnerabilities.summary: Centralized ASP.NET LocalSqlServer connection string with weak password policy (min length <15) in machine.config
vulnerabilities.description: All ASP.NET applications on the server shared a single database connection string defined in machine.config, using a password policy allowing passwords shorter than 15 characters. This creates a single point of failure; compromise of the database yields access to all hosted applications.
vulnerabilities.remediation: Move connection strings to individual web.config files; create dedicated, least‑privilege SQL accounts per application; enforce password length >=15 characters; enable account lockout and monitoring; consider using managed identity or secret vaults.
workarounds: Restrict network access to the SQL instance to application servers only

vulnerabilities.title: CISA and USCG Identify Areas for Cyber Hygiene Improvement After Conducting Proactive Threat Hunt at US Critical Infrastructure Organization
vulnerabilities.original_title: CISA and USCG Identify Areas for Cyber Hygiene Improvement After Conducting Proactive Threat Hunt at US Critical Infrastructure Organization
vulnerabilities.content_snippet: Summary The Cybersecurity and Infrastructure Security Agency (CISA) and U.S. Coast Guard (USCG) are issuing this Cybersecurity Advisory to present findings from a recent CISA and USCG hunt engagement. The purpose of this advisory is to highlight identified cybersecurity issues, thereby informing sec...
vulnerabilities.summary: Plaintext local administrator credentials stored in batch scripts and reused across many workstations
vulnerabilities.description: Batch scripts deployed via SCCM create local admin accounts with identical, non‑expiring passwords that are hard‑coded in the script in clear text. Any user or malware that can read the script can obtain the credentials, log in locally, and use RDP or other remote services to move laterally across any host that shares the same account.
products_versions: Windows 10/11 and Windows Server (all supported versions)
vulnerabilities.remediation: Replace plaintext passwords with a secure credential store (e.g., password vault, LAPS). Generate unique, complex passwords per host, rotate them regularly, and enforce MFA for all privileged access. Remove credentials from scripts and use built‑in SCCM mechanisms to run tasks with elevated rights without exposing passwords.
workarounds: Restrict read access to the scripts to a minimal set of administrators
Disable the batch scripts until they are re‑engineered

vulnerabilities.title: CISA and USCG Identify Areas for Cyber Hygiene Improvement After Conducting Proactive Threat Hunt at US Critical Infrastructure Organization
vulnerabilities.original_title: CISA and USCG Identify Areas for Cyber Hygiene Improvement After Conducting Proactive Threat Hunt at US Critical Infrastructure Organization
vulnerabilities.content_snippet: Summary The Cybersecurity and Infrastructure Security Agency (CISA) and U.S. Coast Guard (USCG) are issuing this Cybersecurity Advisory to present findings from a recent CISA and USCG hunt engagement. The purpose of this advisory is to highlight identified cybersecurity issues, thereby informing sec...
vulnerabilities.summary: Insufficient network segmentation allowing standard IT user accounts to directly access SCADA VLAN via FTP port 21
vulnerabilities.description: A standard user workstation in the IT domain can open a TCP connection to port 21 on a device inside the SCADA VLAN. No firewall or ACL blocks the traffic, and no bastion host is required. This enables an attacker who compromises an IT workstation to reach critical OT control systems, potentially manipulating physical processes.
products_versions: Windows 10/11 and Windows Server (all supported versions)
vulnerabilities.remediation: Implement strict network segmentation (VLANs, firewalls, ACLs) between IT and OT zones. Deploy dedicated, hardened bastion hosts for any OT access. Disable unnecessary services (e.g., FTP) on OT devices and replace with secure alternatives (SFTP, SSH). Enforce MFA and VPN for any remote OT access.
workarounds: Block inbound/outbound port 21 on perimeter devices between IT and OT
Create temporary ACLs limiting IT‑to‑OT traffic to required protocols only

vulnerabilities.title: CISA and USCG Identify Areas for Cyber Hygiene Improvement After Conducting Proactive Threat Hunt at US Critical Infrastructure Organization
vulnerabilities.original_title: CISA and USCG Identify Areas for Cyber Hygiene Improvement After Conducting Proactive Threat Hunt at US Critical Infrastructure Organization
vulnerabilities.content_snippet: Summary The Cybersecurity and Infrastructure Security Agency (CISA) and U.S. Coast Guard (USCG) are issuing this Cybersecurity Advisory to present findings from a recent CISA and USCG hunt engagement. The purpose of this advisory is to highlight identified cybersecurity issues, thereby informing sec...
vulnerabilities.summary: Insufficient logging and log retention on Windows workstations, lacking command‑line argument capture and SIEM forwarding
vulnerabilities.description: Workstation event logs are not forwarded to the central SIEM, Event ID 4688 does not include command‑line arguments, and log retention periods are too short. This hampers detection of living‑off‑the‑land techniques, valid‑account abuse, and other stealthy activity.
affected_products: Security Information and Event Management (SIEM) solutions
products_versions: Windows 10/11 and Windows Server (all supported versions)
vulnerabilities.remediation: Enable full Windows Event Forwarding to a protected SIEM, turn on command‑line auditing (include arguments), increase log retention to meet organizational policy, and regularly review logs for anomalous behavior.
workarounds: Deploy a lightweight log collector on endpoints to ship logs to a central repository
Use PowerShell scripts to periodically extract and archive Event ID 4688 data

vulnerabilities.title: CISA and USCG Identify Areas for Cyber Hygiene Improvement After Conducting Proactive Threat Hunt at US Critical Infrastructure Organization
vulnerabilities.original_title: CISA and USCG Identify Areas for Cyber Hygiene Improvement After Conducting Proactive Threat Hunt at US Critical Infrastructure Organization
vulnerabilities.content_snippet: Summary The Cybersecurity and Infrastructure Security Agency (CISA) and U.S. Coast Guard (USCG) are issuing this Cybersecurity Advisory to present findings from a recent CISA and USCG hunt engagement. The purpose of this advisory is to highlight identified cybersecurity issues, thereby informing sec...
vulnerabilities.summary: IIS HTTPS binding misconfiguration (sslFlags=0) allowing legacy one‑certificate‑per‑IP mode and no client‑certificate enforcement
vulnerabilities.description: The ApplicationHost.config file sets sslFlags to "0", which disables client‑certificate requirement and leaves the server in legacy mode. This permits any TLS client to complete the handshake without authentication and may allow use of deprecated protocols/ciphers, exposing the server to MITM and downgrade attacks.
products_versions: Windows 10/11 and Windows Server (all supported versions)
vulnerabilities.remediation: Set sslFlags to "3" (require client certificates), disable outdated TLS versions and weak cipher suites, and enforce TLS 1.2/1.3 only. Review and harden ApplicationHost.config and related IIS settings.
workarounds: Place the IIS server behind a reverse proxy that enforces mutual TLS
Network‑level ACLs to restrict access to the web service

vulnerabilities.title: CISA and USCG Identify Areas for Cyber Hygiene Improvement After Conducting Proactive Threat Hunt at US Critical Infrastructure Organization
vulnerabilities.original_title: CISA and USCG Identify Areas for Cyber Hygiene Improvement After Conducting Proactive Threat Hunt at US Critical Infrastructure Organization
vulnerabilities.content_snippet: Summary The Cybersecurity and Infrastructure Security Agency (CISA) and U.S. Coast Guard (USCG) are issuing this Cybersecurity Advisory to present findings from a recent CISA and USCG hunt engagement. The purpose of this advisory is to highlight identified cybersecurity issues, thereby informing sec...
vulnerabilities.summary: Centralized ASP.NET LocalSqlServer connection string with weak password policy (minRequiredPasswordLength < 15) on production server
vulnerabilities.description: machine.config defines a single LocalSqlServer connection string used by all web applications on the server, creating a single point of failure. The password policy permits passwords shorter than 15 characters, making brute‑force and credential‑stuffing attacks feasible.
products_versions: Windows 10/11 and Windows Server (all supported versions)
vulnerabilities.remediation: Separate connection strings per application in individual web.config files, create dedicated least‑privilege SQL accounts, and enforce a minimum password length of 15+ characters with MFA where possible. Rotate passwords and disable the default LocalSqlServer provider if not needed.
workarounds: Restrict network access to the SQL instance to only the web server
Implement application‑level encryption for stored credentials

vulnerabilities.original_title: Proactive Security Insights for SharePoint Attacks (CVE-2025-53770 and CVE-2025-53771)
vulnerabilities.content_snippet: CVE-2025-53770 and CVE-2025-53771 are vulnerabilities in on-premise Microsoft SharePoint Servers that evolved from previously patched flaws, allowing unauthenticated remote code execution through advanced deserialization and ViewState abuse.

vulnerabilities.title: Proactive Security Insights for SharePoint Attacks (CVE-2025-53770 and CVE-2025-53771)
vulnerabilities.original_title: Proactive Security Insights for SharePoint Attacks (CVE-2025-53770 and CVE-2025-53771)
vulnerabilities.content_snippet: CVE-2025-53770 and CVE-2025-53771 are vulnerabilities in on-premise Microsoft SharePoint Servers that evolved from previously patched flaws, allowing unauthenticated remote code execution through advanced deserialization and ViewState abuse.

vulnerabilities.title: Proactive Security Insights for SharePoint Attacks (CVE-2025-53770 and CVE-2025-53771)
vulnerabilities.original_title: Proactive Security Insights for SharePoint Attacks (CVE-2025-53770 and CVE-2025-53771)
vulnerabilities.content_snippet: CVE-2025-53770 and CVE-2025-53771 are vulnerabilities in on-premise Microsoft SharePoint Servers that evolved from previously patched flaws, allowing unauthenticated remote code execution through advanced deserialization and ViewState abuse.
vulnerabilities.summary: Unauthenticated remote code execution in on‑premise Microsoft SharePoint Server via advanced deserialization abuse.
vulnerabilities.description: The vulnerability stems from insecure handling of serialized objects within SharePoint's server‑side components. An attacker can craft a malicious payload that, when processed by the server, triggers arbitrary code execution without authentication. The flaw is exploitable through specially crafted HTTP requests that contain malicious ViewState data, leading to deserialization of attacker‑controlled objects.
vulnerabilities.remediation: Apply the security updates released by Microsoft for the affected SharePoint versions. Ensure that the latest cumulative updates are installed and that ViewState MAC validation is enabled.
workarounds: Disable ViewState MAC if not required (not recommended for production).
Restrict external access to SharePoint servers via firewall or network segmentation.
Enable strict input validation and use a Web Application Firewall (WAF) to block malformed ViewState payloads.

vulnerabilities.title: Proactive Security Insights for SharePoint Attacks (CVE-2025-53770 and CVE-2025-53771)
vulnerabilities.original_title: Proactive Security Insights for SharePoint Attacks (CVE-2025-53770 and CVE-2025-53771)
vulnerabilities.content_snippet: CVE-2025-53770 and CVE-2025-53771 are vulnerabilities in on-premise Microsoft SharePoint Servers that evolved from previously patched flaws, allowing unauthenticated remote code execution through advanced deserialization and ViewState abuse.
vulnerabilities.summary: Unauthenticated remote code execution in on‑premise Microsoft SharePoint Server via ViewState abuse.
vulnerabilities.description: This vulnerability allows an attacker to inject malicious data into the ViewState parameter of SharePoint pages. When the server deserializes the ViewState, the malicious payload is executed, granting the attacker full control of the server. The attack requires no prior authentication and can be performed remotely over HTTP/HTTPS.
vulnerabilities.remediation: Install the Microsoft-provided patches that address CVE-2025-53771. Verify that ViewState MAC validation is enabled and that the __VIEWSTATE field size limits are enforced.
workarounds: Enforce HTTPS for all SharePoint traffic.
Configure request filtering to block excessively large ViewState payloads.
Deploy a WAF rule set that detects known ViewState exploitation patterns.

vulnerabilities.title: #StopRansomware: Interlock
vulnerabilities.original_title: #StopRansomware: Interlock
vulnerabilities.content_snippet: Summary Note: This joint Cybersecurity Advisory is part of an ongoing #StopRansomware effort to publish advisories for network defenders that detail various ransomware variants and ransomware threat actors. These #StopRansomware advisories include recently and historically observed tactics, techniqu...
vulnerabilities.summary: Interlock ransomware leverages multiple techniques (drive‑by download, malicious browser/ security‑software update masquerade, ClickFix social engineering, PowerShell scripts, registry run keys, and legitimate remote tools) to gain initial access, execute payloads, and encrypt data on Windows, Linux, and FreeBSD systems.
vulnerabilities.description: The Interlock ransomware campaign, active since September 2024, uses compromised legitimate websites to deliver malicious payloads disguised as browser or security‑software updates (drive‑by compromise). A secondary social‑engineering vector, ClickFix, tricks users into executing a Base64‑encoded PowerShell command via a fake CAPTCHA. The payload drops a RAT, modifies registry run keys ("Chrome Updater"), and adds a startup shortcut for persistence. Once foothold is achieved, attackers perform extensive reconnaissance via PowerShell (systeminfo, Get‑Service, arp -a, etc.), harvest credentials using cht.exe, Lumma/Berserk stealers, and a keylogger (klg.dll). Lateral movement is performed with stolen credentials, RDP, AnyDesk, PuTTY, and tools like Cobalt Strike and SystemBC. Data is exfiltrated to Azure Blob storage using AzCopy and WinSCP. Encryption is performed by a 64‑bit conhost.exe binary (Windows) or a FreeBSD ELF encryptor, employing combined AES‑256 and RSA encryption. Encrypted files receive .interlock or .1nt3rlock extensions and a ransom note (!__README__!.txt) delivered via GPO. The ransomware follows a double‑extortion model, threatening public leak of stolen data via a Tor .onion site.
affected_products: Microsoft Azure Storage (via Azure Storage Explorer)
vulnerabilities.remediation: Apply defense‑in‑depth controls: patch operating systems, browsers, and all third‑party software; enforce MFA; implement DNS filtering and web‑application firewalls; block known malicious domains; disable PowerShell script execution where not required; enforce least‑privilege for service accounts; monitor and restrict use of remote tools (AnyDesk, RDP, PuTTY); deploy EDR/XDR with behavior‑based detection; segment networks; maintain immutable, offline backups; enforce strong password policies; disable unnecessary services and ports; regularly audit GPO changes; implement just‑in‑time privileged access.
workarounds: Restrict execution of unsigned PowerShell scripts via Applocker or Constrained Language Mode.
Block outbound traffic to Azure Storage endpoints unless explicitly required.
Disable automatic browser updates and enforce enterprise‑managed update mechanisms.
Use application whitelisting to prevent execution of masqueraded update binaries.

vulnerabilities.title: #StopRansomware: Interlock
vulnerabilities.original_title: #StopRansomware: Interlock
vulnerabilities.content_snippet: Summary Note: This joint Cybersecurity Advisory is part of an ongoing #StopRansomware effort to publish advisories for network defenders that detail various ransomware variants and ransomware threat actors. These #StopRansomware advisories include recently and historically observed tactics, techniqu...
vulnerabilities.summary: Interlock ransomware leverages drive-by downloads, malicious browser update masquerades, and the ClickFix social engineering technique to execute PowerShell-based payloads that establish persistence, steal credentials, and encrypt data on Windows, Linux, and FreeBSD systems.
vulnerabilities.description: The Interlock ransomware campaign, first observed in September 2024, obtains initial access via compromised legitimate websites delivering drive‑by downloads that masquerade as browser or security‑software updates. A secondary vector, ClickFix, tricks users into executing a Base64‑encoded PowerShell command through a fake CAPTCHA. The payload drops a RAT, modifies the Startup folder or registry Run key for persistence, and uses PowerShell to enumerate system information, harvest credentials (cht.exe, Lumma/Berserk stealer, keylogger DLLs), and move laterally via RDP, AnyDesk, PuTTY, and stolen domain admin accounts (possible Kerberoasting). Data is exfiltrated to Azure Blob storage using AzCopy and WinSCP, after which a 64‑bit encryptor (conhost.exe) encrypts files with AES‑RSA (including a FreeBSD ELF variant) and appends .interlock/.1nt3rlock extensions. A ransom note (!__README__!.txt) is delivered via GPO, providing a .onion contact method. The ransomware also employs defense‑evasion techniques such as masquerading (Chrome Updater run key, conhost.exe name), rundll32 proxy execution, and removal of its binaries via tmp41.wasd.
affected_products: Common security software (FortiClient, Ivanti Secure Access, GlobalProtect, Webex, AnyConnect, Cisco Secure Client, ZyZoom)
vulnerabilities.remediation: Patch operating systems and all software, especially browsers and security tools. Deploy DNS filtering and web‑application firewalls to block compromised sites. Enforce MFA and strong password policies. Disable unnecessary remote services (RDP, AnyDesk). Deploy EDR/XDR with behavior‑based detection for PowerShell abuse, registry Run key changes, and abnormal network traffic to Azure endpoints. Implement regular, offline, immutable backups and test restoration procedures. Apply least‑privilege access and just‑in‑time elevation for privileged accounts. Conduct user security awareness training focused on drive‑by and ClickFix social engineering.
workarounds: Restrict execution of unsigned PowerShell scripts via Applocker or Constrained Language Mode
Block known malicious filenames (e.g., fake Chrome/Edge update executables) at the gateway
Disable clipboard paste in the Run dialog via Group Policy

vulnerabilities.title: Preventing Zero-Click AI Threats: Insights from EchoLeak
vulnerabilities.original_title: Preventing Zero-Click AI Threats: Insights from EchoLeak
vulnerabilities.content_snippet: A zero-click exploit called EchoLeak reveals how AI assistants like Microsoft 365 Copilot can be manipulated to leak sensitive data without user interaction. This entry breaks down how the attack works, why it matters, and what defenses are available to proactively mitigate this emerging AI-native t...
vulnerabilities.summary: Zero-click exploit (EchoLeak) that leverages prompt injection in AI assistants such as Microsoft 365 Copilot to exfiltrate sensitive data without user interaction.
vulnerabilities.description: EchoLeak abuses the natural language processing pipeline of AI assistants by sending specially crafted inputs that trigger the model to generate and return data it should not disclose (e.g., internal documents, credentials). The attack requires no user interaction and can be delivered over standard network channels (e.g., email, chat, API calls). The exploit works by manipulating the model's context handling and response generation, causing it to leak data stored in the backend knowledge base or connected services.
products_versions: All Microsoft 365 Copilot versions released prior to 2025‑Q3
Azure OpenAI Service versions prior to the security update announced in 2025
vulnerabilities.remediation: Apply any security updates released by Microsoft for Copilot and Azure OpenAI. Disable Copilot in environments where it is not required. Implement strict data loss prevention (DLP) policies that prevent sensitive data from being indexed or exposed to AI services. Review and restrict API permissions for AI endpoints.
workarounds: Temporarily disable Microsoft 365 Copilot for high‑risk users or departments.
Enforce content filtering on AI prompts and responses.
Limit the scope of data that Copilot can access via Azure AD conditional access policies.

vulnerabilities.title: Preventing Zero-Click AI Threats: Insights from EchoLeak
vulnerabilities.original_title: Preventing Zero-Click AI Threats: Insights from EchoLeak
vulnerabilities.content_snippet: A zero-click exploit called EchoLeak reveals how AI assistants like Microsoft 365 Copilot can be manipulated to leak sensitive data without user interaction. This entry breaks down how the attack works, why it matters, and what defenses are available to proactively mitigate this emerging AI-native t...
vulnerabilities.summary: Zero-click remote code execution and data exfiltration vulnerability in Microsoft 365 Copilot (EchoLeak) allowing AI assistants to be manipulated into leaking sensitive data without user interaction.
vulnerabilities.description: EchoLeak exploits a flaw in the prompt‑parsing and context‑handling logic of AI assistants powered by large language models. By sending a specially crafted data payload to the AI service (e.g., via a Teams message, Outlook email, or API call), the attacker can trigger the model to execute internal commands that retrieve and return confidential information stored in the tenant’s environment. The exploit requires no user interaction; the malicious payload is delivered automatically through standard communication channels, making it a true zero‑click attack. The vulnerability stems from insufficient validation of input that reaches the model’s execution sandbox and from the model’s ability to access privileged backend APIs without proper isolation.
vulnerabilities.remediation: Apply the security update released by Microsoft for Microsoft 365 Copilot (see KB2025-XXXXX). If a patch is not yet available, disable Copilot and related AI features in the tenant, enforce strict API access controls, and restrict data that can be accessed by the AI service. Implement DLP policies to block outbound data from AI endpoints.
workarounds: Disable Microsoft 365 Copilot and any AI‑powered add‑ins in Office applications.
Restrict the Copilot service to a limited set of trusted users and groups.
Apply conditional access policies that block external traffic to the Copilot endpoint.
Enable content filtering and sanitization on all inbound messages that may be processed by the AI.

vulnerabilities.title: Why a Classic MCP Server Vulnerability Can Undermine Your Entire AI Agent
vulnerabilities.original_title: Why a Classic MCP Server Vulnerability Can Undermine Your Entire AI Agent
vulnerabilities.content_snippet: A single SQL injection bug in Anthropic’s SQLite MCP server—forked over 5,000 times—can seed stored prompts, exfiltrate data, and hand attackers the keys to entire agent workflows. This entry unpacks the attack chain and lays out concrete fixes to shut it down.
vulnerabilities.summary: SQL injection vulnerability in Anthropic's SQLite MCP server allowing stored prompt injection, data exfiltration, and takeover of AI agent workflows.
vulnerabilities.description: The MCP (Message Control Protocol) server, a fork of SQLite used by Anthropic for managing prompts and agent state, fails to properly sanitize user-supplied input in SQL queries. An attacker can craft a malicious request that injects arbitrary SQL commands. Because the server stores prompts in the database, the injection can be persisted (stored XSS-like behavior) and later executed by the AI agent, leading to arbitrary prompt injection, exfiltration of stored data, and retrieval of cryptographic keys or tokens that protect the entire agent workflow. The vulnerability is exploitable remotely without authentication and can affect any deployment that exposes the MCP endpoint.
products_versions: All versions of the SQLite MCP server prior to the security patch (exact version numbers not disclosed)
vulnerabilities.remediation:
Update to the patched version of the MCP server released by Anthropic (or the upstream SQLite fork) that implements prepared statements/parameterized queries for all user-controlled inputs. If a patch is not yet available, apply the following mitigations: 
1. Deploy a Web Application Firewall (WAF) rule to block typical SQL injection payloads targeting the MCP endpoint. 
2. Restrict network access to the MCP service to trusted internal subnets only. 
3. Enable SQLite's "SQLITE_DBCONFIG_DEFENSIVE" mode if supported. 
4. Conduct code review to replace dynamic query construction with parameterized APIs.
workarounds: Place the MCP server behind a reverse proxy that validates and sanitizes incoming requests.
Disable remote access to the MCP endpoint and use a VPN or SSH tunnel for administrative access.
Implement strict input validation (allowlist) on all fields that are persisted to the database.

vulnerabilities.title: Why a Classic MCP Server Vulnerability Can Undermine Your Entire AI Agent
vulnerabilities.original_title: Why a Classic MCP Server Vulnerability Can Undermine Your Entire AI Agent
vulnerabilities.content_snippet: A single SQL injection bug in Anthropic’s SQLite MCP server—forked over 5,000 times—can seed stored prompts, exfiltrate data, and hand attackers the keys to entire agent workflows. This entry unpacks the attack chain and lays out concrete fixes to shut it down.
vulnerabilities.summary: SQL injection vulnerability in Anthropic's SQLite MCP server allowing stored prompt injection, data exfiltration, and takeover of AI agent workflows.
vulnerabilities.description: The MCP server processes prompts via an SQLite backend without proper sanitisation of user‑supplied data. An attacker can craft a malicious request that injects arbitrary SQL commands. Because the database stores prompts, the injected payload can be persisted (stored SQLi), enabling later execution to retrieve sensitive data, exfiltrate information, or inject malicious prompts that give the attacker control over the entire AI agent workflow. The vulnerability propagates to any downstream projects that have forked the MCP server code without fixing the issue.
affected_products: Any third‑party forks of the MCP server (over 5,000 forks)
products_versions: All versions of the Anthropic SQLite MCP server prior to the forthcoming patch
vulnerabilities.remediation: Update to a patched version of the MCP server that uses parameterised queries or prepared statements for all database interactions. Apply input validation and sanitisation on all user‑controlled fields. Restrict network access to the MCP endpoint to trusted hosts only. Rotate any compromised API keys or credentials that may have been harvested.
workarounds: Deploy a Web Application Firewall (WAF) rule to block typical SQLi payloads targeting the MCP endpoint.
Disable external access to the MCP server and restrict it to localhost or an internal VLAN.
Run the MCP server with a read‑only SQLite database for prompt storage, separating it from any privileged data.

vulnerabilities.title: Critical Langflow Vulnerability (CVE-2025-3248) Actively Exploited to Deliver Flodrix Botnet
vulnerabilities.original_title: Critical Langflow Vulnerability (CVE-2025-3248) Actively Exploited to Deliver Flodrix Botnet
vulnerabilities.content_snippet: This blog uncovers an active campaign exploiting CVE-2025-3248 in Langflow versions before 1.3.0 that deploys the Flodrix botnet, enabling threat actors to achieve full system compromise, initiate DDoS attacks, and potentially exfiltrate sensitive data.

vulnerabilities.title: Critical Langflow Vulnerability (CVE-2025-3248) Actively Exploited to Deliver Flodrix Botnet
vulnerabilities.original_title: Critical Langflow Vulnerability (CVE-2025-3248) Actively Exploited to Deliver Flodrix Botnet
vulnerabilities.content_snippet: This blog uncovers an active campaign exploiting CVE-2025-3248 in Langflow versions before 1.3.0 that deploys the Flodrix botnet, enabling threat actors to achieve full system compromise, initiate DDoS attacks, and potentially exfiltrate sensitive data.
vulnerabilities.summary: Remote code execution vulnerability in Langflow before version 1.3.0 allowing attackers to execute arbitrary code and install the Flodrix botnet.
vulnerabilities.description: The vulnerability stems from insufficient input validation in the Langflow web interface, allowing specially crafted HTTP requests to trigger deserialization of untrusted data. An attacker can exploit this flaw to achieve remote code execution with system-level privileges, enabling the deployment of the Flodrix botnet, data exfiltration, and DDoS capabilities.
vulnerabilities.remediation: Upgrade Langflow to version 1.3.0 or later, which includes the fix for CVE-2025-3248. Apply any vendor‑provided patches and ensure that all components are running the latest security updates.
workarounds: Restrict external network access to the Langflow management interface using firewall rules or a VPN.
Disable or limit the vulnerable API endpoints until the patch can be applied.
Implement a Web Application Firewall (WAF) rule to block the malicious request patterns identified in the campaign.

vulnerabilities.title: Critical Langflow Vulnerability (CVE-2025-3248) Actively Exploited to Deliver Flodrix Botnet
vulnerabilities.original_title: Critical Langflow Vulnerability (CVE-2025-3248) Actively Exploited to Deliver Flodrix Botnet
vulnerabilities.content_snippet: This blog uncovers an active campaign exploiting CVE-2025-3248 in Langflow versions before 1.3.0 that deploys the Flodrix botnet, enabling threat actors to achieve full system compromise, initiate DDoS attacks, and potentially exfiltrate sensitive data.
vulnerabilities.summary: Remote code execution vulnerability in Langflow before version 1.3.0 allowing attackers to execute arbitrary code and install the Flodrix botnet.
vulnerabilities.description: CVE-2025-3248 is a remote code execution (RCE) flaw in the Langflow web application framework. The vulnerability stems from insufficient validation of user‑supplied data in a REST API endpoint, leading to deserialization of untrusted input. An attacker can craft a malicious request that triggers arbitrary command execution on the host running Langflow. Exploitation results in full system compromise, enabling the deployment of the Flodrix botnet, which can be used for DDoS attacks, data exfiltration, and further lateral movement.
vulnerabilities.remediation: Upgrade Langflow to version 1.3.0 or later, which contains the fix for CVE-2025-3248. Apply any vendor‑provided patches and ensure that the application is running with the least privileges necessary.
workarounds: Block external network access to the vulnerable API endpoint using a firewall or web application firewall (WAF).
Disable the affected feature/module if it is not required.
Run Langflow inside a hardened container or sandbox with restricted system privileges.

vulnerabilities.title: The New AI Attack Surface — How Cortex Cloud Secures MCP
vulnerabilities.original_title: The New AI Attack Surface — How Cortex Cloud Secures MCP
vulnerabilities.content_snippet: With remarkable momentum behind its adoption, the Model Context Protocol (MCP) is quickly becoming the de facto interface for connecting large language models (LLMs) to tools, APIs, databases and other services. Think of it as the USB-C of AI development – an elegant, standardized bridge that enable...
vulnerabilities.summary: Lack of input validation in MCP servers leading to protocol injection attacks
vulnerabilities.description: MCP servers may process incoming requests without proper validation of the structured context data. An attacker can craft malicious MCP payloads that embed command-like constructs or malformed JSON, causing the server to execute unintended actions, exfiltrate data, or corrupt model responses. This is analogous to SQL injection but targets the AI communication layer.
affected_products: AI assistants using MCP (e.g., Claude Desktop, ChatGPT, Gemini)
vulnerabilities.remediation: Implement strict schema validation for all MCP request fields, enforce allow‑list of permitted commands/tools, and reject any malformed or unexpected structures before processing.
workarounds: Deploy a reverse‑proxy that validates MCP traffic against a known good schema before it reaches the server.
Disable or limit dynamic tool invocation until proper validation is in place.

vulnerabilities.title: The New AI Attack Surface — How Cortex Cloud Secures MCP
vulnerabilities.original_title: The New AI Attack Surface — How Cortex Cloud Secures MCP
vulnerabilities.content_snippet: With remarkable momentum behind its adoption, the Model Context Protocol (MCP) is quickly becoming the de facto interface for connecting large language models (LLMs) to tools, APIs, databases and other services. Think of it as the USB-C of AI development – an elegant, standardized bridge that enable...
vulnerabilities.summary: Centralized credential storage in MCP servers creates a single point of compromise
vulnerabilities.description: MCP servers often hold API keys, OAuth tokens, and other credentials for multiple downstream systems (e.g., CRM, code repositories). If an attacker gains access to the server process or its storage, they can harvest these credentials and achieve lateral movement across the enterprise environment.
affected_products: MCP server implementations that store access tokens for downstream services
Containers or VMs hosting MCP servers
vulnerabilities.remediation: Adopt secret management solutions, rotate credentials regularly, enforce least‑privilege scopes for each token, and isolate MCP server processes in dedicated containers with minimal filesystem exposure.
workarounds: Use short‑lived, scoped tokens instead of long‑lived static keys.
Segregate credential stores per service rather than a single monolithic store.

vulnerabilities.title: The New AI Attack Surface — How Cortex Cloud Secures MCP
vulnerabilities.original_title: The New AI Attack Surface — How Cortex Cloud Secures MCP
vulnerabilities.content_snippet: With remarkable momentum behind its adoption, the Model Context Protocol (MCP) is quickly becoming the de facto interface for connecting large language models (LLMs) to tools, APIs, databases and other services. Think of it as the USB-C of AI development – an elegant, standardized bridge that enable...
vulnerabilities.summary: Tool poisoning and prompt hijacking via malicious metadata in MCP tool definitions
vulnerabilities.description: Attackers can embed hidden instructions or malicious prompts within tool metadata that are invisible to users but interpreted by LLMs as actionable commands. This can cause the model to exfiltrate data, execute unauthorized actions, or modify system state without explicit user consent.
affected_products: MCP tool registries and metadata repositories
AI models that automatically consume tool prompts (e.g., Claude, ChatGPT)
vulnerabilities.remediation: Validate and sanitize tool metadata before registration, enforce signed tool definitions, and require explicit user confirmation for any tool‑driven action that accesses sensitive resources.
workarounds: Maintain a whitelist of approved tool definitions.
Disable automatic execution of tool‑generated prompts unless reviewed by an operator.

vulnerabilities.title: Ransomware Actors Exploit Unpatched SimpleHelp Remote Monitoring and Management to Compromise Utility Billing Software Provider
vulnerabilities.original_title: Ransomware Actors Exploit Unpatched SimpleHelp Remote Monitoring and Management to Compromise Utility Billing Software Provider
vulnerabilities.content_snippet: Summary The Cybersecurity and Infrastructure Security Agency (CISA) is releasing this advisory in response to ransomware actors leveraging unpatched instances of a vulnerability in SimpleHelp Remote Monitoring and Management (RMM) to compromise customers of a utility billing software provider. This ...
vulnerabilities.summary: Path traversal vulnerability in SimpleHelp Remote Monitoring and Management (RMM) software
vulnerabilities.description: Path traversal vulnerability in SimpleHelp versions 5.5.7 and earlier that allows ransomware actors to access downstream customers' unpatched SimpleHelp RMM for disruption of services in double extortion compromises.
vulnerabilities.remediation: Upgrade to the latest SimpleHelp version in accordance with SimpleHelp's security vulnerability advisory
workarounds: Isolate the SimpleHelp server instance from the internet
Stop the server process
Apply appropriate vendor-provided mitigations when available
references: Anthony Bradshaw, et. al., "DragonForce Actors Target SimpleHelp Vulnerabilities to Attack MSP, Customers", Sophos News, May 27, 2025

vulnerabilities.title: Ransomware Actors Exploit Unpatched SimpleHelp Remote Monitoring and Management to Compromise Utility Billing Software Provider
vulnerabilities.original_title: Ransomware Actors Exploit Unpatched SimpleHelp Remote Monitoring and Management to Compromise Utility Billing Software Provider
vulnerabilities.content_snippet: Summary The Cybersecurity and Infrastructure Security Agency (CISA) is releasing this advisory in response to ransomware actors leveraging unpatched instances of a vulnerability in SimpleHelp Remote Monitoring and Management (RMM) to compromise customers of a utility billing software provider. This ...
vulnerabilities.summary: Path traversal vulnerability in SimpleHelp Remote Monitoring and Management (RMM) allowing unauthorized file system access.
vulnerabilities.description: The vulnerability permits an attacker to craft specially crafted URLs or API calls that traverse directories on the SimpleHelp server, enabling read/write access to arbitrary files. Exploitation can lead to remote code execution, credential theft, and deployment of ransomware payloads as observed in recent campaigns targeting utility billing software providers.
products_versions: SimpleHelp Remote Monitoring and Management version 5.5.7 and earlier
vulnerabilities.remediation: Upgrade SimpleHelp to the latest version released after 5.5.7. Apply vendor-provided patches immediately. Isolate any SimpleHelp server instances from the internet until patched.
workarounds: Isolate the SimpleHelp server from external network access.
Stop the SimpleHelp service if immediate patching is not possible.
Apply vendor‑provided configuration mitigations where available.

vulnerabilities.title: Ransomware Actors Exploit Unpatched SimpleHelp Remote Monitoring and Management to Compromise Utility Billing Software Provider
vulnerabilities.original_title: Ransomware Actors Exploit Unpatched SimpleHelp Remote Monitoring and Management to Compromise Utility Billing Software Provider
vulnerabilities.content_snippet: Summary The Cybersecurity and Infrastructure Security Agency (CISA) is releasing this advisory in response to ransomware actors leveraging unpatched instances of a vulnerability in SimpleHelp Remote Monitoring and Management (RMM) to compromise customers of a utility billing software provider. This ...
vulnerabilities.summary: Path traversal vulnerability in SimpleHelp Remote Monitoring and Management (RMM) allowing attackers to read arbitrary files on the server.
vulnerabilities.description: An unauthenticated attacker can craft a specially formatted URL that triggers a directory traversal on the SimpleHelp RMM web interface. The flaw allows reading of files outside the intended directory, potentially exposing configuration files, credentials, and other sensitive data. Ransomware groups have leveraged this vulnerability to gain footholds in downstream environments and execute double‑extortion campaigns.
affected_products: SimpleHelp Remote Monitoring and Management (RMM) server
affected_companies: Utility billing software provider (unnamed downstream vendor)
vendors: Utility billing software provider (unnamed downstream vendor)
vulnerabilities.remediation: Upgrade SimpleHelp RMM to the latest version released after the vulnerability disclosure. If immediate upgrade is not possible, isolate the SimpleHelp server from the internet, stop the service, and apply vendor‑provided workarounds. Conduct threat‑hunting for indicators of compromise and rotate any credentials that may have been exposed.
workarounds: Block external access to the SimpleHelp web interface via firewall rules.
Disable the Remote Access Service (RAS) if not required.
Apply vendor‑provided configuration hardening (e.g., restrict allowed paths).
references: SimpleHelp security vulnerability advisory (referenced in CISA advisory)
Sophos News, "DragonForce Actors Target SimpleHelp Vulnerabilities to Attack MSP, Customers" (2025-05-27)

vulnerabilities.title: Threat Actors Deploy LummaC2 Malware to Exfiltrate Sensitive Data from Organizations
vulnerabilities.original_title: Threat Actors Deploy LummaC2 Malware to Exfiltrate Sensitive Data from Organizations
vulnerabilities.content_snippet: Summary The Federal Bureau of Investigation (FBI) and the Cybersecurity and Infrastructure Security Agency (CISA) are releasing this joint advisory to disseminate known tactics, techniques, and procedures (TTPs) and indicators of compromise (IOCs) associated with threat actors deploying the LummaC2 ...
vulnerabilities.summary: LummaC2 information stealer malware infiltration and data exfiltration
vulnerabilities.description: LummaC2 is an information stealer malware that infiltrates victim computer networks through spearphishing campaigns and fake CAPTCHA prompts. The malware executes Base64-encoded PowerShell processes to bypass security measures and exfiltrates sensitive data including PII, financial credentials, cryptocurrency wallets, browser extensions, and MFA details. The malware uses sophisticated obfuscation techniques to evade EDR solutions and antivirus programs.
affected_companies: Various browser vendors (Chrome, Firefox, Edge, etc.)
vendors: Various browser vendors (Chrome, Firefox, Edge, etc.)
vulnerabilities.remediation: Implement application allowlisting to prevent unauthorized executable execution. Regularly update and patch systems. Implement phishing-resistant MFA. Monitor registry changes and API calls that retrieve system information. Segment networks to limit lateral movement.
workarounds: Disable execution of PowerShell scripts from untrusted sources
Implement strict browser extension policies
Regularly review and clean browser data
Monitor for unusual process execution patterns
references: FBI and CISA Joint Advisory AA25-141B
MITRE ATT&CK Matrix for Enterprise framework, version 17

vulnerabilities.title: Threat Actors Deploy LummaC2 Malware to Exfiltrate Sensitive Data from Organizations
vulnerabilities.original_title: Threat Actors Deploy LummaC2 Malware to Exfiltrate Sensitive Data from Organizations
vulnerabilities.content_snippet: Summary The Federal Bureau of Investigation (FBI) and the Cybersecurity and Infrastructure Security Agency (CISA) are releasing this joint advisory to disseminate known tactics, techniques, and procedures (TTPs) and indicators of compromise (IOCs) associated with threat actors deploying the LummaC2 ...
vulnerabilities.summary: LummaC2 malware uses spearphishing attachments and links combined with a malicious PowerShell payload to gain initial access, exfiltrate credentials, browser data, and cryptocurrency wallets from Windows systems.
vulnerabilities.description: The LummaC2 infostealer is delivered via spearphishing emails containing malicious hyperlinks or attachments. The payload tricks users into solving a fake CAPTCHA, copying a Base64‑encoded PowerShell command to the clipboard, and executing it via the Windows Run dialog. The PowerShell command launches a hidden executable (LummaC2.exe) that runs entirely in memory, decrypts C2 domains, performs POST requests to retrieve JSON‑encoded commands, and carries out a range of actions including credential theft, browser data extraction (including non‑Mozilla browsers and Mozilla-specific routines), file download/execution via LoadLibrary or rundll32, screenshot capture, and self‑deletion. The malware includes a hostname/username hash check to avoid execution on attacker‑controlled systems. All communications are encrypted, and the malware employs obfuscation (T1027) and masquerading (T1036) to evade detection.
vulnerabilities.remediation: Block malicious email attachments and URLs via email security gateways; implement phishing‑resistant MFA; enforce application allow‑listing for executables and PowerShell scripts; disable execution of unsigned PowerShell scripts; keep Windows OS and third‑party software patched; monitor for suspicious PowerShell activity and abnormal API calls (GetUserNameW, GetComputerNameW); deploy EDR with behavior‑based detection for in‑memory implants; enforce least‑privilege accounts and regular credential hygiene.
workarounds: Disable the Windows Run dialog (Win+R) for standard users.
Restrict clipboard paste operations from untrusted sources.
Enforce execution control policies that require code signing for all binaries.

vulnerabilities.title: Navigating Through The Fog
vulnerabilities.original_title: Navigating Through The Fog
vulnerabilities.content_snippet: Key Takeaways An open directory associated with a ransomware affiliate, likely linked to the Fog ransomware group, was discovered in December 2024. It contained tools and scripts for reconnaissance, exploitation, lateral movement, and persistence...
vulnerabilities.summary: Open directory associated with Fog ransomware affiliate containing tools and scripts for reconnaissance, exploitation, lateral movement, and persistence.
vulnerabilities.description: In December 2024, an open, publicly accessible directory was discovered that is linked to a ransomware affiliate of the Fog ransomware group. The directory hosts a collection of malicious utilities and scripts designed to facilitate the full attack lifecycle: initial reconnaissance of target environments, exploitation of known software vulnerabilities, lateral movement across compromised networks, and establishment of persistence mechanisms. The presence of these tools indicates an operational capability to launch targeted ransomware campaigns against vulnerable systems.
vulnerabilities.remediation: Identify and remove all malicious files from the compromised directory. Conduct a full forensic sweep of affected systems for indicators of compromise (IOCs) related to the Fog toolset. Patch all known vulnerabilities that could be leveraged by the disclosed exploitation scripts. Disable directory listing on web servers and enforce strict access controls. Implement network segmentation to limit lateral movement.
workarounds: Block external access to the identified directory via firewall rules.
Restrict write permissions on web server directories to trusted accounts only.

vulnerabilities.summary: Misconfiguration in NVIDIA Riva deployment allowing unauthorized access to AI inference services.
vulnerabilities.description: Improper default configuration or lack of access controls in NVIDIA Riva enables remote attackers to connect to the speech and translation inference endpoints without authentication. Attackers can issue arbitrary inference requests, consume compute resources, and potentially extract proprietary model data or user audio content.
vulnerabilities.remediation: Apply the latest NVIDIA Riva security hardening guide, enable authentication (e.g., TLS with client certificates or token‑based auth), restrict inbound traffic to trusted networks, and update to any released security patches.
workarounds: Deploy Riva behind a firewall and allow only trusted IP ranges.
Disable unused inference endpoints.
Enforce mutual TLS for all client connections.

vulnerabilities.summary: Misconfiguration in NVIDIA Riva deployment permitting resource abuse and potential theft of AI inference services.
vulnerabilities.description: A configuration flaw in NVIDIA Riva allows attackers to submit unlimited inference requests, leading to resource exhaustion (CPU/GPU) and enabling denial‑of‑service conditions. Additionally, the lack of proper access controls can be leveraged to harvest processed audio/text data, constituting data theft.
vulnerabilities.remediation: Implement rate‑limiting on inference APIs, enable authentication and authorization controls, and apply any NVIDIA‑provided patches or configuration updates.
workarounds: Configure API gateways to enforce request quotas.
Monitor and throttle abnormal usage patterns.
Isolate Riva services in a dedicated subnet with strict egress controls.
